Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Gartner cannot be trusted -- its a long story and their recommendations aren't even close to target.  Gartner is part of the problem, same goes for Forrester -- which is why there is so much misinformation in the market.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: They pick PTC and Siemens as leading the pack and that couldn't be further from the truth.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: We started producing our content because manufacturers were listening to Gartner and Forrester and not getting results with the platforms that were selected.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: PTC purchased Kepware because they were supposed to be IIoT leaders and they didn't even have machine connectivity -- Rockwell partnered with PTC because they were supposed to be leaders and they didn't have any open platforms.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Siemens, Rockwell and PTC are all behind the curve, not ahead of it.  Siemens, of the three, is the most advanced simply because they have Win-CC OA.  PTC has a great analytics and dashboarding platform but it ends there.  In IIoT, you need edge driven, open architecture, report by exception, unified namespace, cross platform and an IDE for developing full automation-stack solutions.  Those are your pre-requisites.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The folks at Gartner and Forrester do not develop IIoT solutions, so they don't even know what a leading IIoT solution would look like.

Author: boyang6559
Content: I think the traditional industry software venders used to play the game of creating silos to sell the keys (license).  this business model may not work that well when someone start to use open source, update its tech with community development,  and sell the service (eg power by hour).  IIoT has the tech capabilities to connect things and break silos,  it can be a game changer or disruption for big guys' business model.  it's difficult to wheel a big ship,  especially now,  while not yet known which direction will survive.  it's time for small and fast ship.  The challenge for manufacturing industry is not technology, technology may already prototyped in other industry, it's the culture

Author: alfredoblumenthal3824
Content:
One stupid question for you: In the context on Industrial Internet of Things, obviously a sensor, a PLC, a drive etc, are "Things" that either publish information/data or consume information/data from the cloud/internet/etc. Can we consider an MES, or a PLM a "Thing" in the IIoT world? Since they also publish and consume data to/from the IIoT platform,
Your feedback would be highly appreciated my friend!
Stay safe!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> One stupid question for you: In the context on Industrial Internet of Things, obviously a sensor, a PLC, a drive etc, are "Things" that either publish information/data or consume information/data from the cloud/internet/etc. Can we consider an MES, or a PLM a "Thing" in the IIoT world? Since they also publish and consume data to/from the IIoT platform,
> Your feedback would be highly appreciated my friend!
> Stay safe!
@Alfredo Blumenthal  Welcome to the channel!  The answer to your question is Yes!  All ‚Äúthings‚Äù that produce or consume data are ‚Äúthings‚Äù in our internet of things.  I like to say that they are all nodes in the ecosystem ‚Äî that includes software... because they consume data and make information with it that can also be consumed by other nodes in the ecosystem.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Question of the Day: What does IIoT mean?  Strategically and practically?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Pinned a message.

Author: zackscriven
Content: @Walker Reynolds  is this true?

Author: faction2.0
Content:
> Question of the Day: What does IIoT mean?  Strategically and practically?
@Walker Reynolds 
Strategically: The ability to solve business problems through connectivity. I.e. IIoT is a tool used for generating revenue or cutting cost.
Practically: XaaS, SLAs, on-demand information, predictive/preventative maintenance, process optimization, etc.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> @Walker Reynolds  is this true?
@zackscriven yes -- it is... but it is solved in the Sparkplug connection parameters (how often you want to publish updates) and QoS.  It is true report by exception if you configure it that way.  Which is why you need a solutions architect available for consultation when you are designing edge of network connections.

Author: zackscriven
Content: So the solution would be to set your scan interval to the length of your plc scan cycle or less?

Author: zackscriven
Content: and then you can send those events or updates once every so often.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Its not the scan rate, its the publish rate -- the edge of network node will see all transitions, just only publish the latest value within the publishing interval.

Author: zackscriven
Content: ah. i thought that it published multiple in sort of a store-and-forward type way

Author: zackscriven
Content: if there was multiple updates in one publish cycle

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: So -- let's say I have a REAL on the edge that changes 20 times per second (50ms updates)... and I configure my edge of network node to publish no faster than once per second... it will ignore 19 changes and publish just the last one.

Author: zackscriven
Content: that makes sense. that's probably how you would want it for real

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: OR -- I can buffer all of the changes and publish an array in the topic -- OR I can set my edge of network node to publish that topic on all changes -- OR I could use another option... the point is, the solution needs to fit the problem and you need an architect who knows what they are doing.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: His comment is correct... but it is missing a key point -- that isn't the ONLY way to set up pub sub.

Author: zackscriven
Content: üëç

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: For example -- we have more than 1 transmitter set up on most edge nodes -- one for standard transmits once per second and one for high speed transmits on actual change.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: My answer to the question of the day: IIoT means that we treat all consumers and producers of data and information -- within an organization -- as nodes in an ecosystem.  We give them a place to consume data from and publish information back into.  From a philosophical stand-point, it means we don't limit what information stakeholders have access to or when, or in what form.  It means we make no assumptions about how data or information will be consumed.  From a strategic standpoint, we give people the information they need, when they need it, in the form they need it.  IIoT is the foundation upon which we create the smartphone for industry -- the one portal that connects us to exactly what we want or need to know, when we want or need to know it.

Author: dep05d
Content:
> OR -- I can buffer all of the changes and publish an array in the topic -- OR I can set my edge of network node to publish that topic on all changes -- OR I could use another option... the point is, the solution needs to fit the problem and you need an architect who knows what they are doing.
@Walker Reynolds I've been playing around with this in the Cirrus Link modules in Ignition.  I know the Transmission module can buffer messages if there is comm loss to the MQTT broker, and the MQTT Engine module can direct these buffered messages to the historian whenever they finally arrive.  I also know Transmission can be set to publish buffered history in order, and the Engine can be configured to bypass the historian and instead push all the buffered messages through the MQTT Engine tag.  However, if I were to try and create a tag event on that tag, I would end up with missedEvents=True because of an event overflow.  Is there any way in Ignition to perform stream processing on all the buffered data, or must we use the historian as the event stream?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> @Walker Reynolds I've been playing around with this in the Cirrus Link modules in Ignition.  I know the Transmission module can buffer messages if there is comm loss to the MQTT broker, and the MQTT Engine module can direct these buffered messages to the historian whenever they finally arrive.  I also know Transmission can be set to publish buffered history in order, and the Engine can be configured to bypass the historian and instead push all the buffered messages through the MQTT Engine tag.  However, if I were to try and create a tag event on that tag, I would end up with missedEvents=True because of an event overflow.  Is there any way in Ignition to perform stream processing on all the buffered data, or must we use the historian as the event stream?
@dep05d Are you running the tag event on the MQTT topic in Engine?

Author: dep05d
Content:
> @dep05d Are you running the tag event on the MQTT topic in Engine?
@Walker Reynolds I created a tag event on the tag that is created within the MQTT Engine provider

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: This is a bug -- you should report it to IA and Cirrus Link, when you configure to stream the buffered events through the tag, the events are all supposed to fire.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Are you seeing the tag changes for all of the buffered events?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Or is it just one change, the last element in the array?

Author: dep05d
Content: I see generally the last one, maybe a few in between, mostly with missedEvents=True, depending on the flush timing settings I play with Transmission-side.  I may be a few versions old in 7.9 since that was my dev environment for a different project, so I will try out on the latest and confirm if it's still happening.  I'm happy to hear the expectation is that every event should fire, though!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: What are you doing in the tag event?  Async functions only or are you writing to other tags synchronously, or other synchronous functions?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: It could also be your tag event script -- if you are running synchronous ops and a new event fires, you get an overflow.

Author: dep05d
Content:
> What are you doing in the tag event?  Async functions only or are you writing to other tags synchronously, or other synchronous functions?
@Walker Reynolds just print statements for now.  Trying to make sure I understand how it all works before speculating on how we could take advantage

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: U should be fine there -- start with upgrading to Ignition 8.0.15 and using CLs newest builds.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Those events should all fire.

Author: dep05d
Content: in practice, I would likely just push those along to a message handler on a project.  Whenever tag events came along in Ignition, we learned pretty quickly to keep processing minimal on that thread!  I'll probably try out with latest 7.9 version and follow up with CL if I still have issues.  Thanks for the quick feedback!

Author: marioishikawa
Content:
> Question of the Day: What does IIoT mean?  Strategically and practically?
@Walker Reynolds Strategically, I've seen IIC define it as the IoT when applied to industries, and not people, and by industry they mean all industries, like Smart Cities, Health care, which differs from I4.0. Practically, for me is the conjunction of OT and IT, bringing new IT technologies such as the mentioned PubSub, Big Data Databases ans Analytics tools to solve old OT problems in a different way.

Author: nadream5156
Content:
Question: I have a question. Maybe for one of your Youtube post. 

OSISoft claims that PI is capable of providing IIoT solution by integrating MES, ERP, SCADA/DCS. Do you consider that as an IIoT solution? If not, why? Convincing any big client on using anything like highbyte is near impossible.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Osi-Pi is an application... it isnt a platform or a framework... it should be treated as a node in the ecosystem, not the hub.  It should be used for what it is good at, a historian... using OSI-Pi as the foundation of an IIoT solution is like building a wall on top of a couch... ur stuck with that couch forever or have the wall come crashing down.

Author: bogaczykn
Content: This answers a question I have been meaning to ask. One would think it is possible as the PI sells there system as the "Information Layer" to connect applications much like the unified namespace is described.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: And that is their strategy... if u make the application part of the foundation then it becomes essentially irreplaceable.  Aveva is about to purchase OsiSoft and it is simply because of this strategy.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The key to the IIoT architecture is the technology it is built on, not the application it is built with.  Small strategic  decisions make a huge difference.  For example, using a standalone MQTT broker, sparkplug b standard, edge built asset frames (instead of asset frames in PI)... make PI a historian and analytics node... and now u have an application that can be decoupled from the framework built on the right architecture ‚Äî and break nothing.

Author: bogaczykn
Content: Makes a lot of sense. I spent over a year convincing management to try a small PI system. Might need to reevaluate some as we move on. The purchase of OSISoft will make things interesting for sure!

Author: nadream5156
zackscriven
Content: @nadream those are great questions. My thoughts are 1. HighByte is purpose build to be a UNS.   I don't believe OSI-PI meets the requirements to be an Unified Namespace.

Author: zackscriven
Content: 2. It's built by the core team that built kepware. So it has all of the things they learned over the years on how to develop industrial software.

Author: zackscriven
Content: The larger of a company you are the more of a need you have for a unified namespace.

Author: mrjain.
Content:
Suppose I'm getting the following in JSON via MQTT:
{
  "mac_Id": "54:0A:C4:97:62:ab",
  "power": 0.43,
  "energy": 1990.5,
  "strength": "unusable"
}

Currently, all this is coming via a single topic called incomingData. Does it makes sense to take the value of power and energy and have seperate topics? The data is stored in a DB with a column for power and a column for energy.

Author: walker.reynolds
jaffar9703

Author: takko_the_boss
Content:
> Suppose I'm getting the following in JSON via MQTT:
> {
>   "mac_Id": "54:0A:C4:97:62:ab",
>   "power": 0.43,
>   "energy": 1990.5,
>   "strength": "unusable"
> }
> 
> Currently, all this is coming via a single topic called incomingData. Does it makes sense to take the value of power and energy and have seperate topics? The data is stored in a DB with a column for power and a column for energy.
@mrjain. So I'm not speaking as MQTT Authority numero uno here, but one question I'd ask is:
"Is there a current subscription need *or* a future requirement?"

Essentially, is it more useful to stratify the info as it pertains to your use case? And if so, are there subscribers that'd ingest that data?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> @mrjain. So I'm not speaking as MQTT Authority numero uno here, but one question I'd ask is:
> "Is there a current subscription need *or* a future requirement?"
> 
> Essentially, is it more useful to stratify the info as it pertains to your use case? And if so, are there subscribers that'd ingest that data?
@MikeCurnow.com it depends -- in general, yes.  If using Sparkplug, definitely.  There are conditions where a JSON payload makes the most sense, but then you have to parse on the other side to do anything with the values.

Author: takko_the_boss
Content: Yeah, I mean my first instinct is to look at the question from a big-data standpoint, lol.

Author: mrjain.
Content: @MikeCurnow.com @Walker Reynolds Thanks for the imput. The more I think about it, the current structure is fine. I'm going to look into Sparkplug, the problem is that most of the Cloud IoT platforms from AWS, Azure and GCP don't support plugins.

Author: takko_the_boss
Content: When they can figure out the best monotization model for plugin adoption, rest assured they will @mrjain. lol!

@Walker Reynolds What effect, if any do ya think the Aveva OSI acquisition will have on Rockwell's future use of the platform for historian/analytics?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> @Walker Reynolds What effect, if any do ya think the Aveva OSI acquisition will have on Rockwell's future use of the platform for historian/analytics?
@Brad Frayo It is too early to tell -- I have some calls in to gauge the strategy.  The relationship with Aveva and Rockwell isn't great to begin with, though they will tell you otherwise.  FactoryTalk tools outside of Innovation Suite (which is just TWX) really are not all that great -- they are not best in class in basically anything.  Osi-Pi is a great historian but their rub has always been OsiSoft's business practices and their pricing (which is why Canary Labs has grown so much over the last 10 years).  Aveva, along with Siemens, are the only traditional companies in the space that are leading with innovation (and both really just started distinguishing themselves in the last 24 months eg. I4.0).  Rockwell likes to say they are -- but they really aren't -- their software products are overpriced, underperform and are about as closed as you can get.  From a 10k view, this acquisition makes little sense to me unless Aveva is going to aggressively go after Rockwell's software business and leverage the Rockwell Osi-Pi partnership to do it.  Aveva needs to get to the edge with hardware (not slapping an InTouch Edge label on Indusoft)... so, honestly, I don't know what they are doing here -- unless it is the aggressive move I mention above.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: When I first learned of the Aveva/OSIsoft acquisition a few weeks ago, I thought it was a rather odd move, given the number of historian/client tools already in the Aveva portfolio. My sense was it was about increase access to additional market verticals, as Aveva is not strong in those where OSIsoft is. As was discussed in an asset management/reliability thread on LinkedIn, the thinking is in regards to digital twins in that both companies have significant investments here. Combining engineering/design software with operational software in one stack seems to make a lot of sense.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Thanks @Jasperlg and @Walker Reynolds. I forgot to mention also one requirement that is to be viable for a SaaS. Most platforms have their licence cost per user, focused on the Enterprise customer directly. So they usually charge the same or even more than what we want to charge customers, which makes it also not suitable commercially. I have considered SCADA in the past, but I'm more geared towards to stateless and highly scalable platforms, so I can have it in a Kubernetes cluster globally. Grafana is cool, but it is seriously limited to time series only and it is just a dashboard platform. It does not allow you to do operations and enter manual data like you would in an app. Mendix seems cool, but also very expensive.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: I'm also looking now to other platforms out of the big players such as Siemens. Losant also too expensive. Ubidots: very limited. Thingsboard is promising. Also, just to mention: our tech team has no problem to create reports on a React front end but the problem is having to do that customized for every customer. It just takes a long time to code just because of the layout.

Author: na23909
Content:
> Thanks @Jasperlg and @Walker Reynolds. I forgot to mention also one requirement that is to be viable for a SaaS. Most platforms have their licence cost per user, focused on the Enterprise customer directly. So they usually charge the same or even more than what we want to charge customers, which makes it also not suitable commercially. I have considered SCADA in the past, but I'm more geared towards to stateless and highly scalable platforms, so I can have it in a Kubernetes cluster globally. Grafana is cool, but it is seriously limited to time series only and it is just a dashboard platform. It does not allow you to do operations and enter manual data like you would in an app. Mendix seems cool, but also very expensive.
@Mario Ishikawa Have you tried Siemens Comos and Tableau from Salesforce (Tableau is configurable as you wish). We want to try the Comos platform especially to prevent leaks inside our factories but I dont know if it is really an IIOT solution. Also Siemens proposes a lot of VR to train the employees especially with this time of new normal, it will be great to have some feedback of users if it worth the try.

Author: marioishikawa
Content:
> @Mario Ishikawa Can you provide more information with respect to your Mindsphere experience? Did you like it? Easy to use? Easy to purchase? Learning curve?  I am interested because I have job coming up where I will probably need to use it.
@mdowdell my review might not be fair as I evaluated the platform around 18 months ago. I did not executed a project there but I had access to it and documentation. With that disclaimer, let's go: I did not like it. For a company the size of Siemens and mentioning a platform I was expecting much more. It is an open platform because it allows for connection with other systems, but it seems that the focus is more to be internally open. They want enterprise customers to pay for their own account and they will have access to several vendor products on the Marketplace. So basically you can create a product on the platform and have passive sales, with enterprise customers adding your product to their set. It seems like a modern version of trying to close your protocol so you can be locked with the vendor. You can add multiple add ons as long they are inside Siemens platform. I did not test their time series database but by the documentation it seemed quite simple to me, and not flexible also. You can do more with open source data bases if you know how to do it. And also for front end you would have to do it on you own, but now that they bought Mendix it seems to be more integrated. Buying it is also on the old fashion way. Not as clear as Inductive, which should be the norm now. You need to talk to them on the phone, get a quote, start a contract and so on. User and integrator need to acquire their license as it usually happens with SCADA. I hope this helps.

Author: marioishikawa
Content:
> Question of the day: How did you get started with IIoT?  What piqued your interest and what about it appeals to you?
@Walker Reynolds As an electronics technician I also learned how to program PLCs, SCADA and code in general, back then with Pascal in 1995. Then I worked for a SCADA company for two years before my Computer Science graduation. Since then I have only worked with software for automation, and I have a system integrator company for 14 years. I was always interested in bringing much more than just a SCADA system, so I have usually worked with very large SCADA projects, like one remotely operating the largest private Power company in Brazil with over 30 power plants. With Big Data open source tools appearing I started to get very interested in how tools like Cassandra could be used to disrupt the market, as well as other things like encrypted REST APIs. Short story is that I ended up migrating from SCADA to this so called IIoT market, starting in 2014 but mostly after 2017 when I saw a presentation from IIC and became a member of ABII (which is like a Brazilian partner of IIC) and after 2018 when I joined PackIOT as co-founder.

Content: Here‚Äôs why I started learning about IIOT, I work for a major manufacturer or Industrial Automation Products, I wanted to learn more about IIOT so that I can assist with the right solution for my customers, it may not always be our solution but at least I can give an informed opinion on how we can help and how they align with the IIOT philosophy. Plus I love gadgets and home automation so IIOT is just an extension into my work life from home.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: > My response to the question of the day: I decided early on in my career that I would learn to leverage technology to help save and create middle class jobs in the United States -- by helping manufacturers transform their businesses.  I'm drawn to tech because that's just how my brain works (something I know we all have in common -- gotta know how things work).  My focus has been, since the early 2000's, to help enterprises get connected and digitally inform stakeholders centrally.  IIoT technology, connecting all the smart stuff, seemed like an important component of my vision... so I have spent the last 20 years spending all of my free time studying the technology and helping to push OEMs to leverage the right tech, so we can build the perfect IIoT eco-system for manufacturers.

Author: andersgustav
Content:
> > > Question of the day: How did you get started with IIoT?  What piqued your interest and what about it appeals to you?
> > @Walker Reynolds Well, it wasn`t called that back then. But first time i monitored and controlled something over the internet was in 1999-2000. And I did it using IRC-clients written in Pascal (Borland Delphi) that communicated using text-arrays and ran IO-boards mounted in the computers PCI-slot. 
> The connection was dialup ADSL and I ran on multiple IRC-networks to be able to get the smallest possible lag.
> This ofcourse was just mostly done for fun while exploring what stuff the internet coud do, but for a short period I actually used it for automating and remote controlling (over LAN using a local IRC-server) parts of the production on a plant I was working on, just so that me an my collegue could have a little longer coffebreaks ;)
> Many years later I came across Node-RED and mqtt. I just love the way mqtt makes everything simple, making a structure, making controllers (atm Arduinobased PLCs) self aware - it's just plug and play for me.
> Rigth now I am running a small SCADA-system developed in Node-RED, MQTT is the main M2M-protocol running on a mosquitto broker, but I also use OPC-UA. The history goes into a MS-SQL server (when no money, one uses what one got üòâ ) and our structuremodel is not very far from your unified namespace. 
> 
> However I need some better tools and by using theese free tools just to prove the concept I now wait for funding to invest in better ones - and for starters that is Ignition and Kepware.
> 
> This is something I have to do to have the foundation for a smart factory. The industry I am in are currently stuck in "industry 2.5", and we need the digital transition to have a future. It is just that simple.

Author: zackscriven
zackscriven
Content: This was the video... https://youtu.be/uHDwGzeTmnQ

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> Feedback on our YouTube Video: What is an IIoT Ready Device?
> 
> "I think you should separate terms transport and protocol when talking about connectivity. Because you can transport MQTT data over various transports"
> 
> @Walker Reynolds  does this make sense?
@zackscriven Makes perfect sense to me -- but it does not make sense to the lay person -- which are our target audience for free content.  We use transport and protocol inter-changeably in our content because there is no point in distracting the lay person from the message that devices with intelligence should publish their data using report by exception, edge driven and open technologies.  MQTT is sometimes transport (OPC-UA pub/sub) and sometimes standardized protocol (Sparkplug B).  The fact that MQTT can be transported over serial or ethernet/ip or other is irrelevant (unless we are having a technical discussion about architecting a particular technology stack for a specific solution).

Author: jmckeon
Content:
Make sense. What I have been experiencing when engaging with a prospective they start looking for something they need to address the route of their problem but when we drill down they are actually looking for digital transformation but they don't know it. The next thing is to explain the edge in terms of their assets as in terms of their things they use to do their business or make their products. Then we discuss iiot and then iiot edge device and then the device being iiot ready for the purpose of digitisation of their things so we can interact digitally.

I have discovered that I have to educated the audience and at first I was struggling to find that single starting point of common ground where they audience can be brought along.

Each engagement brings clarity, but to explain iiot device and iiot ready device is a must to explain in simple terms.

Just my thoughts at the moment, maybe the wrong section but it is relevant in my experience at this point

Author: dewayne_warden
Content:
> Feedback on our YouTube Video: What is an IIoT Ready Device?
> 
> "I think you should separate terms transport and protocol when talking about connectivity. Because you can transport MQTT data over various transports"
> 
> @Walker Reynolds  does this make sense?
@zackscriven Absolutely.  The video was short, concise and gave concrete examples to differentiate between a 4.0 product and a non-4.0 product.  Transport is the mechanism of sending information; ethernet, serial, etc.  Protocol is the method of encapsulating that information.  John Renaldi, Real Time Automation, described transport using an example of Sneakernet between two PLCs.  You go to PLC no.1, write down the information.  Walk over to PLC no.2, key in that information, receive and write down the response.  Walk back to PLC no.1 and repeat the cycle.  A simple, yet subtle example of transporting information between sites.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The answer is it has massive deficiencies and was only added to support the Softing integration.  You cannot publish the CLX or CMPLX namespace with it, no support for Sparkplug and is highly limited in its functionality ‚Äî eg. constructing your payload.  Rockwell is not using MQTT to open up the namespace in the PLC ‚Äî which is what we preach.  Yes... I am aware they have a block, I am aware they use MQTT to talk from gateways to other Rockwell devices, I have tested both of their example implementations and they just aren‚Äôt quite there yet.  Speaking with the RA PLC product manager, they made it clear that they will not be opening up their PLCs for 3rd party consumers (non Rockwell partners) because that isn‚Äôt in their best interest.

Content: What are the community's views on the CESMII Innovation Platform architecture? The Core platform function is 'Data Management' (which I commented on in #historian) including Connectivity / Data ingestion / Data Contextualization (modelling,  labelling, relationship definitions with a Graph DB / data access, exchange , management / Workflow & interoperability. Content:
As a data management layer the Cloudera Data Platform is a good bundle of the open source toolset. Runs on prem, hybrid & cloud so suits a large /small multi-site enterprise. NIFI & kafka at the core so brokering / namespace is doable. Can function as site historian & enterprise data lake complete with data dictionary, governance, lineage to support validation. Need to think about building & applying the asset hierarchy in a convenient way. I think the Dataflow module with schema registry will do it

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is a good question on how to model ISA95 context within Sparkplug B.  OPC-UA has a very impressive, but "heavy" implementation of ISA95.  It's not a merely a naming convention.  It's all modeled with full-blown attributes.  It basically "boils the ocean" to an extent that I could almost never see it being adopted in the real world.  

It would be interesting to see a practical approach of modeling ISA95 for namespaces.

https://youtu.be/OobhzbQoUnA

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Random question for the group:  Has anyone had real world success with MTConnect?  Have you been able to take advantage of a protocol like this with a specific contextual informational model?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: We used MTConnect last year in a digital transformation initiative.  We ended up using Kepware's MTConnect Driver to talk to CNC Lathes and then we converted to MQTT using Kepware's IoT gateway.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Were you working with an asset that happened to come with an MTConnect Adapter?  Was this adapter full of data or was it pretty barebones?

While MTConnect has a slick information model, I've found it to be lackluster in practice.  The machine tool builders don't really implement their MTConnect Adapters in a way that takes advantage of everything MTConnect has to offer.  In practice, it's often less than what one could pull off an asset's memory table with a native protocol (e.g., FOCAS, S7, MELSEC).

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: We were working with a Fanuc controller that leveraged the model to its limits.  There were many issues with the integration, not the least of which was Fanuc didnt expose the full namespace using mtconnect

Author: tgchip_1235
Content: Does anyone have an opinion about this Eclipse Foundation IIoT Open Source Solution? https://youtu.be/7KSird8-L6Y

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Promising, but flawed ‚Äî digital twin approach has major gaps.  I love that its O-S, but the tools are really geared toward digital twinning which has major gaps for Industry.  This is why digital twinning hasn‚Äôt had wide success or adoption.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: It‚Äôs developed by people with strong software backgrounds and limited or no operational background ‚Äî eg. the gaps.

Author: tgchip_1235
Content: The digital twin (Vorto) discussion at the beginning was not the most interesting part to me. The more interesting topics were the PLC4x and Ditto components discussed at the end.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This looks cool. The repository is a neat idea. They're being realistic that data will be obtained from the field using native protocols for quite some time.  I'd like to see a test bed or real world implementation.

I had more questions about it than opinions...

In the most diplomatic way, is this yet another information model / digital twin that will fail to achieve any meaningful adoption?  Why is it different?

What's the difference between this and all the various OPC-UA companion specs (e.g., VDMA, MTConnect, Euromap, AIM)?  Could I buy products with this?

Could one conceivably collaborate and participate with the manufacturing/automation industry using this?  Could my apps, assets, or colleagues use this?

With all the work Bosch has done with the Eclipse Foundation and their own IoT products, I'm curious / confused how they will utilize this?

Author: r.pop
Content:
> It‚Äôs developed by people with strong software backgrounds and limited or no operational background ‚Äî eg. the gaps.
@Walker Reynolds  this is a good point. This is why I accepted a speaking engagement on the topic of digital twin on a panel with a couple other folks. My goal is to educate how the concept of a digital twin is a good one, but like all things, needs a good purpose. I plan to focus most of my points on the digital twin of the data layer. Focusing one why bringing manufacturing data from the shop floor into an accessible digital layer is critical for digital transformation success.

Author: autom8ion
Content: Has anyone used the EMQ X Enterprise MQTT-Kafka bridge?

Author: marioishikawa
Content:
@Walker Reynolds when you mentioned: 
" Highbyte, Ignition, FactoryStudio et al have application functionality AND can serve as the open hub.  More and more, we are using a standalone broker for the UNS (HiveMQ is our preferred right now) but we lose any form of abstraction functionality in the UNS when we do that."
--
You use HiveMQ as broker and have Ignition (or other SCADA) as another connected entity on the broker, using the Cirrus module?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Correct -- if we use a standalone broker, then we only use the transmission module and mqtt engine module in Ignition -- transmission lets us send non-MQTT tags into the broker, engine converts MQTT topic namespace into Ignition tags.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> Has anyone used the EMQ X Enterprise MQTT-Kafka bridge?
@Densparker we use EMQ as our broker quite a bit now -- we have two very large implementations with EMQ.  We will be using the Kafka bridge for a new project we are kicking off.  I'll let you know how it goes.

Author: marioishikawa
Content:
> Correct -- if we use a standalone broker, then we only use the transmission module and mqtt engine module in Ignition -- transmission lets us send non-MQTT tags into the broker, engine converts MQTT topic namespace into Ignition tags.
@Walker Reynolds thank you. And the advantage of this choice is because of the limitation on the Cirrus Link MQTT Distributor Module on 50 / 250 clients or there something else?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: 2 primary advantages -- Distributor has client and node restrictions (about 500 tags, about 50 clients) to drive you to purchase their enterprise solution and to keep resource consumption down on the gateway.  The second issue is the gateway itself.  When you use Ignition gateway as the broker, you are consuming resources for that function from the JVM that could otherwise be used for functions that only Ignition can serve.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: How you architect is always a function of the problem you are solving and the architecture you are building -- sometimes Ignition is appropriate for broker, sometimes it is not.

Author: autom8ion

Author: Deleted User

Author: abram7918
Content:
@Deleted User The question highlights a fundamental difference between a message broker approach whereby data is tansfered via MQTT payload + handshake mechanism for data exchange control & confirmation, versus using OPC-UA METHODS which are like an API with the control mechanisms built in. Using OPC-UA Methods requires a client-server connection so the transaction cannot be passed through the message broker.

In the case that a number of consumers need confirmed data from a single producer, using the message broker approach, each consumer must publish its own 'message received' topic that the producer must be configured to respond to. Using OPC METHODS each consumer asks the same question & gets its answer in a controlled way. Higher communication bandwidth required. If that communication is within the factory, that's not likely to be a problem.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: By analyzing their AWS SiteWise offer I found it quite expensive, as well as Timestream. It is affordable for Enterprise doing internally or with integrator, but not for a company to develop their own product over. But even on Enterprise, they get totally tied to the solution. What are your thoughts?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'm still having a bit of a hard time understanding what is SiteWise.   Is it a modeler to complement time series and event handling products?

While these platform products are cool, I really wonder about the commercial viability.  You're right.  The licensing appears cost prohibitive.  I can't see someone adopting these platforms to build out their own solution upon and monetize.  It's crazy how the economics between IoT PaaS and "vanilla" PaaS / IaaS play out.  It reminds me of what often happens to those that build out products on the SalesForce platform.  At first, it's very enabling.  But, at some point, they want out because of the licensing and the imposed technical constraints.  They eventually jump ship.  They find more freedom and achieve superior economics by taking slightly more ownership further down the stack.

At the end of the day, businesses need apps and functionality that can be applied to their industry vertical.  Unfortunately, everyone wants to be the "winner-takes-all" platform owner, but no one wants to be a spoke or own the last mile.  Everyone thinks the last mile is the responsibility of their mythical ecosystem partners.  If there is no money to be made, it won't get done.  Most end-user businesses are SMB and they may not necessarily be able to build everything themselves.  When a platform ignores these realities, it will hinder adoption.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: @js nice thoughts, thanks. I think most of the companies are still in the old license market with system integrators, like I charge it expensive because Enterprise can pay, and SIs will be happy because they will customize it. The problem is also that SIs want recurrent revenue and these solutions are not suitable for them. And developing from scratch in a small company you are not fast enough.

I will admit I'm a hugh fan of AWS and been using it for the past 10 years from the early days of only S3 and EC2, but I feel that is where the market is moving towards the big cloud providers.

Content: No experience with PLCNext or any of the new school stuff. I‚Äôm around mostly Rockwell, Fanuc, and Siemens.

Author: aronsemle
Content: @js good question. I work at HighByte, so my main goal was to see how we get the UN models into these tools. Cirrus Link (Ignition partner) recently came out with a similar tool the takes SparkPlugB and auto-creates models in SiteWise. So as vendors it's our job to figure out how to make it easier to get the UN up into these platforms. It's still an open question to me on how customers will want to manage models (i.e. create them in Sitewise, and pull them down, or create them in tools like HB and Ignition, and pull them up).  In terms of use cases, what I'm seeing mostly is availability/OEE projects. Large manufacturers are looking at these tools as a way to build a turn-key solutions to get machine data up into their cloud platform, and visualized. Basically something a controls person can hook up in a day. They are assuming that if they can make this easy, and the data is their cloud in a modeled way, they can leverage it in other ways in the future. I don't think AWS or Azure are tuned in on the UN concept.

Author: mdowdell
Content: I am looking at another solution similar to Highbyte and Litmus. In this case it is Telit and the deviceWise product. Any experiences or opinions?

Author: paulwright3831
Content: @mdowdell I'm not an expert but have a few customers who use Telit's deviceWise products. They seem to have a healthy market share in that translation gateway space, but my biggest customers also look forward to the day when they (and devices like them) are no longer needed. For many the future of industrial controllers are devices that can send Sparkplug B over MQTT natively from the edge, and there is a small market of them beginning to appear.

Author: mdowdell
Content: Thank you @Paul Wright.  Yes, I agree, that will be a nice day when PLCs have MQTT and SpB native. Unfortunately, until this day comes I am stuck in the industrial brownfield like a blind squirrel trying to find a nut. I believe many here will need the protocol conversion on the edge for a at least another 10 to 15 years given the installed base.

Author: paulwright3831
Content: @mdowdell Sorry for stating the obvious in my earlier reply, and you've raised what I think is a really interesting question: Can we cost justify upgrading hardware that is "working" but not easy to maintain without specific (and aging) support skills, and may not deliver optimum value toward the promise of Industry 4.0. For highly competitive industries like automotive manufacturing it seems to be a no-brainer, and they have at least some money allocated most years for newer tech. But who isn't in a "highly competitive industry"?

Author: aronsemle
Content: @mdowdell deviceWise is really good with embedded protocol conversion. They also were an early mover on MQTT, but I haven't kept up with them since the Telit acquisition. @Paul Wright I'm an old Kepware guy. We thought OPC UA would put us out of business when it first came out. I remember writing our server and client code back in 2010 trying to deal with certificates. 10 years later, Kepware still sells more Modbus and Ethernet/IP drivers than OPC. I'm excited to see change coming, but it comes slow..

Author: paulwright3831
Content: @aronsemle I can relate. In 2006 I was running the EDI department of a Fortune 150 and started hearing "XML is going to replace all that silly flat-file translation you guys do, EDI will be extinct in < 5 years." A decade later we had built exactly one XML-based interface for FedEx (one of our largest customers) who actually needed real-time transactions into our aftermarket parts business. NOBODY else was willing to come off those historic investments and migrate to XML just because it was "the next big thing".

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
> I am looking at another solution similar to Highbyte and Litmus. In this case it is Telit and the deviceWise product. Any experiences or opinions?
@mdowdell 

I demoed Telit/ILS deviceWISE a few years ago.  It has a neat logic engine manage transactions (e.g., parse, trigger, sequence).  It has a ton of connectivity options into IT systems.  We decided against it because, at the time, it did not have all the drivers we needed.  Additionally, at the time, we only were interested in OPC connectivity.  We went with Kepware.  Kepware had more drivers with more features and appeared to be more proactive keeping up with device/protocol changes.

DW has worked well for automotive OEMs and large tier ones with homegrown MES/SCADA apps.  These apps, as one might imagine, tend to have more bespoke integration.  It might involve writing to SQL tables or dropping in driver libraries directly into the project.  AAM and Honda have had successful implementations.  It helped eliminate custom middleware and streamline integration projects.  AAM solved a lot of brownfield problems.  They deployed these Advantech remote IO gateways with WiFi.

Had I known how big of a challenge making field data useful was, I might have spent more time evaluating and considering DW.  But, there is something that did not sit well with me about the product's philosophy and how I saw it being adopted.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Telit struck me as anti-OPC, but for the wrong reasons. They portrayed alternative solutions as leveraging OPC classic (i.e., OPC-DA) off the device instead of a native protocol.  I'm not really aware of anyone that leverages DCOM-based tech as their go-to solution these days.  There are well-known ways around this.  This may have been a misunderstanding.  Beyond the technicalities, it bothered me that Telit and their customers did not seem concerned with standards.  Yes, they transport data in standard ways, but they're not organizing the data itself in standard ways.  There was not much of an emphasis on information modeling.

The DW use cases seemed centered around taking a native device protocol, bypassing OPC (or any other similar standard), and inserting data into an app or database.  This is not particularly transformative.  Essentially, it‚Äôs a more efficient way to build the same one-off, discrete connections that have been in place for years.  OPC, despite its faults frequently discussed here, is at least a standard way to exchange information.  While often a simple name/value pair model in practice, it‚Äôs at least a standard.  There is value to normalizing data in a standard, repeatable way.

For those of that build and manage apps, they know their job does not end at protocol conversion.  They have to put considerable resources into modeling and contextualizing the data.  And, if a new app is introduced, another set of discrete connections must be mapped out and built.  If this can be done faster, that‚Äôs great.  But, it‚Äôs truly a missed opportunity not to question the need for these connections in the first place.  Or, taking a step back further, to question the apps used and how well they serve their purpose.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: I say this not to pick on Telit.  Much of this was driven by initial perception.  I‚Äôm sure there a plenty great ways to leverage DW.  Perhaps this is a function of Telit working with very large customers in the manufacturing and telecommunication industries.  Perhaps their customers have built out their own standards to the point that industry standards are of less importance.  Unfortunately, the use cases were illustrative of ways manufacturers can run into same problems they always have, but just more efficiently.  It‚Äôs just not sustainable to undergo an integration project every time a device or app changes.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
> @aronsemle I can relate. In 2006 I was running the EDI department of a Fortune 150 and started hearing "XML is going to replace all that silly flat-file translation you guys do, EDI will be extinct in < 5 years." A decade later we had built exactly one XML-based interface for FedEx (one of our largest customers) who actually needed real-time transactions into our aftermarket parts business. NOBODY else was willing to come off those historic investments and migrate to XML just because it was "the next big thing".
@Paul Wright I was thinking about the parallels of what we encounter in the IoT world to EDI as well.  Will these mapping problems ever go away?

You're absolutely right.  Everyone has clung onto their legacy flat text formats (e.g., X12, EDIFACT).  And sadly, managing EDI is still resource intensive and prone to delays.  Everyone has their own "standard" of the standards.  None of it self-describing and requires a human to interpret a spec's definition.

I will mention that where XML has began to work out is between apps, particularly multi-tenant cloud apps, and VANs.  Instead of building out translation maps for trading partners in the apps, this is increasingly done by the VANs.  The apps and VANs exchange data in canonical XML.  The investment pays off when there is enough to adopt it.  There is strength in numbers (e.g., multiple ERP vendors, multiple trading partners).  This is harder to adopt in a direct 1:1 trading relationship.

Author: .dhess
Content:
FYI: From a Python SIG I belong to:     "It‚Äôs worth pointing out that currently LabVIEW can‚Äôt work with Anaconda python..!
I ran into this problem‚Ä¶ after a bit of banging my head against a brick wall, NI Tech Support pointed me to this article:

Integrate Conda Python Environment with LabVIEW

Despite the article title, it goes on to say:
‚ÄúPython installed within the Anaconda environment cannot directly communicate with LabVIEW using the Python Node. This is due to the way the environment wraps the Python interpreter, making LabVIEW unable to find the interpreter installation and unable to make the necessary calls.  
The officially supported Python environments that can communicate with LabVIEW are native Python 2.7 and 3.6 installed from The Python Software Foundation.‚Äù

No issue if you are using python from The Python Software Foundation, but it‚Äôs not going to work with Anaconda."

Author: layeracht
Content: Hi all! Maybe a dumb question but how common is it that companies use public cloud services to send their locally collected data from some edge device there? Isn't it the better idea to utilize existing DC capacity to store data centrally and work (AI / ML stuff) with it there?

Author: paulwright3831
Content: Depends more on their cloud migration strategy, which is often "championed" by the CFO, not IT. Too many CIO's are under pressure for having the largest budget in the enterprise (people are the most expensive item and it takes quite a few to run that datacenter, staff the Helpdesk, maintain homegrown apps, protect the network, etc). Then add the cost of all that hardware. The reason cloud is the new world order is its economic model. From an architecture standpoint, I can tell you from some recent automotive manufacturing benchmarking I did that companies in the process controller market are being asked to develop edge devices that can filter data on any number of conditions so that just the bits they need go to the cloud, and the rest is dropped or archived for other uses.  You'll continue to hear a few people say "oh we can't store OUR data in the cloud because of X, Y, or Z", and you'll continue to gradually see them go that route, while some small datastores will stay local. But the future is smart edge devices (not PLCs) with fast CPUs wrapping data in standard syntax like Sparkplug B and feeding it to a cloud-based learning model, and then bi-directionally updating it's own configuration/calibration based on the output of that model.

Author: abram7918
Content: Given the proliferation of smart Edge devices applied 1:1 for each machine, what solutions are being used to manage that fleet of edge devices?

Author: .dhess
Content: @Abram Do you have a specific use case you are concerned with, or just fishing for some ideas. Metrology equipment that tracks some quality metric would be a use case of an area where you you would want to ensure that measurements across all the same type metrology tools are reading all similar against a calibration standard during a weekly tool qual. Tools with optical pathways, where optical spectrums need to be in a certain range across tool sets, could indicate shifts in optical apertures, or perhaps measurement targets have shifted out of a focal plane. There are tools that perform electronic parametric testing self diagnostics, where test return values could be tracked as a tool set constraint. etc...

Author: abram7918
Content: @EgoNoBueno The use case concerns manufacturing equipment in general, not metrology equipment specifically. It's clear that edge intelligence based on locally installed edge devices with significant compute capability are proliferating. There may be 100's of them on a large site, therefore a central device management tool is required.  A number of vendors (such as Advantech) sell devices with a platform allowing remote configuration / start-stop / software update / possibly firmware update depending on level of integration. The requirement is for a device management application which is independent of the hardware, & of any data management or IIOT platform. An example could be LF Edge development on EdgeX Foundry.

Author: .dhess
Content: @Abram Being able to remote update the firmware on multiple devices at the same time sounds like a recipe for a  quick way to go from hero to zero, and a clear violation of  The Eleventh Commandment - Thou shalt not crash the production floor, lest you will lose your reward in Heaven.  I'm going to have to look at all those kibbles and bits you mentioned, as I am out of my little pond with many of those terms.  It all sounds sexy though.

Author: abram7918
Content:
When you have a fleet of edge devices, either geographically distributed or just lots of them in a factory, you need to be able to maintain them centrally, including patch management, software updates with version management & traceability, security management, disaster  recovery.

It's not just sexy, its mandatory to properly cope with a large fleet, document, maintain & prove compliance with security & equipment validation, monitor performance & health of assets, and to enable DevSecOps in support of an agile infrastructure & reconfigurability of production assets.

This is standard in the IT infrastructure world for networks and pc / laptop / server / mobile device maintenance. The tools provided by your typical global IOT vendors don't do what we need.

The OT Community needs to adopt IT ways of working.

Running around with a USB stick & engineering laptop is not the future.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: I'm always surprised at how many companies still have usb sticks and engineering laptops as their current practice! Just shows how far we still have to go.  We are developing our new edge agent software to run within kubernetes, and to be distributed to allow for redundancy and zero-downtime updates to the code. We can deploy a rolling update to all edge agents with a simple command: helm upgrade edge-agent. that even manages the roll-back if the upgrade fails.

Author: .dhess

Content: Hello everyone. Some of you are familiar with Highbyte. How does report by exception work in case of models? Do all attributes of a model get send to the broker when just one atribute has a change? Just so you know I'm new to mqtt üôÇ

Author: aronsemle
Content: Hey laik, I work at HB and can take a try at your questions. The short answer is it's configurable. HB has the full model, but you can configure it to publish only fields that have changed or the full model over MQTT. Sparkplug (protocol over MQTT) as another example will publish the full model on birth, but then only sends fields that change. Happy to show you or discuss more if you have questions. It often depends on the consumer of the data. At times it's easier to get the full model, other times if you're paying per bit of traffic then you only want changes.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Thanks Aron!  From my perspective, this is one of the biggest strengths of HB -- the triggers for publishes can vary and you can group models into common triggers.  Its beautiful.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The options you list are all compelling and have merit.  Depending on the application, there may even be a case to be made to simply choose something with a fieldbus interface that is compatible with an existing PLC you have.  Things like process control or safety will have special considerations.

What are you looking to connect them to?  What kind of inputs (e.g., buttons, motion sensor, safety, legacy asset w/o communication interface) and what will primarily consume it (e.g., PLC, SCADA, IoT App)?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Depending on total # of IO and logic requirements... Best bets for me right now -- S7-1200 starting around $500, EZRack PLC starting around $350, PLCNext starting around $500, Zumedge from Freewave starting around $800.

Author: oleksandrtimofieiev
Content: About you saying, that there might be a case to plug into PLC a connector with some digital protocol and read directly - we currently working on it. We're trying to evaluate if it is possible to reach the controllers' codes and get data, or modify programms to get data. The funny thing is we can absolutely reach the manufacturers of those machines, but their basic position is to vendor-lock us. Answering your question on how we wish to interconnect machines with other nodes, I would describe it as a brain-slug. We want to read discrete I/Os directly from PLCs' pins. Such way as we could do it programmatically. If the controller sets HIGH for a piston or a motor or does it receive some inputs from sensors, we read that directly from PLCs' pins, and register a performed action. The main kind of inputs is tools' activation, some external sensors (mostly optical), very few buttons. The main consumer of this information is OEE calculation tool, i.e. InfluxDB + Python through MQTT.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Siemens has a SCALENCE switch with routing and Open SSL VPN.  It connects to their SINEMA remote management platform.  IBH Softec makes a hardware TeamViewer client that can be deployed in an electrical panel.  It's a gateway that securely encapsulates TCP/UDP-based protocols as a TeamViewer session.

In general, I'm not a big fan of industrial VPN appliances.  In practice, they're often misconfigured and not maintained.  At the same time, I recognize that sometimes they're the only practical option.  My biggest gripe with them is that they're not well lifecycled.  They also lack tools to centrally manage at scale.  Security is hardly a "set-it-and-forget-it" exercise.  If you've worked in networking, you'll know that infrastructure is continuously managed and patched to stay ahead of threats.  It's a formal discipline that has yet to become pervasive in the ICS space.  My preferred approach is to not reinvent the wheel, but to leverage one that works.

My favorite solution is to create a remote access console / jump box behind the firewall.  This is a dedicated, locked-down VM with software specifically to manage the asset(s).  VM is reached through a VPN session.  Console requires a valid directory account, adaptive MFA, and everything is logged.  VM and the asset(s) are each segmented with identity-based access policies via TrustSec.

This has a several benefits:  1)  Security is modeled around the intent.  2)  It's reliable.  Third parties don't have to fuss with their own remote endpoint or software.  3)  It's performant.  The asset's management protocol does not have to be tunneled across the internet.  4)  Change management and version control become part of remote access.

SD-WAN and Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) are some newer technologies that have great potential for remote access.  Assets or sites can become nodes on an SD-WAN.  Access and security are orchestrated through SASE platform (security cloud) rather than an unmanaged firewall.

Author: andymellor
Content: @zackscriven Question relating to the "Your IIOT Strategy and why it's going to fail" video posted earlier. I'm talking with a water company who are implementing an IIoT strategy similar to your 'why it will fail' scenario.  They are not so interested in downtime and OEE - more to do with Energy usage and environmental impact. So the big $$$ issue is environmental - they have deployed flow sensors in to sewers to make sure they don't flood the cities and rivers - pushing the data straight to the cloud, some kind of ML algorithm is trying to detect flood situations before they happen. They are also about to start pushing data straight to the cloud from water treatment sites. My guess is that this will make analysis very difficult to do. Lots of un-normalised data sources. My question is this.... Have you or any of the members here seen a unified namespace approach working with massive amounts of telemetry, and very geographically dispersed small SCADA/PLC sites.  They currently have OSI PI centrally with millions, probably 10s millions of tags. 10 years ago they used PI AF to normalise some of this data - this will most likely also be pushed into the Azure data lake eventually. But for now they are going straight back to the treatment site SCADA and PLCs for the data source.  Wow, what a dump of info - happy to clarify is none of this makes sense.  Just looking for some insight!  Mainly around a central UNS on very large distributed systems, with hundreds of small sites. Thanks

Author: mparris
Content:
I'm benchmarking bandwidth performance between a custom application exposing an OPC-UA Server vs MQTT SparkplugB.  Will look at average bits per second on the wire per Wireshark. Will also use data rates of 50ms, 100, 500, and 1000ms to see how the differences change based on rate.

Anything else of interest I should  capture regarding bandwidth?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The one thing we don't have is a comparison of SPBv1 and MQTT 3.1.1 (vanilla MQTT).  The standards we use in benchmarking are 93% bool, 7% analog (float or int)... the CSIA metrics for distribution of industrial data on the edge (7% are analog values).  When you report, it would be interesting to know how many models you are passing via SPBv1 (UDTs).

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Maybe you could also test with different JSON sizes, like when you send just on key/value pair or something longer that could include like several keys, some keys with arrays (like past 10 values).

Author: mparris
Content:
My first take was analogs changing at the different rates. I can certainly add Booleans. Since analogs are always changing, that is set by the publish rate. But what about Booleans? Should they change at the same rate, twice the rate, etc?  My guess is that the most disparate comparison is MQTT with rarely-changing Booleans.

Comparing to vanilla MQTT is tough, since formatting the data is wide open.  I could encode everything as a string with a lot of fluff or try to come up with my own efficient encoding scheme (good luck trying to beat Google's protobuf). Maybe just settle for a JSON string since that seems to be common?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Only 7% of all registers in the average PLC change at least once per minute... we try to replicate that by having our booleans change once per minute while having the floats/ints behave as normal

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Package vanilla as a JSON -- {payload:{tag1:value1},{tag2:value2}} etc

Author: henning8936
Content: When implenting an IIOT infrastructure with UNS in an I3.0 company (manufacturig), how important are platforms like Ignition or Factory Studio for the overall success? Does it make sens to put together a custom framework for backend and frontend development? I am not saying that I want to do it (I would love to replace our Andon screens, that run on LabView, with ignition). I am just curious, what the experts here think. What tools would you use, if Ignition et. al.  are not an option?

Author: bradfrayo2778
Content: Have you done any testing with CPL410 embedded linux yet?

Author: andersgustav
Content:
It really depends on your skillset, and how much labor you are willing to put into it..
As long as what you use meets the minimum requirements, you could get a long way using tools like mosquitto, Node-RED, streamsheets etc. But I wouldn't stretch those much longer than for a PoC or  anything not to big.
While waiting to be allowed  to build with real tools I have done a lot of this, it has been fun, challenging and educational. And I have provided insight in parts of the production that has been in the dark for forever - so it has been really helpful. But now I'm moving to the real toys üòâ

The power of tools like ignition or FS is that they can do everything, and that really well. It's just what they are made for, you work much faster and get a system you can trust (more).

Author: andyott33
Content:
I just heard about the Haystack Standard by Project Haystack, https://project-haystack.dev/
It seems to be a standard dedicated to the Building Automation sector.
I did a quick look through the documentation and I am wondering if this specification would fit in the IIoT ecosystem? 
Would this be something similar to Sparkplug B? But, just specific to building automation?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Haystack is to BACnet and LonWorks what OPC-UA is to EtherNet/IP and PROFINET.  It's like an OPC companion specification.  It's a markup language for semantically modeling building automation.  It's the meta data for the "tags" coming off of things like HVAC, lighting, power, etc.  It seeks to unify the disparate protocols and data models in the building automation space.  It's goal is interoperability to take the friction out of IoT and SCADA/BAS (e.g., Tridium Niagara) integration projects.

My understanding is that Haystack is purely semantic and independent of transport.  Thus, it can coexist with and leverage MQTT or Sparkplug B.  It's theoretically possible to nest a representation of the Haystack information model into an MQTT or SpB payload.  This would be somewhat analogous to organizing a UNS around ISA95 structure.  It's just another way to organizing the information.  It could be used as a whole strategy or limited to edge use cases.

As I have limited exposure to this space, I cannot attest to the market adoption of Haystack.  On one hand, I could see it struggle for similar reasons as OPC-UA information modeling has.  On the other hand, building automation is much more simple than automating a manufacturing process.  The integration problem space for manufacturing assets (e.g., CNC, robotics, assembly, packaging) is on a whole different scale than building assets (e.g., compressors, air handlers, lighting).  As a result, Haystack might be more practical to implement.

Relevant article on IIoT technology in the building automation space:
https://www.conserveitiot.com/post/taking-project-haystack-and-niagara-to-the-real-iiot

Author: benveenema
Content:
Interesting! I've been wondering why Industrial Ethernet is a thing really. I get it for the SCADA to PLC  or PLC to HMI level connection where there might be a lot of data going back and forth. But why on earth do we need _Ethernet_ with all it's overhead and latency to connect to a valve bank or I/O card? There really isn't (or shouldn't) be that much data traveling. I know we all like to rag on serial and can (I'd personnally love to see I2C and SPI used in industrial settings as well), but aren't they fast enough, lower latency and cheaper to implement than Ethernet?

I don't have the historical context for why Ethernet was chosen over these other protocols. I'd love to hear from the more veteran members about that.

Author: benveenema
Content:
- RBE = Cilantro
- ED = Chili Powder
- LW = Italian Seasoning
- OA = Lawrys Seasoning Salt

Author: dundo6741
Content:
I2C and SPI are prone to EM interference. They, as well as RS232 and USB, are for short connections only.
TCP/IP is also nice protocol for routing using standard equipment.

Author: benveenema
Content: How long is the typical device/sensor to PLC connection? And how much routing needs to be there? Perhaps some applications actually need the distance and routing capabilities but there's a lot of machines where the longest run is 10ft. Ethernet seems like a protocol that's good for things like waste water treatment plants but not as good for discrete manufacturing. Perhaps this is where IO-Link will fit.

Author: mparris
Content:
Looks like IOlink speeds are about 8kbps over 3wires (power and data are separate)  Single-pair Ethernet (power and data over two twisted wires) can be 1Gbps on short runs and 10Mbps on longer runs.

It would allow sensors to publish MQTT directly, which would remove an integration step at the IOLink master.

I guess we'll find out how useful this new tech is and how the market responds

Author: matthijsprent
Content: And what about EtherCat? it seems to combine some advantages of both.

Author: mparris
Content:
I would guess the primary target is distributed devices in a star (hub/spoke) model, and less of a bus model like EtherCAT. 

It would be interesting, though, to see EtherCAT deployed over singlewire Ethernet

Author: richard44160
Content: Agree with @MParris, we should follow single pair ethernet market as it could the most powerful sensor device network ever ! 10 Mbps PoE on 1 single pair ... imagine that a sensor could directly publish to the UNS via MQTT SpB !

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
SPE (aka Ethernet-APL) has a lot of potential as physical media for IO-Link.  It can carry IO-Link connections for sensors and actuators much further than the standard 3-pin 24VDC connection (e.g., M12).  

I would imagine this would be ideal for distributed scenarios where it's beneficial to carry power in addition to data.  This could be an economical alternative to all the infrastructure required to deploy a local IO-Link Master or remote IO (e.g., AC, power supply, breakers, field switches, panels).

I've heard the process industry and utilities are clinging onto PROFIBUS for similar reasons.  They like the ability to carry power over the bus.  PROFINET, while capable of going long distances over fiber, lacks power.  PROFINET, over copper, with Power-over-Ethernet (PoE) never took off as a suitable replacement.  It apparently could not meet the more stringent safety requirements found in the process industry.

For discrete manufacturers with more "dense" fields, SPE/APL is probably not a game changer.  Cable runs are either not a problem or they need to terminate in a nearby panel for safety.  In these environments, the benefits are probably limited to facility and auxiliary assets with limited controls.

It is interesting to think about how this tech could enable the deployment of smart sensors.  One of the most common brownfield issues is deploying sensors on inflexible assets (e.g., no panel space, limited power, no analog inputs, no fieldbus, locked logic, no documentation).  Machine builders, foolishly, love to gut their products of anything useful to integrate with a factory.

IO-Link with SPE:
https://profinews.com/2020/09/io-link-vs-ethernet-or-io-link-over-ethernet/
https://io-link.com/share/Downloads/Konzeptstudien/IO-Link_over_SPE_V100_Jan20.pdf

E+H article on the role of industrial ethernet in field instrumentation:
https://www.us.endress.com/_storage/asset/9068572/storage/master/file/30175427/download/EH-DataAnalyticsUpdatedWP20.pdf

Author: benveenema
Content:
Yes, IO-Links data rate is slow. But bps is not the same as time to delivery or latency.  The bps of an analog, on/off sensor (ex. switch) is very low, maybe 100 bps but the time for that signal to reach the PLC program is very very fast, maybe a few micro-seconds.

In the case of most sensors or devices, there just isn't that much data so bps is not all that important once a certain threshold has been met. What is important is:
- how quickly you can act on that data (ie how much processing before the PLC program can read it)
- how reliable is that data
- how expensive is the required silicone in order to be able transmit and receive that data

The last one is where slower, simpler technologies can really win. The number of transistors required to handle an ethernet package vs an I2C (as an example, but could replace with serial) is 10x or more. This is a limiting factor in how cheap we can sensors and devices. I tend to think, if we could make sensors and devices really cheap (but still good) we could afford to put a lot more of them onto every machine, thereby increasing our depth of understanding of the process at any given time.

Cheaper Sensors = More Sensors = More Better üòâ

Author: benveenema
Content:
The concerns about I2C susceptibility to EM interference is real. I2C was designed for chip to chip communication on a PCB. However, there has been a lot of work done to make it more hardened for longer runs and noisy environments. This article from Hackaday: https://hackaday.com/2017/02/08/taking-the-leap-off-board-an-introduction-to-i2c-over-long-wires/ lays out a few solutions that wouldn't be terribly difficult to implement if you'r comfortable with a soldering iron or breadboard.

The next hurdle with I2C is lack of support by traditional PLC vendors. There are some Arduino based PLCs out there that support it but the major guys have no interest.

Author: andyott33
Content: Thanks @Ben Veenema that's the article I remember you posted. I will take a look through that today.

Author: dundo6741
Content:
In some vending machines I had I2C connection, 1 - 1.5m, long between RPi and 16x2 LCD display.
Every now and then the screen would get garbled. Even when new data was sent, some changes would be seen but still garbled.
I assume that fault lay in part on "stupid" LCD controller and protocol used (no checksum for example) but that mainly occurs due to I2C sensitivity to EM noise.
So I had to add a LCD output buffer in my program, reset the LCD every few seconds and send the buffered data again to LCD.
LCD was flickering but nothing could be done about that ... üôÇ
BTW, I2C speed was very low. Higher speed comm. would be even worse I assume.

Author: benveenema
Content:
I have seen this as well in a lot of lower cost LCD screens. I2C has no checks built in, this is part of why it's so low cost and light weight. The memory buffer on the LCD screen likely got messed up by a bad block of I2C data. To keep data transfer low, the controller is only going to update the part of the memory buffer where changes are happening.

You're software solution of just refreshing the whole screen every once in a while is a good approach. A more electronics based approach like some of the chips suggested in the article above might be more reliable though.

Author: mparris
Content:
I went back through my YouTube comments. It's interesting to hear your interpretation of my questions on OPC-UA translated to a doubt of MQTT/SparkplugB.

To be honest, I was in OPC-UA land at those times and the technology was fresh on the brain, and some of the claims I was hearing in the videos didn't jive with my understanding.  So, I put the questions out there in case I was missing something about how OPC-UA works.

I think the pinnacle of this is when @Walker Reynolds thought I was a member of the IIC or sold a RAMI product. I about fell out of my chair when I heard that.  Maybe a backhanded compliment of trying to go too deep on the subject?  üòÜ 

Also at the time, I only had a cursory understanding of MQTT and I had heard of SparkplugB.  The weight of marketing for OPC-UA is real and that's why I was more familiar with it.

Then I tried SparkplugB and watched the self-discovery process unfold before my eyes... That is IIoT.

So, my journey has been less of needing convincing that OPC-UA isn't appropriate at the Enterprise, but more of learning about SparkplugB, and realizing that these architectural evolutions are a repeat of history (how the internet became what it is today), then being surprised that the marketing term "IIoT" actual describes quite well what industry now needs.

Author: venkyiaf753280
Content: It's so interesting to learn about these stuffs here. That is a great share @MParris . Although, I haven't worked with or used OPC-UA or an MQTT/SparkplugB, I have been reading a lot about them off-late and also learning a lot from @Walker Reynolds videos. What I understand is that MQTT is popular, proven and well supported in enterprise and consumer applications. It makes organization-spanning data exchange possible by decoupling data producers and consumers using a brokered pub-sub architecture and by defining a lightweight, data agnostic communication format that supports millions of connections. Sparkplug B defines an MQTT implementation standard that ensures client interoperability and enhances MQTT with features designed to support the demands of mission critical industrial systems. And finally, the edge devices provide the complementary reliability in the physical layer to process and transmission the field data securely and efficiently. Therefore, the combination of MQTT, Sparkplug B and edge devices forma a complete solution for the IT/OT data networks.
