Author: luisn8316
Content: Question: when a driver says it supports MQTT V3.1.1 spec, does this mean it supports SpB? If not, can someone explain the difference?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
They‚Äôre different. V3.1.1 is ‚Äúvanilla‚Äù MQTT. It‚Äôs pure transport without anything else defined.

SpB add to and relies on V3.1.1. SpB has extra features for state management and further defines the organization of information sent within it. The data is moved the same way, but the data organized in a different way that is useful for industrial applications. A vanilla MQTT driver could read SpB, but it would see extra gibberish that it would not know how to decode.

Basically, SpB is vanilla MQTT with an industrial automation accent.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Here are two great resources on MQTT and SpB. These are far more educational than reading the spec documents.

Opto 22‚Äôs paper on MQTT SpB
https://documents.opto22.com/2357_Industrial_Strength_MQTT_Sparkplug_B.pdf

Industry 4.0 TV MQTT SpB Tutorial
https://youtu.be/eIp3FdQYFnQ

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Does anyone know if KepServerEx can expose an OPC-DA client application as an OPC-UA server?  

I have an application that has an OPC-DA client that was designed to write tags to a PLC via an OPC Server.  I have a scenario where some deployments of the app are without a PLC.  I'm looking to have a OPC-UA client application for data collection in place of where a PLC normally would be.

The typically UA tunneling use case I've seen is:
[OPC-DA Server]  < OPC-DA >  [OPC-DA Client | OPC-UA Server]  < OPC-UA >  [OPC-UA Client | ... ]

My situation is a little different:
[OPC-DA Client]  < OPC-DA >  [OPC-DA Server | OPC-UA Server]  < OPC-UA >  [OPC-UA Client | ... ]

Is it possible to create a DA Server -to- UA Server connection?

Author: Deleted User
Content:
Hi everybody! 

I have a small question here. I just watched the video OPC-UA vs MQTT 2021 Update (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jQLAmHza0Dc) and there it's stated that OPC-UA "makes sense on the edge". I'm not that experienced in this field and I'm struggling a little to understand what that means, especially when being integrated with other system like Sparkplug. Does that mean, that there should be an "entity" polling this Edge-OPC-UA-Server continuously and then bridging this information to e.g. Sparkplug?

Thanks!

Author: marioishikawa
Content: OPC makes sense on the edge means that in the LAN it makes sense, so that PLCs can exchange information of the gateway can talk to the gateway. But even in this case, it also depends of the network size, amount of devicees, and so on. But usually between a few devices such as machines in a single line it is a case. But once you need to move to the cloud or out of the plant, using WAN, then it is the case in which MQTT is much superior and OPC-UA cannot scale.

Author: mparris
Content:
In your diagram, with a DA server and UA server. How do you envision creating a tag for your DA client to target to write to? Because today, when you connect to your PLC from your OPC-DA server on the industrial PC, the DA server is enumerating the registers so your inspection app can connect and write to a register.

When you use a software that is a server on both sides, what tells this software to create a register for your inspection app to target for the write? Are you envisioning a config page to create memory tags?

Another thought, does your middleware have an OPC-UA server? Matrikon has a product that will take your DA client and allow it to connect to the UA server.

Author: mparris
Content:
Report by exception in the purest sense is there is no traffic if the data doesn't change.

If you look carefully in the traffic on Wireshark, you will notice a publish Request from the client to the server. This publish Request is sent at the rate that the client wants data sent to it. Even if there is no change in data (the client can't know if any data had changed, that's why it's asking, lol), the client still asks for the data. 

Imagine a boolean that changes once a year. The client wants to know that change within 1s of the change. The client will set its publish rate to 1000ms and it will ask the server if data has changed in that second. Then at that time a year when the boolean flips, the server will finally respond with the new data. Then the polling continues for the next year.

All the polling traffic from the client that occurs during that year doesn't exist with MQTT, because the client with the new data will publish only when there is a change, and then the clients that are subscribed will get it.

*Disclaimer: I'm ignoring keep-alive packets in this example.  MQTT has a small keepalive packet and OPC-UA uses the publish Request as the keep alive, although I've recently discovered that SDKs also use a ReadRequest of the ServerStatus node (ns=0;i=2256) to make sure the server is still alive, which is additional traffic.

Author: dundo6741
Content: Also, according to Nyquist theorem on information theory, to be able to catch signal shape reliably at the rate of 1s you should sample it at twice the rate i.e. 0.5s. üôÇ

Author: mparris
Content: You bring up a good point.  OPC-UA also has provisions for what is called the sample interval.  This is where the client is telling the server how often it should sample the data source for changes.  This is different from publish rate, which is the client telling the server how often to send the updates to it.  So, for example, you could have a publish rate of 1000ms and a sample rate of 100ms.  By default, however, the queue size is 1, so while the server is queueing the samples at 100ms, when it comes time to publish the results, the client will only get the latest sample. So the client can also increase the queue size greater than 1.  So per the previous example, if the queue size was 10, the client would get 10 samples every 1s.

Author: mparris
Content:
Just came across this blurb that describes a web communication technology called SignalR, which solved a poll/response problem of web pages.

"ASP.NET SignalR is a library for ASP.NET developers to add real-time web functionality to their applications. Real-time web functionality is the ability to have server-side code push content to the connected clients as it happens, in real-time.[1]"

I see the parallels here: HTML = OPC-UA.  Would be interesting to see if the client/server spec ever gets improved to add a real-time API: once the connection is made, the data flows from server to client without polling.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Thanks for your feedback and suggestions, @MParris and @Michael Brown.

I didn't realize Ignition had an OPC-UA server.  I've only used Igniton's OPC-UA client with Kepware's drivers.  It never occurred to me that Ignition's native drivers, along with all other tag providers, all fed into an OPC-UA Server that could be exposed outside of Ignition.  This, paired with a local instance of KepServerEx with the OPC-DA client app should work.  It's like using Igniton and KepServerEx as one would typically, but just in reverse.

Another interesting discovery was the simulator tags within KepServerEx.  Normally, these are used as "dummy" tags to test the server and feed data into a client.  These tags are actually free to be written to like any other OPC tag.  The DA client app was able to write to them as if they were tags tied to a PLC.  From there, the UA server (through a client) or IoT Gateway (MQTT) could deliver the data into the IIoT infrastructure.

It was somewhat comical discussing enhancing native connectivity with the producer of app.  In inquiring about alternatives to OPC-DA (e.g., OPC-UA, MQTT, SpB, REST), they said... yes in  theyear 2021,  "As companies start to become more interested in IOT, a decision will be made regarding how best to support those needs. It is unclear right now whether priority will be given to OPC-UA or MQTT."  This tells me their market is ripe for disruption.

Author: mparris
Content:
I was going to suggest Ignition for you, but they didn't have the OPC Classic Server for you, so didn't think it was needed.

Since KepwareEx has an OPC Classic Server, and you can create a memory tag there (you were using the simulator tags, which are the same concept), couldn't you just use the OPC-UA Server interface of Kepware? How will you use ignition here? Go from UA to MQTT?

If I was the product manager of that inspection app, the decision would be, which interface can I go to market quicker between the two? Then work on the other while clients are buying the software!

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
The handful of IIoT platforms I have worked with (Ignition, FactoryStudio, Progea) all have OPC-UA server functionality. Native to the platform they all do what the Kepware server does, which is connect to devices and shares those tags as a server (there are settings in Ignition to do this). That said, most commercial applications continue to use Kepware as the connection to plant floor data.

There are several tools that are used to map OPC-UA tags to other protocols like OPC-DA, MQTT, etc. I have used the Cogent DataHub for this.  OAS also does this, but I have found the former to be a more straight forward tool. I found OAS to be pricey. It also doesn't support SpB. Simulation tags make it easy to test connections and functionality. I discovered a bug in DH through this process which was fixed prior to commercial release.

Clayton Christensen is famous for his theory of "disruptive innovation". If the theory holds true, I suspect OPC will spend more time and energy defending its current Industry 3.0 position than innovating into a similar 4.0 position.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I should have mentioned it was a requirement that OPC-DA begin-and-end on the same box.  I'm not fond of using OPC-DA across a network.  I don't like to poke holes through Windows to enable DCOM.

If there is not OPC-UA server available, the memory tag concept would enable the client app to write to a local DA Server and then expose as a UA Server to UA clients (DA Client <> DA Server <> Memory Tags <> UA Server <> UA Client).

Given that Ignition has an OPC-UA Server, the client app can write to Ignition's UA server via a local OPC-UA client.  (DA Client <> DA Server <> UA Client <> UA Server).  This is probably the best way.

As far as where it eventually goes, it will go into a QMS/SPC app via HTTP POST.  There are potentially new consumers of this information.  Getting it into MQTT for distribution to othe rnodes via a UNS is likely in the works.  I'm happy enough to get out of the custom middleware business, reduce disparate connections, and start to converge data.

I looked into HighByte, but they only had a UA Client connector.  Additionally, in some deployments, the resulting API transaction to the QMS/SPC require further context defined by the user (e.g., send in data along with chosen attributes).  Given the need for a GUI, Ignition seems to be a natural choice.  As we flesh out the UNS further, we'll return to this.

Content:
I was kind of surprised, but it made sense given all the native driver support and flexibility to expose tags.  I've always resorted to using Kepware because of certain drivers and it's worked out well to de-couple connectivity when working with multiple UA clients.  

It never occurred to me that anyone would need to expose SCADA or other apps as a UA Server.  It seemed like something that only existed theoretically in OPC-UA reference architectures.  Further up the stack, in practice, it seems like most useful apps expose themselves via web services (e.g., SOAP, HTTP).  Generally, the need to get OPC-UA data out of the IIoT platform was to get it back to edge devices.  This could be accomplished by having the IIoT platform write data over the UA client interface.

I've encountered the Top Server product a few times on assets with embedded PCs.  It was literally identical KepServerEx.  It seems like it's a special sales channel / reseller / integrator for machine builders

Author: mparris
Content:
Thanks for the validation. I think you are doing it correctly.  Your results helped tweak my understanding.

The PublishRequest is the non-RBE behavior, here. In MQTT, you set the subscription up front, and then the client never has to request a publish again. So the PublishRequest is wasted traffic seen every time the value changes.

For my mock use-case, the values are changing every 50ms. So there is a lot of PublishRequest traffic that is not present in MQTT.

Author: Deleted User
Content: But there is only traffic if the server changes the value. Otherwise, there aren't any bytes being transferred on the wire. I don't see the unnecessary traffic I was expecting from a pure request/response approach.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Deleted User, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: mparris
Content:
Given what you demonstrated, that invalidates what I said a couple weeks ago that there is traffic from the client to the server even when the value isn't changing.

What you have shown, is that the client must send a PublishRequest with every change of the data, correct?

So to compare OPC-UA and MQTT:

OPC-UA client --> creates a subscription to the server, then sends a PublishRequest
OPC-UA server --> holds the PublishRequest, on value change, the server sends a PublishResponse
OPC-UA client --> receives new value, then sends another PublishRequest to the server
OPC-UA server --> holds the PublishRequest, on value change, the server sends a PublishResponse
*repeat*

MQTT client --> creates a subscription to a topic to the broker
Broker --> sends the updated value to the client
Broker --> sends the updated value to the client
*repeat*

Author: mparris
Content: Is this your understanding?

Author: Deleted User
Content:
That could be right, yes. What I see is that after subscription, the server sends a PublishResponse ONLY on data change and then right away the client sends a PublishRequest. I don't know the meaning of this PublishRequest, but on inspection I can see that it contains something about a "SubscriptionAcknowledgement". 

Maybe it's some kind of long polling?

Author: mparris
Content: It could be that the first PublishRequest is implicit with the creation of the subscription, which is why it's not seen on the wire.  But subsequent data changes have the client replinishing the PublishRequest.  The way the protocol works, if the server doesn't have a PublishRequest in its queue when the publish rate has expired, then it shouldn't send data.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @MParris, you just advanced to level 10!

Author: mparris
Content: I am surprised that you are not seeing an empty PublishResponse at the expiration of the PublishRate (what did you set the rate to when creating the subscription?)  The protocol uses this as a life ping, where the client sends the PublishRequest (informs the server that the client is still alive), then if there is no new data upon the PublishRate expiring, the server should send an empty PublishResponse (informs the client that the server is still alive)

Author: mparris
Content: The architects probably thought, if we are going to have this traffic back and forth, we might as well make use of it as a ping...

Author: mparris
Content:
A quick primer: there are three main parameters when specifying a subscription to a monitoreditem:
1) Subscription publish interval: this is how often the server should send changed data to the client. This value applies to all MonitoredItems within a subscription
2) MonitoredItem sampling interval: this is how often the OPC-UA server should access the underlying data source looking for changes. For example, if a tag represents date-time with millisecond resolution, how often should the OPC-UA server access that data source for a new value of time.
3) MonitoredItem queue size: how many changed values should the server keep until it's time for the publish

Author: mparris
Content:
Question for all you MQTT and network ü§ì 

Given I have a cluster of three brokers, and I want to forward that Namespace to a higher-level broker in the Enterprise, and the cluster must go through a network gateway performing port address translation (read: typical function of a home router for internet access)

what is the best way to connect the two?

(1) a single node of the cluster at the lower-level initiates a bridge connection to the higher level broker. If this node in the cluster fails, then the bridge has to be created on a different node of the cluster,

(2) Higher-level broker initiates a connection to one of the nodes of the lower-level cluster through a network gateway via port forwarding. If this lower level node fails, the higher level broker can fail over to one of the other nodes (I don't even know if "shared connections" for subscription bridges exists in any brokers on the market)

(3) include the higher level node as a member of the cluster. Presumably, if a node at the lower level fails, the other two nodes will keep the higher-level bring up to date. Q: can clustered connections be routed through a gateway performing PAT, or do they need to be in the same subnet?

(4) other?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Each node of the local cluster will bridge to the enterprise cluster. Configuration needs to be identical. I haven‚Äôt tried using different subsets but as long as they are able to connect it should work (I am not a networking expert but subnet mask comes into play). The ports are outbound only from the local cluster to the enterprise. The cluster uses a separate port for binding that is different from listener port.

Author: mparris
Content:
I tried last night playing with EMQx. I'm selecting EMQx given that it includes bridging in the community edition. I could not get the dashboard to work in VerneMQ (I'm running these from Docker containers).

Once the cluster is formed, editing the bridge properties on one transfers to the other nodes of the cluster. I didn't know that's how it works: configuring one configures them all. So each node spins up clients to connect to the upstream broker. So far so good.

I tested publishing to each node, and verified that no matter where the data is published, it appears on the other node AND gets to the upstream broker through the bridge. Also, taking down the original node that was configured for the bridge still allowed the data to go through the bridge, proving that one configuration is shared/replicated between all nodes.

Something odd I can't explain: regardless of if the mqtt-bridge plugin was in a stopped or started state, the bridge functioned either way. I configured the bridge using the rules interface of the GUI: select statement to filters what data to bridge, then create a "resource" that was the client connection to the upstream broker.

Also, if both nodes in the cluster are connected to the upstream broker, are they are both sending data to the upstream broker creating duplicate publishes? The upstream broker seems to send out only one message per publish to my desktop client when it is subscribed, so maybe there isn't duplicated data? Maybe the cluster nodes can differentiate its incoming data: publishes from clients directly connected to them are sent through the bridge, VS publishes received through cluster replication are not sent across the bridge?

Author: mparris
Content:
The next test will be having the lower cluster subscribe to the upper broker so data can be sent back down.

Overall, the technology used by these clusterable products (mqtt brokers, distributed databases, etc) certainly seem like voodoo in that once they are connected in a cluster, it just works.  Way more elegant than trying to get MS SQL Server to replicate in high available cluster (all their documentation talks about using SQL Server on a cluster of Windows Server... Give us even more money!) I wonder how long products like MS SQL will survive one these natively clusterable products get more momentum.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
I had a 3-node EMQx cluster at one point. From what I recall, you had to configure each of them to recognize the other two, but it was pretty straightforward. I have not used the bridge function, but suspect this is pretty simple, as well. That is pretty cool the will share the bridge configuration. I have not clustered my HiveMQ nodes, but perhaps I should to see if it does the same thing.

Did you shut down bridging in all nodes? Where brokers restarted? I find it strange the bridge would still be active if the service was not active.

The purpose of clustering is to ensure that two local nodes do not publish the same data to the enterprise node. Mosquitto made a change to its configuration that required you to name both local and remote brokers to eliminate the risk of getting in a pub/sub doom loop. I have not configured any local broker to receive updates from the enterprise broker. They seem to have thought this through.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
Vorne, RedZone and other products like it make a pretty solid OEE platform. I have run across them a lot in F&B and CPG (AK Pizza, Buddy's Kitchen, Dakota Growers Pasta) because they are priced appropriately and are pretty easy to support. Where they have struggled is getting more granular data. It has been a couple of years since I looked at them, but it sounds like they have made improvements and expanded in other MES functions (genealogy, recipe management).

But to the point of the conversation, they do not meet the minimum technical requirements and is solution based, rather than technology based. It is my contention that solution providers use the "McKinsey model" because that is what customers expect and they is what they know how to provide. When I see the words "connector" and "API" along with a bunch of other modern technology terms, I become suspect. The amazing part is if this architecture worked, why does it continue to fail?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
There are ways to get IT Infrastructure into the UNS.  Kepware, for example, has drivers like SNMP for managed switches.  Splunk, a popular SIEM, can publish out data in addition to everything it ingests.

There are a ton of solutions to monitor and/or control infrastructure (e.g., Splunk, Ansible, Puppet, ServiceNow, SolarWinds, DNA Center).  They have out-of-box support for CLIs and APIs  of all sorts of devices.  It's basically plug-and-play.  Unlike the industrial space, the data models and namespaces of these devices are typically standardized.  They do not vary by deployment in a way that something like a PLC would.  (BTW, this is why non-industrial tech people struggle with industrial tech).

A UNS is probably a good place for basic diagnostic information (e.g., state, temp, cpu load) as it can impact operations.  Infrastructure is one component of asset performance management.  Whether it's a motor or fieldswitch, downtime is downtime.  Providing visibility into every link in the chain across the enterprise is worthwhile.  

A UNS likely won't become the backbone of a NOC or DevOps team though.  There is such a strong ecosystem of tools that provide visibility and control with relative ease.  It's probably not worth reinventing this wheel.  Exposing meta data and embedding reporting/visualizations is more likely.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I've typically leaned on Cisco and Palo Alto Networks for network security.  They have large ecosystems and, beyond detection, they have prevention and remediation capabilities.

I'm not familiar with Nozomi.  From what I gathered, it's OT-focused network security.  These seem to be popping up more lately.  This and Dragos are something I'd like check out.  At first glance, they all seem to pitch the concept of deploying listeners within the Purdue security model.  It's not clear if it's architecture or marketing to established ICS cybersecurity folks.  Also, I'm curious what they offer in the way of identity or micro segmentation.  

The thing that puzzles me about these detection tools is how do they know what is truly an anomaly.  It's like lazily modeling a baseline without any control variables.  Increasingly, much of the advanced malware is turning out to be persistent.  Yes, it takes a lot of work, but one would think intent would be important thing to model security around.

Author: Deleted User
Content:
There are a good number of OT-focussed security solutions out there. 

In addition to Nozomi and Dragos (although I categorize Dragos slightly differently) you have companies like Claroty and Forescout. Cisco acquired Sentryo in 2019 and it is now Cisco Cyber Vision, Microsoft acquired CyberX (now Azure Defender for IOT), Honeywell acquired NextNine. 

They all operate in a similar way, located in the lower levels of the stack and recognising common industrial protocols. For the most part, they are passive - they listen for an interpret traffic rather than polling devices. (Active monioring is an option however). 

There are subtle differences in the way you deploy them - in some cases you need collectors on the network, in the Cisco case CyberVision runs on the network device. 

Looking at these platforms has been a substantial part of my life over the last three years. They all have pros and cons but (full disclosure, I work for Cisco) I think CyberVision has the best balance.

Author: Deleted User
Content:
The answer to your first question is more complicated. We are looking at the management strategy for our OT products but, for now, IND continues. Chances are it will eventually be subsumed into a single platform (IOT Operations Dashboard) along with some of the other management tools like FND/GMM. In terms of ISE, as far as I know, the only link between them and IND is via PXGrid. PXGrid allows ISE to ingest data from IND or CyberVision to provide contextual data about connected devices to help with enhanced segmentation. PXGrid is ‚Äòopen‚Äô and a number of vendors have built that ISE integration. 
Stealthwatch is different because it relies on Netflow data from the switches in the network. Not all the Industrial Products generate full Netflow so, in some cases, Stealthwatch is blind to what is happening in the OT layers. On the other hand CyberVision will provide similar data to Stealthwatch in terms of traffic flows and volumes but can also do DPI etc. I am not sure, but I can check, whether you can push data from CyberVision into Stealthwatch (or if it would add any value)

Author: joan7124
Content: For maintenance & reliability folks, what kind of challenges are organizations foreseeing with closing the skills gap in IIoT?

Author: zackscriven
Content: Pinned a message.

Author: lukesmaul
Content: To get the conversation going; we need to help folks adopt a ‚Äúdata science mindset‚Äù, find the reliability engineers that are already teaching themselves Python and pair them with deep domain experts.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
I have been involved in several similar conversations in a couple of maintenance & reliability platforms. The real challenge is that M&R organizations are focused on closing the wrong skills gap. The problem is framed something along the lines of: there are a lot of experienced people (read Boomers) retiring soon and the younger generations (read Millennials) do not have the skills we need. Namely, we want them to do the same things we have always done.

What they do not seem to understand is that you don't need a bunch of technicians walking around with instruments taking vibration samples and then analyzing them. What you do need is a bunch of wireless monitors getting vibration samples 24/7 with analysts developing code to look for patterns. The latter is of much greater interest. And it dramatically benefits the companies.

Sadly the focus continues to be working with community colleges to train vibration technicians. And fretting why they can't seem to find anyone with skill. Or interest.

Author: venkyiaf753280
Content: M&R guys are finally the end users of the IIoT technology. The IT guys need to integrate the requirements of the OT guys to have the kind of IIoT environment and enterprise that we are looking for in a digital transformation. Executives have to curb their expectations of the technology first and foremost. While the¬†Internet of Things¬†has the potential to make massive changes to daily life and there are many ideas stemming from this technology, the IT and business sides of companies must align first. From there, organizations have a few different options to close the skills gap internally. The M&R guy needs to upskill himself where he needs to understand how to use the technology.¬†Upskilling is a popular tactic for companies that want trusted employees to take on more senior or more technical roles. With the surge of bootcamps and online courses, businesses have the¬†option to train¬†already high-performing employees. IoT specialists need a wide range of skills, which is partly why it‚Äôs so hard to find these candidates. Organizations around the world are trying to help fill this need through courses in data analytics, mobile, hardware engineering, IT security, cloud computing, and more.

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content:
What do you think about TSN? For which application does it offer added value? 
"Hard Real Time Application and 50ms...
In my opinion, hard real time cannot be defined by a transmission frequency, but by the requirements of the respective process for the information runtimes. It makes a difference whether I fold 1000 tea bags per minute or assemble 4 units per minute. I see "hard" real-time in connection with control applications, e.g. servo drives. And for this, I would prefer a proprietary bus protocol that guarantees real-time at OT level instead of IT network-based communication. I remember the separation of these worlds being addressed once in a podcast.

I have the feeling that real-time is also often used as a buzzword without mentioning a connection to a concrete application for which the advertised communication technology then also offers real-time.

https://youtu.be/j42dxuU4EDM

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I believe TSN has a lot of potential because it's a standardized extension of standard ethernet.  This contrasts with the fieldbus technologies developed by non-profit associations with for-profit "puppet strings" pulled by the industrial automation companies.  The largest market for TSN are the broadcast, telecom, and IT industries.  The standard has potentially wide adoption and, hence, good economics.  There is a good chance we will see Ethernet chipsets supporting these 802.1Q/P extensions in the coming years.  The automation industry is "piggybacking" on this work.

Personally, I don't believe it's helpful to distinguish between ‚ÄúOT and ‚ÄúIT‚Äù networking technologies.  Networking technologies are networking technologies.  Whether it is high-speed motion control, an international tv broadcast, a storage area network, or a telecom network; everyone wants performant networks.  The difference is that each desire low latency and low jitter for different applications.  The more this technology can be commoditized, the more effective it can be adopted and utilized.  TSN can exist in the field, exist in the enterprise, and it can traverse both.

TSN seeks to be deterministic in the same way that a fieldbus would.  The difference is that TSN seeks to do it without cutting down and/or modifying what is typically seen further up the OSI model.  Most Ethernet fieldbus technologies achieve their performance by being layer 2 oriented and "dumb".  They have extremely simple object models.  There is very little meta data.  There are header parameters (e.g., EDS files, GSD files) for the transaction, but there is very little to define or interpret the payload.  There is no discoverability.  It requires knowledge of what is being transmitted and how.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is where I think TSN has potential.  It could allow for heavier, but more contextual payloads as well as interoperability with pervasive networking protocols.  This has benefits for not just field level communications, but also very high-speed data collection for IIoT.  The downside is that it requires special switch hardware to queue the traffic.  Given that it took industrial ethernet nearly 20 years to eclipse serial fieldbus adoption, it is safe to say that any TSN adoption will take some time.

Right now, most of the industrial applications are limited to testbeds at places like the Fraunhover-Insitut or RWTH Aachen.  Like a lot of great research coming out of these institutions, there is not a guarantee that the technology will be successfully adopted by the market.  This, unfortunately, lands squarely on the industrial automation companies.  The OPC Foundation has working groups on TSN and the Field Level Communication (FLC) initiative.  FLC seeks to harmonize all the field protocols into an OPC-UA information model over deterministic transport via TSN.

It would be amazing if there were just one flavor of industrial ethernet.  Protocol gateways can be such a hassle.  FLC is an incredibly lofty endeavor.  I‚Äôm not sure OPC Foundation is the best steward for this kind of thing.  Their membership is disproportionately influenced by the same organizations that were complicit in creating the scattered landscape of fieldbus protocols that we know today.  I‚Äôm skeptical that still-active belligerents of the 30+ year fieldbus wars are ready to cooperate.  They likely will draft a spec, but they won‚Äôt shape product management strategy around it.  There are too many that do not stand to gain from interoperability ‚Äì especially at the field level.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This kind of initiative is better driven by an independent, third-party backed by end-users that are sufficiently large with sufficiently deep pockets.  Think like MQTT with Arlen Nipper (Eurotech) and Andy Stanford-Clark (IBM) backed by Phillips 66.  It probably was not a coincidence that no one involved in conceiving MQTT was on the payroll of a PLC or SCADA company.  It can be very hard for something to be successful when there are conflicts of interest.

The more practical industrial applications of TSN are within, rather than across, industrial ethernet standards.   For example, ODVA and PI have been working on their own implementations of TSN for EtherNet/IP and PROFINET, respectively.  In the case of PROFINET, TSN could drive down the cost of or even eliminate their ASICs.  It might afford them to enhance the object model beyond what was conceived in the PROFIBUS days.  For EtherNet/IP, TSN could replace or enhance its current determinism functionality (i.e., CIP Sync via PTP).  This could mean improved interoperability with robotics, encoders, or vision.  Additionally, it could alleviate the performance degradation of using transport security (i.e., CIP Security via TLS).  On the other hand, I‚Äôm somewhat skeptical as there are a lot of features in CIP today that many vendors choose not to adopt.

If TSN achieves wide adoption outside the automation world and becomes standard in Ethernet chips, the economics will be hard to ignore.  If it can commoditize determinism, the automation world stands to benefit.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: I learn more here by accident than other places by design. Thank you for taking the time to respond.

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content:
Thank you JS for your very detailed assessment. Do you really believe that the trend is moving away from specifically tailored fieldbus technologies to general multifunctional IT network technology? If this would succeed in providing the same performance as fieldbuses on the application-oriented communication layers, then new possibilities would open up as you described. However, the devices would then also have to provide more performance, wouldn't they? The "stupidity" of the field buses has guaranteed a fast connection even with limited computing resources, or has it?

The topic is also particularly interesting with regard to commercialisation. Perhaps the former developers of proprietary fieldbuses are trying to regain their status quo via TSN technology and counteract the trend towards open architectures? Can we already see this trend already?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
My guess is that compute has not been the constraint - at least not in recent years.  I believe networks have been the constraints.  I believe what we've seen has been more a function of 
"Well, this is how we always moved I/O in [serial fieldbus predecessor].  Let's stick with this for Ethernet." and "This will never work with TCP/IP or UDP/IP."

At least at the physical layer, we've already seen the industry move off of tailored fieldbus technology.  Serial will live on, but it's not poised for expansion.  It's taken time, but I believe it's safe to say that the market has adopted Ethernet.  Unfortunately, as the internet was becoming pervasive, there wasn't a clear answer on how to handle determinism with the standard stack.  With TSN, it appears, now there is.

You're probably right.  They're trying to stay relevant.  They want a seat at the table, but they don't want to cannibalize their walled garden and their legacy install base... at least not too quickly.  Some, such as B&R, appear to be embracing OPC-UA + TSN more than others.  But B&R has not been successful with their own fieldbus, Ethernet Powerlink.  ODVA views TSN as a way to enhance EtherNet/IP's determinism.   Similarly, PI views it as a way to enhance PROFINET's determinism and compatibility while also relying on OPC-UA TSN to move data "up" from the field.  We'll see what happens.

If we can see Rockwell or Siemens embed support for OPC-UA and TSN into their drives without any compromises, we'll know the verdict.

TSN is seriously powerful even with a heavier protocol like OPC-UA:
https://www.br-automation.com/downloads_br_productcatalogue/assets/1519253860692-en-original-1.0.pdf

Author: dobermai
Content: If you‚Äôre into Sparkplug B, the broker vendors who are in the Sparkplug Working Group are Cirrus Link and HiveMQ. Both have trial versions and HiveMQ professional is free to use for 25 connections (there is also an open source version available). HiveMQ comes with clustering, extensions, Control Center (for client details, trace recordings to debug MQTT / Sparkplug traffic, Subscription overviews, Retained Message overviews and a lot of integrations to Enterprise Security systems and is used on the shop floor at companies like Daimler. Depending on your company policies it might also be noteworthy that broker vendors like EMQx are chinese venture backed companies while Cirrus Link is American and HiveMQ is German.

Author: venkyiaf753280
Content: One of the concerns of a supplier to the aviation industry that I spoke to, who supplies  detailed parts, sub-assemblies to the Israeli Aerospace Industry, Elbit Systems, Rafael, Gulfstream, Boeing, Lockheed Martin, etc., is very interesting. He says that each OEM, his company supplies to, has its own system and and as a supplier one needs a system to deal with all these different systems. Interfacing with a lot of different systems of the different OEMs is the biggest challenge as a supplier. How does one overcome this challenge in an IIoT environment?

Author: ianskerrett.
Content: Our HiveMQ Pro/Enterprise does not support in-memory persistence. Our customers are typically concerned with reliability of messages delivery.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'm assuming those systems you're referring to are each OEM's supplier-facing portals.  Learning and administering these systems have a very non-trivial cost on the business.  With enough customers, it can become its own bureaucracy.

A lot of this worked is substituted or complemented with B2B commerce messaging protocols like EDI and cXML.  These automate the exchange of everything from purchase orders to scheduling to remitting payments.  These can also be utilized to exchange traceability or certificate of analysis data.  This technology has been around for decades.  It's somewhat primitive and the standards are not robust.  But, it works and is widely supported.

The aerospace industry has lagged behind other industries in B2B messaging adoption.  Much of this is driven by the lower volumes and diversity of customers.  It makes the payoff, especially for conservative suppliers, of automating the transactions less-obvious.  Another factor is low ERP adoption.  It takes serious investment to close the last-mile of functionality for aerospace.  They lack the expertise to integrate the necessary processes.  Additionally, there are all sorts of infosec requirements that few understand and, as a result, can inhibit change.

In an IIoT context, everything in the business is plugged into the architecture.  All of the data silos are unified and accessible.  By extension, an OEM customer can be a node in this ecosystem.  The right information can be intelligently exchanged over any protocol whether standard B2B messaging or an API.

It's probably worthwhile to examine how this supplier currently exchanges information with its customers.  Wherever the employees are pulling data from, they should be connected to the UNS.  This collective architecture (e.g., UNS, database, ERP) could be exposed to the customer with B2B messaging software.  This software can be standalone or a module within a full-featured ERP.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Have you looked into PTC ThingWorx Kepware Edge with the A-B ControlLogix Ethernet driver?
 
While the name implies otherwise, it's actually a lightweight version of KepServerEx running on Linux with the most popular drivers and interfaces.  It's not actually ThingWorx, but rather it has the web socket interface for connecting to ThingWorx (i.e., "AlwaysOn" protocol).  It has OPC-UA Server and MQTT client interfaces too.  There is docker support.  I would imagine it's smaller than Ignition with the driver modules.

Author: mparris
Content:
Major disappointment with KepwareEdge:

(1) The only configurable interface is through a REST interface. It's up to the customer to build their own GUI or use Thingworx
(2) their docker container only works when in contact with the company's license server
(3) the license server is a VM running CentOS.

So the use case for sending out an edge gateway to an equipment manufacturer to be setup with an information model will not work with KepwareEdge in Docker.

I tried node red a little, but the EIP interfaces seem too rigid, where I worked need to specify the tags individually. It's too much work for what is supposed to be an industry 4.0 tech stack. I want a software that will discover all the Rockwell tags and make them available through an OPC-UA Server.

Any other ideas? üôè

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342

Author: chrisgele
Content:
About a year or so ago, we were looking for an alternative to Ignition Transmission module (now called IIoT) to run on a Freewave ZumLinkIQ radio.  RAM memory on Freewave was 2 GB and Ignition Edge took most of that.  Freewave recommended a product from Autosol called eACM.   This software takes Modbus/TCP or Ethernet/IP and converts to MQTT & SpB.  At the time the cost was $150 per license, but not sure what it is now.  
Website - https://autosoln.com/solutions/eacm-edge-polling/  
Protocols supported - https://autosoln.com/solutions/protocols-supported/

Author: michael.brown
Content:
The simplest way to use python to send MQTT data to AWS IoT Core is to use Greengrass Python SDK.  
Its as easy as

import greengrasssdk as gg

client = gg.client('iot-data')

returnstuff = client.publish(
     topic='GiveItATopicName',
     payload = 'data i wanna send'.encode()
)

boom....its in the cloud.

https://github.com/aws/aws-greengrass-core-sdk-python

Author: jimbetsinger
Content:
I have been using OAS in production for several years...I am slowly converting my stack to open\free protocol servers where I can.  The issues I've had with OAS is ease of use (not!), user interface and documentation are confusing\vague (intentionally), and the stingy licensing strategy (i.e. expensive).  Things I like is their support and technical staff are great.  I requested an output to InfluxDB for their logger module.  They worked with me to develop some baseline requirements and had a working prototype in a week for me to try out.  
They used the free C# InfluxDB Client from Vibrant (source on GitHub) and added it to their license model (not cool!).  Which triggered me to look into the other dependencies they use and ~90% are open\free dependencies and then they just wrap their GUI around them.  So I am following suit...  .NET has all the protocols use as free NuGet packages you can download and add as a dependency to create your own server.  I am currently using MQTT (MQTTnet), Modbus RTU/TCP (easyModbusTCP), OPC (OPCFoundation.NetStandard.Opc.Ua), and BACnet (BACnet protocol library for .NET).

Author: dep05d
Content: I've been working with Solace for a little while now, we are working on a POC using it as the UNS for a fairly large distributed Ignition footprint.  The multi-protocol support and bridging of distributed brokers were features that caught our attention.  So while acting as a 3.1.1 compliant MQTT broker, it can also use other messaging protocols (JMS AMQP etc), including allowing publish via http, and delivery of subscriptions into rest endpoints.  This opens up a lot of paths for us to adding legacy business systems as UNS nodes, where implementing a mqtt wrapper application isn't as practical.  There is also a microgateway option that will act as a web proxy so existing request/reply web service calls can be routed through the broker to generate events into the UNS.  So far it has seemed promising.  The bridging feature (they call it "DMR" or "event mesh") should allow for a single UNS to be distributed geographically, where local site nodes can continue to exchange data even if the other sites are disconnected.  It also gives us a single entry point into the UNS in the cloud rather than explicitly bridging to each facility.  I'd be very curious to hear if anyone else has any experience or feedback on it.

Author: Deleted User
Content:
Hi everyone!
Last year I did an IIoT project with Apache NiFi. My NiFi flow consumes data from an MQTT broker, then does a little transformation stuff (uncompressing payload, decode protobuf payload, formatting the data to an SQL syntax) and finally puts the transformed data into a PostgreSQL/TimescaleDB table.
Recently I found out that Apache has another toolset called Streampipes that seams to have quite a few similarities to NiFi. It also seams that Streampipes is designed mainly for IIoT use cases as it supports quite a few industrial protocols (ethernet, field bus) out of the box. Now I am wondering wether Streampipes would have been a better choice for that project.
What are your thoughts on NiFi vs. Streampipes for IIoT?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
There is no chance he is an automation engineer -- that is for sure.  He would know the answer.  However, he is probably a software developer who has been asked to do a job he hasn't done before.  The answer is:

1. No IO
2. Automation apps that run on PCs are 1 tiny thing the PC shares resources with and they get no special priority
3. Software patches 
4. Software bugs
5. Control Panels and PLCs are dedicated to process safety, reliability and quality (the goal is 99.9999% uptime per year) and PCs are not

This question comes up more and more -- any other points you would add?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The answer is, sort of, but not really.  It only scans controller tags and has a lot of difficulty AOI and UDT instances and does nothing for motion control.  It is resource intensive -- and the resource consumption isn't limited to the module itself, you see big spikes in CPU on the processor itself.  It isn't tied to the underlying event engine in the controller, so it has to poll for the changes -- you can see the problem here.

Content:
MQTT is Report By Exception by creation, so no need for implementation.

Content:
Hello All. I feel bad for not having posted. So, I wanted to share something with you all. It is Coretigo - wireless IO Link that can work up 20m. This is different than the Balluff wireless which is just really a small-gap inductive coupler. With Coretigo you can get low-latency wireless connection and their Master has OPC UA and MQTT. Sweet!! Right??

We are currently specifying this equipment in some EAOT and a telemetry project. For the EAOT tooling well will be using a 24VDC inductive coupler (think Weidemuller) for electrical power transmission. The telemetry application for compressed air consumption (ProTip - great place to start for an inital DX project). I am including some SICK flowmeters (FTMG (have IO Link or OPC UA and MQTT) that we will be using. 

Anyways a  quick description of the the telemetry application... More than 150 semiautomatic assembly cells common in Tier 1 automotive that we will need to measure compressed air consumption. We will install SICK flowmeters connect them to Coretigo¬¥s Master via the Bridge than backhaul the MQTT with FreeWave ZumEdge. There are some more details, but I think you get the idea.

The EOAT tooling will actually use the low latency. Not really a big deal with the Telemetry. Also, the Coretigo range can be increased by using a different ("whip") antennae and living with a higher latency. Maybe Coretigo is overkill for telemetry, but I love the idea of using IO Link sensors and being able to add other "intelligent" sensors for future applications.

One last thing.... price.... very competitive. I don¬¥t have permission to divulge here.

Author: justinb0044
Content:
Hi all,

I have come across an issue regarding vanilla MQTT and Ignition MQTT engine module.  

Currently I have a TTN LoRaWAN server running on my local PC.  The TTN server publishes sensor data to an inbuilt MQTT server.  I used Node-Red to subscribe, parse and write sensor data to a modbus register in a PLC in order to get the data into Ignition.

I have tried using Igntion's MQTT engine to connect and subscribe to the TTN's in built MQTT server, however I couldn't see any sensor data.  Would I be correct if I assume this is due to the TTN server is publishing data in vanilla MQTT payload and Ignition Engine is looking for a SparkPlug B payload?

Ideally I would like to be able to use Ignition's MQTT engine to subscribe to the sensor data rather than my current configuration.

Has anyone got any suggesting?

Author: mparris
Content:
There are certain namespaces that ignition subscribes to by default. spBv1.0/# is one of those.

Try looking in the settings of the MQTT engine for a page/tab to add custom namespaces/topic subscriptions.

Author: justinb0044
Content: Thanks! @MParris I managed to get it working

Content: @justinb0044 , just a quick follow-up on this.  I also have some LoRaWAN TTN sensors and was using MQTT Engine to pull them into Ignition Maker..  Unfortunately, with the 4.0.7 version of MQTT Engine, it no longer converts the `@` in the username and topic definitions for the TTN MQTT integration (https://www.thethingsindustries.com/docs/integrations/mqtt/) and stops updating.  I just wanted to let you know about this in the event you update your module and stuff stops working..

Author: hans06919
Content:
Hi All, 

I have been working on a remote machine control project and it has me somwhat stumped as in how to proceed. In the past we have simply used the webvisu from codesys to control the machine from remote locations. However, wanting this system to be scalable, and have the ability to link individual machines together onto the same HMI display(a cellphone  or tablet) we needed a different solution.

One of the solutions I have been exploring is having the PLC publish tag data via MQTT to a topic in a Digital Ocean droplet that is running an instance of thingsboard on it. Thingsboard allows for great customer/device management and the ability to create individual dashboards for each customer. My problem with this solution is the dashboard doesn't seem to allow me to modify the widgets to what I need done. It also isn't extremely mobile friendly.

I am wondering if anyone has experience with this kind of thing and could recommend a better direction to take? For sending PLC data to the cloud, I think that MQTT is the way to go. However on the front end, I am looking for a solution that is immersive, and intuitive for the end customer. I have thought of going down the road of creating an app, but that then limits the amount of customizability I have moving forward. I'd be happy for any ideas that you may have.

 ‚Äî

yes, MQTT supports TLS and certificate-based authentication - if you are interested in a deep dive check my YT video where I cover following topics:

* how to setup the Private CA and use it to sign certificates for IoT devices
* how to generate self-signed and CA-signed x509 certificates
* how to establish trust between IoT devices based on x509 certificates
* how to encrypt MQTT messages using TLS
* how to verify the identity of a device based on the certificate it is presenting
* basic setup of Mosquitto MQTT broker

Author: mparris
Content:
The Opc foundation has created a branding problem.

OPC-UA client/server data access (a mouthful?) Is the workhorse of machines. It is 99% of the deployments.

They also talk about historical access, alarms and conditions, etc. Then there are the transports specified in part 14 of the spec: PubSub uadp, Pubsub AMQP Json, Pubsub AMQP uadp, PubSub mqtt json, PubSub mqtt uadp, and PubSub Ethernet. A mouthful again.  Each cannot talk directly to the other.

How good is sales teams of vendors keeping all this straight?

So the OPC Foundation says that comparing OPC to MQTT isn't correct because OPC makes use of MQTT, too. Except when you look at the market, it clearly isn't used. So they act like they have all the solutions, but it is only on paper.

Author: mparris
Content: In short, the foundation is okay with shortening "OPC-UA client/server data access" to "OPC-UA" when in a positive context, but are not ok with the shorthand when comparing to MQTT.

Author: omarazizahmed
Content: I see!

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: And most of the times (at least in my experience) that people mention OPC UA they are talking about OPC UA client/server data access so it's usually ok to compare it with MQTT or more specifically MQTT/Sparkplug. Often the discussion is not OPC UA vs MQTT/Sparkplug though but how to bring the two together and how to bring the existing OPC UA devices into a MQTT world. I prefer having that discussion.

Author: dep05d
Content: Does anybody have some benchmarks for the number of tags (or changes per second) an Ignition MQTT Engine can handle?  I know MQTT Engine can filter on Group ID's, but with some event brokers able to seamlessly integrate topics across hundreds of instances, a single unfiltered MQTT Engine node could end up with many millions of tags.  I assume these are lighter weight than OPC or Expression tags, but just curious what type of scale you all have seen in production?  Thanks!

Author: duncanct
Content: Looking into IO Master units I have some questions maybe the community can help with. Specifically units with MQTT capabilities. The Pepperl+Fuchs are one that seem to do report by exception over MQTT. IFM have MQTT capabilities but need a "local" agent polling which seems like a drawback compared to a stand along IO-Link Master that has some sort of onboard intelligence. Are there any other brands worth looking into? Being in South Africa most of the supported products seem to be European-centric here.

Content: @Duncan we are working on a proposal using the pepper+fuchs IO Link with mqtt into the UNS. The IO link will be connected to rfid tag readers for door entry and exit with directions or movement monitoring. Still firming up on the solution and if this doesn't work will look at ifm IO link....willing to share and exchange experience as we go through this

Content: @jmckeon thank you. Ifm seem to have a solid offering but the only draw back is you need to run their software locally to poll the Masters, but that is from my initial research, so could be wrong. Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: IFM IO-Link Masters can work with a PLC polling over a compatible fieldbus or without a PLC with MQTT to any piece of software (JSON payload of IODD). The MQTT is not report by exception coming off the master. It publishes on an interval. I suppose some sort of dead banding could be done within the UNS to make it report by exception for clients subscribing to this data.

Author: duncanct
Content: Thanks @js. Assume this confirms P+F is a better option. Going to look into SICK too. Any other manufacturers worth checking out?

Author: Deleted User
Content:
Hi there, 

I have a question about OPC UA. I first tried in #general but got no answer, so maybe that's the wrong channel for such things. 

Maybe somebody here can help. So, here's the question: I'm having a little trouble with an OPCUA detail (oh, surprise). It is my understanding  that the certificate/private key pair used for the (a) secure channel and the one for (b) client authentication may be different, but I'm wondering if having two different pairs makes any sense in the real world. My scenario is some kind of bridge to OPCUA that can be "easily" configured by the user (which is not that easy much given the clusterfuck OPCUA is), and if possible, I'd reuse the client cert&pkey for both purposes in order to annoy the user a little less. Does that make sense? or there are situations where you'd want two different pairs.

Thanks!

Author: mparris
Content:
I've never utilized certificates as an authorization mechanism, only have used anonymous or user/password 

I've used certificates for the transport: Sign, and Sign/Encrypt.

I don't know of any reason why the certificates can't be the same for both use-cases.

Author: Deleted User
Content: Thanks. I guess I'll stick to only one certificate.

Author: rkwadd
Content: A certification and validation program costs a fortune to maintain. Many such programs seek underwriting to stay afloat, which regularly leads to the certification itself becoming tainted as it serves the interests of the funding organizations and not customers. I would love to be wrong about this and hear more details on a scheme that would work. The people here are connected to all the right companies and consortia etc that handle compliance testing and certification and I‚Äôd love to help get something viable moving if this time is different.

Author: ianskerrett.
Content: The Sparkplug community will be publishing TCK to be the basis of a conformance test for Sparkplug compatible products. Maybe offer to help with the TCK?

Author: benveenema
Content: Yes, and it leads to bureaucracy and "keep-out" barriers as well. A good model to look at is how the Open Source Software and Open Source Hardware organizations handle they're "licensing". It's self-established, a company decides its software is open source and release what they consider to be enough source code to be open. The community then agrees or disagrees. I'm not sure what recourse, other than public disagreement they have if someone falsely brands their product as "Open Source"

Author: mparris
Content:
I recently wrote an article on LinkedIn outlining the difficulty in sorting through the noise of emerging technologies.

@Huber I know you were cataloging SparkplugB products.

What about making this catalog more open? I don't know what platform is most appropriate, but something like GitHub?

A simple listing of company, product, specific technology, what layer(s) of the automation stack is targeted, free trial available?, OPC data access included?, Link for product information, and possibly notes from the public regarding successful bench testing or production deployments.

Regarding specific technologies, it would be an enumerated list such as: SparkplugB node, Sparkplug primary application, Sparkplug secondary application, mqtt 3 broker, mqtt 5 broker, OPC-UA client events, historical, alarms and conditions, OPC-UA server events, historical, alarms and conditions, OPC-UA publisher mqtt json, publisher mqtt uadp, subscriber mqtt json, subscriber mqtt uadp, or any of the released OPC companion specs.

NOTE: OPC-UA client/server Data Access is not allowed on this technology list as the list will get too big. There would be a column indicating if OPC server, client, both, or none is included.

@everyone what is the best open, public platform to host this?

Author: mparris
Content: Ideally, the order of the list of products would be randomized with every page refresh to communicate no favoritism.

Content:
Let's take on the challenge to create this list ahead of the upcoming OPC-UA Marketplace, because you know what technologies will be missing from that list!

Author: vincent98001027
Content:
Hi,
I'm new in the IIoT space and still learning about it. I working toward centralized the data on shopfloor. 
In my company, the data of each system is store in a SQL Server. As a result, there are several different SQL servers. 
Is there any solution to ingest the data of several different SQL to a single main SQL for every time the SQL(one of the different SQL) received a data? 
(In short each time the sql server received the data i would like the main SQL to able to ingest the data)

Sorry, if this is an absurd question

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
Hello Vincent. Not absurd at all. That is exactly what a Unified Namespace (data infrastructure and integration layer) is designed to do--- provide a single source of truth containing the current states at every moment. This post (link below to the UNS channel) and the video right after it are a good place to start learning about this.

https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/740564843710382080/869593610746732624

Author: vincent98001027
Content: Thanks, Sherry. The concept of the UNS seems promising and the solution I need to ingest the data.

Content: Are the MQTT Broker metrics really relevant from a business / plant operations perspective? I think I would keep them only with all the other software operations metrics e.g. in Prometheus because I think the broker should be an invisible part from the plant operations perspective. Of course someone has to operate the broker 24/7 but that shouldn‚Äôt be the people working with machine / PLC data. In the next case those people don‚Äôt ever notice that the MQTT broker is there.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: I really think plant operations should not be operating software. They should operate the plant. Instead they hopefully have a software development / platform team that set up everything professionally (fully automated, highly available, on a modern platform, with proper monitoring and alerting disaster recovery etc.) and also operate the broker as well as any other infrastructure component that is not a PLC. Especially nowadays that we want to run all kinds of services, data analytics / streaming analytics and ML models to digitize the factory. Btw I‚Äôm not saying that this team should come from the enterprise IT or be managed by it. Just from my experience in many cases the plant operations people do not have the expertise to do so because it‚Äôs not at the core of their work. I think that‚Äôs actually one of the big challenges that IIoT faces.

Author: mparris
Content:
Another use case:

There is a single MQTT broker, and edge of network Nodes on the plant floor connect to it. To help reliability, an MQTT broker is later added to form a cluster. Because both broker1 and broker 2 are publishing its status via SparkplugB to a designated group, all the applications discover the presence of this broker2 and add it to their internal broker list. When broker 1 goes down, the applications switch their connection to broker 2 and data resumes.

Auto-discovery.

Author: mparris
Content: To continue, there is a cluster of five brokers. Applications are connected to the first. During normal ops, the second broker goes down. The applications detect that the node is no longer connected through the Death Certificate. If broker 1 goes down, they don't waste time trying to connect to broker 2, they automatically connect to broker 3.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: I would really try to avoid this. The clients ideally should not know anything about the broker cluster topology and not implement any logic to connect to different broker IPs. I would deploy the MQTT broker to a Kubernetes cluster and do the load balancing via the Kubernetes Ingress. Kubernetes would also allow me to use an Kubernetes Operator for the MQTT broker (e.g. HiveMQ provides one) that makes operating the broker much easier. On premise you could also use DNS load balancing on top of the Ingress so the clients really only need to know one broker subdomain name (I wouldn't buy an HW load balancer for this). In the cloud you would just use whatever the cloud provider offers as external load balancer.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Also you should use at least a three node cluster (ideally distributed over three availability zones) so you always have at least two instances running. You also need this when you do rolling upgrades of the broker. Again with the load balancer the clients would not need to know anything about the broker topology or how many nodes there even are. They wouldn't even notice when a node gets added or removed or an old one gets restarted on a different Kubernetes cluster node.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: The only thing that the clients should implement is a reconnect backoff strategy so they don't reconnect all at once if one broker cluster nodes goes down. With the HiveMQ client lib you can configure different reconnect strategies: https://www.hivemq.com/blog/hivemq-mqtt-client-features/reconnect-handling/

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content:
A broker cluster upgrade would ideally look like this:
1. The Kubernetes Operator would first check if the cluster is healthy and would then set the first node into a maintenance mode. This takes it out of the load balancing so it does not receive any new connection requests, makes it not accept new connections, drains the node (disconnects the clients) and takes it out of the replication. When we implemented a DC/OS Framework (basically same concept as Operators under Kubernetes) for HiveMQ, we built such a decommission task into it. Unluckily HiveMQ did not yet provide a REST endpoint for setting a node into maintenance mode. @Ian Skerrett Any update on this?
2. The Operator shuts down the node and restarts a new node with the updated version which will be reachable again. The new node might be started on any Kubernetes cluster node (availability zones could be considered of course). 
3. Waits till the cluster is fully replicated & healthy again.
4. Continues the same with the next node
And the only thing the MQTT clients would need to know is how to reconnect when they get disconnected.

Author: IIoT#4707

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Side node: I would not use DNS load balancing, especially if you are not in control of the clients AND the DNS server then. DNS caching can break the whole thing. Then it would be better if the clients keep a list of fallback domains and you update that list (important the list of domain names and not the IPs of broker nodes).

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: I correct myself: I would not use DNS load balancing at all üôÇ

Author: mparris
Content:
I've been wanting to learn more of kubernetes and your posts will help me give it a try.

I will say that first impressions are that the architecture you outlined needs to be deployed by very skilled OT personnel. The number of abstracted layers sounds more like a system appropriate for a data center.

On the other hand, I'm reminded that Chick-fil-A uses similar architecture for their restaurants, where a skilled team manages remotely and the "operators" just need to know how to plug on power and connect a Networks cable.

I will also say that I don't like the idea of a single-point failure that s load balancer brings to a cluster of brokers.   By pushing the load balancing function to the client, the broker can be a true cluster. My goal is a masterless cluster where ANY of the nodes can go down and not affect function, they are all equal in function.

All that said, I still need to kick the tires of K8s and see what is possible. Microk8s sounds interesting. If it requires one node to be a single entry point, then I'm not interested.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content:
If you want to try out Kubernetes, then have a look at k3s/k3d. K3s is suitable for one node deployments in production for example on edge devices. 

About the failover: the clients can keep a list of multiple subdomains provided by multiple Ingresses that lead to the same cluster (and you can update the list via MQTT). That way the clients also don‚Äôt need to know about your cluster topology. 

About only having to plug in power and network cables: this can be done if you have hardware that has a Lights Out Management (e.g. from Dell or HPE). Then you can remotely trigger the automated provisioning of an operating system and Kubernetes via LOM and PXE Boot basically as soon as someone plugged in the hardware. This can be done both for a normal on premise edge cluster or just a k3s on an edge device in some control cabinet. We built that kind of platform for customers already. That allows you to have identical deployment environments in the cloud, on premise and on the edge devices.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: It‚Äôs pretty nice if you can select to which environment (e.g. one or all of your edge devices) you want to deploy to just by adding labels to your deployment definition and pushing it to a git repository.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Do you mean by building your own plug-in or by leveraging the $SYS topic and building a service that republishes the messages in a Sparkplug compatible way or can EMQ X already publish the cluster topology updates via Sparkplug out of the box? If there is no out-of-the-box support and I really wanted to do this (which I would not, see above), I think in the case of EMQ X I would go the way of republishing metrics and not the plug-in way as usually there is no one who knows Erlang. All assuming that EMQ X provides cluster topology updates via $SYS. Does it do that? Or would I be able to extract that info from your Prometheus metrics? Speaking of Prometheus support: Is there also a way to expose metrics directly via Prometheus metrics endpoints (and have them automatically scraped under Kubernetes) or do I always have to go through your statsd plug-in and a Prometheus push gateway? I think the approach with the Prometheus Pushgateway is not a very cloudnative approach. It‚Äôs not scalable / highly available as you always have only one instance of it and you have to configure your service manually to use it.
