Author: richardphi1618
Content: Had some question on Spark Plug B and best practices to implementation

Author: richardphi1618
Content: I do considerable amount of work around developing information models following the MTConnect and OPC part 100 specification

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @richardphi, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: richardphi1618
Content: I have also been trying to push the idea of being able to automatically build your information model inside of something like an MES

Author: richardphi1618
Content: at first I thought you would build your information model using your topics as stand ins but spending more time with MTconnect using something like a "probe" topic may be more worthwhile (apologies thought it would be helpful to give background on my questions)

Author: richardphi1618
Content: first question is about how one would handle data quality

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: No worries -- background helps

Author: richardphi1618
Content: something I think OPC UA does well and wish we saw more of with MQTT

Author: richardphi1618
Content: usually you use a QoD code but it looks like SPb tries to solve this with its birth and death messages....

Author: richardphi1618
Content: maybe im trying to implement old thinking on new technology

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: MQTT 3.1.1 uses QoS and State to ensure that the connection is stateful -- SPb uses birth and death to ensure you can trust the current value of the topic in question

Author: richardphi1618
Content: birth and death being the book ends on the data stream not sent on each "publish" (is what Im seeing)

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: OPC is really built on server/client -- even the pub/sub implementation has remnants.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: So -- the Quality of Data, and whether or not a value is stale means something in OPC.  In MQTT, especially SPb, if the connection is good, the value can be trusted.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Birth and Death are book ends on the connection, not so much the data stream -- they happen on instantiation (SPb has a big initialization JSON on birth)

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: QoS is on the publish level and determines how important that publish is (2 means make sure the subscribers get the message no matter what)

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Sort of, yes

Author: richardphi1618
Content: yea im familiar with the ~~modes~~ QoS but because of that implementation I dont need to worry about QoD? What about an edge device streaming data from a newly "woken" machine typically we would treat the data as "uncertain" I was hoping there would be a way to mimic this in SPb

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I would start by reading about QoS in MQTT 3.1.1 and MQTT 5 -- that should help form the vision.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Then we can go over the edge cases and specific use cases -- you're on the right track though.

Author: richardphi1618
Content: another question to bring it back to my background is really the intent of how best to use an MQTT

Author: richardphi1618
Content: should I publish a JSON object using my information model or can I publish to each topic using the topic structure as my information model

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: You can do both

Author: richardphi1618
Content: yea I started out doing the later but I see the merit of doing the first

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Honestly, the implementations are 50/50 here

Author: richardphi1618
Content: wasn't sure if there was "preferred" industry standard

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: A lot of people start out with the latter and then shift to the former

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The choice gets made by the architect

Author: richardphi1618
Content: I thought about following MTConnect in how the implement and have a sample / current / probe topics. Not sure if that would lead to a dead end

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @richardphi, you just advanced to level 2!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: At the end of the day, the topic structure in the broker is what matters -- that is what the clients consume.  How and edge device publishes to the broker is less important.  All good brokers can parse a single JSON object into a topic namespace with many topics: values

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: This is a good idea to pursue -- we do something similar with Kepserver MTConnect driver -- if you convert the MTConnect namespace into an MQTT namespace using the IoT Gateway in Kepserver (publish one big JSON), brokers parse it out and you have the sample / current and probe topics in the namespace.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Especially off the Mazak smart adapters

Author: richardphi1618
Content: I honestly haven't played around a ton with kepserver outside of using it as an opc ua server. will take a double look

Author: richardphi1618
Content: what about Kafka? A co-worker has been pushing it with what I am doing and I am more comfortable / familiar with MQTT. (maybe verring way off the path here with this question :P)

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I cut my teeth in the Northeast... and Kepware is in Maine... so it was sort of the prevailing tool.  We still do a ton of work with Kepware.  HighByte is built by former Kepware people.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Kafka really is better suited for optimizing time series data and not real-time device events -- but, this question does come up a lot.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: We use Kafka to optimize time series for streaming to data lakes

Author: richardphi1618
Content: what interested me is he said it had the ability to run "connectors" that push directly to DB (didnt know about EMQ-X at the time when he brought that up) and the ability to catalog the schemas of the message payloads along with version history....

Author: richardphi1618
Content: again I am just starting to get my feet wet with Kafka and by no means ready to switch my messaging protocol of choice but there is something there to investigate in my mind

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Yep -- its all about providing max value for transactions

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I like using Kafka above the UNS -- from a client that aggregates many topics into a transaction table for shipping to a DB or DL.  Kafka is missing the real-time components and the bi-directional element needed for UNS (which is why we use MQTT).

Author: richardphi1618
Content: Im curious what you mean by "optomize"

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Make more efficient for streaming == optimize.  Time-series and transactions are incredibly inefficient for transmitting anywhere once the dataset is constructed.  Kafka optimizes prior to streaming (to give the impression that transactions are streaming when they are really being optimized buffered and pushed).

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Kafka is the transaction optimizer in the Apache eco-system.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: version info and metadata are really value adds to the transaction optimizer

Author: richardphi1618
Content: fair enough ones a butchers knife while the other a swiss army knife? or am I being too reductive?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: A tad reductive but apropos

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: One more quick point -- we use MQTT brokers for the UNS so we can unify data and information in a common structure to give us current state -- one that we can scale in perpetuity.  Kafka is great at the data component but not the information component (transformed data that we can act on)

Author: richardphi1618
Content: yea but with the Kafka connectors you can transform the data to whatever information model you need (relative to the direction of flow)

Author: richardphi1618
Content: added layer of complexity though....

Author: richardphi1618
Content: again not 100% on what the pain will be for what Im suggesting

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Absolutely... but if what you want is an eco-system of producers and consumers -- where every node is a potential producer and consumer -- then you need an eco-system built on technology that makes that easy.  Kafka has some powerful tools for going from data source to data consumer or data store... but after that, we are adding additional connectors to go back from where we came (and we're going to have to open ports to expose ourselves for that return trip)

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: This is where the architect comes in -- weighing minimum technical requirements, digital strategy and cost benefit of each architectural decision.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: 25 mins past my bedtime -- great talk -- looking forward to doing it again.

Author: richardphi1618
Content: Thanks again. Gave me a lot to chew on!

Author: mriiot
Content: Here is documentation from a Kepware IoT Gateway HTTP implementation we did in 2015.  The general concept was for external signals (eg. data collection software) to request a 'feature' from factory equipment.  The software would query Kepware over HTTP and return business usable data.

Author: mriiot
Content: Example on page 2 is a 'quantity' feature.  It requires that the client requesting that feature send in 'sample size', 'work order', etc.  DemandPoll for that device connected through Kepware is pulled high, initiating communication with controller, and returning weights back to the feature script.  The script then does some math and returns a quantity back to the caller.

Author: mriiot
Content: As a side effect data from caller and any calculated values by the script were sent into Splunk into a 'material movement' bucket that could be analyzed at some point.  These transactions were in an open state until the requestor successfully posted a transaction to some business system.

Author: mriiot
Content: I guess if I were to redo this in 2021, I would send those business system transactions to some broker so more systems could consume.

Author: walker.reynolds

Author: mparris
Content:
Regarding the MQTT Part 2 video, is this understanding correct?

@Walker Reynolds 

1) Base data model support
All OPC-UA servers support the base DA data model. This is equivalent to the Sparkplug base data model of NDATA and ProtoBuf encoding.  OPC-UA and Sparkplug are equivalent here.

Author: mparris
Content:
2) Data model discovery

OPC-UA server does advertise what companion specs it includes in its Namespace using the Namespace Array [ns=0; I=2255]. There is a high likelyhood that the companion spec  includes a custom structure that will not be understood unless the client also has the companion spec data model.

Sparkplug Templates are simply structures created from the base Sparkplug data types. The device implementing the Template advertises the structure with it's Birth Certificate. Because the structure is simply comprised of the base data types, every sparkplug client will be able to represent the structure without apriori knowledge.

Sparkplug beats OPC-UA here.

Author: mparris
Content:
3) making use of data model

The application receiving a data model must understand the data model to do anything useful with it.  This is the case with both OPC-UA and Sparkplug.

Author: ravil1
Content:
ogamma Visual Logger for OPC supports complex type values with some limitations. If you log to MQTT or Kafka, then complex type values can be logged as JSON formatted text. If you log to InfluxDB, there is a choice - either as JSON text, or you can decompose complex values up to base type leave nodes, and log each leave separately. It is possible to set up a deadband at each leave node too, to filter our noise level changes.

In Ignition, I believe you should be able to add each leave node separately.

Author: mparris
Content:
The MQTT dissector automatically invokes the sparkplug decoder off the "spBv1.0" topic.

Given OPC-UA pub/sub has no standard topic definition, it will require a user to configure a proprietary topic to trigger that decoder.

As you point out, the user would need to know which underlying protocol is in use and then go to that configuration to configure the proper trigger.

Author: mparris

Author: rkwadd
Content:
1. Watch Walker‚Äôs YouTube videos
2. Pick a specific problem you want to solve
3. Find a hardware and software stack to address that problem
4. Write about it, or build it and write about how you built it

That and ~$100,000 should get you a PhD

Author: ravil1
Content:
This is what OPC UA does: clients ask for sampling interval, queue size, and what to do if that server-side queue of data values becomes full - drop the latest value or oldest. Also, by sending the next Publish request only after processing the previously received Publish reponse, the client-side is always kept in sync with the server side.
I was guessing that considering that as community members here claim that MQTT Pub/Sub works well in their use cases, then sampling/reporting with the same rate for all consumers ( assuming that the fastest required) is just fine.
Other than overloading some consumer applications, I wonder, is it possible that the network is overloaded too with too many messages?
I would assume that this can be mitigated by subscribing only to really required topics, avoiding wild-card subscriptions.

Author: dobermai
Content: This is exactly what flow-control is for. This is a standard MQTT 5 feature. The client can tell the broker how many unacked messages at the same time should be sent: https://www.hivemq.com/blog/mqtt5-essentials-part12-flow-control/

Author: ryankershaw
Content: What about using something like Node-Red to reduce the data transmission rate?  Take the subscribed MQTT tag, have it go through two processes: one that limits data transmission to every 5 minutes, and the other that pushes a new variable if there's a significant rate of change?  Here's my mock up (should warn you, I'm a recently converted hardware guy, still getting the hang of this stuff):

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Hopefully I haven't butchered that too much, but I think it provides a general idea.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Instead of subscribing to the original MQTT tag, you would subscribe to a new one that has the reduced data transmission rate.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
Walker Reynolds ‚Äî 09/13/2021
One of the most important things to note -- is that the vast majority of PLC tags do not change as frequently as once per minute.  That is, about 93% of all tags in a PLC namespace, change less than once per minute (on average, across all PLC applications).  Edge Driven & Report by Exception makes all of the difference.  When you are only pushing changes AND no-one is ever waiting for a response, you can move a massive number of tags.

Author: ravil1
Content:
I thought that often, if a measurement yields a floating number type result, then each measurement will give a value slightly different than the previous one. Like 20.123456 first time, and then 20.123457 next time, and so on. So if you sample the parameter every millisecond, then you will get data changes every miillisecond. 
Using deadband, you can filter out such small changes. In other terms, the deadband is like the desired precision of your measurement. 
When you measure integer type values, for example, if that is the counter of something, of course, the picture is different. Or boolean values, like if a door is open or not, that would not have noise fluctuations either. 
In OPC UA, each client can ask the server, what sampling rate and precision it needs to get data with. If your use case is such that for all data consumers, the same sampling rate and precision are OK, then this kind of possibility of a per-consumer flexible configuration loses its value.
Note that in OPC sampling rate is not the same as reporting rate. It is how often the server takes reading (in case with a sensor - how often performs measurement of the parameter). If the reading value is the same, or the difference does not exceed the deadband, it is not reported over and over again.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Yes. This is why rules are applied at the edge using various software such as Highbyte.

Only supporting OPC-UA client/server Data Access would not be sufficient to be on the list

It would be products containing one or more of the following technologies:

SparkplugB node
Sparkplug primary application, 
Sparkplug secondary application,
MQTT 3 broker,
MQTT 5 broker,
OPC-UA client events, historical, or alarms and conditions,
OPC-UA server events, historical, or alarms and conditions,
OPC-UA publisher mqtt json, publisher mqtt uadp,
OPC-UA subscriber mqtt json, subscriber mqtt uadp, or 
any of the released OPC companion specs.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Let's start with one contrarian thought: Companies don't usually get "frustrated by vendor lock-in".  That's a myth perpetuated by, well, other vendors.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @RickBullotta, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also, critical in the analysis of what to use is an inventory of what already exists.  Of course most implementations are brownfield, and even in greenfield cases "stuff" comes in from OEM equipment suppliers, companies have "preferred suppliers", and so on.  I've seen waaaaaaaay too many people connect directly to PLCs and other sensors/controllers when they've already partially contextualized the data in a SCADA/HMI system or historian.  Makes little sense to add more comms load on the control level and another system to maintain.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I'll also take a contrarian POV on the need for cloud for implementing AI/ML analytics and predictive maintenance.  That's changing fast.  There are some good reasons to leverage the cloud for this, but it's no longer as clear cut a line.  Even training of models can be done quite effectively at the edge in many cases.  And in many industrial settings, whether you train cloud or edge, it's still often advantageous to train instance level or "in-situ" models rather than population models.  For example, you might have 100 of the same pump across 5 sites, and you're using a vibration sensor to get some insights on performance and reliability.  Each pump might be handling different materials, be mounted on a different foundation/surface, be surrounded by other sources of vibration or noise, and ultimately instance-level training might yield the best results versus the approach of aggregating the data from all 100 pumps and building a unified model.  That can work for sure if you happen to get lucky with all of the features and inputs to the model (some of which won't necessarily obvious or easily measurable).  In any case, we need to be flexible on "what runs where".

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think of IIoT as a distributed systems problem.  In a perfect world, workloads could run symmetrically or in a location independent manner (cloud, edge(s), fog, rain, wind, whatever).  Not there yet.  And of course, cybersecurity, latency, cost, supportability and availability issues all weigh into the choice of what to run where.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: My take has always been to abstract the ugliness away at a level above the protocol wars. Call it digital twins, asset models, unified namespaces, cybercheese, or whatever.  I don't care.  But the abstraction is critical to making it all work and play nice together and to allow value added apps to be built on top of the abstraction.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The other fail is that people often take too much of a "data-centric" approach.  They often fail to integrate actionability, whether that involves calling services/methods, writing values, etc.  And when they think "data", they often conflate historical data with real-time data.   And they often ignore "events" (which are just a special kind of data with multiple bits of information in them).  So when we get to discussing options for infrastructure, protocols, vendors, and platforms, some are good at one aspect of this but pretty shitty at others.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Similarly, any IIoT platform should have the concept of discoverability at its core.  That means both the ability to "discover" from source systems and devices and level of namespace and context that it can, but also that the aggregate model/twin/namespace is discoverable and searchable by other apps or tooling.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: And lastly, I'm a huge believer in event-driven, responsive apps.  Sure, we might need to do some polling at the lowest levels of the protocol stacks, but above that it should support both pub-sub and on-demand access.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: OPC (classic) was supposed to solve the last foot problem and unburden developers from every having to write another device driver/IO driver again.  How'd that work out?  Ask the SCADA and historian vendors how much engineering capacity still goes towards drivers.  OPC UA tried to be the evolution of that and a lot more, but I think the long time that it took to achieve even a modest level of adoption led to a good bit of technical debt and obsolescence, combined with an increasing level of complexity that just wasn't necessary.  MQTT was "elegant in its simplicity" at its beginning for the very specific problem of telemetry, but it clearly fell short in terms of interoperability (no formal payload practices, namespace practices, etc) and simply sucked as a mechanism for request/response (methods, services).  It also presumed the world was hierarchical, which it ain't.  So we bolted on Sparkplug, which was well intended in its mission, but missed the mark on a bunch of fronts.  I personally think it loses/hides some of the goodness of MQTT in the way topic names and subscriptions can be managed.  I also think it is too opaque and "chunky" in the way it defines the prebuilt topics and moves data and metadata, and not very "queryable".  And MQTT isn't the ideal medium for accessing historical data or other datasets/application data.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: So we kinda end up with a Franken-platform when we go to implement real-world solutions.  While I don't presume it was perfect, and it had plenty of flaws, that's what we tried to address with the ThingWorx "thing" model and the underlying protocols and abstractions.  It never really got finished and some good stuff got taken out of the platform sadly (notably a very cool pub/sub layer - no idea why they yanked it).

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @RickBullotta, you just advanced to level 2!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: But generically, that type of abstraction, discoverability, and invocation/access approach is probably where we need to head as an industry.  I've offered REPEATEDLY to get involved with many of the industry efforts in these areas, but they're all closed off to individuals, despite what they claim.  They only welcome corporates, vendors and academia.  F*ck them. üòâ

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I have a pretty clear idea of how to evolve MQTT, Sparkplug and such along with a different concept for a broker and edge stack and an additional modeling layer to solve these problems.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: But since every vendor, standards group, whoever wants to defend their little fiefdom and can't see beyond that, we end up with these asinine debates about whether MQTT or OPCUA or DDS or MTConnect or CheeseWhiz is better.  They're all good and they all suck.  Which is why we need a metalayer on top of them.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: So there ya go.

Author: andersgustav
Content:
In my industry, we mainly have three major monolithic suppliers of equipment.
They all deliver best n class systems to different segments of production, but do not give us access to all (or any in some cases) the information from the equipment if we do not buy the entire system from them. And we do not want this, as in some stages of our production we have to make do with poorer solutions.

As long as the technology is open, all suppliers can easily support it (if they want) or we can use e.g. gateway solutions to adapt equipment to our needs. SO I do not see much danger (for us) for technology lock in that way.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Your "industry" needs to change, and the buyers need to make open access to data a part of the contract.  It's not a technology or vendor "lock-in" issue - it's a vendor "lock-out" issue isn't it?  And if the vendor can provide a solution, if you can abstract away whatever weird or mainstream thing or protocol they use, you should be good to go.

Author: andersgustav
Content:
You are right, and for me it makes sense to get suppliers to support a methodology that can easily be supported by many.
Then they can rather concentrate on building the staining machines in their respective segments, rather than forcing customers to buy shit that they do not really want.

The one supplier, who is the only supplier who delivers equipment to a specific segment in our production, would rather not sell their product than open up data access for their customers.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Generically think about a new type of enhanced broker that include both a pub-sub comms channel (or channel(s) such as TCP/UDP/WebSockets/CarrierPigeon) and a REST/Microservices channel or channels over any protocol that makes sense.  Add far more statefulness and queryability to metadata/namespaces/topics.  Add an asset/twin/entity model that addresses more than just data, and that can also model the relationships between entities.  It also needs a type system so that it can identify entities that share common capabilities.   It needs to also provide access to the historical view of this data (it doesn't necessarily need to be the archiver, but it could be).  It should be scalable and distributable across network boundaries.  It should support some form of federation of namespaces.  And it should support high availability.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I'd also probably layer in a far more granular permission model

Author: benbecker4100
Content:
Question, in the scenario here, we are wondering how best to handle.  Our device interface sends sparkplug B to the MQTT broker for the connected instrument.  The issue we are wondering is what to do when the device connection is lost but the connection between the device interface and broker is still active?  Naturally we would publish a DDEATH, but there may be diagnostic or troubleshooting data that can continue to be sent that will be lost if we sent the DDEATH.   

‚Ä¢    Do we not send a DDEATH but instead show a state topic that shows the connected status of the instrument? 

‚Ä¢    Do we send the DDEATH and then turn around and send a modified DBIRTH that presents just the diagnostic / troubleshooting measures until the instrument comes back online and then send a full DBIRTH?

‚Ä¢    Do we send the DDEATH and transmit any diagnostic information vi node level topics?

‚Ä¢    Do we send the DDEATH and not try to report any device specific diagnostic information altogether until the connection is re-established?

Author: mparris
Content:
A great question!

As you stated, there are many ways to slice this.

In sparkplug, there always must be a node. Devices are optional.  If what you are describing is that a device is a separate piece of hardware, where it is reasonable that the connection is severed or it loses power separate from the node, then it certainly makes sense to send a DDEATH representing that loss.

The diagnostics you are talking about are not in the device (because it is disconnected) but are happening by the node itself. So my first thought is to continue sending the diagnostics in the node object.

So here is something else to consider, a node can have virtual devices. So it's possible, too, that you organize your address space by putting these diagnostics in a virtual device that has a similar name to the real device so that an application could subscribe to those two devices (real and virtual), then the application would see the DDEATH of the real device and continue to get the diagnostics info.

You can, of course, keep the diagnostics in the node metrics, but currently Sparkplug would require an application to get ALL metrics in the node, even if they only care about those device diagnostics. The only lever to pull on segmentation is to create virtual devices.

Author: benbecker4100
Content: Awesome, appreciate the feedback @MParris will toy with these ideas

Author: mparris
Content:
I would definitely avoid sending a modified DBIRTH. Some applications could interpret this as the missing metrics are no longer valid, so remove those metrics from memory. I've actual requested this for ignition... Seems reasonable that if a node or device sends a birth certificate without certain metrics, that is saying that those previous metrics are no longer valid.

Sometimes, it is very useful to keep the old metics and get to see what the last known data was. Timestamp, CPU%, disk space, or RAM could be a good examples.

Author: benbecker4100
Content: That is interesting, we have noticed ignition is additive in nature and doesn't remove metrics on modified births...seems to make logical sense it should represent the latest birth and you're right, this could be deceiving sending a partial birth, i think the two options you proposed make more logical sense.

Author: mparris
Content: The other thing I've noticed is that a restart of the mqtt Engine leaves the folder structure of the nodes and devices, but removes the tags. Apparently, the tags are still there in a historical sense, but no longer available as a real time tag until it gets another birth certificate.

Author: benbecker4100
Content: That is interesting

Author: mparris
Content:
I had it wrong, so I updated my post.

Apparently version 7.9 ignition didn't have the means of keeping tags across a restart. When version 8 rolled around, mqtt Engine was able to keep them, but people liked a clean slate, so preferred the tags get removed.

Author: mparris
Content: https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/t/mqtt-engine-auto-prune-removed-metrics/46785

Author: rickbullotta
Content: This is an example of where I find the "chunkiness" of DBIRTH messages to be a bit problematic - and I was surprised to see that the broker discards tags/metadata on restart.  Persistent metadata, particularly in the case of intermittent connectivity, is somewhat essential for tooling.  I also find the inability to "query" tags/metadata with Sparkplug B problematic.  Perhaps different brokers/apps have a separate channel for this (they should) but it's a flaw IMO.  This is what I was referring to with the idea of a "services" side channel for a modern broker that provides these OTT services.

Author: mparris
Content:
@RickBullotta  Sparkplug needs to be improved to have a dynamic number of levels ahead of NDATA and expose metrics as individual topics below the NDATA topic.

Being restricted to a single"groupID" and needing to receive ALL node metrics and have the application parse through them doesn't scale.

My theory is that it was designed for a simple, centralized structure with a single application that would get all data anyway.

It shows it's limitations when using it in a distributed system, especially across an Enterprise.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I have a long list of needed improvements. üòâ  But the core question is still "is this the right way to do it"?  In a heterogeneous environment, my gut tells me that the appropriate abstraction is still above this layer.  Call it digital twins, asset models, machine maps, or cheese curds - I don't care - but it should be a place to provide federated access to a model that is representative of how we want to consume and interface the data, services and events, not how the device or edge node represents them.  Whether this metalayer uses MQTT or something else is a separate discussion.   Using Sparkplug B to query/access data from your maintenance management system, MES system, ERP system, etc doesn't make any sense to me, for example.

Author: mparris
Content:
I'm wondering if GraphQL can generalize enough for what you have in mind?

For the past couple months, YouTube has been pummeling me with GraphDB ads, and it's getting more attention here.

Reading the blog that @Kirt Anderson  posted yesterday helped me understand a bit more what it's all about.

Author: mparris
Content: Seems to be trying to make APIs dynamic and have a "self-discovery" function, similar to MQTT on the data side.

Author: mparris
Content:
I agree that information modeling needs to happen. I also assume Sparkplug was really intended for a device-centric deployment, which is at the lowest level of the stack.

Moving higher up, there become MANY more ways to slice the data. For example, show me the real-time CPU usage for all my equipment, no matter where it is in the Enterprise. An infrastructure should enable this, without needing specific applications.

If SparkplugB allowed metrics to be topics, similar functionality could happen through standard MQTT subscriptions, but would still be tightly coupled to the data model in the device itself, which seems too fragile for the Enterprise level.

Author: mparris
Content:
I also think that moving operations to thinking connecting Equipment to infrastructure and connecting applications to infrastructure is the right trajectory.

Today, most still think point-to-point is the best way to integrate equipment above the PLC layer.

Author: kirtanderson
Content: @MParris - I think that you've captured the essence of it. There's a demarc between the devices with their layer 0-1 data and the tools that define how it is modeled and consumed. What is necessary is a platform that abstracts away the difficulty of configuration and management of the model for data at the bottom of the stack (provided by our MQTT event bus) and a simplified single point access to a common data model for all functions within the enterprise (the GraphQL API.) We happen to think that MQTT, GraphQL and Federation services are the answer - largely because nothing else available commercially can do it very well.

Author: kirtanderson
Content: At Libre, we are guys that came up through the ranks as controls and SCADA engineers that transitioned out into data infrastructure, MES and ERP, consulting and BD roles. Although we understand the needs and challenges of the lowest level of the stack, we also understand that the only real way to success in manufacturing is to design top-down with the needs of engineering and IT staff being subordinate to the needs of the business. The sticky part of that is that you also need to design a supportable, user friendly stack that engineering and IT can configure and maintain. From reading most everything that is posted here, it appears that people are struggling to make that happen because there are a million tools for data access and nothing that ties it all together..

Author: kirtanderson
Content: That's why we believe that our stack is viable. We didn't create this platform because we felt like we needed to be right and that we needed to be the most knowledgeable people out there. We did it because we have 100 collective years of experience that tells us that a tectonic shift is needed for this industry to move forward. We think that we created the basis for that shift, but only time will tell.

Author: kirtanderson
Content: @MParris - I think that my primary point is just that we're not trying to say "Everyone is wrong and we're right." We're just trying to say "Hey - this might be viable and we made it free so that you can minimize your risk in evaluating it."

Author: andersgustav
Content: If there was a tool or a function that i needed, that you did not offer in your plattform. Could I easily make it, and add it to / use it with your plattform. Or would that have to be done by you?

Author: kirtanderson
Content: The simple answer is that you can do it yourself. The Core will be open sourced and so, as long as you are an end user, you can write your own microservices to extend the platform to your business use cases. The underlying language is Go.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It could be a small part of the solution (GraphQL), but not as the core today.  There's still a fundamental need for a persistent model and metamodel as well.  That could of course be accessed via GraphQL or SQL or ODATA or encoded squirrel chirps - probably all of the above depending on the consumer/client.  I think it's worth mapping out the functional areas required and then overlaying what an appropriate functional and architectural decomposition of that might look like.   I also believe strongly that abstractions help at all levels - including the API level.  A legacy tool might best access the stack via a SQL wrapper (JDBC, ADO, etc) whereas other apps might want a binary-over-HTTP/2 API, and all points in between.  I always built that into my products via pluggable serializers for inbound and outbound requests.  Something analogous to a "mime type" or the Content-Type/Accept headers in HTTP handled the negotiation.  And yes, even - gasp - XML in some cases where it was REALLY old stuff.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Sparkplug and non-sparkplug can co-exist next to each other in the same broker.  You can have an IIoT platform (e.g., Ignition) handle the different encodings by parsing and synchronizing value across the topic namespace.  This provides flexibility to work with vanilla and sparkplug b clients in the same ecosystem.  The clients would publish into different parts of the namespace depending on what they support.

You could also potentially leverage a gateway to enable Sparkplug B ("SpB") support.  This could work out as some onboard IoT protocol (e.g., MQTT, OPC-UA) interfaces are clunky and require explicit programming on which tags/registers to publish.  The gateway would hit the native protocol and then publish SpB.  Going from standard MQTT to SpB is an interesting gateway use case.  Maple Systems cMT-SVR might do this.  HighByte is an option.  It has connectors for both.  If you need a local HMI, Ignition Edge would work too.

Here's a good discussion on dealing with legacy nodes in a Sparkplug B namespace:
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/740564843710382080/832980568974295040

Author: jman444
Content:
I think that is more than the structure of the MQTT topics, here are my questions:
1. What is the entire dataflow? (from device, to dashboards, alerts, historian)
2. How is the data processed? Do you use serverless functions that listens on the incoming MQTT topics and then save the result in another topics?
3. What happens if the MQTT consumer that saves the data in the historian database is down for 10 minutes, the messages will be missed?
4. What happens when the same device type is used for two different use-cases? The data collected from these devices might have the same structure, but each received parameter has a different meaning.. How do you convert this data into meaningful information?
5. How many concurrent devices can handle this architecture? What is the throughput (messages/second)?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ...except the "non-sparkplug" namespace is not discoverable/queryable.  Big flaw that I'm hoping gets addressed by an MQTT "side-channel" that exposes this via some type of REST API or other microservice.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Exactly why I'm not a fan of ISA 95 (BTW I was part of the original committee and attended meeting #1).  And the world is not a hierarchy, despite what Purdue, S95 et al say.  Organizations *can* be hierarchial - assets and equipment and real process flows quite often are not.

Author: mparris
Content:
By "not hierarchical" do you mean that there can be more than one hierarchies /views at the same time to describe the relationship between assets, equipment, and processes.

Similar to getting a different answer regarding what the relationship is depending which person you ask?

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
When dataheads hear S-95, they think RDB, but I think that this is one of those places where a graph (especially implemented as  a knowledge graph) is superior to a tuple. Traditionally we need to store multiple tables with multiple keys to represent the different relationships (be they hierarchical, proximal, etc.) 

In a knowledge graph, each entity exists as a node in the graph and the relationship exists as an edge between them. Sometimes multiple edges between the same nodes representing different relationships. It provides for a much more dynamic representation of the organization for MES/MOM (S-95) purposes while allowing for other modeled relationships outside of that definition. All stitched together via federation services.

Not saying it's "the" solution, but it's certainly a more dynamic and flexible one than most current offerings.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Think of the interconnections between equipment in a lot of food plants, chemical plants, etc... - they can't be modeled with a hierarchy.  And obviously when you extend IIoT to utilities, power grids, water/wastewater networks, etc - are networks, not hierarchies.

Or for an oversimplified way to think of it, if you need to draw a horizontal line or a diagonal line across branches to represent a relationship, it's not a hierarchy. 

As @Kirt Anderson says, a graph model is superior in that it an easily model pure hierarchies, but it can also model more complex relationships.  Most graph models also allow metadata/properties and "typed" relationships between nodes.  It becomes an incredibly powerful way to model manufacturing "stuff" - both the physical entities and the information assets/artifacts that we use in our applications.

I used to get super frustrated with trying to figure out what would be indirectly or directly affected in my system(s) if I made a change to "X".  Even today, most systems don't do a super good job of helping you with that or visualizing those dependencies.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: BTW, despite the name, there's very little in common between GraphQL and Graph databases.  There are better ways to traverse/query graph db's than GraphQL (though you can do it somewhat).

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
If you want to experiment, you can get try out a graph db and learn more about it here (I'm a fan of Neo4J and their team):

https://neo4j.com/try-neo4j/

Author: rickbullotta
Content: And there are plenty of other graph database options of course.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
It's about 10 years old, but if you want to get a sense of the thought process we were going through when we selected a graph database initially for ThingWorx, here's a presentation from the wayback machine on the topic.  It has a decent overview of Graph DB's from Emil Eifrem, the CEO of Neo4J also.  Click on the "download slides' link.

https://qconlondon.com/london-2011/qconlondon.com/london-2011/presentation/Using+a+Graph+Database+to+power+the+Web+Of+Things.html

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: I don't think this really needs to be part of MQTT itself. You can solve the "discover part" already today either through wildcard subscriptions (using your own Microservice), birth messages as in Sparkplug, a broker plug-in offering a REST API or... I'd say it's one of the great things about MQTT that it does not try to solve everything but offers you the flexibility to do it yourself.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: We'll agree to disagree.  That's trivial to standardize and make implementors and customers lives' easier.  What you described does not solve the real goal of interoperability.  Also, namespaces should be queryable, not just discoverable.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Broker plugin that offers a REST endpoint -> queryable

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Yup.  I wrote one a couple weeks ago.  But there's no standardized/uniform approach to this (at present) and therefore not interoperable.  That's all I'm saying.  Even if all we did was use Sparkplug B formats for the returns from the REST API (and a more expressive syntax than wildcard expressions for queries), that'd be a big step forward.  And it does require that the broker do a bit more magic when topics are transient, but I think that's OK.  I would also like to see the concept of flexible metadata on a topic as a first class capability of MQTT and/or Sparkplug.  That capability can provide other queryable attributes for topics.  Cheers.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
I think I (the guy who has been in this industry for a whole almost two months, so good chance I'm off the mark) kind of disagree with you on this.  Yes, the overall structure with that of a network, but the individual nodes would each be their own hierarchy.  For instance, processing unit A would be a singular node within the facility, but processing unit A would also have module 1, 2, and 3 that would be a part of it, and each module would have its own widgets, etc.

You mention that having to draw a line across branches makes it a relationship, not a hierarchy, but this type of structure is pretty similar to what would be seen in a matrix organization.  I wonder if it would be possible to leverage this as a way to describe some of these new structures.  For instance, looking at your example of utilities, one side of the structure would be the generation (wind, gas, nuclear) facilities, and all of the hierarchy that comes along with it, and the other side would be the network that represents the transmission (lines, substations).

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That's an organizational hierarchy, not an asset model, of course.  Orgs do tend to be hiearchial.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @RickBullotta, you just advanced to level 6!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ...and of course there are hierarchies in there as well.  But the aggregate can't often be modeled well as a hierarchy.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Hierarchies/interconnections/relational/graphs/mindmaps, they're all just just "models". Some models perform better in some scenarios than others. It all depends on what type of "view" you need. You can model anything as hierarchical if you put some effort into it, but the value of that model might be limited in some scenarios. You're touching on this point, but I wanted to put some "verbatum" to it.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I guess my core point is that a graph/network model can handle all the use cases (including hierarchal), whereas a hierarchal namespace is more limited in its applicability.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Hmm.. loose ideas and thoughts here (you've been warned). My thinking now is that this is why you would want to decouple the data from the models. To provide flexibility in which way you want to model / view the data. So, correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't this what Libre is doing? Adding a modelling layer on top of the data layer?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Don‚Äôt know about Libre but that‚Äôs how I‚Äôve always done it.

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
Yes, Jon, that is what Libre is doing. __But__ it isn't doing anything new or in any way novel from the perspective of having a manufacturing schema - that's still provided by ISA-95. WW did it with System Platform but with tighter coupling to the SCADA layer. OSI did it with Asset Framework but with tight coupling to the historian. Both allowed you to create an S-95 structure but didn't enforce the ontology. Libre enforces the S-95 ontology but the graph allows for relationships that weren't really possible in a relationally based product. 

In both cases (WW/OSI - and for that matter, VantagePoint and every other SQL model), the performance sucked:
1. Because of the transposition of time series, 90 degrees off from the transactional layer.
2. Because a relational data structure doesn't make non-hierarchical models easy to create and makes the querying of the data for complex models a nightmare.

What Libre is attempting to do is to create a more configurable and dynamic structure for data modeling and a more computationally efficient and user friendly means of aggregation while providing single point querieable and subscribe-able data access.

As @GeoffNunan frequently says, "We didn't reinvent the wheel, we just made it round again."

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content:
Hello Guys ‚úåüèº
In the last Q&As, Apache Kafka was often mentioned. My question is, why is MQTT better suited as an IIoT protocol for your backbone, since Kafka also follows a pub/sub architecture and historising events as an event store. Also, the stream processing capabilities can be used to directly process, enrich and prepare data streams for a consuming application. Or is the lightweight messaging of mqtt the minimum capability of an IIoT backbone? Perhaps the answer here is again not either or and depends on the use case. Could you clarify this topic for a general use case? @zackscriven

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: A plant can consist of many other namespaces, including a Sparkplug Namespace (SNS). I would use a tool like HB (or Ignition of FS) to normalize/aggregate the many namespaces into a single UNS. The UNS would be common across plants. PLCs are a great example. The topic structure of an Opto22 groov EPIC and EZLogix PLC is different below the Device ID. The Area namespace (includes all lines) would be normalized in the UNS using the aforementioned tools. This allows for flexibility at the plant floor and consistency across the enterprise.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: But HighByte doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúserve‚Äù the UNS, just feeds it. What is the architectural component in that scenario that would serve up the UNS?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
The operative verbs I use are HighByte builds/creates/defines the UNS. It connects to all of the intelligence (SQL, API, CSV, OPC, MQTT/SpB, etc.). and defines/builds the models. Currently, the models are published to an MQTT broker for other intelligence to consume (and publish back to). The broker can be thought of as "serving up" the UNS, but the structure is a critical piece. Where it is different is the broker, other than clients and retained flags, does not store any data. 

If I remember correctly, HB included a broker in version 2.0, so it could "serve" the UNS. I don't think the intent was to use the internal broker in production.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ‚Ä¶and of course HB typically runs at the ‚Äúedges‚Äù.  One of the areas I want to work with this group on is expanding the concept of the UNS to a broader entity model that enables services/methods and richer metadata to be part of the mix.  Looking forward to the dialog!

Author: zackscriven
Content: Kafka comes up so much we should just do a video on it. The answer is always the same‚Ä¶ we use Kafka for optimized streaming of time series data into a data lakes

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
Edge is one of those terms that means a lot of things, based on context. When I use edge, I am referring to devices the factory floor, whether that's PLCs, sensors, instruments, etc. Since HB sits on a server, I wouldn't call it an edge device, but it does connect to them to build the UNS. But edge devices are not the only intelligence within a UNS. 

One of the concepts that is discussed is how business all do the same things: they sell stuff, plan stuff, control stuff, ship stuff, etc. All of these systems are connected to a UNS. When there is an event (we sold stuff) that information is published to the UNS. From there other systems will consume the data (we plan stuff). When the product is shipped (we ship stuff) that is event is published to the UNS so AR can consume it (we bill stuff).

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: The beauty of the UNS is the data models can contain as much or as little as makes sense. The IIoT platforms we discuss enable all of the services/methods and metadata we care to include.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Sort of - you're of course constrained by the capabilities of the technologies and products you choose to build upon.  And I was referring to service/methods from the POV of "logical services" on the end elements (machines, devices, systems), not the services exposed by the platform(s).  For example, a machine exposes a "DownloadRecipe" method, or a device exposes a "RunCalibrationSequence" method.  Mapping those into the UNS is one thing, but a secure and reliable way to execute them in a firewall friendly manner is a whole different thing.  This'll be more clear after some of the discussions coming up with Walker and Zack where we're gonna do some mind melding. Cheers.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Looking forward to it!

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content:
In my opinion Kafka is no very well suited to be used as a central IIoT message broker as it misses many features that you need for IIoT (or IoT in general). For example it does not support dynamic topics (topics need to be configured) which means that a new client can't just publish to a topic without configuring it first. Due to this a subscriber can‚Äôt just ‚Äûautomatically" recieve data from new devices using wildcard subscriptions. Also Kafka does not support topic hierarchies which are essential for a unified namespace. 

Further, Kafka is missing some other important IoT features as keep alive / last will & testament / retained messages. A bit less important but still relevant is that Kafka client is relatively complex and resource intensive and the Kafka protocol is more heavyweight than MQTT. Depending on your cloud connection and the amount of data that you are dealing with, this can become a problem. If you have a lot of plants and you want to use Kafka on premise, it also comes with quite a bit of operational effort.

You can also find a good summary on why Kafka is not a good solution for IoT here:  https://www.hivemq.com/blog/streaming-iot-data-and-mqtt-messages-to-apache-kafka/

That being said: Kafka is a great extension to any IoT/IIoT platform and I would always use it on top of an MQTT broker for streaming use cases or generally just to store all messages for data analytics and continue from there, even if you just want to persist the messages in an object store.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Yes, please make a video on Kafka vs MQTT in a UNS! For me, @Daniel_H., it would be like trying to fit a square peg in a round hole. I'm sure you could build a UNS that would "work" with Kafka, but it would take a LOT more force and you'd end up with a peg that doesn't fit too well and you can't unpin it. Kafka isn't an IIoT protocol, heck it's not even a protocol, it's a streaming solution.

Author: aljosavister
Content: I totaly agree, but I wold just add that in Kafka topics can be autocreated just by writing to whatever topic you specify in the client. This can be prevented by auto.create.topics.enable=false configuration.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Ah, right. Totally forgot about the possibility. In that case you have to make sure that the server defaults are properly configured so they make sense for you. In the past, we never used the autocreate because we always had to configure Partitions, Retention/Cleanup/Compaction etc. individually per topic so they fit our requirements and at some of our customers we have to request new topics via a self-service portal / online forms. And don't ask me, why they don't offer APIs for it.

Author: graeme.welton
Content: Hi @RickBullotta, great to see you here! I was a Lighthammer user in its early days. We have never referred to our product, Flow, as an IIoT Platform, but rather as an ‚ÄúInformation Platform‚Äù. However, based on some of the concepts/features you highlight above, I am wondering whether we should ü§î. It has features such as: federation of multiple data source namespaces, abstraction of these namespaces into a combined ‚Äúmetamodel‚Äù (hierarchical, but representative of how we want to consume information), a permission model, a type system (we call these templates), a calculation and projection engine, a ‚Äúpush‚Äù integration mechanism to share information (via plugins like MQTT for example) and an open REST API for custom clients.  Not all the features you describe, but a solid base?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I didn‚Äôt see your reply before now for some reason! Thank you for detailing this out, I didn‚Äôt know about the topics not being dynamic.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: As @aljosavister noted, you can configure it to be dynamic but then Kafka will take the configured defaults for things like partitions, retention period etc. and at least in our case we usually have to configure them because we don‚Äôt use the same defaults for all topics.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Bottom line is that Kafka was just built for something completely different and therefore not ideal for IoT/IIoT use cases.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Exactly! Couldn‚Äôt have said it much better myself.

Author: jimmybarnyard
Content: What are people's thoughts on wrapping the MQTT architecture with VPNs?  I'm thinking users would feel more comfortable with an outbound connection that allows inbound traffic if it was wrapped with a vpn to the cloud and the broker and application (historian, etc) are within a private vnet in the cloud.

Author: jimmybarnyard
Content: We worked a lot with Clar0ty at my previous employer.  Felt like they were the leader in the space.   That said, have a few contacts at Nozomi now and it seems like an "up and comer" in the space...  I think purpose built tools for OT security like this have been a big hole since our networks went from proprietary bus architectures to standard Ethernet.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content:
We added InfluxDB to our database comparison for IoT projects as well as some query tests. Keep in mind that that we are comparing apples and oranges here (non-timeseries DBs with timeseries DBs) so you have to interpret what the results mean for you yourself. The initial idea was to see how the scalable SQL databases YugabyteDB and CockroachDB perform in those use cases as we wanted to see to which extend we could use such SQL databases in IoT projects but then we kept adding other DBs. https://github.com/MaibornWolff/database-performance-comparison/
One more note: For the inserts we are doing batch inserts as we assume that we ingest them from Kafka and not directly from a MQTT broker.

Optimisation suggestions for any of the databases are welcome!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: A few thoughts when comparing databases : Hardware matters, A LOT (some are more memory intensive, others more computationally intensive).  High availability configurations matter, A LOT - poorly implemented HA can reduce performance by orders of magnitude.  Query/retrieval performance matters, A LOT - eventually you need to get the data out, and testing with simultaneous query load can unearth concurrency issues.  And the often overlooked item is the impact of data archival/deletions on performance (some DB's don't even permit deletion per se).   If you think about it, at steady state, a database will be deleting roughly as much data as it is inserting, so assessing that impact is valuable.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Replication is another example that can cause such an additional load on a database cluster if you have to replace, remove or even add a node.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: For sure - related to HA and scalability.  It's amazing how many DB's, even horizontally scalable ones, do best on benchmarks in a single node scenario.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: The database comparison above also does not include mixed workloads or such scenarios as a cluster upgrade during the tests üôÇ It's meant to get a first impression.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Also the tests are done with a specific scenario in mind (ingest data from Kafka). For example if you try to do single inserts with a high frequency into InfluxDB or Elastic you won't have much fun.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: In any case, for me it's still mind-blowing what a single node Postgres can do.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Are you using the time series extensions for Postgres (e.g. TimescaleDB) or "raw" Postgres into SQL tables?

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Just raw Postgres. I'm pretty sure that we will add TimescaleDB as well at some point. It would also be interesting to see how other Postgres extensions like Citus or Patroni compare to YugabyteDB/CockroachDB. We would probably test Patroni because I'm not sure if there is a Kubernetes Operator for Citus. But first we will probably add Elasticsearch in the form of OpenSearch. I'm a big fan of Elastic for doing analytics in IoT projects and it's easy to operate if you have a good Kubernetes Operator and it has enough resources üôÇ It was a joy to run it under DC/OS (Mesos) even at larger scale. I'm still a bit sad that DC/OS came to an end (even though it totally makes sense). It was a great product.

Author: karlden
Content: Hi, if I publish an MQTT message to the broker with a retain flag, and I from another client later subscribe to that message. Is it then the broker that automatically sending the retain message to the client? Or is it the client that is first reading and then subscribing?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Almost üôÇ Let me correct you a little. You publish a message to a *topic* with the retain flag. The broker will hold on to that message  and when a new client subscribes to that *topic* it will receive the retained message (and of course future ones until it unsubscribes). You have to be careful with retained messages though, at least in 3.1.1 (I still need to look up what options you have in v5). It will be retained indefinitely until an empty message is published to that topic. It is somewhat analogous to a memory leak.

Smaller vendors like Litmus, Losant, Omnio, Softing, TwinThread, Libre, Flow, Flow Director, Crosser, and others play a role too.  And even companies like InfluxData (InfluxDB/Telegraf).  I'm sure I missed more than a few.  Anyway, it's a great idea to have a directory like this, but its value is proportional to its inclusiveness and accuracy.

If they only support vanilla MQTT or OPC-UA DA, they don't make the list.

Author: rickbullotta

Author: mparris
Content:
Open access is a good feature, too. And products may have open access, but expose them through proprietary interfaces that require manual integration.

Something needs to change in the market to improve the integration of devices, systems, and applications.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ...though many IIoT platform and product vendors have already done that "manual integration" for the customer in the way of adapters, agents or connectors.

Author: mparris
Content:
I suspect the majority of these help automate the integration at the Communication layer, but not the Information Layer (as defined by my diagram on the catalog)

While helping integration through pub/sub, even SparkplugB falls short here.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Could you elaborate on "automate the integration at the information layer"?

Author: mparris
Content:
Consider the following tech stack:
--Physical
--internet
--transport
--communication
--information
--application

For an integrator trying to deliver a product at the application level, how much of the tech stack is automated and how much must be developed?

Fortunately, today, physical-internet-transport (Ethernet-IP-TCP) is so common that these are assumed to be automated for the integrator... No development required.

In the communication layer (my definition),  an application protocol (per the traditional 7-layer OSI model) is considered coupled with an encoding method for a particular information layer. (Coupling application protocol and encoding together in one layer isn't important... It could be considered two different layers, but just trying to keep the tech stack model simple.

In the communication layer, there is a lot of combinations in the world, and it can't be assumed that a product supports one's favorite communication protocol. This layer automates the need to map to transport objects (individual bytes) and allow mapping of communication objects (registers, variables, etc) Examples at this layer are:
**MQTT--SparkplugB-ProtoBuf
**MQTT--UA-JSON
**TCP--UA-Binary
**HTTPS-MTConnect-XML
**Ethernet/IP
And so on

Then there is the information layer. Object definition lives here, which specifies various combinations of data objects found at the Communication layer to form a complete object. Rather than an application integrator having to manually map communication objects (registers/variables), he can map information objects, such as a machine, remoteIO, etc.  This is what the OPC companion specs are trying to do. Factory+ at University of Sheffield in the UK has some object definition examples sitting on top of sparkplug.

The use cases for universal object definition may be limited compared to all the applications that will exist, but the fact that we don't have this for anything is more telling of the state of the industry than anything else.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Ok.  Makes sense.  Just a difference in terminology.  I should give a brain dump someday about what/how/why I did some of this in ThingWorx.  I think it would be good fodder into the broader UNS and IIoT discussions.  Have a great weekend!

Author: mparris
Content:
Definitely would be a good video.

I know I'm not saying anything new, but figured I'd spell out how I frame the problem.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: The VLAN segmentation is a good practice, but why are they whitelisting access by IP?  That's clunky.  Why not use an identity-based NAC?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: That's a little beyond my IT knowledge, but I know we're looing at using some "new technology" from Cisco to at least partially automate things based on the vendor part of the MAC address. I'm assuming that could be used to automate isolation of PLCs and CNCs, etc.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: If you're a Cisco shop, you should hopefully have Identity Service Engine (ISE).  Instead of whitelisting IPs, you'll segment with what's called TrustSec.  You and anything else that needs to connect will have identities in a directory (e.g., AD).  ISE will have roles tied access policies for your industrial network.  Identities get issued those roles.  When these identities are authenticated, they'll be granted access.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I'll have to check with my IT/InfoSec contact and see if this is what we're planning.

Author: niravpatel4231
Content: From a non-IT technical perspective. Can I use an edge device with L3 capability with TrustSec/ISE? Can this then allow segregated LAN devices that are NATed on this device to allow traffic through? Or do the NATed devices also need to be ISE?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Just confirmed with IT, pretty much all of our core switches are EOL/EOS so there's a project underway to refresh all the networking gear. Should have been done this year but logistics delays are pushing it into Q1'21.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Devices can work with TrustSec directly or indirectly.  TrustSec is a NAC architecture based on 802.1x among other technologies.  802.1x, in a nutshell, is authentication to switch ports.  Some devices support it and other do not.  With PLCnext being a notable exception, most industrial devices do not.  The way around this is bypassing authentication, segregating, and issuing policy on the device's network rather than the device itself.

To answer your question, yes, but with variation in implementation and levels of support.  The access policies can extend beyond layer 2.  It's more of a question of with what and where the policies are being enforced.  The switches, wireless controllers, and VPN clients typically do this.  Without knowing more about your edge device, I would assume it can't do enforcement directly.  You might be able to drop in VPN clients (acting as supplicants) on it to create enforcement points between the various NAT'd device networks.  Or, assuming the NAT'd device networks are advertised to the core, you could create access control policies for these externally.  Alternatively, it's probably more straightforward to connect everything to switches directly and simply enforce policy there.

Author: mparris
Content: In case others had similar questions on why Data Access only was being excluded from the IIoT Catalog, below is my LinkedIn response to @Ravil  and Kevin at Inductive Automation:

Author: mparris
Content:
Below are a few points regarding why products only having Data Access are excluded from the catalog:

(1) When a product lists OPC-UA in its datasheet, in nearly all cases it is referring to Data Access (DA).  Generalizing ‚ÄúDA‚Äù as ‚ÄúOPC UA‚Äù has made it difficult for end-users and integrators to locate the minority of products that support OPC UA technologies beyond DA.

(2) In OPC webinars, the presentations have focused on the growing number of working groups, Cloud Library, information models to move data from the sensor to the cloud, and other new technologies. It is valuable to highlight the products that are a result of this work.

(3) Data Access is the lowest bar of entry into the OPC UA portfolio.  Including only Data Access within a product is not notable, especially since the technology has been released over 15 years.

In summary, the industry should recognize and encourage products implementing functions outside Data Access. Especially since the functions that are within scope of this catalog such as A&C, HDA, Agg, GDS, Pub/Sub, and Companions Specs have contributed over 4900 pages to the specification, whereas Data Access accounts for 52 pages.

Author: ravil1
Content:
I thought a gateway application converting real-time data from OPC UA to MQTT is an IIoT application. Or at least related to IIoT. 
Also, thought that to implement UNS using MQTT broker, SparkPlug is not necessary. 
Also, thought that just using SparkPlug does not guarantee that the information model published by a Publisher using templates, will be useable by any third-party Subscriber app.

Author: mparris
Content:
If you're objection is regarding calling the catalog "IIoT", then I won't argue with you. It's very likely that there's a better name to convey what the purpose of the catalog is.

If your objection is regarding excluding OPC UA Data Access and vanilla MQTT, then we before is a diagram to help explain

Author: mparris
Content: Off the bat, I don't think solutions actually exist to fully  automate integration as one would hope. The purpose of the catalog is to highlight the products in the market that make use of technologies that give one the best shot at automating their integration.

Author: mparris
Content:
MQTT does provide some level of integration automation, by decoupling the data from specific devices through topics.

In terms of data modeling, however, MQTT is actually worse than Modbus. That's where SparkplugB and OPC Pub sub come in.

So for the catalog, MQTT is excluded, but PubSub and SparkplugB are included.

Author: mparris
Content: OPC UA Data Access is excluded, even though it provides the same level of automation by converting bytes to variables, it lacks the capability of MQTT which goes to another level of automation by abstracting away needing to know about the device itself

Author: mparris
Content: However, not all is lost for OPC-UA Data Access. If there exists products that implement a defined companion spec, then that achieves a level of automation worthy of recognition.

Author: mparris
Content:
Maybe people have become satisfied with what OPC UA Data Access is delivering because it leapfrogged Modbus in capability (and others).  Meanwhile, Data access is leapfrogged by PubSub and Sparkplug.

There is no benefit to highlight the presumed thousands of products that support Data Access. All that would do is divert attention from the REAL goal of OPC UA, which is the automation of integration.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I don't necessary agree - "data access" is far more than just OPC UA and MQTT data.  Legacy systems, process historians/time series DB's, and so on are all essential to a unified view of assets and operations.  It's amazing to me how many IIoT "platforms" can't access time series data, for example.

Author: mparris
Content:
You are creative with your names for things (carrier pigeon, for example)

The catalog I created is to list products making use of standard interfaces that are defined more than wide-open API, etc. Any better name than "Public IIoT Catalog"?

I'm not trying to say thorough this catalog that only these products should be used to make it work, or if products aren't on the list that it means no one should use them within industry.

very simply trying to highlight products that can make life easier during integration, since connecting two things together that more fully understand the comm/info reduces engineering needed.

Author: mparris
Content:
Also, industry experts spent a lot of time developing specs such as OPC UA Historical, which is included in the scope.

I really want to know the products that use this

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
I'm using an Opto 22 Groov Rio to turn a legacy machine into an IIoT machine. I'm using Node Red to manage the I/O and implement flat MQTT to a mosquitto broker installed alongside Kepserver and being pulled in via a Kepserver MQTT channel. It works great but the Rio's are running on PoE so they stay online even when the machine is turned off. One problem has an obvious solution. I need to tie into an output on the legacy controller that's hot when the machine is on.

The second problem is more interesting. If the Rio goes down due to power loss, how do I know it's offline?

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: You can use a Last Will and Testament message (https://www.hivemq.com/blog/mqtt-essentials-part-9-last-will-and-testament/) to notify any subscriber when the Groov Rio disconnects ungracefully. Note that the Last Will message will not be sent by the broker if the Groov Rio disconnects gracefully with a correct DISCONNECT message.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Cool, I need to read it a few more times, but being RBE, how does the broker know when it "disappears"? It looks like there's a defined keepalive if LWT is implemented?

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: The situations in which the broker sends the Last Will message are listed on that page as well.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: In general the HiveMQ MQTT essentials are a pretty good source for learning more about MQTT. There are also some MQTT 5 essentials.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Yeah, the firmware on the Rios only have 3.1.1 right now but I know I upgraded my lab EPIC and the updated Node Red has 5 now.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Ok, re-read it top to bottom so I have an idea now. Next question, what are the best practices to implementing a LWT within a UNS ecosystem? Would it be a separate root node?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ...with the caveat that detecting "ungraceful" disconnects isn't always easy or reliable either.  Often you need failed attempts to send keep-alives/receive keep-alives and other stuff to know that the connection is actually gone.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Back in the day when Paho was the only real Java MQTT client lib it was even worse: Because Paho was so buggy sometimes our services thought that they still had a connection but they didn't receive messages anymore. So we had to build something so each service instance would send itself pings via MQTT periodically to know if it still could receive messages or if it had to reconnect. Thank god the HiveMQ team built a better MQTT client lib eventually.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: But I really don't want to bash the people who built the Paho lib here. I think Paho suffers from the same problem as many widely used OpenSource projects: They are used by a large amount of people / companies but get only very little investment. So I really appreciate their work.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think many people, even very technical people, mentally form a picture of a TCP socket as a physical thing, and find it hard to imagine that it would be hard to detect when one disconnects!

Author: mparris
Content: Isn't the entire purpose of TCP is to provide reliable communication, and if it's broken, provides the needed indication that the connection isn't reliable?  SYN and RST packets, for example?

Author: ravil1
Content: True, it might take tens of seconds (around 20) to detect TCP disconnection, when peers are connected via multiple physical network hardware (switches, routers). Therefore to detect network problems (like disconnection) within a guaranteed period, some kind of heartbeat/watchdog polling must be implemented. Usually, OPC UA Client SDKs read server state node in configurable intervals and timeout.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
We have two implementations at this point. 
1. Manual finishing machines (VFD or pneumatic). For the VFDs we used one digital input, one digital output, and one isolated analog input. The input ties into a signal to know if it is running or not. The output can be used to disable the drive until the production order is logged into Tulip (http://tulip.co), and the analog input is to know how fast the equipment is running since we have validated requirements for medical devices. Typically 0-10 or 2-10 volts. We used two EPICs for 41 pieces of equipment, cable trays, control cable, ethernet for the MS Surface GO interfaces, etc.
2. In some legacy rotary finishing machines. They have very old GE/Emerson controllers and it wasn't worth the cost to tie in or replace, so we went with a Rio in each of the 6 machines since it plugged in quite easily since there was extra DIN rail inside the control cabinet. We used PoE to power the Rios and are currently only using 2 I/O. A wetted digital input hooked up to a current switch on the drive to know when it's "running" and then one of the Type C relays wired into the door interlock so we can disable the equipment until the production order is logged into Tulip.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: The 2nd Ethernet port came in handy on the Rios as well, as we could connect the MS Surface GO tablets we use for Tulip without having to get another data drop or install a separate switch.
