Author: ravil1
Content:
Hi all, I have a question about data modeling: where should it be implemented? As I understand, in the UNS concept, using MQTT broker, when data is published in MQTT topics designed to reflect ISA-95 hierarchy, means that the data modeling is already implemented at the stage when that data is published. So, if a PLC supports MQTT, then your data modeling is already implemented at the PCL level. Is that right?
I wonder, how this modeling at the PLC level is done? How it is designed in the first place, and then how it is provisioned to the PLC, and then how changes are maintained? For example, how do you change the frequency of data being sampled, or how do you change the deadband?

I think also possible to implement modeling at some higher level. So the PLC would present data values in a flat way, like input1, input2, input3, etc, and outpu1, output2, etc. And then you compose a model at some middleware application, like HighByte - where you compose for example model for the Pump1, mapping variables from PLC to object fields, like PLC1/input 1 becomes Pump1/temperature, etc.

Which way is the most common?  Isn't the second more flexible, because my guess is that configuration at the PLC level is harder than the configuration in some middleware applications like HighByte?

Author: zackscriven
Content: Pinned a message.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Not always. You can model / restructure tags right at the uns level if you need to. But ideally yes you model at the edge with a smart PLC

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ...and there's another category of models for the "stuff" that moves through processes.  Production orders, service tickets, shipping or material movement tasks, etc.  They're very "data heavy" but can also have some intelligence of their own, independent of the processes around them.  It's fun to try to model all this stuff out in a way that they can interact.  I've done quite a few though experiments on agent-based or actor-based approaches to MES for example that would blend these things together in sorta the ultimate event-driven manufacturing app.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: What differentiates Direct Numerical Control from Computerized numerical control? DNC from CNC..

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
DNC typical refers to CNC program transfer/backup or, if there are memory limitations, drip feeding the program from an external computer.  

As far as advancements, I could see programs getting exchanged over an IIoT protocol instead of file transfer protocols.  Perhaps CAM applications become more aware of the IIoT ecosystem and their post processors could embed this intelligence into the NC programs.  Perhaps the programs might become more standardized with metadata to provide deeper level of visibility into the process, the asset, and their productivity.

Even with the native protocols, machine tool telemetry can be challenging.  NC programs are often in their own world from the rest of the asset's controls.  The machine programs require specific programming to pass context to other machine memory for monitoring.  Most machinist create programs that are basically just raw tool paths.  This provides very little context that is useful for other people, alarms, or applications.

Author: rkwadd
Content:
DNC is a confusing term. It is shorthand for file transfer system for part programs, which has little to do with ‚Äúdirect‚Äù or ‚Äúnumerical control‚Äù. Thumb drives are a widely used alternative, as is writing a part program at the machine. Windows network file sharing service (which is built into the OS) is a common competitor/substitute.

I don‚Äôt have a vision for its future other than that it will go away as a term and be supplanted by more useful feature descriptions as the people who used first generation DNC and therefore have an idea of what it is, does, and means all retire and/or die.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
"...have an idea of what it is, does, and means all retire and/or die."

lmao

Author: rkwadd
Content: Help me out with how DNC is relevant and applicable today and maybe I‚Äôll have a more useful take on what‚Äôs next. As an equipment architecture, DNC with mainframe+MCU has been replaced by PC based controls. As a storage and data transfer system architecture just pick your edge+cloud architecture of choice and that‚Äôs the replacement. The term DNC soldiers on as a catch all for ‚Äúwe do network-y stuff with industrial equipment‚Äù but I don‚Äôt think anyone still sells DNC systems without monitoring, dashboarding, analytics, or OEE features built in. Maybe there‚Äôs something I‚Äôm missing; I‚Äôm def not an expert in DNC.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Setting aside the data collection stuff, it's still very popular for job shops.  It simplifies version control and reduces training burden.  I think the data collection aspect has been a way for providers to earn additional revenue from smaller organizations that don't have a SCADA or MES.  I liken these data collection solutions to an electric typewriter or a word processor.  They're making something that is effectively dead more efficient.  But hey, old engineers love building reports in Excel.

I think one of the big issues is that DNC occurs on file-based interfaces separate from the general communication interfaces (e.g., native, opc-ua, mtconnect).  Once these can converge in most control platforms, DNC will become a relic like punched tape.

Author: rkwadd
Content: Yes. That is a perfect summary of what I see now and in future for DNC.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Does MTConnect support program transfers?

Author: rkwadd
Content: You can send a file and MIME filetype via the mtconnect agent. Generally the file is actually a reference not the file itself for performance reasons. So what you actually send is metadata. It‚Äôs not that widely used and is a relatively new feature.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I'm surprised there isn't a more rigorous means for transferring gcode and such, with signing and encryption, confirmation handshakes, etc...

Author: rkwadd
Content: that exists and is used at ITAR shops. I think it‚Äôs usually a business process thing not a tidy bundled software. Not exactly sure of the details but now I‚Äôm curious and will ask around. Proshop, Paperless Parts, Tulip are all working on how to do it as a reasonably priced  turnkey. Among others I assume.

Author: rickbullotta

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I used my "uber broker" and now have my 3D printer's data available via an MQTT broker, plus via a REST API, along with full historical data support *and* topic/namespace browsing - and no Sparkplug needed.  Data is currently logged to InfluxDB and queryable through the same REST API that will let you browse topics, read current data and historical data, and write data.  Of course an MQTT client can still use pub/sub to subscribe or publish directly to the broker (and those topics will magically also get historized and be available via the REST API).  Boom. üí•

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: Thank you for all your comments. Let me give you some background. We are currently using a legacy DNC solution which over the years has been enriched with functions such as TRS, monitoring, maintenance, ... As part of our digital transformation, we are gradually replacing modules of this solution with more modern solutions. For example TRS in Tulip, maintenance in Infor EAM, monitoring via UNS and Grafana... But in the end we still have the DNC aka transfer CNC files from a central server to the machines with versioning, editing, comparison functions, ... We are wondering how to replace these functionalities with something  more digital 4.0, such as git for versioning, API/MQTT control, ... Indeed, it is not a question of investing in a specific solution, but rather of using "standard" solutions of an IT/OT stack in IT/OT convergence journey

We use Cimco and it works "fine", but I have often thought that it should be possible to replace a lot of the functionality with git, but I think it would be a lot of work to layer an interface over it to abstract the end users from all the complexity of git.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I would recommend sharing your vision with a company like Cimco.  They have among the best CNC editing and DNC technology with integration into major CAM packages.  They're not strangers to integration, but their core product is focused on a very specific solution.  Perhaps their product could be enhanced to coexist and interoperate with an IIoT infrastructure.  Perhaps they could add MQTT or REST interfaces for remote orchestration.

Another company worth getting in touch with is System Insights / VIMANA.  They're one of the few IoT products with deep functionality and domain expertise in machine tools.  It's built on a modern AWS stack, it's MTConnect-based, they understand G-code, etc.

Again, one of the largest issues here is going to be the existing machine control architectures themselves.  NC programs typically get exchanged over a file transfer protocol (e.g., FTP, SMB) and everything else is on a separate communication protocol (e.g., FOCAS, MELSEC, S7, OPC-UA, MTConnect).  Outside of a DNC package with some secondary data collection, it's rare to find products that can interface with both.  It's even more rare that they'll support multiple machine builders, multiple protocols, etc.  Ideally, as @Russ from the Internet alluded to, this problem will disappear one day and we won't even think about DNC.

It sounds like there is some market for some sort of super gateway for CNCs.  While there is definitely a need to abstract away the native interfaces on the CNCs, it's not as simple as converting everything to MQTT or HTTP.  This is much more sophisticated than consuming tags.  These aren't just SCADA workflows (e.g., trending, visualization, alarming).  There will be client applications needed to handle CNC editing, visualization, version control, etc.

The project is currently focused on remote, low-end embedded Linux systems connected to the cloud via low bandwidth cellular (Cat-M). However, it should be applicable to any distributed system where you want to sync data and config in any direction. People are currently using it to get data from modbus devices to cloud, then into influxdb, run rules to send SMS alerts and control other endpoints, scheduled rules, etc.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'm assuming by "MQTT Cloud" they're referring to a broker hosted in the cloud.  An MQTT broker is technically a TCP server.  An MQTT client opens TCP connections to the broker to publish and subscribe to data.  Inside this connection, data can move both client-to-broker and broker-to-client.

If they're inquiring whether they can connect some sort of app/device with a generic TCP Server to an MQTT broker, they can indirectly.  Suppose a device exchanges ASCII telegrams over TCP.  A gateway could do this.  On one end, a TCP client would read/write ASCII to the device.  On the other end, an MQTT client would pub/sub to a broker.

**Can [an] MQTT [broker] [hosted in the cloud] connect to a TCP Server?**
Yes, but with a gateway.  An MQTT broker is also a server.  It needs an MQTT client to create connections.  Likewise, the other TCP Server in question needs a TCP Client to create connections.  The gateway would need two client interfaces:  one for MQTT connection and one for the TCP connection.

**"Does the client have to connect to [the] MQTT [broker] first?"**
Yes, but not first.  Always.  Only clients connect to brokers.  The messages inside the connection, however, can be exchanged in both directions.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: The last time I looked at it about half a year ago, they hadn't solved yet how to run under Kubernetes and it was unclear to me how they would provide support for VerneMQ which is integrated as MQTT broker. Would be interesting to know if they subcontract VerneMQ as they don't seem to have committers on the project. Regarding Kubernetes it was unclear how their product would play together with Kubernetes as you have to use their service deployment mechanisms. Also, they did not yet support Sparkplug and only supported single node deployments (no horizontal scalability except for VerneMQ). All in all you could see that the product has potential but it just wasn't there yet. Maybe they have already resolved some of the points.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: My code is just a POC to validate some design ideas and not at all how I'd implement it in a real product.  The concepts would be the same but the implementation would be more at the broker level rather than outside of the broker.  But it did help to confirm my belief in the benefits of blending a REST API with MQTT and backfilling some of the limitations of MQTT with something less opaque than Sparkplug (or we enhance Sparkplug and MQTT to fill their respective limitations).

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
Yup, now that you mention it... Here's the diff from mosquitto on my Jetson Nano:
`# diff -Nau mosquitto.conf.orig mosquitto.conf
--- mosquitto.conf.orig    2021-01-30 09:50:24.236183650 -0500
+++ mosquitto.conf    2021-09-02 16:49:40.407512440 -0400
@@ -212,7 +212,7 @@
 # listener 0 /tmp/mosquitto.sock
 #
 # listener port-number [ip address/host name/unix socket path]
-#listener
+listener 1883 0.0.0.0
 
 # By default, a listener will attempt to listen on all supported IP protocol
 # versions. If you do not have an IPv4 or IPv6 interface you may wish to
@@ -235,7 +235,6 @@
 # Not available on Windows.
 #
 # Example: bind_interface eth0
-#bind_interface
 
 # When a listener is using the websockets protocol, it is possible to serve
 # http data as well. Set http_dir to a directory which contains the files you
@@ -341,6 +340,9 @@
 # "openssl rehash <path to capath>" each time you add/remove a certificate.
 #cafile
 #capath
+#cafile /etc/mosquitto/certs/ca.crt
+#keyfile /etc/mosquitto/certs/server.key
+#certfile /etc/mosquitto/certs/server.crt
 
 
 # If require_certificate is true, you may set use_identity_as_username to true
@@ -509,7 +511,7 @@
 # Defaults to false, unless there are no listeners defined in the configuration
 # file, in which case it is set to true, but connections are only allowed from
 # the local machine.
-#allow_anonymous false
+allow_anonymous true
 
 # -----------------------------------------------------------------
 # Default authentication and topic access control`

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Lots of options.  Do you need PCCC (e.g., SLC 5/05) or EtherNet/IP Class 3 (e.g., ControlLogic)?  Does the MQTT need SpB?  Do you need an edge appliance or would a software gateway suffice?

If the nodes are not widely dispersed all over a WAN, this decision is usually shaped by scale.  Software gateways will generally scale up more economically than hardware.

Real Time Automation ($$)
Kepware ($$$)
Kepware with IoT Gateway ($$$$)
Kepware + HighByte ($$$$)
Matrikon ($$$)

Author: billbither4379
Content: Hi Rick! I can't tell if you really believe this or not. If you do, I would to challenge you! Managing a scalable on-premise infrastructure that includes IoT data with security and uptime like AWS or Azure would be really difficult. AWS outages are rare (and seem to happen in US-EAST-1 more than others for some reason). Mature SaaS/cloud solutions can fallback on other regions when an outage like this occurs.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Nah, just couldn't resist.  I will say that I'm more a fan of hybrid solutions where mission critical stuff runs at the edge and other stuff can run at the cloud.  And ideally the edge based stuff has the option of being managed from the cloud as well.  

And as you point out,  a well architected cloud solution (I'm quite sure MachineMetrics fits this definition!) can be made very resilient to DC or Zone failures.

The issue I've seen is usually when the connection to the cloud is lost for any number of network related reasons (telco issues, weather, on-prem WAN gateway failure, etc) - then all the cloud redundancy in the world won't help.

Understanding the failures that could happen and whether your systems/processes can tolerate them is a good practice to go through, and should guide what/where to deploy workloads and apps.

Author: billbither4379
Content: Agreed! We see far more issues in the field with internal IT issues / firewalls, etc create network problems vs actual cloud data providers being the problem. Buffering data at the edge with some limited functionality until the connections are re-established is important.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Interestingly the home automation folks are going the other direction, and pushing more/most logic and interaction to the edge.  Availability, latency, and so on all matter.  Ultimately I'm a huge fan of architectural models that allow you to move functionality anywhere up and down the network from edge(s) to cloud(s).

Author: billbither4379
Content: IFTTT does not provide good latency, and home automation does not consume much data - so I get that. For single tenancy, moving up and down the edge to cloud stack is easier, but managing 1000's of single tenants is hard and expensive. We are primarily multi-tenant for the cloud side, which means all our customers use the same version of software,  updates are pushed out faster, and if any one customer were to greatly increase usage (say - connecting 1000 machines), it wouldn't phase us.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: We did some research and analysis on industrial data flows in typical factories (specialty chemical and CPG primarily) and found that the vast majority of people and apps consuming high volumes of data and/or in near-real-time were on-site, usually co-located with the data.  When you start adding up all the cloud meters that those round-trips cost (ingress of data, API calls, etc.) it can really add up!  In those use cases, there was typically an existing store of data on premise.   Duplicating all of that data in the cloud isn't necessarily optimal, but is necessary sometime (to support ML stuff, aggregate analytics, and so on ) - which of course MachineMetrics offers and I would think in a lot of cases your customers weren't already collecting that data, so it's not really duplicated.

Author: mparris
Content:
Just watched the Beckhoff OPC UA Pub/Sub webinar.

Does anyone have experience with products implementing the OPC UA Pub/Sub Spec?  Is it true that a subscriber needs to connect to a publisher over OPC UA Client/Server to understand the full amount of data that is within the PublishedDataSet?  @Ravil

Author: marioishikawa
Content: also curious about that

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
That's been my understanding.  One needs client/server to be able to browse and expose the various OPC-UA services.  This is similar to EtherNet/IP.  The Scanner will first establish an explicit connection (TCP) with the Adapter first and the I/O values are exchanged over an implicit connection (UDP).

This is one of the reasons why AMQP has been a preferred for transport in OPC-UA Pub/Sub.  While a pub/sub protocol, AMQP has native support for request/response messaging patterns.  Its originated out of the financial services industry to solve complex service bus problems.  It's not as lightweight and simple as MQTT, though.  It does not get used much for IoT devices and telemetry applications.

Check out this presentation from a few years ago at OPC Day Finland.  Presentation is about TSN, but many client/server + pub/sub questions came up.  Around 21:30.
https://youtu.be/zgXmEBl_iNI?t=1293

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
What's really interesting is that there is not really a consensus on transport at this point.  So far, we've seen mostly UDP for M2M applications (e.g., Beckhoff, Siemens).  MQTT for embedded devices to cloud (e.g., B&R).  AMQP for SCADA and Cloud (e.g., Iconics).  Add in TSN, and there have been concepts involving all three transports for M2M.

What's concerning is the framework touts the flexibility of multiple transports, but automation OEMs are developing products without this flexibility.  They each appear to have a preferred transport.  The transport(s) the market adopts is going to be more a function of what products support than the transport technologies themselves.  The prospect of deploying gateways to adapt various transports for OPC-UA is bizarre.

Author: mparris
Content:
That video is amazing!

He says that there is no need for Pub/Sub, except for TSN, because they already have subscriptions (data on change) through client/server.

This is likely the best embodiment of the blindspot that those in the Fountain had at the time. It's amazing how Sparkplug existed at the time and could be evaluated, but appears that no one involved in the specs did any market research to learn about it? How else does one explain that OPC UA Pub/Sub lacks standardization around it's payloads and topic paths?

I figured that a simple thought-experiment would have convinced these guys of the power of Pub/Sub: just as OPC UA abstracts the particular register numbers and allows discoverable data, Pub/Sub abstracts instances of devices and allows discoverable systems

Author: mparris
Content:
These presentations seem more often than not to be given by people that have not integrated systems. Seems that most assume there will be integration involved, and that for their considerations, it is assumed as a given.

Anyone living through the pain of integrating a spider web of client/server connections, immediately understand the benefit of Pub/Sub.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The way Munz berates the audience member about asking about pub/sub for cloud connections is not uncommon at these events.  Very reasonable questions and concerns informed by reality get shot down all the time.

If subscriptions were sufficient, we would have not witnessed people leverage all sorts of pub/sub technologies for the past twenty years.  One-to-many integrations and lightweight communications are important requirements.

You're absolutely right about those lacking experience with integration.  Look at that slide about cloud federation.  It's absurd.  We've poked fun at the vertical reference architecture that "layer" OPC servers before.  This one for cloud federation is insane.  It's multiple transports point-to-point in the same architecture.  I also don't know any OEM that is going to rely on their customer's cloud (or namespace) as a way of obtaining remote access to provide services or collect telemetry.  Most manufacturers have enough trouble exchanging data sets between PLC/HMI and ERP layers within their own org.

Yeah, it's funny this presentation was in 2017 and we're still talking about this technology today like it is in its infancy.

Author: mparris
Content:
It seems that the OPC UA Architecture is not driving towards "edge-driven".

I'm listening to the OPC Year-in-review, and they are discussing the Cloud LIbrary.  The concept as I understand it is if a product wants to know the information model of a device prior to connecting to it, it can hit a cloud endpoint to find out what information it has.

This seems at a high-level equivalent in approach to discovering devices by connecting to some parallel infrastructure such as a Global Discovery Server.

It seems they have started down the client/server road and are in too deep to pivot to have the devices themselves provide their Information Model for others to consume.  Also similar to lacking a means of discoverability that is built-in to the application infrastructure, rather than parallel systems (global discovery server).

Content:
Here are some examples that make me want to puke:

<Aliases>
<Alias Alias="Boolean">i=1</Alias>

<References>
<Reference ReferenceType="HasTypeDefinition">i=61</Reference>
<Reference ReferenceType="HasComponent" IsForward="false">ns=1;i=1005</Reference>

<UAObject NodeId="ns=1;i=5006" BrowseName="1:AutomationMLFiles" ParentNodeId="">

<Reference ReferenceType="ns=1;i=4002">ns=2;i=18</Reference>

This is an unimaginably poor design.

Content: @RickBullotta do you know if NodeSet files are intended to be XML XSD-type files (defining the schema) or are they intended to be XML-type files (defining the instances), or some hybrid of the two?

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
...or it could work kinda like LDAP where models can be "cached" and synced from a central cloud repo to an edge/distributed repo.

One nice thing about having a comprehensive model (not just types, but instances and their relationships also) stored persistently in a repo (even if it's quite dynamic) is that tooling/app builders can just access the repo and not need to interact with the real time systems (brokers, devices, etc).

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
AFAIK NodeSet files are XML files (not schema files) that are kind of a "meta schema" or capability definition.  There are XSD files to define what the format of the NodeSet files are. You can see more here:

https://github.com/OPCFoundation/UA-Nodeset

Author: mparris
Content: Am I correct to understand that the strength of XML is to have a schema with an implementation, where the implementation can be verified as valid per the defined schema?  Otherwise, it's overly bloated compared to JSON.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: I think JSON is a much better format, specially when implementing an array.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: But the ability to validate to a schema is only useful if the client understands it, right? From a manual command line point a view, running a command that validates the output doesn't necessarily make it more useful to me. I still have to parse it with something.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It actually doesn't need to be bloated, but yet, it usually is.  But when you put multiple values inside an element or attribute in an opaque way like they did, you lose much of the benefit of XML schema.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The challenge is that there is no broadly implemented standard for JSON schemas.  As such, one of the things we did with ThingWorx was to include metadata in the JSON docs themselves to describe what was contained.  It turned out to be super powerful - more or less "embedded schemas".  Of course those same schemas were available separately as well.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is triggering.  This brings me back to the first time connecting to a server.  90% of the time spent was parsing this nonsense.  I was incredibly confused that using a standard was harder than not using one.  One can reverse engineer a fieldbus without documentation faster than they can build an interface for this with documentation.

I don't get how the namespace indexing came to be.  I can't imagine what the design assumption was 15-20 years ago.  It's the most bizarre XML.  I've seen legacy data representations used in finance and supply chain / logistics get encapsulated into new protocols and it's never this ugly.

Author: mparris
Content:
If creating an instance of an OPC UA Companion Spec, I'm assuming that an XML schema would be a way to verify that the instance is compliant with the companion spec, that there are no typos, or properties put in the wrong location, etc.

For the machines, you are correct that the XSD wouldn't help there.  It's more of a quick compliance test for developers.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Think of it like ISO 9001 - XML Schema lets you validate that the instance is compliant with the spec - even if the spec is a piece of sh*t.  Much like ISO 9001 lets you validate that the product was made consistently, well documented, and to spec - even if the product is garbage.  At least it is well documented garbage.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Triggering is exactly the word I was looking for!  Thanks.

Author: mparris
Content: I recall that Ignition had to deploy an update about a year ago to not define an OPC UA tag by its <namespace index + ID>, but rather by the <namespace index description + ID>, which then required Ignition to do a lookup on connect to the UA server's namespace index array.  This is because on reboot, an OPC UA server is not required to keep the namespace indices consistent

Author: mparris
Content: Yes...it ensures the instance is as good as the spec, but says nothing about how good the spec is üòÜ

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is a really interesting comparison.

I know a very good management system consultant.  He has a good sense of humor and is transparent about how absurd these certifications can be in practice.  He'll call it the minor non-conformance racket.  One of my favorite stories involved how his firm would promote at trade shows in the past.  They could hardly find any potential customers interested in obtaining certification or consulting services.  Instead, they were bombarded by auditing and compliance professionals inquiring if they needed anyone or how to get in on the action.

It's not for the customers or outcomes, but the people providing the services.  It's like an industrial complex.  It makes me wonder... who are these specs benefiting?  SDK builders?  Consortium / standardization managers at the automation companies?

Author: mparris
Content:
I think your question is exactly the point I'm at with this rabbit-hole: who is the customer?

I've become convinced it is someone other than the integrator or end-user.

Author: akoscs
Content: Well...the thing is, that OPC-UA definitions follow their own way of describing things (just like e.g. the STEP standard defined their own language of describing stuff with Express, Express-I and Express-G). Then you want to use XML to serialize something that was not meant to be serialized with XML, so you project everything to an XML "space" and you end up with something ugly. The point is, that XML is not the goal, XML is just the ugly thing describing the more abstract ideas.

Author: akoscs
Content: Not if the information models are standardized. Do you have to have a separate server and gateway for the CANOpen DS Profiels? No, because they are standardized.

Author: akoscs
Content: No, the XSD can verify syntax. The comp spec is all about the semantics.

Author: akoscs
Content: The goal is to ease vendor lockin, so ... benefitting clients /endusers/integrators ... implementation is under debate (well, only I seem to be debating) but goal is to ease vendor lockin.

Author: akoscs
Content: Are you also looking at other methods to describe complex models using their XML projection? Are you looking at a UML model in its XML representation? A STEP file in its XML representation? A Word file in its XML representation?

Author: rkwadd
Content: This is an important nuance. XML as a representation of an information model has limitations. Theoretically the blame for the mess shouldn‚Äôt be on the underlying model. And theoretically a better and cleaner representation will come along. In practice‚Ä¶.? Doesn‚Äôt seem like the specific problems Rick ends up in a clock tower over have anyone working to resolve them with something like canonical UML instead.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It's mostly theoretical.  One rarely has the freedom of choice when it comes to protocol or transport on industrial nodes.  It's more of a function of a brand than anything else.  "The market" does not decide protocol, but the hardware that adopts protocol.  And the market for this hardware is constrained by locality, compliance, tradition, workforce, distribution agreements, etc.  In other words, industrial automation is purchased for countless reasons other than protocol.  Additionally, industrial nodes are rarely lifecycled for protocol enhancements.  For example, how many PLCs sold in the past ten years are going to soon have support for AMQP/TSN?  Virtually none.

For similar reasons, I find it bizarre when standards bodies adopt a particular technology (e.g., OPC-UA, EtherCAT).  For example, when China standardizes on EtherCAT, they're implicitly endorsing Beckhoff.  It's not like Rockwell and Siemens are going to interoperate over EtherCAT anytime soon.  Is that going to stop manufacturers from acquiring machinery that is not available with Beckhoff controls or EtherCAT?  Of course not.

As long as users don't have the choice, being transport independence is more a hindrance than a benefit.  Unless the standard has some sort of compatibility requirement, it's just another interoperability issue for consumers sort through.  Consumers don't want to deal with two products stamped with the same certification failing to interoperate.  This diminishes the value of the standard.  The point is that the engineering should not exceed what a bespoke integration would take.

I'll concede some benefits. It can prevent "reinventing the wheel". There are "steady" foundational technologies like TCP/IP or TLS that can be relied on. As transport security for TCP evolves, a protocol can leverage it.

Transports will most certainly evolve over time. A more sound approach is to commit to a steady roadmap of support. Without this, the standard becomes byzantine and less useful.

Author: rkwadd
Content: MTConnect has a bespoke protocol that most deployments use. If you want the MTConnect semantic definitions but carried over OPC use the OPC-MTConnect companion specification.

Author: rkwadd
Content: As far as I know, none of the domain models represented in OPC UA companion specs are exclusively built to use OPC. Most are adapted from other standards that predated UA or developed concurrently.

Author: jon.forbord

Author: ravil1
Content: Not sure what exactly you mean. For me, OPC UA node identifiers design in general is just perfect. You can use 4 types as identifiers, and can identify nodes at any scope: namespace URI scope, server scope, and using extended id - absolute scope. It might look messy just at the first glance. But after working in this domain for years, you would value how well thought system is this. In OPC UA, some stuff might look redundant or too complex, but when you encounter more use cases over time, then understand why it was done this way.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Exactly why adoption of the more exotic parts of OPC UA is minimal.  It's obtuse, messy, not human friendly, and the way it is encoded in XML is just plain horrible (you can't easily XPath it).  Let's hope the JSON stuff that they're working on is done better.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
"OPC UA node ID is *not*, by itself, a string. It is primarily a structure, containing the namespace (URI, index or both), and the identifier. OPC UA Node Id *has* a string representation, but the string representation is not the Node ID itself. The very same OPC UA node ID can be represented by multiple strings. You should not assume that two strings that appear different represent different node IDs. For example, "ns=1;s=SomeNode", and "ns=1;SomeNode" are strings that represent precisely the same node ID, because the "s=" prefix (for string identifiers) is optional. Or, "ns=0;s=Objects" may be the same as simply "s=Objects", because the default parsing context assumes the namespace index zero (when missing from the string)."

Literally 12 different ways to define a node ID.  And even more ways to express them.  That's just ridiculous. 

ü§Æ ü§Æ ü§Æ

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
All one needs to do is read this and try to decipher it to understand what the opposite of "user friendly" is:

https://documentation.unified-automation.com/uasdkhp/1.4.1/html/_l2_ua_node_ids.html

And the whole approach can lead to huge numbers of unnecessary API calls doing lookups or getting metadata.  

The only possible explanation for such a horrible design is that someone must have already implemented it this way and pushed this awful approach through.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Trust me, I'll never be convinced otherwise.  I've already relegated OPC UA to legacy, not future.

Author: ravil1
Content:
For me, as a developer, this is just flexibility and freedom in designing address space depending on the specific use cases. In the end, those node ids often are not visible to the end-users, they see human-readable display names, or they might see them, but no need to deal with them directly. Moreover, application  developers do not need to encode /decode node ids themselves, it is already done at the SDK level. And SDKs handle Node Ids internally in an  efficient way, so finding the node in the address space does not take a long time.
I guess it depends on mindset, for some might look awful, which is fine. If somebody does not like it, I guess free to move away.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ...but if you want to deal with friendly names you end up doing a ton of lookups.  Too much flexibility = too much complexity = reduced readability + more difficult interoperability.  As I said, we'll have to agree to disagree.

Author: ravil1
Content:
At the enterprise level, you can eliminate such flexibility, and for example design all your node ids to be string type, and morever, you can design them to be exaclty like MQTT topics. As I say, OPC UA is more generic, and you can map to it almost any other protocol / obkect model. But not opposite. 
Having string node ids might make mixing OPC UA and MQTT very easy.
And of course, if this looks too complex and not neccesary in particular project, it is possible not use OPC UA at all, nobody forces I guess, right.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Yet virtually every example and tutorial is some variant of the infamous "ns=0;i=12345"

Author: ravil1
Content:
But you don'e need always follow this kind of example.
Having numeric identifiers has its own advantages in particular use cases, For example, is resource constrained devies you can use as identifier index of the array of variables (in the server address space, where no large standard id's like 12345, but ids are like 1, 2, or 3). this makes finding the node very effecient.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The best thing the OPC foundation could do is to deprecate "bad practices" and recommend one preferred "best practice", whatever that is.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: "1" works just as well as 1 - just sayin'

Author: rickbullotta
Content: In fact it saves 3 bytes. üòâ

Author: ravil1
Content: To me, there is no absolute "best practice". I doubt that having always numeric node identifiers is recommended as the base practice.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: And yes, I'm aware that a 1 character string isn't just one byte.  That was a joke.

Author: ravil1
Content:
No, on the wire it does nto save 3 bytes. When you transfer strings, you need to prepend it with the string length. Which is usually 4 byte integer. 
When you transfer numeric node id, it depends, how big is the number. Small ids are transferred as 2 bytes, and large ones as 4 bytes, I don't remember exactly. So it is not always 4 bytes.

Author: mparris
Content:
The one thing the conversations on this discord have proven is that, consciously or not, the strategy for OPC UA is to provide a very large solution set to accommodate many different use cases. It's continues to be a revealed on this discord server as a design principle at the very core of the specification.

I used to view this as a strength of the surgical. As one of the pillars discussed here is openness, what's better than an open framework that can enable developers to evaluate a given problem and be flexible to accommodate any number of ways of optimally solving that problem? Why restrict innovation by reducing the possibilities to a narrow feature set?

I then realized that this thinking was primarily from the perspective of developing a server.  The attraction of options for the server developer is the nightmare of the developer of the client. The client must accommodate all the possible variation that servers may present.

My thesis is that wide market adoption of a standard won't happen unless there is an obvious and compelling client application: something that provides value itself which then requires the standard to utilize.  For example,  a conversation may start: "Why should I use OPC UA over Modbus?" Then a response:  "Because there is this awesome desktop application and if you use OPC UA, you'll get to utilize that application. If you use modbus, you won't. Ohh, and also there is this other awesome cloud service. If you use OPC UA, you get to utilize it. If you use modbus, you don't"

Author: mparris
Content:
Given my thesis is that market adoption is primarily driven by how compelling the client/consumer/subscriber application is, making it difficult for developers to create these awesome  client/consumer/subscriber applications by smothering them with the breath of options, is a direct hurdle to the end goal.

The excitement and technical accomplishment around freedom of choice for developers of producers/servers/publishers will be the very reason for the sluggish adoption of OPC UA.

It's the job of the OPC Foundation to be good stewards of the market and be good product managers. The capability of a product manager is not measured by what they say"yes" to, but what they say "no" to.

Author: mparris
Content:
And I know our good friend @Ravil will disagree with my statements, as we've discussed before.

I don't have any evidence to empirically prove my thesis, I am just offering the justification for why I choose to view it in this way.

I think at this point in the discussion, one can be characterized as (1) one who prefers a more narrow spec that covers 90% of the use-cases, but sacrifices the 10% in exchange for simplicity (= more immediate adoption) or (2) one who prefers a specification that enables developers many options to cover 100% of use-cases.

I think underneath the Sparkplug vs OPC UA discussions is really, at it's heart, a debate about two different strategies of specifications.

Author: ravil1
Content:
I think yes, you are right. And numbers 90% vs 10% might be true too. But actual ratio of these 90% and 10% might be not as 9:1. Can be opposite - those 10% can be very large projects, while 90% are low scale projects. 
I already wrote multipel times, that all depend on specific use case. There is no rule "always use only MQTT", nor "always use only OPC UA".

Author: ravil1
Content:
In case with Modbus and OPC UA, they are not mutually exclusive nowadays. There are many gateways converting Modbus to OPC UA, so if you have Modbus, consider you have it available over OPC UA too.
Soon my company will offer affordable Modbus to OPC UA gateway too. Will be avilable as software only, or combined with the small device box. Combined with ogamma Visual Logger for OPC, you can then push Modbus data over MQTT to the cloud or regular MQTT broker.

Author: benveenema
Content:
"Furthermore, the classic DA Servers had only capabilities for a simple hierarchy, i.e. a tree-like structure with branches and leaves. Hence, many vendors have used the full folder hierarchy to create unique ItemIDs (e.g. ‚ÄúFolder1.Folder2.Folder3.MyTemperature‚Äù). This lead to massive redundant strings, wasting memory and slowing down performance when looking up or searching for individual Items. With OPC UA, this concept has been abandoned."

Lol! Sounds like DA was better. I spent years doing development on 8 bit micros (PIC > AVR üòâ), so I understand resource constraints. The thing is, those days are largely over, especially in the industrial space. Even a basic Cortex M0 could handle strings like this with ease, let alone an M4. Only the most cost conscious embedded (like $2 toys, greeting cards) would be concerned with these levels. Anything with connectivity has a price level to afford basically as much memory as it needs.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: If you can afford it for this project, an Opto 22 groov Rio would be somewhat overkill but also perfect (~$750 US). You can program it in Node Red if you want, or python, you just have to request a free SSH license to get to the shell. It's got tons of I/O configurations including two form-C relays. And it can run on PoE if you have PoE switches so you don't need a power supply.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: And you can use the built in MQTT publishing of the I/O or control it in Node Red if you need more flexibility. The newer model (~$850) has Groov View (I think) and Ignition Edge (requires extra pay for license from Ignition though).

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'm assuming safety and RTOS are not a concern?

Here are some suggestions that don't totally fit your requirements, but showcase some broad approaches.  Some of the edge devices appear like their intended for hobbyist / DIY applications than industrial environments.  Sure, there exist hardened devices but they don't seem to consistently fill the void in the market.  It appears that there is a trade off between what's optimal for control/connectivity/apps and what's optimal to connect field devices.  If you're struggling to find a "unicorn' product, perhaps it's worth breaking up the requirements for multiple products to satisfy.

Opto22 or Beckhoff are good I/O options.  Their I/O modules can be paired with a full-blown PLC or they can function as a remote I/O.  You might find the Beckhoff's TwinCat runtime might be a nice home for your C/C++ applications.  TwinCat is an extremely flexible solution.  B&R is another dev-friendly platform to look into.

If low cost is an objective, take a look into Access IO products.  I've observed their solution to be surprisingly reliable.  As mentioned elsewhere, another option to explore is the industrialized RPi or Arduino solutions.

If your actuators will be drawing a lot of current or you can't find suitable I/O for your application, look into using relay contactors.  It can be far more economical, reliable, and flexible to decouple the control power and its outputs from the actuator loads.  It's added complexity, but it will allow you to "adapt" more products to your application.

Author: jeastburn9264

Author: benveenema
Content:
In addition to low-cost. The hardened Arduino I/O variants offer a better developer experience than any Real Controller I've used. There are gaps (like industrial ethernet protocols and built-in HMI), but any time I've used Real Controllers I find myself missing:
- open source documentation and collaboration like stack exchange
- a good IDE
- version control, including branching and diffing
- good library support. Real Controllers will have libraries for basics like E/IP, but lack a lot of business logic libraries and the ones I've found are poorly documented and confusing to use. It seems the Real Controller community isn't very into sharing
- Full suite OOP tools. Codesys with ST comes close to being able to implement full OOP but its still clunky and lacking
- Event driven or functional tools. Again, Codesys with ST comes close but you still can't pass a function as a callback. Pretty hard to do event driven without that.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: My experience is kinda the opposite, mostly due to the software limitations of the Arduino IDE and language/libraries, and the "unusual" programming quirks when trying to do any kind of comms in or out of the Arduino devices.

Author: benveenema
Content:
The first rule of using Arduino, is not to use the Arduino IDE. Maybe the pro IDE, though I haven't tried it. There is an Arduino extension for VSCode that is very good and allows you to use all the code highlighting and static analysis built in there. However, it doesn't solve the global libraries issue when you are handling multiple projects.

That's why the second rule of using Arduino is to use PlatformIO. Nearly every "Arduino" board, including most of the hardened, industrial Arduinos can be used within PlatformIO. PlatformIO has a proper library manager, similar to NPM for Javascript that has all the friendly Arduino libraries in it already. It also allows you to structure your files in multiple folders, has proper debugging support and a unit testing framework.

I think the confusion comes from the word Arduino meaning different things to different people. Some people think Arduino === Arduino Uno and dismiss it out of hand. Some people think Arduino == Arduino IDE and rightly have a poor taste for it. I think of Arduino as a microcontroller platform and HAL (hardware abstraction layer). Admittedly, it's not the best HAL or platform, mBed is arguably better. However, it is the easiest to use for newcomers, extremely widely adopted and loved by the open source community, which means there is tons of great learning content and open libraries for just about anything you would need.

There are holes or gaps, lack of printf for floats and little comms outside of serial (although ESP32, among others has an ethernet stack and MQTT Arduino libraries exist). You also can't "download" a program from an Arduino in the field like you can a PLC, something that trad industrial controls engineers have come to expect. I think there could be a nice marriage between an Arduino, for ease of controls programming and an Rpi, for the heavy comms, vision processing and edge AI/ML/Compute, all wrapped in a nice package with a single communication line and programming environment.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Maybe we should just call them microcontrollers then...

Author: benveenema
Content:
Aren't PLCs microcontrollers as well then...

Piggybacking off the Arduino name has caused a lot of confusion from end users. I still think there's value in it from a marketing and compliance perspective though. If a controller is labeled as Arduino or Arduino compatible, it means it conforms to the Arduino HAL (which is actually called "wiring") and can use any of the Arduino libraries.

Author: matthewjd24
Content: When you set up an MQTT namespace, are you putting devices as the lowest level topics, or data points *about* the devices as the lowest level topics? Such as Room/Sensor1/On and Room/Sensor1/Temp, compared to Room/Sensor1 sending an XML with On/Off and Temp

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I prefer individually subscribable data points. That‚Äôs basically the main difference between Sparkplug (all  lumped together) and ‚Äútypical‚Äù MQTT (individual topics per data point).  Though even with ‚Äúplain‚Äù MQTT the cloud iot providers sometimes funnel everything through a single topic per device.  I have a prototype where I do the best of both worlds by automatically expanding Sparkplug messages into individual topics/datapoints.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I‚Äôll try to put that code on GitHub soon.

Author: matthewjd24
Content: Thanks. Some of our machines will generate a lot of data so I wasn't sure if one topic per machine with an XML of all that data would be the better way to go. It seems like it's important how I'm planning on storing the data. Right now I think we're going to have one machine status table, so if its status changes we will need to read all of its data and write it as a new row to the table. In that case maybe an XML is better

Author: matthewjd24
Content: Because with individual topics, it would just publish the one data point that's changed and we'll need to go hunting for the rest.

Author: mparris
Content:
The design assumption with Sparkplug was limited to use-cases where devices were sending data to a "Primary Node", and the assumption was that it was going to get everything anyway.

Once Sparkplug started catching on to other use-cases, such as Secondary Nodes that only care about a portion of the data, or scaling Sparkplug to represent an enterprise instead of just a cell or line, then this design assumption really started to hurt.

Author: mparris
Content:
I think going forward for Sparkplug revisions, the discussion will likely be around what is the right balance between packaging it all together as a synchronous publish to save bandwidth vs individual asynchronous publishes which required multiple MQTT Ethernet, TCP, MQTT headers, which adds to the overhead.

I haven't seen @RickBullotta PoC, but if the concept is to receive a synchronous publish (since most use-cases will be to publish the latest changed value every 1000ms (or whatever rate), and then expand it within the broker to their individual topics so that clients can pick and choose what metrics they care to receive, I think that is a fantastic solution to that problem!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: My current approach uses whatever update rate is used for Sparkplug messages.  I just subscribe to those and handle them appropriately.  I'll try to post some code tomorrow.

Author: willsobel.
Content:
I would not start with "digital-twin" as the goal, I would set some business goals you want to achieve with a twin. Since digital-twin is a poorly defined term that can mean anything to anyone (we have done twins and taken advantage of the "buzz", but it makes me feel dirty, mainly because I feel like I'm playing into the hype of the marketing overlords).

For robotics, are you looking for process monitoring (is my machine operating when it should?) Is my machine moving like it should (kinematics?) Will this robot fight with any other robots? Do you want an animation of the plant? 

Depending on what you are trying to achieve, you can then pursue the data. When I'm doing digital-xform projects, we start small and then grow into the end goals. Chasing a lot of data upfront will be time consuming‚Äìmy suggestion is to stay agile. I worked on the ISO DT project w/ MTConnect and robotics to show how to get feedback. It really depends.

Most robot APIs can give you joint positions and end effector positions given a coordinate system. You can do the kinematics yourself to compute interference. Usually the robot vendors make the models available online using DH params. ABB has OPC-UA using two models (makes life confusing), FANUC uses EIP (ControlLogix), etc... ROS-2 has some interesting tools that layer on top of existing robots and provides a lot of functionality. ROS-2 supports DDS as the communications layer.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yeah, it's important to be specific.  Get a list of everything you want to make a delivery requirement (e.g., registers/addresses, tags, acceptance test).

I've done a lot of projects with Fanuc robots.  In terms of making them "IIoT ready", there exists all sorts of communication interfaces that can be specified.  This is somewhat trivial.  The bigger problem is making sure the robot programs are built in a such a way that they're providing good data.  For example, it's good to go overboard with position registers and expose them for data collection.  This provides context of what the robot was doing when analyzing other data.

Fanuc robot tips:
-Define everything as a position register
-Be declarative about state/intent in each routine.  Historians and alarms can be useless without context.
-Map User Operator Panel (UOP) signals
-Identify SNPX variables of interest.  A lot of the data for predictive maintenance and anomaly detection can be found here.
-Enable HMI Device software option (GE-SRTP protocol) to read/write to registers directly.  This can be preferable to indirectly accessing internal registers through mapping to the I/O payload of a fieldbus (e.g., EtherNet/IP, PROFINET)
-For more advanced control or analytics, partner with vendors with experience in the KAREL programming environment.
-If also using Rockwell PLCs, look into leveraging the PLC Motion Interface AOI.
-Find a good gateway for the native protocol (SRTP).  I usually use the Kepware GE Ethernet drivers.

Kuka has an embedded Windows PC supervising its controllers.  These are among the most easy to get data out of and closely participate with the OPC-UA / I4.0 movement in Germany.  Some of the more modern ABB models have a lot of slick interface options.  They have everything from the OPC-UA to fieldbuses to web services and libraries.  They've seem to have upped their integration game since acquiring B&R.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Ok, so this will be a Fanuc robot but with AB PLCs as the cell controller... We already have Kepware and should already have the GE drivers so that's one option. My orginal plan was to buy a RTA MQTT gateway to sit in front of the AB PLC though...

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
There is a quite a bit the AOI can pull in over EtherNet/IP, but it's not everything.  The native protocol on a Fanuc robot is technically SRTP/SNPX (and also potentially FL-net).  With the non-native protocols, typically everything must be mapped into the "i/o racks" for the fieldbus interface to "pick up".  It works well enough for field integration, but it's not as elegant for data collection.

In most implementations, I usually prefer AB Safety PLC supervising the robot and anything else in the field.  While the R30i- is a great controller, its ladder engine is very old school and the interface options are more bespoke.  There usually isn't much room for expansion in the enclosure.  It's better to do the visualizing, alarming, safety, and other device control on a more focused platform.  In parallel to this, data will be collected directly from the robot over the SRTP interface.  It seems to add friction to go always go through a PLC to data out of a robot (map to robot's i/o rack, exchange over fieldbus, map to PLC's robot tags, map to data collection UDT, exchange over native protocol, etc).

If you need a field gateway for SRTP, check out Maple Systems.  They have GE drivers.

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: I would say that this isn't necessarily true.  If you are connecting a historian to the UNS, and you use the historical data for batch reporting, or any other function related to batch release, I'm fairly certain you have to validate at least on data integrity, and the system is subject to change control.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
As much as I hate saying this, this really is a "it depends" question.  With a plant at a sufficient size, this is a job for network engineer.  A good network should be balanced.  It should be driven by intent and policy.  Typically, when things go wrong, it's attributed to one of two things.  The first is an improvised network with unmanaged switches everywhere.  This inevitably leads to performance, reliability, and security problems.  The second is a well-intentioned network that is too rigid and difficult to manage.  This is where no one knows what the traffic flows should be and all the one-off policies across disparate appliances becomes unwieldy.

I would start with the Cisco Converged Plantwide Ethernet reference architecture.  It's very Rockwell-centric and I wouldn't necessarily advise adopting it end-to-end.  It's also a bit dated in that LAN technology has evolved in recent years.   Namely, it's still using traditional topology (core/distribution/access) or it does not factor in software-defined networking.  But, the principles regarding segmentation and security are sound.  The DMZs at various levels can appear like the Purdue security model (which is often cause for concern), but notice that it prescribes using identity-based access control.  I like this because it's not just showing how to handle Ethernet at the upper levels, but also in the lower layers for fieldbus applications.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/enterprise/design-zone-manufacturing/landing_ettf.html

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: In this particular example, the historian of record is OSI PI. The UNS is added to provide contextualized information, rather than all of the PI connectors. I will find the video/graphic and post.

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: Thanks David.  My contention is that the dependency on whether or not the UNS to PI connection is subject to validation is related to what the historian data is used for.  I sold PI for 15 years, and pretty much all of my pharma customers validated their PI systems because, at some level they were using the data to make decisions on batch release.  Whether it be deviation investigations, to connection to the EBR.  So at the very least the link between the PI system and what is delivering it's data should be validated to document that it's performing it's intended function.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: You are I are saying the same thing. The connection between the control system (DeltaV) and the historian (PI) and subsequent connections (PI, ERP, etc.) are all validated. The connection between the control system and UNS is validated. Anything else out of the UNS is not.

Author: michael.brown
Content:
Interesting thread...a few data points to throw into the mix. The sitewise connector is actually made up of 2 lambdas, the OPC-UA Collector and the SiteWise Publisher - they are joined together by the SiteWise Stream manager in the middle and the Greengrass MQTT Broker as the executive  active realtime messenger and a separate API "Batch Writer" directly to the Sitewise service...
That's the real-world technical breakdown.
other data
- AWS just joined the OPC Foundation last year....its going to be interesting to see where it goes.
- AWS is seriously customer driven - if customers do not provide direct feedback that native OPC-UA capabilities are required - the service teams will not build it or be slow to build it - regardless of the memberships.

 All that to say it's straight up Client/Server today that's converted to API and MQTT/Json payloads on the local device before being landed in the cloud.

Author: rkwadd
Content:
When a framework, standard, or specification has wide product support, the discussion about whether products exist simply goes away. It‚Äôs replaced with discussion (or, you could say, ‚Äúendless complaining‚Äù) about specific details of certain implementations, pricing, sub-version support, programming language support, localization, time lags in support for new versions, backwards compatibility, and on and on and on. 

This is just a general observation, not a specific comment on OPC. I believe current estimates put it at over one brazillion installs in any case.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Since we recently spoke about OPC UA over MQTT: At the end of last week I realized that OPC UA Pub/Sub has actually very little to do with OPC UA Client/Server. So far, I assumed that with Pub/Sub you just send the OPC UA object hierarchy via MQTT but it turns out that the OPC UA foundation created something much worse. Turns out that with OPC UA Pub/Sub you are sending values in byte arrays without names or meta information wrapped in a lot of overhead via MQTT. And if the implementation provider didn‚Äôt implement any of the (of course optional) alternatives to communicate metadata, each subscriber needs to know what field sits where exactly in the "byte sausage" that is sent over the wire. This happens to be the case with the Siemens implementation. Which would be fine if there were any schemas that you could use to parse the binary data but there aren‚Äôt. Also, at least the Siemens implementation requires you to define an explicit publish interval, so no report by exception is possible. And because the spec is so badly written, all of this is probably fully OPC UA Pub/Sub compliant. Btw I‚Äôm not annoyed by the Siemens implementation but by the OPC UA spec itself.

Author: rkwadd

Author: rkwadd
Content: For an industry standard to work, the standards developers have to understand the sort of problems you describe here, *before* a standard is written, then spend hours debating and trying to agree on the exact solution. People who worked on the OPC UA spec itself would likely counter your criticism with ‚ÄúGreat, then join the committee and help fix it,‚Äù but to me that‚Äôs an unreasonable ask. Best case is you open an issue in the relevant GitHub repo or something‚Ä¶but that doesn‚Äôt actually exist. The entire paradigm for how these things get written is still based entirely on big, long, dense meetings to write big, long, dense documents. Standards Development 3.0, you could say.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: One possible solution to OPC UA is :  sudo rm -rf

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: One of the worst things about the whole OPC UA Standard is that very often it doesn‚Äôt actually standardize anything at all. There are just too many optional and non binding parts. To me it feels that the objective was not to be compatible but to let any vendor do whatever they want, keep their existing solutions, let them add their vendor-specific add-ons and keep their ecosystems closed and still be OPC UA compatible. End of rant.

Author: mparris
Content:
I don't know if that will be the title, but the content I'm wanting to write is the latest phrase that is appearing "OPC UA over MQTT" doesn't actually mean anything...

And if I don't want to use MQTT, would I do "OPC UA over AMQP"?

Or, if I just want to stick with client/server would I do
"OPC UA over OPC UA"?

Author: mparris
Content:
I believe it was a strategic decision to get companies to support it.

I fully expect the latest announcement of cloud providers supporting "OPC UA over MQTT" is in the same boat...

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Probably.

Author: rkwadd
Content: I‚Äôm trying to thread the needle and keep coming back to this line between what transport is technically addressed in the documentation vs what is deployed in the wild and/or widely used.

Author: rkwadd
Content: Specifically to avoid over promising.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Maybe to add: Of course I don‚Äôt think this was an orchestrated effort but too many involved parties pushed their own interests too much and the current standard is the result of this. I do agree though that some people made the strategic decision to leave it like this in order to get or keep companies onboard.

Author: kcollins
Content:
As far as I'm aware, Telegraf doesn't have an input plugin that can consume MQTT Sparkplug B topics/payloads.  The MQTT Consumer plugin expects messages in one of the Telegraf input data formats.  It would be a nice to have that plugin as a thing though.  ü§î 
https://docs.influxdata.com/telegraf/v1.21/plugins/#mqtt_consumer

Author: mparris
Content:
Putting aside any consideration for the performance of the protocol or the performance of a MQTT broker, something that isn't readily considered is how fast can a PLC consume MQTT data?

Many PLCs have firmware designs centered around consuming its proprietary fieldbus as fast as possible. MQTT functions typical live in userspace, and aren't granted equal priority.

Also, on the firmware development side, MQTT will not have received equal attention as their own fieldbus protocols, so it should be expected to be slower.

By the way, all of what I said above regarding MQTT also applies to OPC-UA. Many on this Discord server have found limitations of OPC-UA when compared to the fieldbus

Author: rickbullotta
Content: What are your thoughts on OPC UA over TSN?

Author: mparris
Content:
A technology is only as good as the products that implement them.

OPC UA on its own is a very interesting technology and has promised a lot of benefits over fieldbus protocols.  OEMs have had over 15 years to consider and then realize these benefits.  Why has this not happened?

It seems that OEMs need a market reason to put the effort behind developing the technology within their products.  OPC UA hasn't been successful in this regard, so I'm doubtful that OEMs will be convinced to divert resources from their fieldbus technologies or other proprietary products over to OPC UA TSN.

Why would TSN would convince them to implement it fully where OPC UA didn't do that 15 years ago?

Author: jpmoniz
Content: I‚Äôm still trying to figure out why safety Over UA.

Author: mparris
Content:
The prevailing sentiment is: we should do it so all things can interoperate with one another.  The only way this is convincing is if there is a KILLER use-case to consume OPC UA devices, which will force end-users and integrators to demand products include OPC UA so that they can be consumed by the killer use-case.

I don't think any use-case has been developed/discovered, so there isn't any market demand for implementations on the producer side.

What is the killer use-case for TSN, to force end-users/integrators to demand it instead of all the fieldbus methods of today?

Author: jpmoniz
Content: I wonder if this is just a pepatory thing for 5g.  I would assume incorporation of TSN would be for long distance use cases.  I personally find it if no real use right now. I think they are operating on if they build it they will come.  Like most OPC specs reality shows they never show up.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I don‚Äôt know, other than OPC UA hoping to be a common device descriptor model for all levels of the stack vs fieldbus DDs which really aren‚Äôt. Just a guess.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: But why would TSN be a driver for that?  They could do that now if they wanted.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @jpmoniz, you just advanced to level 6!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: TSN could play a valuable role for supervisory control also, couldn‚Äôt it?  For example an AI algorithm making real time adjustments or near real time control algorithms that span multiple systems up and down the stack. Not suggesting OPC is the answer, but determinism and some of the other aspects of TSN could be useful at multiple levels.

Author: jpmoniz

Author: justinb0044
Content:
Hi all,

Is it possible to have a two nodes publishing and consuming to the exact same topics in a spark plug b namespace? Eg I want node 1 to publish to OpenCMD topic, I then want node 2 to subscribe to that topic and tigger en event.  I know this is easy to do with vanilla MQTT however I don't know how this would work with spark plug b, has anyone got any experience with this?

Author: mparris
Content:
A Sparkplug node will have a groupID and a nodeID. The combination of the two MUST be unique for each node (similar to IP address). All the metrics (data) fall under this unique identifier with the NDATA topic.

Within NDATA, there are sequence numbers, so if multiple devices are using the same GroupID and nodeID, they will have unsynchronized sequence numbers and cause confusion for the consumers.

There is also a birth certificate that a node must publish that contains all the metics that a node has. If the second node doesn't have the same exact metrics, then a consumer will notice and request a rebirth. And this loop will continue indefinitely if two nodes are claiming the same GroupID and nodeID.

Author: mparris
Content: Two nodes can subscribe to the same topics... They just can't publish to the same topic in SpB.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ...though this is largely on the "honor system", isn't it?  There's no protocol level way to enforce this, is there?  You could use broker-specific ACL techniques, but nothing generic that I'm aware of.

Author: mparris
Content:
Correct.

Workout ACLs, I've often wondered how people would troubleshoot a malicious application that subscribed to # and after receiving topics publish back to the same topic but with malformed data.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: So, technically you *could* have one "device" (or node or client) publish the *BIRTH messages and others publish metrics for that same ID.  Not that you should, but you could.

Author: brianpribe
Content: So I‚Äôm installing a new electrical panel for my house. Wanted a system that could have battery storage, inverters, and car charging for down-the-road upgrades. I‚Äôve looked at a few different suppliers and the one I went with was Leviton (Home Depot). They have a pretty cool system. The backplane has all of the connections needed for wiring the panel, while being modular. They sell 1-pole and 2-pole breakers, thermal, hydraulic, AFCI, GFCI, AND embedded WiFi breakers. Now their smart breakers are proprietary and don‚Äôt integrate with other systems, but it doesn‚Äôt mean u won‚Äôt be able to in the future (IMO making this proprietary isn‚Äôt a bad design, it caters to the market well).  Cost is really good too for getting a working panel. More advanced breakers will increase the cost obviously.

Content: Better yet and open source hub for it. House value wise, it‚Äôs much better to have a turn-key solution for the house because then there‚Äôs no learning curve, special components, or software to have it operate. For these breakers they link to a hub that is installed inside the panel. That hub then connects to your house and then to Levitons cloud, giving you access to it on their app. If Leviton chooses to integrate with other services then that‚Äôs great for a solution. For open source, if the hub was capable of being configurable then you can configure the system to your liking. It‚Äôs a very capable and customer friendly product if it were to have those two options.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I have one, but haven‚Äôt started playing with it yet. CtrlX has a lot of potential. It‚Äôs an open PLC platform, much on the same ideas as PLCnext. Codesys based. And the really interesting concept is based on the concept of automation as software, not hardware. So you no longer buy a PLC with motion control, or a PLC with CNC. It‚Äôs all one hardware that you buy licenses to extend from the base functionality. Their whole range of CtrlX drives and other equipment will be driven by the same idea, of reducing the number of hardware products, and differentiate on licensed software capabilities. Do not mistake this to be ‚Äúbuy our ecosystem‚Äù-approach. It is based on open standards and is meant to be an open solution. That being said, I haven‚Äôt tried it yet, but there is definitely potential for Bosch Rexroth being one of the vendors that can be part of the solution.

Author: jonnywright4
Content: @Richard Shaw  I‚Äôm excited to support here as both a member of this community & Mentorship program, and involved with this platform at Rexroth. In essence this is the ‚ÄúSmartphone of Automation‚Äù that @Walker Reynolds  talks about. It‚Äôs a powerful hardware platform that is implemented in a Controller, Motor Drive OR Industrial PC; same architecture in each. Combine this with an operating system, like Android or Apple IOS, where you have an App Store, Github community and Partner Community with many I4.0 & IIOT Companies providing Apps. The ctrlX CORE, the ‚Äòoperating system‚Äô common across the above hardware, is Linux snap based and built around a Data Layer which is essentially its own internal UNS that any App can publish/subscribe to in real time. There is a Codesys App for the traditional Automation projects but you can essentially write applications in any language using any development environment. As it is an automation platform at it‚Äôs heart, there are the usual distributed IO and safety system modules and a whole host of protocols to talk to the rest of the IIOT world. We had a great conversation with @jmckeon  last week who recognises that Rexroth are indeed aligned with the vision of this community:¬† https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6918471797017300992/. We are also working with a  global end user who also see the huge potential in this platform. Let me know if I can provide you with any other info.

Author: jhisw
Content:
Hi everyone üëã  I want to build a simple "IIoT"-Counter. Say I have a PLC and a publisher that polls the PLC for a boolean variable.
PLC <- Publisher -> MQTT Broker <--sub-- Counter

What we want is report-by-exception, so the value should only be published when it changed.

How would you do it on startup of the publisher and counter system?
I think the Publisher should publish the current state it observes on startup. Let's say the published boolean is true on startup.

I see two possibilities now:
Either the messages are retained. Then the Counter would store the first message as a current state.
Or the messages aren't retained, so every message is a new observation of the process variable. But in that case, I still couldn't count up, because if the Publisher just started up, it only published its first observation, not an actual change of the signal.

What are your thoughts on this?

Author: torije
Content: What would the counter be in this example, just a visualization in a dashboard? Which solution fits depends a bit on how worried you would be about losing track of the count, if the "truth" is a variable in the PLC that counts upwards, I'd say using retain in the broker is a very decent option. In that case, if the publisher or counter services restarts or shuts down, when you come back online, as long as the broker is running you'll be initializing the counter service with the last known good value. As soon as that changes, a new value is published and the counter updated. But again, kinda depends on the case.

Author: jhisw
Content:
Thanks for your answer. The PLC doesn't count up. It only has a boolean. A binar sensor or whatever. And I want to count how often the sensor becomes true.
The counter could be visualized on a dashboard, yes.

Author: torije
Content: Ah, in that case it's a bit different. Depending on your other requirements, you can either add the business logic to calculate the counter-variable either on the publisher, or on the subscriber. I would add persistence to the point where you do the calculation, for example if you wanted to publish the correct counter-variable and not just the boolean, you would add the logic in the publisher. Then you can choose to either rely only on the brokers retain setting, or adding some persistence to the publisher. If you want to publish only booleans, the brokers retain setting isn't going to do you any good, instead you'd need persistence in the subscriber. You could also choose to say that the subscriber has the logic for doing calculations, and then publish the counter value back into the broker.

Author: jhisw
Content:
I see the persistence on the side of the subscriber (the counter) and not relying only on the brokers retain capabilit (interesting point though. haven't thought about it like that yet).
The publisher should only publish the current process variables.
So the approach is exactly like you mentioned in your last sentence. The subscriber is doing the calculations, persisting it and publishing the counter value back to the broker.

I think I will not retain the process variable and the counter will handle the first message it receives as a current state, remember it and only increment when the value was false and becomes true.
