Author: rickbullotta
Content: Not an IoT platform.  It's sort of a low-end "everything" ERP-ish thing, with an IoT add-on.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: 99.9999% of the time this is best done in the PLC.  It's trivial, with a built-in counter block in almost every PLC ever made.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: No matter what you do, there's a chance (likelihood) that the publisher will miss a boolean transition, since in most cases the actual reading of the PLC is still polled on a time basis, even if it reports out on an exception basis.  Technically it's still even possible that the PLC could miss it too, but far less likely.  Doing counters at the SCADA or other higher level is not very reliable.

Author: torije
Content:
Where's the fun in that though? Next you'll tell me that connecting the sensors to the PLC via 5g and storing the time series data in a blockchain isn't the optimal solution either... 

Got the impression that part of the idea here would be to test out the publish->mqtt->subscribe flow, otherwise fully agree with you. Stupid simple is a good thing if we actually care about the values being generated. 

If you're still eager on using the MQTT setup, perhaps a useful case could be to calculate a rate based on the counter and publish that?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Always keep in mind that the counter resolution (HZ) can never be more accurate than 2X your poll rate plus latency.  And will generally be less than that!

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
One approach is to retain the values in the broker, and check them against the sensor value when you start/restart the publisher. 
It's becomming a more common pattern to think in terms of actual state and desired state where the retained value in the broker is the actual state, and the sensor value is the desired state. The the publisher only publishes if the states are dofferent

Author: rickbullotta
Content: And truth be told, it‚Äôs  basically a crapshoot whether you‚Äôve missed  no state changes or 10000 state changes.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Even brokers that support QoS 2 have some limitations on retention and are slave to the ability of the publisher to store and forward.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
You're right @RickBullotta, but this is a problem for the publisher, not a problem of MQTT. It is the same problem if your publisher is a PLC or some python code running on a raspberry pi. Highly reliable, Fault tolerant systems are hard.
The question that was being asked was how do I prevent publishing initial values on a restart of the publisher. 
The questions that were not being asked are many, and include how do I ensure that even if I re-start a publisher, another is there to take over? How do I fail over to another publisher if this one dies? How do I know if this publisher has failed?

Never ending spiral it seems.  Hope you and Libre team are kicking butt!

Author: trouble_d.
Content:
Im currently using RabbitMQ as broker with MQTT plugin.. I'm looking forward to experiment with EMQ but i see some +- its nice if you can share your experience or opinion...

-   One missing features for RabbitMQ is QOS2 but im asking community what is real issue to don't have it ? For messages that need to be processed only once , I store additional data as "command_id" inside message its kind of workaround for processing clients... 
- RabbitMQ does not support MQTT5 and currently it is not required by any application or client but this can change and with RabbitMQ there is no plan in short time this will be integrated... We need to be flexible EMQ has support... MQTT5 is hire for while but nobody cares (take this with "" ) are we gonna wait for next gen?
- RabbitMQ give us benefit that we can use it directly with our APP messaging (backend use AMQP for messaging) ... There are no 2 messaging clusters we use Rabbit for MQTT and in-app comunication... This reduce app code (complexity)  since one broker and one client library is used... 
- I don't have 5milions active devices use-case as 90procent of apps.... I don't need to scale worldwide üôÇ So RabbitMQ is still optimal and bit more CPU usage is OK for this case... I think many Brokers and UN does not need to scale like gas industry requirements is... The same is in IT world we call it "You are not the Facebook" if you understand...

Is anybody using RabbitMQ and EMQX or migrate from one to another to add some points to this ?

Author: jermuk
trouble_d.
Content: To presist state you can also use Rabbit MQ that is more easy to maintain than kafka... How do you handle the limit of topic that kafka can have ? just if you use sparkplug data struct or how you structure your data in topics ? Im also Kafka user but using it a side from MQTT not all goes to kafka...

Author: geoffnunan
Content: How does kafka help the publisher know what to publish when it start up after a failure? It still comes down to desired state versus actual state, where desired state is the sensor value, and actual state is the value that was last published. You either have to read that from a retained value on an MQTT topic, or you have to read it from Kafka, I guess I don't see the value in the extra overhead of Kafka? I have not done much with Kafka so might be missing something entirely

Author: jermuk
Content: what do you mean by the limit of topics in Kafka? or do you mean the count of partitions? we structure it according to our datamodel (https://docs.umh.app/docs/concepts/mqtt/), where we have for each "high integrity datapoint"  like orders, produced pieces, etc. a seperate topic and then one single topic for each asset for processValues optimized in the processing for high throughput. and then not every message actually lands up in the corporate cloud kafka broker, only the relevant / aggregated ones. we typically use a kafka broker and mqtt broker for each factory to do already some data processing.

Author: jermuk
Content:
lets take an example of "amount of produced pieces". there is one light barrier providing the distance. from the distance there is a microservice sending an mqtt message each time something has been produced (A). and then there is a microservice counting the total amount of produced pieces (B). the total amount (state) could be persisted in a retained mqtt message. 

lets imagine now following scenario:
microservice A gets somehow stuck and delays the processing of 10 count messages. B recieves them all at one time, before writing the final state in the retained mqtt message it crashes. now the information of the 10 count messages is lost. with kafka (and some implementation) you can easily ensure that each message is processed exactly once (not only delivered once). in this case B after reboot would automatically reprocess these 10 messages and write the state again (without processing a message twice or never) --> exactly once processing

there are various deviations from this case (microservice gets overloaded with messages, state is calculated by the mean average of the last 100 seconds and then there is a fail;ing microservice, etc.)

i hope that gives you an idea

Author: jermuk
Content: these are mostly rare edge cases with a very low probability, but the probability is never 0. as soon as you scale out, you will encounter these kinds of stuff more and more

Author: jhisw
Content: Looking forward to reading our article!

Author: jhisw
Content:
Interesting to see where this is going once the whole architecture starts growing.

I think, for taking a retained value or not on startup, it depends whether you have a highly available broker or just starting out with a few docker containers on a Pi.
In the first case, the last state could be fetched from a retained value, while the latter case would require to publish on startup anyway. The counter would regard the first message in either case as "This is the current state. Now let's wait to see a state change from false to true, to count up."

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I guess this is a somewhat contrived example, as I'd rather put the count where the event occurs.. but there are probably better examples of this from the business logic side of things.. I understand that Kafka and mqtt is a fairly common combination in microservice architectures, but I'm still on the fence on the benefits vs the drawbacks for Kafka to maintain current state in a manufacturing architecture context. On a side note, this debate made me think of a debate I had back in the days with a guy in IT (I'm OT), about using UDP vs TCP. He posed the question, but what if the message gets lost using UDP?! Well, it's a real-time system, if it's an old message, we don't care. Can't have the system act on what happened in the past. Just as an example of one of the underlying differences in IT and OT.

Author: kiwimalice

Author: jermuk
Content: this is a good point. you need to do trade-offs. we are for example saying that the "business related information" needs to be at-least-once (new order, etc.) and that this information cannot get lost under any circumstance. But then to reduce the overhead we have a "high throughput" channel / topics for stuff like temperature, x-axis position, etc. where it is fine when sometimes data points gets missing

Author: jhisw
Content:
If you just publish the new order to a specific topic, and it isn't read in a timely fashion, you may have yet another order that you want to publish and override the former order message.
I read about mqtt5 publish-request pattern today. Wouldn't that be a solution, at least if we know for sure that there's only one consumer of the order message?
Publish order -> not getting an answer -> storing it as "not processed" -> trying again later (doing this for every order that wasn't acknowledged)

Author: jermuk
Content: good point with the overriding of retained messages. unfortunately, the mqtt standard does not provide tips on the implementation of the pattern you mentioned and naive implementations will probably suffer from similar challenges (e.g., most MQTT brokers store messgaes only in RAM and only buffer it to disk every x minutes). what I think would be absolutely great would be an mqtt broker that is using kafka in their backend to ensure this type of stuff. until then, I think there is no way around kafka in complex setups

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Solace use kafka behind their mqtt broker to enable reliable messaging over mqtt.
[Edit].It turns out Im wrong on this. While Solace queues look and smell just like kafka, they are not kafka. Solace have a series of blog posts explaing how they are different.

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: MQTT to Queue messaging in Solace use Kafka behind the scene?

Author: jermuk
Content: interesting

Author: dep05d
Content: This isn't quite correct.  Solace converts all protocols to it's own internal format for transport, and guaranteed delivery queues and retain message stores use disk storage.  It can also guarantee delivery between brokers in a mesh, send retain messages to other brokers, etc.  However, there are also external Kafka source/sink connectors that could be used for similar purposes.

Author: ianskerrett.
Content: fwiw, HiveMQ persists data to storage not in RAM. This is exactly why we don't lose messages.

Author: jhisw
Content:
I think there's another problem in 2.A., that isn't mentioned in the article. The fourth disadvantage is, that the topic can only have exactly one subscriber.
Zero subscribers would mean, no entity is there to acknowledge the processing of the message. And more than one subscribers would raise the question, who is supposed to acknowledge its being processed.
So you'd lose the many-to-many characteristic of MQTT.

Author: jermuk
Content: I think there are two ways of ackonowledging. the ones mentioned in the article (using the MQTT protocol and QoS > 0) and what you described using additional acknowledgement messages. interesting method, but it will cuase the issue that you just mentioned

Author: mparris
Content:
If all data for an equipment screen is published over MQTT, one can now remotely view the same screen from their phone just as the data is being seen on the shop floor.

I have considered the ability to "replay" data as a troubleshooting tool, similar to a DVR. If someone notes that something unique happened, an engineer could call up the timestamp and playback the data at some speed to review.

Sounds like Kafka should do the trick?

Author: jermuk
Content: Kafka is used very often as a "replay" tool for development of software (take some data from production and insert it again and again in a development setup). we use it additionally to troubleshoot malformed messages by taking a look into the log. for IT engineers this is a really great tool. for OT engineers troubleshooting a problem not in the software but on the machine I think a proper database like timescaledb in combination with grafana would be better suited (better UI, less complexity, longer time ranges e.g. comparing the temperature with the temperature of the last year)

Content: Good morning everyone.(at least there is morning here in Sweden).. I am atm looking for a new platform to our company.. Today we are using a pretty basic one from a local vendor here but the functionality is very limited which results in that i need to do all the special functions using node red and then embed my node red pages in our platform.. Our nodes are mostly loraWAN devices which we connect to a few gateways.. We do also have some OPC-UA servers running on Siemens PLC which we use some live data from.. As we are a small company and we have smaller individual production lines we do not want to spend to much money on a big IIoT platform.... It would also be nice to have easy visualization.. As it looks now i am the only developer since the programming skills in the rest of the company is limited.. So a platform where it is easy drag and drop for visualization would be good.. Anyone have an idea ?

Author: torije
Content:
There are quite a few devices that should be able to do the data acquisition part for you. If you want a physical device, you could look to something like an Opto22 RIO where you can use drivers for Node-RED to connect your different equipment. Or you could run some software for integration, like Node-RED (https://nodered.org/), Telegraf (https://www.influxdata.com/time-series-platform/telegraf/) or Crosser (https://crosser.io/) on an existing piece of hardware. There are also physical gateways, like Moxa (https://www.moxa.com/en/spotlight/industrial-computing/cloud-ready-iiot-edge-gateway/index.htm), Opto22 (https://www.opto22.com/products/groov-rio) or SIA (https://sia-connect.com/) and a whooole lot more. 

I am of course biased, but visualization of time series data is easy to get started with in Clarify (https://www.clarify.io/). There are many alternatives like https://grafana.com/, https://braincube.com/ or even https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/solutions/industry/manufacturing/iot/#overview 

I'll say this though - if you put in the effort of organizing your data in the field, converting your OPC UA tags, metrics from LoraWAN, etc. into a cohesive structure using (for example) MQTT + Sparkplug B - you can test multiple solutions for visualization, and when you want to expand your usage to start with anomaly detection, automatic reporting, combining data from multiple sites etc. You'll have the foundation to build upon instead of re-doing a ton of work organizing your tags in each new system.

Example setup: Node-RED (read from OPC UA, LoraWAN devices etc.) -> Sparkplug B -> MQTT Broker -> Clarify (Storage and drag-and-drop visualization). Perfect solution? Of course not, but it's a solid start.

At the beginning it felt quite complexwith helmet chart / kubernetes, especially as an mechanical engineers, but after spending some time on learning programming it starts to make sense and IT likes it as well. As you seem to be a programmer you might have a better start than me. I have now already connected some Siemens S7 and a rockwell using opc. Author: jermuk
Content: tricky situation üòÑ

Author: jermuk
Content:
i would probably start by setting up a MQTT broker (they call it in this discord "unified namespace") and start sending data through it. with this, you are doing nothing wrong. 

additionally, you can start to structure your node-red flows a little bit (basically making a flow always very short, for example one flow just sending data to mqtt, then one flow just taking it from mqtt, processing it and then returning the result, and then one sending it to other datasources). that alone might provide you with some more overview over node-red.

this might help you in progressing with the project to the point where you can show the impact of that. 

i think on the long term your company needs to be able to handle at least Node-RED flows (or any equivalent to it) as it is hard to find anything that is easier

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Ironically we push the boundaries of Tulip more than most. B&D Stanly is using it for EXACTLY what it was designed for. We're using it for extensive machine monitoring, not just for digitized work instructions, manual assembly and inspection. We find the edge cases üôÇ

Author: torije
Content: How responsive are they to feedback? If you're pushing the boundaries, I'm guessing you probably hit some walls in the product at times

Author: hobbes1069
Content: They only have specific time buckets (Today, Yesterday, Current Week, Current Month, etc). We have a four shift 24/7 operation with shift changes at 5 am/pm. I had to get VERY creative to work around that limitation.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Basically, we have the shift schedule in a Tulip table, and then created a connector function (custom REST call) which I'm polling from Node Red to get the current shift. Then I take the result and publish it via MQTT to my EMQx broker which I then pull in to Kepserver via their IoT gateway and pipe that back into the Tulip machine as a machine attribute then the shift gets written into every record of machine state change. Which can then be used to filter in analytics. üôÇ

Author: torije
Content: Hah! That has to qualify as VERY creative üò¨ I guess that answers my question about their responsiveness to feedback...

Author: hobbes1069
Content: They do accept a lot of input from us, and we've actually provided a lot of "feedback" around MQTT support, which we now hear is "coming".

The intention here is to find something that can manage that gap and can be connected to our current ecosystem (UNS, MQTT and current web apps).

Author: rickbullotta
Content: One issue ThingWorx doesn't have is limited connectivity.  It can connect to just about anything.  The challenges are around pricing, scaling for extremely large systems, and a bit dated tech stack/user experience.

Author: p.j.leblanc
Content: Isn't the ThingWorx (connectivity) server basically Kepware?

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
For devices and such, yes, Kepware, but it can connect to lots and lots of other stuff, including other IoT and IIoT clouds/platforms, and almost any system in use today.  The usual stuff like SQL DB's, REST APIs, MQTT, and so on, plus a lot of 3rd party add-ons for connectivity and other functionality.  The pricing can be prohibitive for many though.  And the MQTT integration isn't ideal.

https://marketplace.ptc.com/productLines/280#!/list/page/1

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Right now I'm trying to integrate a Rio with a UR Robot and working on finding a common "language" to share information. I started with NodeRed and MODBUS but it's not working right. Someone pointed out that a company makes a MQTT URCap for the UR robots. Overall MQTT has been very reliable for us. I have mosquitto running alongside Kepserver in the cloud but I didn't want to rely on external connections. So I decided I can create a "mini" UNS for the cell and then either also publish to an external broker for try my hand at bridging since I haven't had a opportunity to try that yet.

Author: jermuk
Content:
were are also doing it quite often. maybe not on the PLC, but on a seperate ipc at the edge as a tool to ensure that people on that device can work with the data, e.g., create new node-red flows. much better to do it there instead of a central server, where you might loose overview if you have 50 custom flows running. also it provides the automation engineer with more control instead of sending it to a random VM, where IT is blocking him to access it.

its more of an organizational topic for us than that it is actually required from an architectural perspective.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: This is where having both OT and IT tools comes in handy.  The OT side of things runs things on the edge, while the IT side handles things from a central point.  So, in this case, new flows or analyses could be developed centrally using an OT system in a pilot plant (or if a facility has a best practice that could be used), and then deployed out via the IT tool that controls the software instances from a central point.  Further, while the analyses can be useful at the edge, they probably provide a lot more value if they can be compared across the organization.

Author: luis_gastao
Content:
I went through an evaluation process with them.  They have some cool features for MES,OEE, etc.
I recommended against it at my company because of the following:
1) integration/‚Äúnamespace‚Äù is done through a data lake.
That is not the best approach (or an approach at all) for integration, creating a UNS, etc
2) pricing model is through contracts (eg: need to sign a X year contract with them, and you locked)
3) solution was extremely expensive. I think what they wanted to charge for a POC was the cost of the entire solution we are architecting with ignition, which will be open architecture, technology driven .

Author: luis_gastao
Content:
4) there was no free trial.
The trial would have to be through an expensive POC

Author: luis_gastao
Content: 5) also, I think the solution is somewhat new. Which is not necessarily a problem, but I just wasn‚Äôt sure about stability, flexibility, scalability from what they presented

Author: luis_gastao
Content: If you are looking for something more prebuilt, that wouldn‚Äôt require much development, there are some integrators that can help, while still allowing for a open architecture solution

Author: ivangap.
Content:
Hello David,
We are an automotive Tier 1 vendor.
We run bout 20 production lines where we have several PLCs, welding controllers, sensors and IOT devices.
In addition, we run SAP ERP and our in-house developed MES where we carry out work order management, scheduling, downtime control and OEE
We need to set up a Unified Name Space to collect and organize data from these devices and systems
I need to be able to subscribe PLC, ERP, MES, etc. to this namespace so I can use information from any of these sources, process it further and post back resulting new information to the UNS
We area a relatively new facility in business for around 4 years
Most of our machines, technology and infrastructure is relatively new and state of the art

Author: omarazizahmed
Content: @ivangap. . I am intrigued.......This is very interesting. Where are you now? What stage? Are you looking to publish Kepware data directly to the namespace? You would probably want to model it first. What about the sensors? Do they communicate over OPC UA or MQTT? What historian are you using? I see you have references a few companies on the right side. HighByte being one of them. I do work at HighByte. This seems like a good initial approach. Besides creating a UNS, a good idea is a use case. What is one thing you are trying to solve. More importantly, how can you use the UNS to solve a business problem quicker and in a more scalable approach. The what information can you more easily and more readily marry together to solve for an application.

Author: akoscs
Content: Quick question, did anyone hit a performance limit with NodeRed when used as reading opc-ua and dumping it in a data base? I would assume, since it is single threaded, performance will degrade at a few hundred variables, right?

Author: jermuk
Content: you could montior the CPU consumption and find out. but could also be caused by the database. writing a lot of tags into databases are typically done using batch inserts instead of single INSERTS

Author: nickn5549
Content: I would say much more than hundreds on any decent hardware/VM. I have 100 flows 'manipulating data' (polling from DB to UNS, DataOps, OEE calculations) and one instance of Node-Red doesn't hit the ceiling (4xcores CPU avg 25% on the server). If you need more - run more Node-Red instances... Some of the flows are moving around serious payloads - whole BOMs, whole MO traceability data...

Author: jon.forbord
Content: How did you setup your OPC UA flows, You might hit limits on the number of sessions on the OPC UA server if you don‚Äôt setup the flows correctly.. as each ‚Äútag‚Äù will then be another UA session.

Author: akoscs
Content: It was more of a theoretical question, before I begin something that will not work is there a way to set up the OPC-UA flows properly?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Single threaded can sometimes increase performance. It‚Äôs been a while, and it happened to me when I copy pasted a flow from the internet somewhere, and then copy pasted x number of instances of that flow üòù

Author: eddiiee_
Content:
Hello guys! I've recently stumbled across a surprising issue in my company. I'm quite new to this discord and the new way of thinking industry 4.0 as well. Been working with industry 4.0 projects like Process control through multivariate data analytics, Object defect detection with machine learning and big data analytics for business. With that said my knowledge in IIoT is limited, but i strive to improve everyday.

Back to the problem. The Digital manufacturing team in IT has sold in a new "Digital Core" with the updated ERP, new MES, some other core system for us + ignition as unified name space. This has been implemented at 4 factory sites and are now implemented at 2 sites that I govern over. That's when I figured out that it's not actually the new IIoT architecture they are implementing. They have a traditional integration in an isolated way between ERP, MES, Sharepoint, print&apply and some more. Then they are dumping the datamodel from MES to Ignition to prepare for a future IIoT network. But to my understanding that will create a need for redoing all integrations that currently goes through MES to go through Ignition in firsthand, to strive towards a single source of truth. No one has really been questioning this before since it's the common way of integrating. Do you have any recommendations how I can proceed with this? I have talked with upper management and they agree it's not correct but it's hard to change a decided project spanning over both ERP&MES. I feel I need some quick concrete clarifying results to show why to change. Any suggestions?

TLDR:
1. The IT team has sold in to management that they are implementing IIoT with ignition
2. What we are getting is the traditional automation stack with point to point integrations
3. This has been done at 4 factory sites, now it's time for 2 sites that concerns me
4. They agree with the arguments but that's not enough. How can I show that this is not the future in a concrete way. Suggestions?

Author: eddiiee_
Content:
//Best Regards
Edvard

Author: andersgustav
Content:
God morgen Edvard.
Build a UNS-architecture next to the existing system using MQTT/SpB. Demonstrate them the value  and win the results war.
You will not be able to convince anyone to replace what they have done - but you might be able to get to add to it.

Author: jermuk
Content: you could talk about the direct and indirect costs for maintaining the point-to-point system and try to get at least one plant or a couple of factory lines based on UNS. then you have a better foundation in a couple of years when their current automation stack explodes in terms of complexity and costs. changing something now will probably be already too late and they will think that you just want to block their ongoing project. or go for the parallel approach

Author: eddiiee_
Content: Demonstrate the value and win the results war, I know that reference. And that's the tricky question. What are the results that I need to produce to show it. Won't be possible to develope two architectures side by side, it has to be a small proof-of-concpet that delivers value. hmm still thinking about it...

Author: eddiiee_
Content: That might be doable. To integrate one or two factory lines parallell in UNS and prove the value by adding more information and visualize it. The point will be that with traditional integration all that information won't be doable in a reasonable amount of time or cost. Or if they disagree, then we have made a case for them to invest and implement and either way we will improve. Does that make sense?

I guess i have to look outside for that, any recommendations?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Apparently ‚Äúnobody‚Äù invests in architecture, so you‚Äôre more likely to succeed if you rather build in architectural improvements as part of every project, and build it brick by brick. It‚Äôs also really hard to convince anyone to rebuild the structure for the sake of future theoretical benefits. In what area of the stack do you actually possess some influence on decisions?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: And I‚Äôll second @Anders Gustav to look for some outside eyes on your digital transformation!

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Find a useful business problem that relies on structure/consistency from the endpoints across your plants that you currently don‚Äôt have. If the use case can also leverage two or more nodes in your software ecosystem even better. The scalability problem should show itself pretty quickly. Like others have pointed out find some like thinkers within the org to help form your case and ideas. These conversations can be hard to sell sometimes but get easier when the noise gets louder.

Author: eddiiee_
Content:
The direct areas of influence is in the OT area of the automation stack where i have the responsibility to give recommendations for guidelines, which could very well be mandatory. Currently there are few or none recommendations and a very decentralized organisation. Which in itself can be good, but currently the competence level for the decision that are made in the OT-area are not leveled. Thoughts?

The decision has already been done for the 2 factories and won't be rebuilt. But there is an opportunity to do different for future implementations and that's where I would like to put my effort.

Author: eddiiee_
Content: Do you have any concrete Proof-of-concepts that have been made elsewhere? I'm thinking an obvious one for us is maintenance. Currently maintenance is mostly time-based and in best case condition-based though rare. If we could utilize machine data, maintenance system data and production data to show how the value of an unified information structure and of visualizing data from 2-3 nodes, with the potential of predictive within reach. Though this demands a quite high competence and willingness to learn and change from that department which in my experience is usually the more traditional area.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Alright! I‚Äôd set the MTR as the basis for all OT, and focus on requirements for data modeling, such as a standard for machine state (to be used for OEE and machine learning). The other plants can be handled as legacy integrations when you‚Äôve won everyone over ü•≥

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Predicative maintenance isn‚Äôt where I‚Äôd start. That would be further down the line, but a good thing to lay the groundwork for as you go along. Start talking to the people on the ‚Äúplant floor‚Äù and find out what their problems are. Ask them ‚Äúwhat one thing, if fixed, would make your job a lot easier?‚Äù and questions like this. I‚Äôd bet there‚Äôs a shit-ton of problems that never gets fixed because they‚Äôre low value.

Author: johndevenney
Content: You may want to start with tracking OEE and alarms in some machines or processes that have a PLC. Find some machines or processes that the operators say has a lot of short stoppages (i.e.. door, light curtain, and/ or part clamp alarms). This will show the accumulated loss of production, then once you know what the alarm is correct the issue. This will show the value of what you are trying to achieve and help gain supporters from other groups within your organization.

Author: itami0432
Content: Hey, is anyone here familiar with using Cellular networks for IIoT connectivity instead of the traditional internet connection ? I am just starting to research the concept and hoping to get some insights.

Author: itami0432
Content: ^ sorry for the vague question, kind of an amateur here

Author: itami0432
Content: for example,  I need to establish a connection from a historian to AWS. I have already explored the option of using a gateway device (running aws greengrass in my case) that will take in the data and send it to the cloud through an https connection. But I am wondering if I can send this data over cellular networks instead and if this will bypass any firewall issues on-site

Author: itami0432
Content: I guess I am asking about cellular vs ethernet for sending data from an on-site device to the cloud, as you can see not an expert here

Author: jermuk
Content:
Some thoughts:
- if your connection is bad and dropping often, https might not be the best protocol as it has a lot of initial overhead when connecting. MQTT might be a better alternative 
- depending on the data volume and cellular connection, it might not be enough to to connect an on-site historian 
- bypassing the companies firewall might sound like the quicker solution, but there are reasons why the firewall is setup like this. I recommend cellular options only in early stages where the value of an implementation is still unclear.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Yeah, we've seen a few applications where cell service is being considered over a wifi connection.  Essentially it comes down to bypassing the internal infrastructure to get to the cloud.  As @Jermuk mentioned, this is especially advantageous in early applications, though we have also seen this as a preferred architecture with OEMs and skid manufacturers that want to monitor their equipment in the field without having to interface with the local network.  In applications where there is a spotty network connection, there are platforms that have store and forward capability that should be able to help out.

Author: ary4053
Content: Hi, looking for a proven Energy (Kwh) and water flow (gal/h) wireless IIoT sensors. Any input? Thanks

Author: rickbullotta
Content: You also need to consider signal strength and electrical interference when trying to apply cellular/wireless tech in an industrial setting.

Author: mithrand0696
Content:
Hi all, still learning the ropes here, could use some guidance. I am just wondering whether Ignition Edge must always be paired with Ignition Server?
If we want to perform OEE and record downtime reasons can we just use Ignition Edge and connect to AWS IOT ecosystem?

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Yeah, the rebar in concrete tends to do a good job at imitating a faraday cage.  This is one of the nice things about newer wireless tech/standards like ISA100 and 5G, they both use mesh networks to get the job done, so many more routes to a main hub and usually shorter hops as well.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ‚ÄúSell moar hardware‚Äù

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
Of course, I'm in sales, that's the ultimate goal üòÇ 

Seriously though, the new mesh stuff is great because the repeaters actually have some value aside from just receiving and transmitting, plus you usually have a bunch of wireless sensors between the furthest part and the hub, so you can be pretty sure about the signal strength readings since there will be multiple pathways back.  I remember having to design and install 434MHz point to point systems and getting a reading that was pretty reliable (non-critical systems in a more commercial environment) in commissioning, but once people started walking around the place the signal would start to really degrade, which would usually mean a repeater.  This would have been solved had there been mesh networking at the time because it was only the furthest sensors that were flaking out, but still required a repeater to boost the signal.

Author: patanj2
Content: No.  You don‚Äôt necessarily need  Ignition server of your goal is just to publish data.  Depending on what additional functionality I.e modules that you want,  at a certain point you should just buy full Ignition.  A nice thing is that you can figure out exactly what you need with the trial license.

Is there any limits on AWS reporting where its just not possible to do it there?

Author: nickn5549
Content: Overall great stuff (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WgEeaNxNb9w) about WHY you need to transform digitally and WHY you need to do DTMA. Great tangent regarding the generations divide and why you won't be able to keep any young employee if you ask them to do dinosaurs' age tasks - shovelling paper around and being copy-paste junkies... Dinosaurs died and agile creatures (mammals) took over.  About HOW to do DTMA...it still sounded like a teaser... our DTMA is great the other ones are sh*t.  Only some hints were dropped here and there about the pillars of the 4.0 Solutions DTMA...which felt to me, a bit far from the promise of  the title of the podcast 'Answering your questions on DT and DTMA'. I liked the podcast, but it didn't answer my DTMA questions... I was expecting more of a DTMA revelation....maybe I was naive or fooled by the promise of the title.  One thing though, the first time when the DTMA sh*t list was mentioned in the video, SIRI didn't make it in the sh*t list (flawed assessment processes), the second time it did - with a remark about what NOT to DO - "I'm not talking about SIRI's assessment in Europe" (1:13:43 timestamp). Care to elaborate? From all the hints that I get from 4.0 Solutions regarding their DTMA and comparing that with what SIRI (from Europe, it might be from TUV, but is the official DT assessment embraced by Singapore and shared for free with the world) does, I get that they are very similar... WHY? They work, assess you against meaningful pillars, put you on an I3-4.0 scale, and compare your score with all the major industries. With outputs from it, you can definitely go ahead and write your startegy, architecture, technical minimum requirements and also see what potentially can hinder your progress and what to do to avoid it.

Content: I got pulled into Digitization at work, right now mostly Tulip, but I found Walker's IIoT rant and it was game over after that. Couldn't watch enough. Now fastfoward a year of so. We still have Tulip as our primary "Hammer" for all "nails" but we're finally starting to put in some real cloud architecture.

Author: lucasj8094
Content:
Hi all, 
My company is currently evaluating Litmus Edge vs. OSI PI System as our options for IIoT, and I was wondering if anyone has experience with one or the other. Especially interested if anyone has experience with both systems.
Thank you!

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: While there's some overlap in functionality, they are two very different platforms that accomplish that overlap in very different ways.  They could also be very complimentary (I know much more about PI - would leave Litmus to @Ryan Kershaw).  What is your ultimate goal?

Author: nickn5549
Content: I saw too much paper on the Shop Floor and too much firefighting caused by paper records discrepancies...that was 10 years ago...I took it on me to fix that. 10 years later, the paper is almost gone and once introduced to UNS, I can see clearly how the whole thing can be improved further... Having said that the roots are much deeper....25 years ago when I started in EMS, working for big US Corp Solectron, brand new SMT lines fully automated and they wanted us to do shift handover on paper with signatures...what? why didn't a graduate computer science and industrial automation? to start filling out papers? And here you go...first little system was up in no time...few years forward we've had all the SMT lines connected and monitored...ahead of the times...at least after that Solectron learnt early and created an internal software development dept.  on top of their MES division

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Quite honestly I wouldn‚Äôt look at solutions first.  I look at the pieces you need relative to the problems you are trying to solve.  Then understand what capabilities you have and what ones you need.  Then build out accordingly but do so with some sense of vision tied back to business value.

Author: lucasj8094
Content: Even though that may be the best path overall, with the way our company works, each separate "piece" I try to bring on is a HUGE process to go through IT approval and all that. So we're looking for something that's scalable and flexible and can grow with our business needs. And in my mind the fact that Litmus opens up the docker world to us is a big bonus. Not that we couldn't adopt docker otherwise, but getting that approved separately would probably be another 6 month ordeal.

Author: lucasj8094
Content: Our first use case is actually fairly simple. We'd like to be able to remotely monitor and control some rooftop cooling units that speak Bacnet. Initially we don't really need the historian piece of the OSI PI Data historian, we're looking for live monitoring with alerts for the facilities guys so they don't have to run around the building all the time. Since you're familiar with the OSI system, do you find that most implementations end up using Kepserver EX to communicate with Allen Bradely PLCs?

Author: jpmoniz
Content: If your looking for docker capabilities I would look at cloud platforms to provide that service rather than a product.  Azure stack edge is a good example of that.  You might want to take a look at what the guys at 4ir Solutions are doing with containerized ignition deployments.  As far as OSI goes I‚Äôm actually not that familiar with it. One of our divisions uses it and yes they use kepware with it as well. If you looking for a historian I would give canary a look.  I still stress to look at the bigger picture and understand how all of the products will integrate within your environment.

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: Kepserver EX has been very common in cases where you anticipate a diverse set of data sources outside of AB.  OSI also has a couple of options to speak BacNet and OPC.  Litmus Edge would be a more modern alternative to any of those from an OT integration perspective.  Our software Quartic.ai can also do similar things as PI, like monitor and alert, and  also can leverage ML to optimize and provide recommended setpoints to operators.  We also have everything containerized and can run from edge to cloud.

Content: @Richard Shaw @youri.regnaud @MRIIOT @TNTony whats up guys. complete newbie here when it comes it CNC machines but I'm pretty familiar with IoT devices. I'm curious, what kind of use cases have you guys seen for IoT and CNC machines?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: We use Kepserver to interface with CNC machines and PLCs to pull tags for uptime and reporting.

Author: mr.rippie
Content: What is a tag? And where does the IOT come in? What kind of devices and sensors are you guys using for the CNCs?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Looks like you're starting from scratch so too much to explain in one message but google is your friend. "Tags" can be used in a universal sense, in that it's data from a machine. In PLC nomenclature it's a specific data point (the state of IO or other information). Kepserver also uses the word "tag". In MQTT it would be "topic". So in general a "tag" is the value of a data point at a point in time.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Some tags may not frequently change value, others may change multiple times a second.

Author: mriiot
Content: Depends on the cnc controller as to what data is already available, but you can always add vibration and temperature sensors for predictive

Author: mr.rippie
Content: Thank you for that explanation. I'm just getting familiar with the manufacturing jargon so I apologize if some questions seem elementary. It seems to me like your definition of tag is synonymous to datapoint or sample which is embedded system jargon for me.

Author: mr.rippie
Content: What are some common sensing applications you've seen with cnc machines and what are some you would like to see in the future (if any)?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Like @MRIIOT mentioned. There's tons of data you can get directly from the controller, but common sensors to add would be vibration to check for spindle or axis wear.

Author: newtonfernandez
Content: Hello guys, how are you doing? Last week I had a conversation with a costumer about his digital transformation journey. He told me he understood the benefits of IoT (edge driven, based on technology, etc.) But he mentioned that, considering a green field, it is very clear that everyone should start using IIoT. He doubts about brown field, where already there are some well know systems like PIMS, MES, Power BI, Analytics, OSISoft PI... according to him, the cost/benefit does not work here, once that the systems they have today are nor prepared for "cloud" or even UNS (MQTT, for example). So, how to argue against these points? How would be the process for integrating the brown field on the IIoT era? I would appreciate your thoughts.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I would guess that 99.5% of my customers at ThingWorx were brownfield.  That's the norm, not the exception.  And with the right platform choices, you can connect to and abstract away legacy quite well.   Bottom line, your customer should moving with their digital transformation - legacy is no excuse!

Author: jon.forbord
Content: What @RickBullotta said. Brownfield is added using gateways. And if the customer thinks they dont have a problem, he‚Äôs in the stage 0 of Digital transformation. First step is to realize they have a problem. What things do they struggle to achieve with their current setup? Are they able to scale their initiatives? What problems are their rank and file not able to or don‚Äôt have the time to solve?

Author: ryankershaw
Content: No, this is something different from us.  I'm trying to get some info from our guy that works with Google, but this is different from their Manufacturing Data Engine, which we're part of.  https://cloud.google.com/solutions/manufacturing-data-engine

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Right, so from what I hear, we (Litmus) were not that involved with the Core IoT platform.  We were, and still are, part of the Manufacturing Data Engine (MDE).  The take, at least from our perspective (aka, not official Google), is that Core IoT was the individual device authentication, streaming and data routing tool, and MDE is the data engineering platform.  Since MDE with the MC and MCe parts that we provide can do all of that, MDE essentially became the de facto industrial platform.  Again, nothing official, but hopefully gives a bit of background.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: https://steve-yegge.medium.com/dear-google-cloud-your-deprecation-policy-is-killing-you-ee7525dc05dc

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Exactly this - two completely different things.  It might be good for Google to issue a PR to clarify some stuff.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Yeah, you think that would be part of it.  At least give some hope in the retirement statement, i.e. " we're shutting this down, but no worries, we'll get you ported over to MDE, or 'x'."  But yeah, Google still has manufacturing capabilities through MDE, which was the super awesome one thanks to its excellent MC and MCe components (I may be biased on this, FYI).

Author: andreasbackman
Content:
Think you need to give a bit more context here. What are you trying to achieve? 
Report by exception basically means that you push a new value to a topic when the value you're monitoring changes. That could be a temperature sensor you're sampling; each sample (if different from the previous one) is to be published to the broker.

Author: joshlawson9986
Content:
Hi just chime in, Siemens Xcelerator is more a like product portfolio than one solution as a whole. All the tools that are included of course will integrate to each other or run on their own.

Siemens Portfolio is pretty deep in terms coverage in industrial domains , probably I would say largest cross industry portfolios. They also strong I. The PLM space leveraging all the Engineering Tools and bridge ERP+Engineering+Execution, adding to this Simulation Tools for Engineering of product, Simulation of Engineering for Equipment , Simulation of Factory layout and operation , I think missed bit on this forum is I4.0 concepts are to simulate , before execute , then feedback to simulation and back to Engineering... IE closed loop processes. 

Seimens is solutions are not perfect , no one company can do all, but the mix of capability they have access engineering to execute and data capture is not matched  by other companies as a one stop shop.

They are like a SI that has purchased the tools over time and integrate them, aka Siemens Xcelerator.

Of course they get technical debt on this and will take time to really be 100% potential...

Content:
Siemens generally not locking up their tools for their use only you can use them and integrate pending the technical options carried by the tools of interest...

Of course in mix is low code app frame from Mendix also a Siemens company...

Siemens Tia portal is for Siemens PLC/Automation ecosystem . Not across this as I general left PLC stuff while ago while used to use Siemens PLC in me electrical days pre TIA ...I'm a old bugger...

How TIA it is interoperable with other systems can not say as not personally dived into this...

They of course offer many more tools across the stack for business as stated Engineering Ideation Mechanical-electrical-eletronics-semicon Engineering Simulation, PLM , Planning, MES for Targeted Industry, medical, pharma, process, electronics assembly ( this is my main domain), mechanical, machining, semiconductor so...broad church as they say ..

My interaction with Siemens is I sell there solutions for Electronics Manufacturing and they have generally open interfaces and APIs for SI work loads...I been working on MQTT plugin for publish events from the PCBA(PLM)Valor Process Preparation tool  clients as they running by the users , testing this now with a client Aka Nick Niculita here in i4.0 forum etc.

I believe statement is a general one from Siemens, that they believe in this but will depend on the tools involved if open data interfaces is technically there...

I suppose we'll have to wait and see üòÜ and what ur doing sounds cool, the SI I work for does mostly Siemens PLCs and I've toyed with the idea of working for Siemens's Jersey hub if I hate myself enough one day.. so u could say I'm at least a bit invested in their long term outlook üòÖ

Author: andreasbackman
Content:
I've done a quick Siemens Industrial Edge evaluation for a customer and I must say I'm not really convinced.
On a concept level it's kinda ok, but when you get into the details it's a real pain in the ass. 
It's quite annoying when you know the tools running there, like docker, but you can't really get your hands on them as the OS is locked down and the only interface you have at your disposal is the web ui. So if there's a problem you just have to hope that you find some kind of logging that will disclose the underlying problem, but you might also be out of luck there. 
An analogy would be to think of it as a car that leaks oil, but has the hood bolted and you can't open to see where the leak comes from.
This was just one of several annoying things I found out the hard way....

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: This was a known issue of the Paho Java implementation a few years ago. I‚Äôm not sure if it still exists. The library thought that it still had a connection to the server but actually didn‚Äôt and therefore your application did not receive any messages anymore. The whole threading implementation back then was a big mess. At first we built a wrapper around the implementation which would send itself pings via MQTT to make sure the connection was still there and would automatically reconnect if it wasn‚Äôt. When the HiveMQ client library came out we switched to that one and never went back.

Author: gregory.g.
Content:
Hi guys, maybe a stupid question but how are the different MQTT versions interoperable? 
We have v3, v5, SpB, etc. I read for example a Siemens PLC (incl standard function blocks) works with v3. 
Any risks or certain remarks when you try to standardize on SpB? If you have any good videos or reading material on this topic.. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Author: hobbes1069
Content: At the broker level they're pretty much interoperable. But that's largely because MQTT is payload agnostic. Each client needs to be able to speak the same language.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
As far as distinct "protocols" it's more:
Vanilla 3.1.1
3.1.1 + SpB
5

Author: autopsias
Content: Well I think you might get quite a few applauses here where the majority of the audience is non MBA. But honestly I think you‚Äôre over generalising. There are plenty of MBAs like me which are also tech savvy and also want to make a difference in this space. MBA is not the issue in my view. skills, vision and mission is. Also don‚Äôt forget there is a reason the majority of the digital transformations fail even to get started, and one of the reasons is because in a lot of situations the business case is made in a non tangible way, or with rather flimsy arguments or comparisons with tech companies which were green field implementations . And then we want to blame the MBAs for not acting properly‚Ä¶ sometimes we need to do better as well to make things start.

Author: joshuastover

Author: andreasbackman
Content:
Had a first meeting with Litmus this morning with a client looking for an IIoT edge platform.
Anyone knows if they support SparkplugB for mapping proprietary device protocols to MQTT?
And how about writing into a UNS with the Litmus MQTT connector, what possibilities are there out of the box?
Maybe @Ryan Kershaw can shed some light on this? üôÇ

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @AndreasBackman, you just advanced to level 3!

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
If I couldn't shed at least a little bit of light on the subject, I'd probably be in a bit of trouble!
Yes we support SpB mapping, but not as a direct integration.  For now we would use our flows engine to make this happen.  This would mean building a connection, but once it's done once, it's easy to duplicate.  Honestly, if we haven't already built an integration for it, it's probably because we haven't been asked for it a lot or at all.  I would expect that if we had someone push the subject this would get automated pretty quickly.
As for the UNS question, the possibilities are endless.  MQTT is a standard integration, so we can pull data in from any source you connect to and send it to a UNS via the MQTT integration.  Data can be processed using flows beforehand so it's not raw data going to the UNS, and we can adjust reporting to reduce what is being sent (i.e. setup a hysteresis on an analog signal for a report by exception rule).

Author: andreasbackman
Content:
Sounds great!
Maybe I can ask for a SpB implementation now then which might tick another box for you in this customer case üòâ

Author: dep05d
Content: Do you think this is related to the fact that Sparkplug is very much an Ignition-centric technology at this point?  We have a large install base of Ignition and when looking at Litmus, it's been hard to find enough substantial differentiating factors between the tools, so I wonder if there is a divergence in user base.  While Litmus offers containerization, low code flows, many drivers etc, there is still a hump for us to overcome in terms of "Ignition could do it, even if not quite as easily" when justifying cost for an additional or replacement edge platform.  How would you describe the role Litmus plays alongside something like Ignition for data collection and processing at the edge?

Author: ryankershaw
Content: I'm pretty sure it's on the planning docket, but I know there are a few priorities that are being worked through at the moment.  Some really cool stuff that we're working on is all I can say at the moment.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
Might be.  If many of the applications that are using SpB are in an Ignition environment, we might not be getting the exposure to the demand, so to us it wouldn't seem like there's an urgent need to address.

As for the Ignition vs. Litmus question, it's one that comes up a lot.  Essentially (and remember I'm going to be biased on this one because of the name on my paycheque) it's a SCADA vs. IIoT comparison.  Ignition was born as a SCADA system and does that extremely well, while Litmus was born as an IIoT system and does that extremely well.  SCADA handles single plant applications well, is able to address topics such as recipe management and safety through processes that have been developed through years of experience and implementations.  IIoT handles multi-site applications well, and can make data more accessible and allow for more advanced applications through its ability to gather data and handle it on a large scale basis.  In many applications, we work in parallel with SCADA systems.  We let it handle the day-to-day operations of the plant, and we handle the larger strategic questions and continuous improvement applications.  If you want to make something, use SCADA, if you want to make it better, use IIoT.

If there was one thing I would highlight in the Ignition vs. Litmus discussion, it would be the Litmus Edge Manager (LEM) feature.  LEM doesn't actually work with any pieces of equipment, it only interfaces with any of the deployed edge platforms and allows for central management of the system.  While an organization with only one or two deployments may never touch it, anyone bigger than that considers it to be an essential part to managing the entire system.

Hope that helps!

Author: patanj2
Content: For one,  MQTT not an MQTT version,  it is a payload and messaging sequence definition on top of MQTT.  The risk of standardizing on SPB is that it is not really built into that many tools and it has other shortcomings like ‚Äúchunkiness‚Äù of messages,  meaning you may have to subscribe to 5000 tags even if you only want one for your application.  There are lots of discussions on this server about pros and cons of SPB,  with many expressing it is good at lower levels but not enterprise layer.

Content: Hey guys new to the group here, lots of incredible information and really interesting discussions going on around here. Super happy to be part of the group! I've recently gotten into IIoT (my background is in traditional microsetvice dev/architecture) and my initial assessment is there is a lot of IIoT platforms out there: Mindsphere, ThingWorx etc. I was curious what everyone's thoughts on closed platforms vs some of the open source IoT platforms such as AWS offering with greengrass and IoT core. I like the closed solutions because they have a lot of capability out of the box, but open source is very attractive for the future even though it requires some initially overhead developing some of the components required to match some of the closed IIoT platforms. Anyways just curious to hear what others thoughts are and learn from from everyone here as I'm new to the industry.

Author: andreasbackman
Content:
Hi Zach and welcome! üëã 
It sounds like you have similar background as me, coming from software dev/architecture, and I'm also evaluating different IIoT platforms with a customer.
I'll sum up what I currently know (and remember üòÖ )
We've looked at:
- Azure IoT Hub with IoT Edge runtime (currently in use); A bit too technical for the customer's technicians. I've heard they've also had problems with what the Edge's status really is, says it's online when it in fact it's not. Nice with the docker runtime you can manage remotely and you also get access to some Azure features at the edge like Functions, AzSQL etc.
- AWS SiteWise and Greengrass; Have just been looking into the docs and some videos. The digital thread seems very neat with the asset modelling and such and at least according to Walkers (https://youtu.be/eyDcWPic0Do) it's a bit more open and perhaps easier to make part of a UNS
- Siemens Industrial Edge; Not production ready imho. Built from a bunch of existing open source software but bundled into something not very fluent to use nor debug etc. Simply still in beta if you ask me. Otherwise, on paper it looks good and has a bunch of potentially interesting features.
 - Litmus.io; Haven't got any hands-on experience yet (getting there!) but to me it looks very promising. Compared to Siemens it's quite similar concept but a lot more mature and polished and with more features. One aspect we look at a bit different is that we'd like to do all the configuration from the manager side and just get that pushed to the edge nodes. E.g. making flows (with their node-red) or just configuring the connectors to PLCs and other devices has to be done on the edge itself, but can then be templated and pushed to others. I guess this works, but after seeing how e.g. Crosser and Omnio does the same things in the cloud and just having a docker runtime fetching the changes at the edge, this feels a bit clunky.

Seems like I'm running out of chars to write, so wrapping up here üòÉ

Author: andreasbackman
Content:
Oh, and another thing I forgot.
Both Siemens and Litmus.io has their own OS which can either be run on physical hardware or as a VM and thus they handle updates for the whole edge stack. Azure and AWS options are dependent on a linux OS (well Azure IoT Edge can be run on a Windows box, but who would do that :D), so with such a setup you need to have a proper way of patching the OS level too. Ansible could be one option there.
What it boils down to is that you have a bunch of requirements for your specific case and your organization's capabilities. Write them down first! Then look at what boxes the different platforms check and look for other pieces to fill in the blanks. That's at least my take on it üôÇ

Content: Why wait for the customer demand for Sparkplug B? Could it be that the end users looking for products with Sparkplug B will not even engage?

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Finite resources!  We have a way to deal with it at the moment, which means that box is sort of checked.  If we had someone that really pushed us on it, we could probably get the development work done quickly, but it would mean taking resources from other projects that are higher up the list.  Most of the applications that I have worked on, it really hasn't been an issue, so I don't know if it's something that's limited to Ignition applications, or it's just not that widely adopted at the moment.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
Yeah, really comes down to a chicken and egg scenario.  Though when you look at it that way, it's an either/or situation.  I think what you normally see, and I think this is what you're seeing now is sort of a back and forth.

1. SpB starts getting used
2. Software companies start supporting via hacks/workarounds
3. SpB starts getting used more often
4. Software companies come up with better integrations
5. etc,etc

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Yeah, SpB would need to be there in the environment before we really needed to start supporting it.  As far as I know, we're not typically going to be the originator of SpB.

Author: andreasbackman
Content:
So what I'm after is an endpoint conforming to the prometheus standard that a docker container running on the edge can use to collect data to get stats of the edge device. In this case that would be the litmus runtime and server. That data would then be sent to a prometheus server.
Another scenario would be if the Litmus edge could instead collect metrics from containers (many supports this out of the box) and pass that up to the manager to be shown on a dashboard, as you already have stats about the edge devices there.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: As long as you're using a container in this scenario, then it's fairly straightforward since we have a direct integration of containers.  We can send information to and from the container as needed.  Dashboards can be a separate container which can take the information gathered from others to build the dashboards.  Server connectivity could be via integrations or flows depending on the requirement.  Either scenario should be pretty straightforward.  Any communication method: drivers, containers, flows, integrations, and even OPC-UA are standard features for the platform.

Author: andreasbackman
Content: Ok, but I'm thinking explicitly about prometheus standard and if you can either expose such data to a collector or if you can function as a collector and show that information on your existing dashboards in the manager

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
Sure, as long as we can connect to it, and it looks like there are a few ways that can be done, then the data just needs to get normalized, which should be fairly straightforward.  Once it's normalized, then out it goes to wherever via an integration.  So, say we connect to the database with the MySQL Server Exporter, which looks to be an official Prometheus exporter.  This would connect via our integrations layer, which would allow us to expose incoming data from the database, or send data back out via this connection.  Once data is in the Litmus platform, then we can send it where it's needed.  In this case, we'll take the incoming data through the flows engine and process it (normalize, analyze, and adjust if needed) and then expose it to (for example) InfluxDB and Graphana via integrations.  InfluxDB will act as the collector and Graphana will handle visualization.  Locally, we have a database in the platform, but that's meant to handle short-term storage for analysis and store and forward capabilities.  Longer term you're going to want to use a specific DB application.

This is probably a little rough, but our engineers would make it work nicely.

Author: billliu4646
Content:
Question on Sparkplug B - I am implementing a custom EoN Node complying with Sparkplug B. What are the reasons or scenarios for using:

A) Multiple nodes each has 1 device. Each device represented by a node.
B) 1 node with multiple devices.
C) 1 node with 1 device, but metrics is prefixed with device IDs representing multiple devices.

I am interested to hear your thoughts

Author: nickn5549
Content: modbus https://github.com/stephane/libmodbus

Author: mparris
Content:
A couple of classifying points:
-Nodes can produce metrics on their own.
-Devices are not required on the producer side.

Knowing these two things, would that change your list that you are investigating?

Author: billliu4646
Content:
Thanks for pointing that out. I didn't know that. Yes, it does change the list. Option A doesn't make sense any more because the single device doesn't do anything. Option C doesn't allow selective subscription so I removed it as well. Revised list below:

B) 1 node with multiple devices.
D) Multiple nodes, no devices. Each equipment represented by a node with node metrics.

Option D seems to increase the client count for no reason. I guess option B is the way to go.

Author: mparris
Content:
I've used devices to segment different types of metrics within a node, such as fast analogs, slow analogs, and discretes. This lets applications that don't care about the fast moving analogs not get bombarded.

The benefit of a single PC doing one node and multiple devices rather than multiple nodes is that the consumer application can get everything about the PC through a single MQTT subscription.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôve done it the same way, albeit functional grouping, not by signal type. Considered separating the fast moving stuff, but landed on not doing it. The future will let me know how stupid that decision was ü´£

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Option B

Content: A PC is not a PLC. Nobody can guarantee linux compatibility in the future since that is not under their control. Choose a hardware which is linux compatible and put the linux you want on it. Either you buy hardware (i.e. a PC with a fancy case)  or you buy hardware and software (i.e an ipc with an OS). If you want more control then buy hardware, but then you have to manage the software on it. Linux is open source, with all of its advantages and dissadvantages. If you buy a PLC that is closed source with the advantage of 20 year service support you get the dissadvantage of not knowing its internals hence you do not connect it to the internet

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôm also confused. What is an edge device? General purpose computer connected to hardware on the edge of the network? Or are PLCs edge devices? Is there a size restriction? Would a server rack connected to the control network be considered edge devices? Is it defined by nodes on the network that are at the edge of the ethernet network?

Author: rehenley
Content: An edge device sets at the edge of a controls / automation implementation that talks to field devices, sensors, instruments, VFDs, etc‚Ä¶. If thinking about it in terms of the ISA-95 model it would be the device that controls the line or cell equipment.  Enterprise ( company X)  - Site (company x /Dallas01) - Area ( company x/Dallas01/bottling ) - Line (company x/Dallas01/bottling/line1 )- Cell (company x/Dallas01/bottling/line1/filler01) - device (company x/Dallas01/bottling/line01/filler01/PLC01)

Author: rehenley
Content: There will also me an edge device at the line level in the description above that controls the overall function of the line itself.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @rehenley, you just advanced to level 5!

Author: rehenley
Content: That is the type of device OT engineers consider ‚Äúedge‚Äù when taking about edge driven.

Author: akoscs
Content: Edge/mist/fog/cloud all are terms originating in IT, not OT. An edge device sits at the edge of the network. This is a loose definition but it is the best I got. Can a router be edge? Yes, edge router. Can a PC or any compute capable device be edge? Yes id it sits at the edge of the network. Can a PLC be an edge device? Certainly, any newer PLCs can do this. What is the edge of the network? In IoT it is the end of the IP network. In OT or IIoT, it might be the end of ‚Äúan‚Äù IP network and the edge device may have further IP based connections.  My feeling is that in OT/IIoT edge device is used to designate gateways (protocol gateways). This is the aspect which bringa in the software side, as protocol gateways are inherently tied to software functionalities. A protocol gateway in many cases translatea between multiple communication protocols. For example it polls data out of a PLC over modbus and publishes it to the cloud using MQTT. This is edge driven, that the communication gateway, an edge device in this case) initiates the communication towards the cloud and not vice versa. I do not think it has to do with the ISA model. That is a data model, in an extreme case an edge device can feed data to the Cloud from all the PLCs in one area, that is how the network is defined, it is orthogonal to the data model. Can this edge device functioning as a protocol gateway be a PC? Yes it can, a rugged one running Ubuntu server, docker and Azure IoT Edge, definetly! Can an edge device be a RPi? Sure, it can even run the same Azure IoT Edge software. Or it can run EdgeXFoundry or anything else.

Author: nickn5549
Content: I have around 60 RPI running as edge devices reading all non-critical sensors in the facility - Temperature & RH (room, fridge, dry cabinets), PH, CO2, air purity

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @NickN, you just advanced to level 17!

Author: nickn5549
Content: Older ones (RPI) were installed 6-7 years ago and still working fine

Author: rehenley
Content: Ok, got ya.  That makes more sense.  I would not put a PC in the bucket of things I would consider ‚Äúedge‚Äù, but iPC would definitely be.

Author: rehenley
Content: Lol, edge is not a term originating in IT.  The fact that you think it is, is a function of your perspective.

Author: rehenley
Content: But really it‚Äôs just semantics and it‚Äôs irrelevant as long as we can all agree to a meaning.

Author: rehenley
Content: The vast majority of devices in OT are Ethernet / IP enabled and can therefore be anywhere on the network the transport layer and above have nothing to do with the edge in the Industry 4.0 / IIoT realm.  The edge is the point between the field sensors : Instruments and the first intelligent Ethernet/IP enabled network device.  Well, traditionally that was the case but now most of the field devices are Ethernet/IP enabled. Instruments, sensors, etc‚Ä¶. So that is becoming an outdated model also.   The edge most definitely refers the point of demarcation between discrete devices and the device that aggregates them and provides context and control.

Author: rehenley
Content: At least in my world, lol.

Author: rehenley
Content:
That‚Äôs what this whole thing is about.  Technology has advanced to the point that edge devices are capable of significant  computational power and autonomy. Use that tech to most efficiently manage the IIoT towards the end goal.  Which is what?
The contextualization of data to analyze and create relevant information to make decisions based on the best possible set of information.   After all few well intentioned people make bad decisions on purpose.  It‚Äôs nearly always about bad information or poor analyzed data.

Author: akoscs
Content:
Wikipedia disagrees with you. ‚ÄúThe origins of edge computing lie in content distributed networks that were created in the late 1990s to serve web and video content from edge servers that were deployed close to users.[3] In the early 2000s, these networks evolved to host applications and application components at the edge servers,[4] resulting in the first commercial edge computing services[5] that hosted applications such as dealer locators, shopping carts, real-time data aggregators, and ad insertion engines.[4]

Internet of things (IoT) is an example of edge computing. A common misconception is that edge and IoT are synonymous.‚Äù https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edge_computing

Author: rehenley
Content: Well, it Wikipedia say it then‚Ä¶ ü§ì

Author: rehenley
Content: I promise this is the last I will say about it because it‚Äôs really not worth spending much time on. As long as others understand what you are conveying that is all that really matters but in a field like IIoT where there are already a lot of confused people ambiguity is not our friend.  Long before there were commercially viable video servers or even Netflix there was OT. It wasn‚Äôt called that then ( OT the original IT - instrument technology).   When PLCs and remote IO first came onto the scene we called the first point of IO aggregation from field devices the edge of the network.  So from an Industrial perspective that‚Äôs where edge comes from.  IIoT is exclusively and industrial concept so within the confines of IIoT it stands to reason that‚Äôs where it came from.  IoT a little different than IIoT would be a more likely place to see your definition used and yes that of wiki above.  Good conversation thanks.

Author: zeratall
Content:
Obviously the Industry 4.0 YT Channel!! I think for talking about specifically IIoT it s an awesome resource, that covers a wide range of content, from managing culture and understanding digital maturity. integration/implementation discussion, to live streams that discuss where we think the industry is going. 

Also this discord. I really enjoy seeing everyone's ideas, thoughts, and comments about everything IIoT, and a lot of times those comments get me thinking in new ways that I wouldn't have been exposed to before.

I also enjoy reading books, there are not a lot of IIoT specific books that I found that cover the breadth that I'm looking for, but I do find Industry 4.0 and Microservice Architecture to have a lot of parallels, and there are a ton of books on microservice architecture design patters and practices, so I constantly find myself reading those types of books and applying some of their principles in IIoT. 

One other thing that I do a lot in my day to day job as an Architect is develop cameo models for ITOT, and I haven't really found any content that talks to that ( modeling IIoT) which I think is an important one.

Author: rehenley
Content: Has anyone done research into the 2-wire Ethernet solutions and their implementation in the sensors/instrumentation arena?  Using SPE and Ethernet-APL?  I have heard E&H is working on solutions.  I have used E&H's ethernet/IP flow meters and they are wonderful.  They allow for massive increases in the customization of instrument operations/interaction.  If we could get entire classes of sensors and instruments to run off 2-wire Ethernet and interact with those devices via Ethernet/IP it would completely change the way a controls engineer can control and monitor processes.  I would like to hear if anyone else is tracking this and get links to information related to it.  I have an opportunity to set up a greenfield manufacturing facility and would like to take advantage of this tech as much as possible in the buildout: scheduled to start mid-2023. <<<<also posted the same comment in the Digital Transformation server topic >>>>>>.

There's wirelessHART that you could bridge to MQTT. Is this a pet project and the cost needs to be minimized? Or is this a commercial project that's funded? Lots of options.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Starting to see some movement towards putting that sort of networking capability directly into sensors, though there are not a lot of companies that are making the jump.  I have to say, I have had an utter hatred of E+H from 20 years of competing with them, but credit where credit is due, they're getting ahead of the curve on this sort of stuff.  Even without going to a senor based 2-wire ethernet, many sensors are going the ethernet route, many through a standard ethernet port of the controller.  Even if you can't get that type of communication on the sensor or the controller, you can always look at some sort of converter to get it to ethernet, which would allow for it to be swapped for a native ethernet device in the future.
