Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This brings up an excellent point.  In reading about SPE and Ethernet-APL, the complexity of IP-based hardware and firmware is often raised.  This raises the total cost per node.  In the process or life science industries, one can get away with four or figure lab-grade instrumentation that measures out to a 20 decimal places because the process depends on it.  In discrete manufacturing, the process may not require much precision.  In fact, the sensors are often basic switches (e.g., tank level, pressure, temperature).  Many machine builders don't even bother installing analog input cards.

IO-Link, a simple serial protocol for sensors and actuators, has been proposed as a solution to this problem.  It enables sensors to be simple and, most importantly, low cost.  It uses standard unshielded field wiring and does not require costly analog input cards.  The IO-Link interfaces, called "Masters", are like 2-4x more economical than analog cards and the associated wiring.  They can be deployed on a fieldbus or standalone with an IoT protocol.  It's not perfect technology.  Depending on the solution, one might have to parse and map in the payloads.  But, the technology is at least really well documented.

What I especially like about the technology is the market adoption.  It's not like specifying unicorn.  What many are using as switches or analog sensors in more traditional deployments (e.g., 0/24VDC, 4-20mA) are actual IO-Link capable sensors.  It's simply a matter of turning on the right configuration and connecting them to an IO-Link Master.  The same transducer and compute inside a sensor that normally generates signals for a PLC input card to interpret can be interfaced with directly and digitally.

Related discussions:
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/742458745031884921/818680913743446026
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/740336217580765245/881303753284780094

Author: trentc
Content: I‚Äôm a fan of IO Link, especially as replacement for analog, digital from the start. The other features such as access to  sensor identity information and parameters have significant value in digital solutions. However the masters aren‚Äôt cheap, IFM and balluff are the leaders in IOLink. Also check out coretigo for wireless IOLink.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
I recently got the P+F IOLink Cloud kit and it does work, but the Comtrol master is kind of "clunky". And as we discovered, the firmware updates are not well managed by P+F, requiring email assistance. 
They sent me updated firmware (newer than what's on the Comtrol site) and it had a PHP error in the web server. It also was notably lacking MQTT which it was advertised to have.
After emailing them again, I got new firmware links (of the exact same name) and the homepage now showed MQTT as a supported protocol, but it was still missing the MQTT menu option.
Currently P+F engineering is "looking at my issue" as of a week ago, still no response.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It's my understanding that the masters are only a couple hundred dollars.  Analog input cards run at least twice as much.

Here's some __rough__ data points:

IFM AL1122 (IO-Link Master, 8 ports):  ~$300
AB 1734-4IOL (Point I/O IO-Link Master, 4 ports):  ~$400
AB 5069-IF8  (CompactLogix Analog Input, 8 ports):  ~$950
AB 1756-IF8 (ControlLogix Analog Input, 8 ports):  ~$1,400

Author: trentc
Content: ‚ÄúCheap‚Äù is relative. We would have to compare the cost of the whole package because analog inputs may be expensive but the sensors aren‚Äôt always, and some IOLink equivalent sensors are significantly more expensive. But if you compare the cost of typical digital IO‚Ä¶. IOLink is expensive. But the capabilities and flexibility of IOLink and mixed IO make its value proposition very appealing for those looking to leverage the technology.

Author: trentc
Content: Not to mention those are AB prices, not a brand I would consider ‚Äúcheap‚Äù in cost.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Great points.  Especially on the AB part.  In reality, these are a bit lower.  I didn't pull contract pricing.  But, hopefully this provided an overall picture of relative cost.  This doesn't include the associated costs of shielded field wiring.

What sensors have you found to be more expensive?  My focus is on discrete and automotive.  Outside of motion and safety and metrology, sensors tend to be inexpensive in this space.  Occasionally, some sort of fluid or liquid may need something special.  Process industries are a completely different beast.

When I first began to dabble with IO-Link, I realized a lot of sensors (e.g., pressure, level, flow) used with DI already had IO-Link on it.  The cost was generally about the same.  And, regarding incumbent analog sensors, the pure IO-Link versions were significantly cheaper.  When one considers there was already onboard processing to configure and generate electrical signals for PLCs to consume, it makes sense that it would be more economical to connect to this digitally.

The other area where I might be able to concede it's expensive is on very small machines.  There are segments of the control market where mainstream fieldbus support starts to drop off.  The marginal cost of adding support for a protocol starts to really climb.  Also, these machines tend to be built for low cost of acquisition and not necessarily low total cost of ownership.  The machine builder may steer towards to lower-cost, commodity components.  But, above this extremely price sensitive segment, the differences in cost shrink.

Suppose an asset needs twenty process sensors.  There's an option to use them as switches with digital input modules or IO-Link with an IO-Link Master.  While they're both about a couple hundred dollars, let's assume the total difference for everything came down to a couple grand.  Given the overall acquisition cost of the asset, is it worth stranding all this process data out in the field?

Author: trentc
Content:
For Digital IO the cost of the sensor is negligible, many MFG have started including IOLink on all of their digital sensors because the cost difference, and value proposition. The added cost is all in the master, Omron NX 4pt digital input module is $73 vs NX IOLink 4pt master is $470. For someone focused on cost per point, you can really drive the cost down using IOLink Hubs with standard IO. This flexibility drives down cost, and still allows one to have IOLink masters in place to utilize when an IOLink capable sensor is chosen.

For analog IO, just for quick reference, Omron NXIO 4ch Analog input is $225 + an IFM pressure sensor for around $143 x 4 total is $797, but if we switch to Omron NX IOLink 4pt master at $470, + 4 IFM IOLink Pressure Sensors at $175 x 4 total is $1170, that's 146% cost of Analog to switch to IOLink. For someone incurring that cost, that isn't leveraging the data or features of the technology, sees this as a hit on the bottom line.

My preference is IOLink as the default because of the data interface capabilities, and when it doesn't work for {reason} then the architecture should allow for the flexibility to adapt. 

I plan to explore more IOLink features adding value further up the stack, as I do see its value. But legacy decision makers don't always feel the same.

Author: joshuastover
Content: **Question of the Day:** Have you worked with Edge Gateways that turn automation data into IIoT Data? If so, which is your preferred gateway? Have you worked with PLCs or controllers that support IIoT protocols like DNP3 or MQTT? If so, which is your preferred hardware?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: There are several that I used depending on use case. Maple Systems cMT-SVR is great for purely converting tags. Ignition Edge or Tatsoft FX sitting on an OnLogic industrial PC is another. Last option is Opto 22 EPIC is attractive because it is an industrial hardened device that does not need OS support. These are used for modeling at the edge. And perhaps some edge processing with Node-RED.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Boring but true, have used Ignition Edge. Pretty ok modeling capabilities and decent at mass-adding tags from OPC UA. It also supports scripting on tag events. I have tried Hightbyte, but not as Edge gateway.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I'm a fan of the Opto 22 groov products as well, but don't forget about the Rio! Not expandable, but highly configurable I/O with native MQTT and OPC UA publishing or Node Red if you want to customize it. And it can be powered by PoE so you can even tell when a machine is offline. You can take almost any "dumb" machine and turn it into an IoT ready asset. The newer version ($100 more) can also run Ignition Edge.

Author: hutcheb
Content: That‚Äôs cool, any idea if it supports any sort of TSN protocol (EthernetIP, Profinet)?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: So a couple of options. If you're OK using Node Red, there are nodes for EthernetIP for sure and probably Profinet. If you want something with support then use Ignition Edge, but that will require purchasing a license.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: We've used the EthernetIP and ModbusTCP nodes with pretty good success.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
Opto has a nice interactive explorer for the Rio as well. You can use it to lay out your I/O configuration and then download the image for reference.
https://www.opto22.com/products/groov-rio-explorer

Author: akoscs
Content: EthernetIP and Profinet are not TSN protocols. A Profinet RT over TSN might exist commercially at some point in the future, but that does not make it a TSN protocol. Non-realtime protocols over TSN do not make much sense yet (they could become real-time capable with TSN but current applications are limited)

Author: akoscs
Content: There is some profinet support but not the real-time version of profinet.

Author: trentc

Author: akoscs
Content: TSN is bleeding edge‚Ä¶currently more blood then edge. It has some really cool features for industrial usecases, but there are some limitations in configuring network controllers due to the fact that it is just not ready yet. Many companies are working very hard on putting it to good (industrial) use but currently there is no wide scale adoption it is still very new and somewhat unfinished.

Author: trentc
Content:
TL;DR
I prefer the solution that enables quick time to value, advanced programming capabilities, extensible and easily maintainable. 

For edge uses my preferences
1. Open industrial controller with PLC (Codesys Based) and higher level programming capabilities.
    Rexroth ctrlX (solves most problems in many ways in one uniform package)
    PLCNext (low entry cost, highly programmable, and extensible)
    Opto22 (quickest time to value, solves most problems)
    Wago (open and expandable)

2. Free and Open on low power IPC
    Node-red

3. Licensed software on IPC
    Ignition edge (limited drivers, but no brainer if using ignition)
    Litmus Edge
    Codesys Runtime
    Kepware (fall back)

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Pretty much agree. I also like RTA purpose built gateways. I haven't had a chance to use one yet at my dayjob, but they put on a great industrial protocols training at their home office.

Author: thavo007
Content:
On our side, we wanted to add IIoT features to existing OPC UA machines that manufactures bikes worldwide. 
We initially used a Beckhoff TwinCat sending MQTT messages to the cloud. but after extensive research and bench (our numerous needs : report by exception support, cheapest, manufacturer rapid support, small size device , easiest, OPC UA support, Azure IoT Edge and IoT Hub support with MQTT , NO Licence, support of internet instability thanks to Edge retrial send policies, no OS so that we don't have to manage OS updates hence instability...), we selected a small basic
Advantech ECU device. 

We spotted some other devices such as IFM or Cloud Rail, and might change in the future, but they are not available right now. 

The main drawback so far of our choice is that the report by exception needs to send flat data (may be Sparkplug will help? However, if we send all data everytime, the data structure remains). 

Appart from this drawback, we can now supervise all machines worldwide. 
Because we need real-time OEE calculations, we collected time series telemetry, it contributes to the digital transformation. 

https://buy.advantech.eu/SRP-IoT-Gateways/IoT-Gateways-Devices-WISE-PaaS-EdgeLink-Gateway/model-ECU-150-12A.htm

Author: thavo007
Content:
Hi Marc, my needs are aligned with my customers' needs :

Have an Industrial IoT Edge that combines two advantages :
1) be as flexible as a ruggedized fanless industrial PC with docker containers, running on latest Linux. 
And plenty of features, ex. : Have a Azure IoT Edge agent running full of features ( file upload, certificate management, device lifecycle management, firmware/OS/app update, remote deployments of AI, ...). 

2) be as easy to startup and robust as a PLC  (no OS to update, nearly no security patch to manage). 

Many actors are targeting to ship those two advantages and claim to support that... But the reality Si different from the sheet. 

IFM made a strategic partnership with CloudRail : it leads to one of my favorite IIoT device.... AND only in theory üòÖ because on paper it suits my needs. 
I was not able to buy it, due to the electronical shortage, I was only able to buy from IFM its regular IIoT system. I also got a mini-Advantech instead. Ifm are preparing two versions to be released, mid-2023... I'm looking forward.

Author: walker6715
Content:
Hey all, 
Our company manufactures a type of fully integrated linear coil motor that allows for reasonably accurate (back drivable) force control without the need for external load cells/drivers/encoders/etc. We came out of the aerospace/simulation/robotics space and are looking to get a bit more into the industrial automation side of things. We have a ton of fast data coming from an RS485 Modbus RTU connection. Usually this would go directly into the FPGA/whatever is controlling the robot but now looking as to what may make more sense for an IIOT thing one would expect to see in a factory setting.
Anyone on here have any suggestions on where to start looking regarding existing edge devices that may make sense to integrate with first? The space is still pretty new to us so just looking for something we can start playing around with to get our feet wet with.
Thanks!
PS a vid of our motors: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RjJve6p7rko&ab_channel=IrisDynamics

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Are you looking for some kind of interface you can OEM? Or something off the shelf to "partner" with?

Author: walker6715
Content: Given that were not at all familiar with the space I was leaning towards partnering with someone already operating inside a few ecosystems. I'm not 100% sure if that's really a thing or not but if it was I thought id start the looking there.....

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Are you looking for something that will publish the data from the motor? Or actually accept input as well?

Author: walker6715
Content: Ideally both. In most applications we've done to date the motors are really being used bidirectionally. I.E. as an output device (force, position, etc) and an input device (how much force, is backlash present, what position etc). Again I'm not clear if this is a common thing on the industrial side but yes, ideally a gateway/bridge device that could be configured for both I & O.

Author: mattmigchelbrink
Content: Go download the free trial of Ignition to get your feet wet. An IIOT device should be vender agnostic, and use open protocols. Probably look into OPCUA, MQTT, MQTT w SparkPlugB

Author: akoscs
Content: If the data is part of a control loop then this approach will never work due to latency.

Author: akoscs
Content:
First of all you need to decide what applications do you want to support with your device! 
-If you want to integrate your device to industrial applications as part of a control loop then look into EtherCAT, sercos, ProfiNET and CanOpen. These are the 4 industrial protocols used in motion control applications where latency and jitter has to be kept minimal. Any other approach (OPCUA, MQTT, Modbus, etc) will have much higher latencies and will not work well. To give you a specific example, any modern (above low quality) robot or CNC controller uses one of these communication protocols to communicate with the drive amplifiers of the axis motors. 
-If you do not want to/need to be in the control loop and prefer a more experimental, less industrial approach for robotics you can look into ROS and develop a ROS driver for your device. 
-OPCUA receives a lot of criticism in this community (in my opinion only part of that is deserved) you can look into that for integrating with industrial systems.
-MQTT is also interesting it is wide spread in the IT world, less wide spread on the shop floor.

Author: sachin_k22
Content: if realtime control is what your intent is you be better off with an embedded device running an MQTT broker that feeds the robot RTOS. However, if the intent is to use this fast data as inout to any 'higher' systems then suggest exploring an industrial gateway like EWON from HMS and others from RedLion. They do have a slew of configurations for IIoT needs.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @sachin_k22, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: akoscs
Content: No, please never ever do real-time over mqtt. My definition of real-time is coming from the controls industry, 10s of microseconds level latency and 10s or low 100s nanosecond level jitter. Mqtt cannot come even close.

Author: jermuk
Content: i know i am late to the part, but if you are using the ifm ALxx series (e.g., AL1350) and want to use docker, you could look at sensorconnect, which automatically extracts all datapoints and pushes it into an MQTT or Kafka broker: https://learn.umh.app/docs/core/sensorconnect/ and https://hub.docker.com/repository/docker/unitedmanufacturinghub/sensorconnect/general

Author: jermuk
Content:
as edge device, we are leveraging the K300 from onlogic running flatcar and k3s (previously just k3os, but thank you @Marc J√§ckle for the recommendation)

btw: sensorconnect is fully open-source, so feel free to use it üôÇ

Author: mparris
Content:
@Jermuk  why benefit do you see having changed from k3os to flatcar+k3s?

Any reason you aren't targeting microk8s?

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Spot on akos - real-time is not negotiable and a fieldbus is definitely the way to go. Products that offer IoT for realtime control tend to manage all the motion and controls at the device level - but the IoT side will either report data, or allow for the management of recipes (however - I doubt wirelessly controlling this device is a good idea). @pmcfadden 5G is a new technology that could enable real time industrial communication - but I'm not familiar with applications of it....I have seen research demos of it working well

Author: jermuk
Content: k3os is not maintained anymore :/ additionally, flatcar is more flexible while still allowing only docker container. It seems more mature in the sense that more people have worked with it and provided feedback so far. This includes additional configuration options, more debug options (like kernel crash logs) and you can also host just some Docker containers on it with docker-compose (which is a great addition to people wanting to leverage the United Manufacturing Hub, but not want to spend too much time on Kubernetes)

Author: mparris
Content: Did you consider microk8s?  Maybe it doesn't include the docker interface that you said flatcar has?

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Flatcar is the operating system. MicroK8s would compare to k3s. Flatcar is a fork of the former CoreOS Container Linux and as such very mature. It's a minimal, container-focused linux with a very small attack surface. It's a great solution, especially when you go for immutable infrastructure (it uses an immutable filesystem). It was originally forked by the startup called kinvolk which was eventually acquired by Microsoft.

Author: mparris
Content:
Thanks @Marc J√§ckle , I missed that detail. I thought microk8s included the OS, but actually requires the snap interface.

I suppose the equivalent would be Ubuntu Core+ microk8s, but then if docker is desired, that has to get deployed separately, whereas Flatcar OS is built for that?

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Yes, it would compare to Ubuntu Core + microk8s although I haven't seen anyone using microk8s in production yet. At least for distributed cloud systems it's not a popular combination. Might be more common combination in IoT projects though, where Ubuntu Core is more common. Ubuntu Core and Flatcar have quite different philososphies. Ubuntu follows a more traditional approach with its Snap system to install software while in Flatcar you would not install anything (the file system is immutable, which reduces the attack surface further) and only run containers.

Author: akoscs
Content: 5G does work with real-time constraints, but I only saw it working on private local network. TSN is also something that can make a non-real-time communication protocol usable in real-time application, but mqtt is not compatible with such an approach. You can see motion control done with non-real-time components it kind of works...until it doesn't.

Author: mparris
Content: If the file system is immutable, do the container images have to get downloaded on every reboot of the device? That seems like a bandwidth hog...

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: The only times you usually reboot a Flatcar system is to do a system upgrade which would mean a completely new image if you follow a immutable infrastructure approach which doesn‚Äôt happen that often. That needs some bandwidth of course but shouldn‚Äôt be an issue in typical plant scenarios. Maybe more so on an oil rig or a wind turbine. In all of the cases, it often makes sense to have an on prem container registry anyway that gets synced with the main registry in the cloud in case a container needs to be restarted while there is no internet connectivity. Or sometimes you might want to start something new while the cloud is unavailable.

Author: mparris
Content: I believe iohubos followed this philosophy, but I think they had a way to pre-load docker images within the os image... Just in case üòâ

Author: jermuk
Content:
for developing stuff and trying it out, immutable systems are in my opinion more effort. However, in production, this really pays off. Because now you can easily replace, spawn multiple docker containers, setup entire networks, etc. reproducibly. So no more tutorials on how to install software, how to configure containers, setup DHCP, IP, etc.. If something fails, you have the same system up in a couple of minutes and even automatically.

we even went a step further and now for provisioning we just need to boot from one standard usb image and together with our server it detects automatically the device (based on MAC address, etc.) and installs and configures the OS including the kubernetes cluster running UMH (kafka, etc.). 

setting up an entire factory floor with edge devices including software to read out the machines, pre-configured node-red flows, etc. now takes under 10minutes, lol

Author: mparris
Content:
Awesome!

I'm on a path to achieve the same üòÅ

Have you considered pxe boot instead of the USB drive?

Author: akoscs
Content: nice work! Is it all one cluster with heterogeneous tainted nodes (e.g. a gateway) to know which machine connects to which node (physically)? Where do you get the k8s master config when you boot up a new instance from scratch (no other redundant master to get it from)? Do you use Terraform or ansible?

Author: jermuk
Content: the usb boot image is a customized iPXE image üòÑ @MParris

Author: jermuk
Content:
these are all different clusters / instances of the United Manufacturing Hub. Each with their own message brokers for local buffering and data exchange, own Node-RED, own stream processing, etc.

we are actually using iPXE together with matchbox and flatcar to archieve this. the helm chart for node-red and all that stuff is the nthe united manufacturing hub

Author: akoscs
Content: Would a 1 cluster with different namespaces for each instance work or is there some reason that prohibits a 1 k8s cluster approach?

Author: jermuk
Content: 1 k8s cluster works in good networking environments (server farms). however, manufacturing has often disruptions in it, so each machien needs to be able to work independently from any networking connection

Author: akoscs
Content: But his has not much to do with the number of clusters

Author: jermuk
Content: to monitor, configure and maintai nevrything we have currently a UI in alpha version, which helps in keeping the overview over everything - from networking to services and errorsi n the dataprocessing

Author: akoscs
Content: Have you tried Backstage?

Author: jermuk
Content: you could setup everything also how you said (one cluster, multiple tainted nodes, each node is then running an MQTT broker, etc.). however, there would still be some ccentral components (like them aster k8s node) that could fail / cause disruptions of something happens with the network connections/

Author: jermuk
Content: not so far, but ill take a look

Author: akoscs
Content: You make multiple masters, you do not really care where the brokers run, they have no special physical requirement, tainting is needed if there is special HW or special physical connection e.g. to a machine over a different ethernet network. You run all instances of UMH in dufferent namespaces. Other then your doubt on reliability do you see any problem with this approach?

Author: jermuk
Content: the advantages then would be that you can configure everything in the same cluster right? this looks for me a tradeoff between accessability (one cluster) vs reliability (multiple independent cluster).

Author: akoscs
Content: I do not see it this way. You have let's say in total 10 nodes. let's say 2 are special (assume are connected via RS485 to old machines). Now if we make 2 clusters, we have 4 and 6 nodes in the clusters. There is nothing special about the one with 4, the special two nodes are in the other cluster. Let's say each cluster has 2 master nodes, which are not isolated (also act as worker nodes). If the 2 servers acting as master in the same cluster fail 1 of your clusters is down for good. If you have one cluster with 10 nodes and 4 masters (the same overall number of masters as before, but now in one cluster) if 2 of them fail the cluster redispatches the resources and works. Also compute is better distributable so it is less likely that a worker node fail will cause compute power insufficiency (in 2 clusters if one node dies and you do not really have enough compute but the other cluster has compute power you have problems). The two special nodes make no difference, if that HW failes you loose connection to the old machine no matter which option you are taking. So I only see advantages to a 1 cluster approach... With the added benefint of...you know...only having 1 cluster :).

Author: jermuk
Content:
but what happens if the network connection between two nodes drop and one or multiple nodes are left alone somewhere. your approach works when then odes ar eclose to each other, but if there is a distance there will be problems. if the node with the RS232 connection will loose network connection, could it continue operating, buffering the data and then sending it out whenever the connection to the rest of the cluster is restored? also those nodes could be in different networks behind firewalls.

as far as I know, also all large cloud providers only offer kubernetes clusters with all nodes in the same region.

Author: akoscs
Content: All these reasons affect you the same way no matter if you have 1 or two clusters.

Author: plxnt_kid
Content:
https://github.com/jpmens/mqtt-watchdir

Thoughts on this library?

I think it is extraordinary.  We have many OS file system type event driven triggers that need subsequent consumption and realtime processing / ai pipeline affecting hundreds of machines across the organization.

I had been using CIFS and other low level protocols such as samba to ingest into a file directory based UNS (ie. I had created a realtime file directory UNS in common with all OS across the company as network drive of files akin to a UNS for these events across all computers in the organization / on network)

I titled it the "global directory" being the singular file system for all OS computers on network updated in real time and exporable to all other computers.

To make note, CIFS is working very well for this application, it is immediate and lightweight and bi-directional serving any OS file system on network and easily configurable.

I have a file system monitor on this global directory generating event triggers for any file change on event allowing me to explore any file change in any computer on network in any directory by proxy.

The only problem I am having is prescriptive event triggers on CIFS transfer which is why I think the report by exception model of MQTT would solve this issue in concert with the CIFS protocol or os. libraries specific to python.

This library has the potential to interface with OS file system events and immediately publish events via MQTT to a unified namespace.

How are you all integrating OS file system events into the unified namespace in real time?  There are hundreds of manufacturing machines that do not use PLC OPCUA and rely on file system level data transaction running on a Windows / Mac / Linux operating system.

What I am thinking is to continue using my global directory of CIFS networked computers across all computers on net and then run this library on the entire global directory and immediately pub into MQTT broker.

What do you guys think?

Author: plxnt_kid
Content: that way this library could run on one VM server with potentially hundreds of cores and parallel threads and not by a client specific install or service on all computers

Author: plxnt_kid
Content: I believe CIFS is a reliable, efficient, and robust protocol for file transaction within an OS ecosystem

Author: plxnt_kid
Content: though is limited by its non report by exception nature

Author: plxnt_kid
Content: I'm hoping to combine CIFS and MQTT in this way to produce a global file directory event architecture and UNS

Author: plxnt_kid
Content: you could also have the global directory be a consumer and write consumption based files to any computer file directory on network in realtime via CIFS

Author: plxnt_kid
Content:
I was also successful using CIFS + S3FS to land any computers file directory in realtime for any change directly to S3 AWS datalake in realtime using only 8 linux cli commands 0 code.  The only thing I am missing is the event triggers and subsequent consumption requests afforded by MQTT 
to summarize 
OS agnostic file directory change / whole structure --> global CIFS protocol network drive for all directories running multi-core / thread parallel event scraper --> MQTT publish on any file change in entire directory structure to UNS 
Now you tie any OS file system event and subsequent file data on network to realtime data consumption in PLC OT / CLOUD APP / MES / ML / SCADA / ERP from UNS using MQTT

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Entish, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: plxnt_kid
Content:
Potentially with very little code or configuration you could:

1) Be notified when any file changes on any OS on any computer on the entire corporate network
2) The contents of that file
3) The contents of the file and directory structure in UNS via mqtt

Author: plxnt_kid
Content:
All in quasi baremetal realtime running on a multi-core parallel thread networked VM using CIFS and MQTT lightweight protocols
With only a singular VM running the code execution for the event scraper for the file directories on all OS's across the entire company

Author: plxnt_kid
Content:
In theory you turn any OS and all data in storage into a node on network in UNS prod and consume via MQTT
With a single VM service

Author: zeratall
Content: For those of you that use Thingworx do you have tips for debugging when developing services? With a software development background I find it extremly difficult to write and debug code in Thingworx without the use of a locals window, and not being able to step through code etc. Curious what others are doing in that regard?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: A lot of log output.  It‚Äôs really the only option.  That said, you can actually write your services in any language you want and have that code run as a microservice invoked transparently from ThingWorx via its ‚Äúremote thing‚Äù protocol.

Author: terrancesmith
Content: The "IDE" is one of my least favorite parts of native thingworx development. You're probably doing most of these already but here's a 2 things I do.  Use try, catch and reference the stack to get line number that threw the error. And I create a "locals window" by creating a json with any parameters I want to see and logging that at certain points.  Nothing crazy, but doing it the same way creates more readability than a bunch of random logger.infos() or something.

Author: zeratall
Content: Aaah that's actually a good idea about the Json!

Author: terrancesmith
Content: When I'm just debugging one service, I change the service output to json and view it there so I don't have to go to the logging window.  But that doesn't help if you're trying to debug multiple services at once and need the outputs synced up..

Content: It‚Äôs super easy.  Your remote thing can provide any number of services.  It‚Äôll be a stand-alone process that can run anywhere - same machine or any machine/device.  It just needs to be able to connect to the ThingWorx server. There are SDKs for a bunch of languages.  Keep in mind that this only lets you debug the service, not the script that invoked it.

Content: yeah, we are polling via REST. As far as I remember, there are some MQTT functionalities missing as well as it does not interpret the actual sensor data as it does not download the IODD files. Also the data polling frquency was lower than what we could od via REST + a patched firmware (the current version has a bug which makes the io link master crash if you ask it too often via REST. if you ask ifm nicely, they'll give you the updated firmware)

Author: markpitout
Content:
I want to touch on a comment @zackscriven made about the upcoming SCADAPack 47xi during the last podcast video. He said that the SCADAPack "has PLCNext vibes".
I want to point out a difference between the two that might also help explain the price point.

Aside from being built for the oil and gas industry (ATEX Zone 2 certification, -40 to 158 ¬∞F temperature range, G3 conformal coating, etc.) the SCADAPack 47xi also has a distinctly different internal architecture to PLCNext:

PLCNext has a single CPU (might be multi-core depending on model), which runs a Linux OS, with PREEMPT_RT patch for realtime applications. The IEC61131 logic that controls a machine or process executes as a process thread inside Linux.

The SCADAPack 47xi has two seperate dual core CPUs: one for executing IEC61131 logic and RTU functions, and the other for running the Linux OS. Data is passed between the two through a dedicated link that synchronizes the object databases of both CPUs. The SCADAPack is built this way so that the process control application can reliably execute, unhindered by what might be happening in the Linux OS.

Author: markpitout
Content:
I am curious to know how resilliant PLCNext is when the Linux OS is strained, say by a poorly coded application that has a memory leak, or that consumes alot of CPU time (or a Cyber attack). 

Would anyone who has a PLCNext controller be willing to run a small test for me?
The test is:
1. Deploy a small IEC61131 application, with a digital output that switches on/off every second and an analog output that ramps up/down.
2. Use SSH to log into the Linux OS, and execute a fork-bomb (or multiple).
3. Monitor if the digital and analog outputs still behave as expected.

For reference a fork-bomb is a program that recursively forks itself. A simple example is executing the following code in the terminal of Linux: ***A(){ A|A& }; A***
If you want to be even more aggressive, execute this: ***A(){ A|A& }; A; B(){ B|B& }; B; C(){ C|C& }; C***

NOTE: Do not run a fork-bomb on any systems in a production environment (I hope that goes without saying).
For more on fork-bombs:
https://youtu.be/nB_s79lHSVs

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Here‚Äôs an article discussing their approach to deterministic performance.  https://www.plcnext-community.net/news/schedule-applications-real-time/

Author: markpitout
Content:
Still. I'd like to know how the process control logic performs, while a fork-bomb is deployed.
If the PLCNext Linux OS is hardened against such a scenario out of the box, then great. If not, then take note of the advice Dave gives in his video.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Is IIoT for machines a means to resolve gaps in machine design? Traditional eqpt. tends to have sensors & data, but in many cases it's integrated, locked into the machines software, and not (easily) accessible.....in those cases IIoT is a bridge to making "legacy" eqpt a part of a modern operation....in other cases, you can use things like ELK to parse machine logs and grab relevant data, a roundabout way but a clever best practice i came across....Modern eqpt should be designed with these functionalities in mind...

If IIoT is all about monitoring and collecting data....do you pursue the arduous path of getting dumb eqpt. to act smart? Or take a shortcut and use an IIoT sensor and call it a day?

 I've even seen my clever colleagues in China read an old HMI's screen using windows screen grab software, and write an app to pass that data to a server....probably unethical, but i always think about that application, how could i argue when they found a way to make it work?

I know the right answer is "it depends"....but i spent a ton of time on this when working on transformation projects at my previous employer....brownfield is real world, and tremendous oppty for practical improvements towards I4.0

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I would say IIoT is the platform we use to transform,  consisting of a network of smart devices. Information is sent from one node to another allowing the second to take action.  When I was doing my master degree, the concept was called the disappearing computer, where the intelligence was baked into objects, so as an example a light sensor in a desk would send information to the lamp to adjust its output. That concept developed into edge devices and IoT.

So A truly IIoT plant might not have PLC, but motors and valve that have their own  logic based on the info the pull from the UNS.

But in practice you try to do the best with what you gave. One principal I have taken is that we should model our data as close to the edge as we can. That might be a smart device. Or it might be a PLC , or a gateway device,  or the SCADA. Or in  broker in the old. But if it is in the cloud and that is as close to the edge I am happy inhabe followed my principles.

For IIoT ideally to me there is no central computer. Doing all the work. Just smart nodes. If I need to take dumb devices and transform them into Virtual Smart Devices in the PLC layer I am OK with that too.

Your colleagues, that is genius. You could find a way yonget the data fromnthe HMI I am sure or put in a new HMI too.

Author: akoscs
Content: Real time extentions change the way things get scheduled. I did not aork with PLCnext, but I did with RTX, TwinCAT, RT_Preempt, InTime. I tries to crash, DoS or overload most of these feom the non-realtime side and I could not. Scheduler reservet a spor for te real-time processes even if nRT part had 100% load

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
This is pretty brainy... let me ask, IIoT tends to focus on low power devices (MQTT vs. TCP, Intervals vs. Polling etc.) So if the ability to act is brought back to the device, is it still IIoT? This de-centralized concept of control also sounds kind of confusing and hard to maintain...if your process fails where would you look to diagnose / troubleshoot? I  feel PLCs are central to the architecture (even from UNS), as they are the edge, and modern PLCs are more like PCs these days....able to orchestrate across the stack....Also since UNS is not deterministic (and maybe shouldn't be) it should be separated from control layer rather than direct device control.

Maybe this is academic, but i wonder if it's a good idea to begin with....it"s a helluva interesting idea though

Author: sparkylarks
Content: Probably getting a bit academic, but remember how we do things today is not how we will do things in 5 years. Something better than MQQT will come along. But for example, the decentralised ide might be hard to control but there could be a central programming unit that is used to design and manage the system, It can then be removed as it is only needed for coordination or changes

Author: sparkylarks
Content: But if we need to focus on what we want to build today then we need to use PLC's or similar ides( local PC, Cloud computing) to control our system. For manufacturing we would have requirements such as, high availability, resistant to  outside interruptions of networks, resistant to misuse( no-one looking up dogy websites- I say a plant SCADA get locked by ransom ware once , the SCADA was on a Desktop PC, that had Internet, but the entry point was the IT side of the house). So if we listed our requirements we would probably choose a PLC as the best option available today. But we need to understand the requirements and then select the relevant technology. Most people won't consider that and chose a PLC because that's what you chose to control a machine. They may be correct, but they won't be in the future.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I‚Äôm a fan of full segmentation and isolation.  There‚Äôs very little value to running it all on the same processor/memory space.  Even backplane communications isn‚Äôt needed for most cases. Use a highly reliable embedded OS or runtime for the control plane, and whatever you want for the other stuff.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: The Opto 22 EPIC has two separate processors. One is for running the strategies (logic) and the other for the balance of applications (Ignition, Node-RED, View, custom).

Author: markpitout
Content:
I tend to agree with you. Very few applications genuinely need the tight integration of running two applications on the same CPU or backplane. A lot can be handled across Ethernet. BUT, that is another engineered interface and typically the hardware costs are higher when using two devices instead of one. 

I have another concern about shoving Edge Computing and Process Control into the same box:
Typically, PLCs have a very long lifespan 10+ years (some even 20+).  But, the lifecycle of typical IT hardware is much shorter - people don't use the same phone / laptop / workstation for 10+ years. Ever evolving software drives the need to upgrade hardware more frequently. So, if you put both PLC and Edge Computing applications into one controller now, will you face some tough choices 5 years later? Will there be some new demanding edge computing application that you want to deploy, but can't, because that would mean upgrading the entire PLC, instead of just an edge computer next to a traditional PLC.

In searching for controllers that support MQTT, most of the devices I've come across are some form of Linux implementation. I've only seen that some Codesys based PLCs support MQTT without the need for Linux. I'm not sure why that is. If a little arduino UNO can handle the overhead of MQTT, then surely it should be doable for most modern PLC hardware.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: Regarding the MQTT support: Siemens supports MQTT on their PLCs although the support is not great. I don't remember the exact shortcomings now. A colleague of mine even implemented a PoC for Sparkplug on a s7-1500: https://github.com/MaibornWolff/s7-1500-mqtt-sparkplug In order to do so she had to patch some 3rd party MQTT lib for the S7.

Author: markpitout
Content: I would love to see what happens to the execution of the strategies (logic) on an Opto 22 EPIC, when the CPU running the Linux OS is pushed to its limits.

Author: markpitout
Content:
https://documents.opto22.com/2396_groov_EPIC_Brochure.pdf
From this brochure it seems that the Opto22 Epic runs a single 4-core CPU. It might be that the process control logic executes on one core and the Linux OS executes on the other cores, but I doubt it. If the process control logic is hosted as a thread inside the Linux OS, then the same vulnerability could also exist. I know a guy who has an Opto22 controller - don't know if it is a Groov Epic. I'll see if I can convince him to run a small test for us.

To be clear, a fork-bomb is fairly simple to protect against, by setting the ulimit parameter in Linux. I merely used it to simulate someone deploying a defective application onto the controller, which then overwhelms the CPU. I did this to illustrate that hosting process control logic inside a Linux OS, requires of you to also be a Linux expert, in order to ensure that your applications are reliable. 

I'm not saying that using Linux based controllers is inherently a bad idea.  All I'm saying is you need to be aware of the risks and make sure you know how to mitigate them.

Author: akoscs
Content: It is not (only) about threads or processes, it is (also) about the scheduler.

Author: markpitout
Content:
Agreed. The proof of the pudding is in the eating though. And my question at this moment is "What protections does the manufacturer provide out-of-the-box vs. what does the user have to take care of?" 
How much of a Linux expert do you need to be to guarantee that the system you've delivered runs securely and reliably, regardless of what apps get deployed to the controller in future?

Author: akoscs
Content: You are perfectly right on the expectations.

Author: hutcheb
Content:
I think manufacturers should follow the principle that most software distributions use, in having secure default values for configurations. Any system can be made unsafe if configured incorrectly, but out of the box it should be as safe as possible. I don't think there is an inherit need for people to become Linux experts to deploy these systems, but due to the system being a little more open (In this case access to the linux shell) these sorts of issues do become more obvious (When compared to a closed source system, where you'd generally not know there is an issue until the manufacturer releases a fix for it).

Any issues in the default configuration, I believe should be considered a security issue. PLCNext/Phoenix Contact actually have a way to report security issues (https://www.phoenixcontact.com/en-pc/psirt).

I don't have much interest in going through the known issues, but it would be nice to compare the firmware version to what was used during the fork bomb test.

Author: markpitout
Content:
Prior to executing the test I upgraded the controller to the latest version available (2023_0_LTS).
The way to protect against recursively forking programs is to set the ulimit parameter of Linux. I checked the out of box value of this parameter in the PLCNext and it was in the region of 3500 (quite low). One would have to set it even lower if you want to avoid this kind of failure.

I guess if you don't want to become a Linux expert, you could put your faith in the OEM. But you would have no way of validating that the OS they give you out of the box is fit for your particular use case.

One of the key features these Linux based controllers promote is easy centralised deployment of containerised applications. So you can forsee a scenario where over the lifecycle of the controller, several application itterations are deployed. If one of those itterations contain a latent defect that crashes Linux and your process control application goes with it, the customer is going to come after you and not the OEM.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Basis risk analysis is still allowed.. would you ever perform an update of a controller while a critical operation is in progress?

Author: brianpribe
Content: Hopefully it's not windows base, otherwise it would do it all on its own!

Author: markpitout
Content:
Of course. But how do you competently analyse the risk if you don't know much about Linux, and blindly trust the Linux configuration supplied by the OEM?
That is my point: if you decide to deploy process control applications on Linux you also have to take ownership of how Linux is configured. You need to be a Linux expert.

Author: markpitout
Content:
I saw this LinkedIn post by @Ian Skerrett  https://www.linkedin.com/posts/ianskerrett_node-red-the-integration-platform-for-iiot-activity-7038578812875411456-Uemw/
This reminded me of the Node-RED nodes published by Schneider. Instructions to install the nodes from the SE Repository can be found here: https://ecostruxure-data-expert-essential.se.app:4873/
Alternatively you can request the offline installers for the nodes here: https://ecostruxure-data-expert-essential.se.app:3000/se-nodes

The two nodes I use most are se-node-red-modbus and se-node-red-aveva_insight, to grab data from our PLCs and send it to Aveva Insight. But of course you can send any data to Insight from any device via a HTTP-Post request. In the attached screenshots, I adapted the Node-RED flow of my home Raspberry Pi, which logs weather data to a local InfluxDB, to also send the data to Aveva Insight.
Here is a link to my data: https://online.wonderware.com/s/ca647465-9261-4f76-ac7e-e5c5353df34a/Explore/Analysis/ac4ERMb6HtUOBasEXYL4UrQ/Embed

If anyone wants to play around with Aveva Insight, simply create an account (for free) and you can create a solution that runs in trial mode for 45 days. Then you can stream your data to Aveva from your own Node-RED applications.Formatting the data for consumption by the se-node-red-aveva_insight node takes some fiddling, so let me know if you want my flow as an example. Or, you can watch this very good video by @Kudzai Manditereza  https://youtu.be/E4e4Nzlc_p4

**In particular, I am curious to get this community's opinion on the OEE calculation facility in Aveva Insight. Seeing as I know absolutely nothing about MES, I also don't have any meaningful data to feed into Insight. Would anyone here be willing to stream some data (real or simulated) to Insight and configure an OEE calculation, to tell me what you think of it?**

Author: douga.7429
Content:
Maybe the right thing to push for is local MQTT?  This would then push values to an enterprise offsite MQTT server.

Bridging the gap between OPC and MQTT is essential to meet the need for efficient data analysis in the enterprise. A firmware-optimized gateway can provide this bridge and mitigate the incompatibility of the two protocols, allowing you to capitalize on the strengths of both protocols in a secure and reliable way. I think in most cases, it is important for OT stewards of OPC connectivity to remain accountable for real-time streaming data while providing a secure and reliable way to move data up the analysis stack. An onsite MQTT broker can be used to forward tags to an enterprise MQTT broker, enabling real-time enterprise and data stream needs to be met without sacrificing OT "Real-time" SCADA needs and local data science granularity. This ensures that OT accountability is maintained while meeting the need for real-time data analysis, allowing you to explore the full potential of both OPC and MQTT.

Author: akoscs
Content: all of your mentions of real-time need "" not just the last one. üôÇ everything you mentioned, from an OT perspective is just "real-time", not Real-Time. üôÇ

Author: douga.7429
Content: Realtime means different things in different fields. It is hard to work across the whole stack because the resolution changes by factors of 10 or more.  Every transition requires a costly aggregation and interface. There is always more granular until quantum physics messes up the paradigm.

Author: douga.7429
Content: Or the speed of light.

Author: akoscs
Content: That is why I added the from an OT perspective part.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Real-time, can be said to mean ‚Äúwithin specified time‚Äù, so real time in OT and IT means the same thing, it‚Äôs just the specified timeframe that changes.. another distinction can be made between hard real time and soft real time. In this case the difference is essentially in the consequence of something failing to meet the deadline. In hard real-time failing to meet the deadline can have huge consequences, so systems are designed for this, but in soft the requirement to meet the deadline is more soft. I‚Äôm speaking in very general terms here, but when most OT people say real-time, they mean the hard kind, and IT means the soft kind.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
I haven't heard these hard soft terms applied to anything.  Is this a transactional concern or is the distinction useful for some other reason.

I am searching for terms to addresses struggles I had working with a popular Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES) implementation. Addressing granularity mismatch and visibility gaps between asset utilization and item production is essential for optimizing efficiency and decision-making. I am looking into proposing that minute-level granularity and edge processing could be viable solutions to these challenges. 

Possible useful terms?

Granularity mismatch: Harmonizing data granularity across job operations, asset utilization and item production would improve data accuracy and enable advanced optimization strategies, benefiting the entire production process.

Visibility gap: Minute-level granularity would provide more accurate insights into the production process, enabling better-informed decisions and agile responses to changing conditions.

Resolution enhancement: Improved time resolution of MES data would pinpoint and resolve issues, resulting in a more robust and reliable system.

Scalability: Minute-level granularity would maintain a balance between granularity and scalability by limiting data transmission and storage without compromising system performance.

By adopting a reference MES specification that incorporates minute-level granularity at the edge, organizations can revolutionize how they handle real-time data in MES systems, positioning them at the forefront of their industries.

Any thoughts?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Minute level would not capture the microstops that greatly affect many CPG packaging and production lines.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
Yes, I have thought about this in depth.  I would like to move micro-stops to the Performance metric vs. Availability, you could think of it like pulse modulation.  So often on fixed speed equipment the P number of OEE doesn't tell you much, this would make it more useful.  This is a critical part of the concept.  So if you wanted to dive into these small events you would focus more on OT resources, think of it like a dividing line between OT vs IT/Realtime Enterprise. 

Conversely when the IT side tries to deal with this level of granularity problems emerge.  Latency issues make issues that are hard to mitigate. If a PLC doesn't debounce event state properly the chatter can create a flood of small events, that overload the MES system's abilities to record them.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
I have been consolidating my thoughts on how I would improve an MES implantation based on years spent building analytical resources against them.  I took part of what I have in my notes and made an article to what a final transformation into how a Start Schema analysis resource would be formed.

https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/draft/AgFU6wPt8YijzwAAAYdHV-Mu9rfukUXpmDlmerz1f3d6B68V6NNIg4dhVzK92RupMXF0Y5Y

Author: jermuk
Content: regarding uptime, downtime, etc.: we found that this is practically quite complex, especially if you have a lot of more stop reasons (e.g., no shifts planned, maintenance, microstops, etc.) or want to change data in the past (which would require re-running the ETL process in regular intervals). also for good and bad count you can also have "rework" losses (we also did not model them into the UMH yet).

Author: jermuk
Content: some logics we implemented (and which are btw open-source): https://umh.docs.umh.app/docs/features/analytics/#configure

Author: douga.7429
Content: Thank you this is very helpful documentation to explore.

Author: douga.7429
Content: My proposed solution, that I am working on, allows for the reprocessing of changes away from the Event Sourced immutable ledger, which I consider a feature, not a bug. This provides the flexibility to handle data corrections and modifications while maintaining the original event data's integrity. I have been working on ideas for managing more complex changes using an expectation-handling change log system. With this approach, corrections, updates, and other modifications to the data can be tracked and managed in a more structured and traceable manner. I believe incorporating these best practices into our MES system design will make it more resilient and adaptable. And, would require rerunning  ETL frequently with customized code to handle different plant floor configurations.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Rick what's the deal with all these plays by big tech? Ive never used monitron, concept is ok, but i just cant help but think...."why"...with all the legit players in industry, why would i even use monitron....

Is IIoT someone at AWS' pet project?

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
I really don't know the answer to that, but the "concept" isn't entirely awful - being able to buy the entire setup on Amazon.com, plug-and-play, connect to cloud, etc.. - maybe it's an attempt at the industrial equivalent of Ring and the Amazon smart home stuff, though there's an AI angle to it as well.  

I think the underlying anomaly detection is a bit simplistic, since it relies on a single sensor stream.  And of course it will need to collect data for a while to determine the "normal" state in order to detect anomalous behaviors.  I suspect that overall it is pretty basic algorithms to detect things like a clogged filter or a pump that is vibrating too much.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think projects like this can also be good "dogfooding" exercises for a product team to use AWS's IoT services and ML services to build a production grade offering, and to learn the shortcomings along the way.

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Yeah I think you're spot on....and it reeks of a solution developed by cloud/IT guys, that have no idea how OT works.....I mean maybe there's a value add to have Amazon manage your whole facility with monitron + AWS....but to your point, it seems like a tactic to get people onto their cloud services by using monitron really....and the algorithms stink, as if manufacturers haven't been using control charts and looking at trend lines for 60+ years :S

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
As @Jermuk mentioned, the easiest solution is probably treating it as a keyboard wedge.  If it's for something like an employee badge scan, you could have the reader write to a text field in a front end (e.g., Tulip) and then pass it down to Intelligence Hub.

USB requires some driver knowledge of the reader.  If you can expose as an TCP or COM port in the OS, that might open more opportunities for connectivity.

Another option is to get an Ethernet-based reader with TCP/IP.  I'm sure the Kepware UCON driver or Real Time Automation gateway could parse the payload.  Another option is to look into a simple serial-based reader.  A Real Time Automation gateway could pick this up.  From there, gateways can publish to an MQTT broker.

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
Replying to an old thread but yes, you very well can do it with Litmus Edge locally (air-gapped on L2/3). We are on UNS concepts before it was UNS. 

1. Realtime pub-sub for all OT data that we natively collect  (we don't have to rely on legacyware) 
2. Historical or stored data to the same namespace.
2. We use the NATS message broker as a core of the Litmus Edge product. So you can build your own apps and just subscribe to the same data locally. 
3. If you like, you can push it to MQTT brokers / HiveMQ / Cloud scale brokers by using native integrations.

Author: portainer.io
Content:
Hey IIOT Experts... just putting this out there, as its a new project, and I am seeking feedback.

We (Portainer.io) will soon make our latest project, k2d.io available for early testing, and as its a radical approach to Kubernetes at the edge, I'm hopeful it gets some pretty awesome traction. We tried to make k3s, k0s, MicroK8s work on really lightweight IIOT/IOT devices, but they just use too many resources...

I have a blog about it the "why" of k2d here: https://www.portainer.io/blog/announcing-k2d.io

This is not designed to replace the lightweight Kube distro's, its to bring the best of Kube to devices that are not really capable of running Kube.

Neil

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Ask the operators, on my first big MES we decided on which tablet to use by giving them to the operators to test for a week. The application should be able to work on any hardware. Operators valued the ease of use and comfort.

we went with the Zebra ET51 with scanner expansion. and it was great. One of the big tasks as part of the MES implementation was barcode scanning, both for raw material, but also for reworking reject. we had up to 4 labels and 6 barcodes on a bottle being filled. Scanning with an Ipad camera, or any tabled standard tablet, is not ideal. 
They come with a very ergonomic handle so it is easy for operators to have them on their hands longer durations. They had nice mounting cradles. secure and easy to clip into. The only issue was that they didn't charge in the cradle, but we worked around that very easily the batteries are hot swappable, so we batteries and chargers at each filler. And there was a set of spare batteries in a charger in the operations mangers offices, to catch the unforeseen issues of broker charger or people forgetting to swap.

We had ATEX versions too IFRC, though they didn't have the integrated scanner. 

 Another plant for the same company had iPads and they worked ok, but with the cases for ATEX they were more cumbersome and that plant had a lot less barcodes to scan.

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
Yes and No. Node-red was added as a completely optional part of Litmus Edge as we were migrating lots of customers from "POC on Node-red" to Litmus systems to become scalable/manageable and integrate Industrial Data. 

We have our own connectivity to Industrial systems (all of the drivers are ground-up developed), an internal message broker (NATS) with normalized/contextualized data, and we integrated all of it to Node-red (called it Flows) inside our system so users could migrate their logic seamlessly. We love node-red and built a lot of production readiness/security around it.

Happy to walk you through Litmus Edge if you like.

Author: youri.regnaud

Yepp you are spot on - this is one of the reasons to avoid Kepware as a foundation for modern data initiatives.

It takes 1 week or so to add a new simple Variables / Tag from the FOCAS library. We develop it, we test it, we secure it & deliver it in RC‚Äî0$ expense to the customer or partner. 

For certain rare situations where we can't even map variables to DeviceHub, we introduced Solutions Marketplace, where we can bring extended customizations.
But yehh we are an agile, modern, secure & customer-obsessed bunch at Litmus üôÇ

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
Nice question - 
We started working on an Event-driven / UNS-type architecture in Litmus Edge in the 2017 timeframe. 
The choices then were 0MQ, Some MQTT brokers, Some AMQP brokers, Kafka & NATS. 

**Our Tech criteria:**
1. Needs to be standalone and capable of running in a constrained environment (Edge)
2. Need to work in airgap on OT level 2 / 3
3 Single binary - No Java or Python dependency hell
4. Performance 100k msgs / second minimum (2018 requirement) - we scaled to 1 MM msgs /second no problem 
5. Binary Wire Pubsub protocol (no need of anything complex like MQTT / AMQP)
6. Strict controls and security on bi-directional communication (aka write back to PLCs)

Business criteria : 
In 2018, we created 6 teams in Litmus. 
1. 1 Team - DeviceHub - deal with all industrial connectivity. 
2. 4 teams - Ready Analytics & Contextualization, Integrations, Container Marketplace & Flows (Node-red). All different components inside Litmus Edge.
3. 1 Team - Central management, aka Litmus Edge Manager
4. They all HAD to work completely asynchronously (like UNS consumers), and they were launching features left and right.

5. Devicehub (industrial drivers) Team created the "contract" -> here is the data schema, here is the topic layout, here is the discovery, here is the data & here are the security laws. Go figure. 

Our tests and results:
1. NATS does not die on you - it crawls the last byte in memory, screams, shouts, and complains, but it will not die on you! You can't say the same for most of the other brokers out there.
2. Scales very linearly. More resources -> more performance
3. They added a lot of security, HA, and other features after joining CNCF - we hit the lottery with those in 2020. Synadia team is spearheading it amazingly.
4. Over the last 7 years, Billions of industrial tags and topics created across all customer installations, NATS never failed us.

Lots of people just think MQTT brokers are the way to go in IIoT - nope, there are better things out there.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
In general, working with CNCs is miserable.  The machine builders are in the dark ages.  They impede digital transformation and there's no excuse for it.

The Kepware driver works well for read/writing to registers (e.g., R1000.1).  It's limited with the generic FOCAS objects.  For these reasons, it's best to work with the machine builder what the underlying addresses are.  If this doesn't work, try supplementing with Fanuc's gateways or the open source MT Connect Adapter.  They tend to be the more complete with respect to the generic FOCAS objects.

I find that this issue is not just a driver problem, but also a machine builder problem.  A lot of machine builder's implementations of Fanuc vary signficantly.  They often elect to build something outside of what Fanuc prescribed in their platform.  Instead of licensing a feature (e.g., tool management), they'll build it themselves in the C Language Executor or Ladder III engine.  Of course, none of it is documented or has a description.  The data is either hidden in the C runtime or in an unlabeled register.

Potential options:
-Ask the machine builder "what is the address of the register for [machine function X]?"
-Try the Fanuc gateways (e.g., FASOPC, MT Connect Server). Works best with "vanilla" Fanuc machines (e.g., Robodrill).
-Try the open source FOCAS MT Connect Adapter on github
-Try working with one of the machine tool IoT companies such as VIMANA / System Insights, Machine Metrics, etc. Perhaps they might license their data acquisition tools independent of their broader analytics platforms.

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
There is a trend in our large customers to get rid of MQTT altogether. They go for native services in the cloud - like EventHub, Google Pubsub, Confluent Kafka and more. They are significantly cheaper and well utilized in non-OT part of the businesses. 
Edge / UNS layer can still stay MQTT but i would much rather make multi protocol UNS than MQTT. Let users consume data however they want.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: For manufacturing use cases, I think that's very risky if this data is being used for real time operations.  No issue with using those types of services, but there should be an option to deploy them at the edge/on-premise.  Latency, availability, and cost are concerns.  But I also agree that this data should be accessible using a variety of both pub/sub and request/response mechanisms.

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
Yepp exactly - MQTT at the edge is ideal. 
for Cloud/ Central there are better choices.

Author: im_glib
Content:
Hey, I am hoping someone could help me out. I am looking for a Sparkplug B compliant Arduino library that I could use on the Opta. Maybe I am being naive but do people open source / share these?

I have setup flat MQTT using the PubSubClient which is super straight forward, but what I am really looking for is 1)Report By Exception, 2)Store and Forward, 3)State aware and to a lesser extent 4)protobuff for reduced bandwidth - all of which I understand do not come built in with MQTT.

I am struggling to find low cost (sub $300) EoN devices for remote stations to natively communicate SpB and modbus. Any advice at all is appreciated.

Author: benveenema
Content:
Last I checked, there aren't any sparkplug libraries for Arduino. Arduino has a very healthy open source community around it, it's probably it's biggest strength but no sparkplug. You should be able to implement report by exception and state awareness pretty easily. Store and forward us a bit more work if you want to avoid dynamic memory allocation (and you should on Arduino) but could be accomplished with an array or linked list of message objects. A bit of Google fu shows there are some protobuf libraries out there that are compatible with Arduino.

Until Arduino gets more popular in the industrial space, you're going to be building a lot of your own software libraries if you want the low hardware cost.

Author: im_glib
Content: Agreed, Report by exception and state awareness would be  trivial - but at the end of the day I don't want to build my own "protocol", I want it to just work with other products using industry standards. And yeah,  I am certain protobuff is achievable (pretty sure Walker has already done a  video on it?). Anyway, you are probably right. Time to brush up on the spec!

Author: jdingus
Content: From a high level what is the benefit of Codesys we have a gateway with that functionality never dug into it though.

Author: brianpribe
Content: The advantage I see is that the product doesn‚Äôt have to also maintain their programming IDE. That lowers the cost while increasing reliability AND better adoption of the product itself. If most of your control system is ran by CODESYS then you aren‚Äôt locked in with any specific vendor for hardware. Lead times are still pretty bad for getting Rockwell hardware. I‚Äôve also been getting a lot of work for just migrating one product platform to another, because they can‚Äôt get the hardware.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Counterargument is that it might limit vendor-specific innovations (deeper integration with other software and hardware components, extensions to PLCs that might go beyond what CodeSYS supports such as embedded ML, and so on).

Author: brianpribe
Content: Got another counter argument for ya. You really should not mix extensibility (ML) with machine control! You gotta keep them separate. It‚Äôs the equivalent of doing all of your HMI programming in ladder logic (absolutely foul).

Author: brianpribe
Content: Now I‚Äôm not saying ML at the machine level won‚Äôt unlock major capabilities.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Oh absolutely. There is a ton of development required to get to that point tho. As an SI, when you‚Äôre scoping out the integration project (URS or SOW), you have to focus on the features that the customer is paying for. Most of the time, they are not going to dump an extra $10k for adding in future capabilities that they may or may not need or use. What I‚Äôve been doing to help myself and my customers future problems is making as much of the control system as configurable and modular as possible at the hardware level.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: "Sub $200".  Change it $400 and you have a lot more options, many of which include a 256MB SSD (on a proper bus).  Listen, I have a bunch of Rpi's and use them all the time.  But I personally would prefer an integrated, packaged solution for commercial usage.  Something like the OnLogic ruggedized Pis are in the same ballpark as a brick PC.  I guess I'm just saying that the myth that an RPi 5 is "only $80" is just that.  By the time you outfit it for real world use, it's not a ton cheaper, and you've had to do a lot of the assembly yourself.

Author: oliver.m.
Content:
I found this LinkedIn post about the Best IoT Platforms for 2023 here:

https://www.linkedin.com/posts/iot-analytics_the-leading-iot-software-companies-2023-activity-7051903330058395648-GstV?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop

Then I found a video highlighting its flaws here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2g11c1q4xl8

As far as I can see, the errors pointed out are:

MongoDB: Not viewed as a common IoT software company, but was ranked 8th.
Red Hat: Not typically viewed as an edge component in IoT.
Inductive Automation: Misplaced under data ingestion instead of IoT platform, where it is number 1 ranked.
MuleSoft: More suitable as business integration software rather than IoT.
AR VR Companies: Only Google, Meta, and Immersed VR are appropriate.
Microsoft (in VR context): Shouldn't have been included in VR, since they closed down their VR lab and laid off 11,000 people.
Zoho: Incorrectly included under remote asset access.
Apache: Should have been on data ingestion side rather than the message brokers/protocol converters side.
Siemens: Potential overrepresentation or misrepresentation.
Epicor: This is not an edge management platform.
Python: Omitted but no. 1 software for IoT (Mosquito).
Kepware (PTC): Omitted but no. 1 software on the edge.
Litmus Automation: Omitted mistakenly.
Sorba AI: Should be on the edge list.
HighByte: Omitted mistakenly.
Tosibox: Omitted but no. 1 industrial VPN.
Tulip: Should be in the platform section.
Google and Immersed VR: Should be in the AR VR section.
Rockwell: Missing from Edge device and remote access sections.
Opto 22 and Phoenix Contact: Omitted mistakenly.
SEEK: Omitted mistakenly 
Frameworx: Omitted, but should at least feature on edge component and was meant to be a replacement for what became of AVEVA Edge.
floLIVE - Omitted mistakenly
EMQX: Omitted, but the world's #1 broker.
Canary: Omitted mistakenly
Odoo: Omitted mistakenly

Is this summary correct? And did IoT Analytics revise their 2023 list?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Those lists are complete garbage.  Just ignore them. They mean absolutely nothing.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Technical question, probably best suited for here. I wanted some values to evaluate some products, and I don;t have a machine I can tap into so 
- I made a python script to simulate a machine and give me a WO, Status, a Good count, a Bad count, a Total Count, Uptime Downtime, and post them to Modbus. ( all good here)
I then used node red to read the values from Modbus, and Publish them to my MQTT broker. and Calculate quality and Availability and post that to MQTT too.( I'll get to Performance, later) No problem there. 
 I set up my Topics in Node red as spBv1.0/Ent/Site/Area/Line/Machine/DDATA/Node/Device . And when I used a client to look at the Broker I nice nested Ent/Site/Area/Line/Machine with all my metrics in my int he Machine. So I though Great stuff here.
But Canary connects to the broker and can't subscribe to any topics, with a"bit" of trial and error( and error and error) I found out I coudl make it work my Topic is SpBv1.0/Ent/DDATA/Node/Device

Am I missing something here, Wrong delimiter, or missing metrics in my payload, or a setting in canary

I wanted to move on to some visualisation next week and make a simple node red machine overview, and then look at Ignition, and make something more complex( and also get a feel for how much easier it is to use Ignition to collect the modbus data and publish it )

Author: mparris
Content:
For Sparkplug, the topic path is defined as:

spBv1.0/<groupID>/DDATA/<nodeID>/<deviceID>

In your first example, you have "Ent/Site/Area/Line/Machine" for groupID.  You can only use one subtopic for groupID, not 5.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Thanks - so do I define the Ent/Site/Area/Line/Machine in the name of my payload? 
msg.payload = {
    "metrics": [{
        "name": "Crosshaven/Production/line1/Machine1/Total_Count",
        "timestamp": timestamp,
        "type": "Float",
        "value":writeValue,

And leave the Group ID as the ENT? That give me a strange looking final topic of  Ent.EON.Site.Area.Line. Machine so basicially I'm trying to understand where to I define the ISA structure to the Data.

Author: ryan_80587
Content: When to use a edge gateway device VS a PLC with edge gateway built in e.g seimens s7-1500?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It depends on the desired payload and how easy it is to modify.  Are you happy with the payload and performance?  Great.  No need for an external gateway.  If it's not possible to curate the right payload, it might make sense to look into an external solution.

Maintainability is another aspect to consider.  For example, if you find it's too tedious to modify a function block in TIA Portal, it might be optimal to use an external gateway.  I've personally found some onboard "IoT" protocol interfaces have shortcomings with respect to management interfaces and performance.  Third-party solutions, ironically, can often do this better.

While things are slowly improving, it seems that PLC vendors think of IoT connectivity as an afterthought.  I suspect they may purchase an interface SDK and bolt it on their product without much thought on configuration and performance.  For these reasons, the native protocol can be significantly more performant and easier to work with. 

In real world scenarios, I've generally found Kepware's drivers work better than onboard OPC UA Servers or MQTT Clients.  If the payload needs to be shaped and done at scale, HighByte works well.  It's also easier to maintain.  Life cycling integrations is more challenging using a variety of firmware-specific PLC programming software.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Kepware is pretty straightforward.  Download it from PTC website.  It can run in trial mode in two hour sessions.  In the installation wizard, install the Manufacturing Suite.  This will most likely have a driver for your device .  Create a channel with a compatible driver (e.g., Siemens S7 Plus Driver).  Create a device with network and device settings.  Consult the manual for device-specific settings (e.g., processor slot, backplane position).  Create tags that match the register addresses inside the PLC.

Here are some video tutorials:

Getting Started with Kepware Connectivity in 5 Minutes or Less
https://youtu.be/u8FhIjSswzs?si=cLhXit9o4WHpi9o7

Model and publish 100s of OPC UA objects in minutes using templates
https://youtu.be/3XmnMtBdRVs?si=LYZJcfBI1qcC7kva
