Author: ericschummer
Content: Question for the group: how come this is an iiot-edge channel, and I rarely see anything about Lorawan, wireless sensors, and integrations into enterprise applications from an  IOT perspective ?   is lack of value ?  is that  the crowd is more  into something else ?  is not being familiar with it ?   I would like to hear your opinions on the matter if anyone cares to open the discussion

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Lorawan has its place I think. From my perspective in a traditional manufacturing plant not so much. There are already too many incumbent technologies that can solve the use cases. I know from a process industry side of things it seems to be more popular but also seems like it‚Äôs fighting with WIFI and cellular. My interpretation is its uptake has been mostly driven by asset management/reliability folk that are less caring about the underlying tech and infrastructure required.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
In most manufacturing, physically, there is sufficient density of controllers and networks.  Every few meters, there are assets with three phase power, air lines, water lines, gas lines, etc.  Just moving an asset can cost anywhere from tens of thousands to millions of dollars.  The facilities have the utilities and infrastructure to support the assets.  In this context, running Ethernet to assets is trivial.  There is not really a scarcity of power or networks.

Most of the interoperability problems in manufacturing stem from semantics.  The presentation of data is different in every asset, app, etc.  It's challenging to make the payloads usable.  The secondary challenges are transport protocols.  Almost no one is worried about the physical media (or wireless networks).

The problems with sensors are usually around integrating them into control systems.  Installing shielded cables and analog input modules for PLCs is costly.  There often isn't room inside of electrical panels or the PLC does not have spare capacity.  If bypassing the control system, the challenges are contextualizing the sensor data and merging it with asset data.  There are tons of standalone sensors solutions that are lower cost, but there is an integration cost of making that data usable.

LoRaWAN doesn't really solve a problem that most manufacturers have.  It's just another field network.  They convert these all the time.  The merits of one field network technology over another matter less than having fewer of them and reducing their support burden.  Being able to easily discover, browse, and use the data sent over a network is more important than how it's delivered.  This is what that the telecom and networking companies fail to understand when they try to go to market in industry.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Building on @jpmoniz points, LoRaWAN is more relevant in those fleet or asset management scenarios.  I consider these applications closer to non-industrial IoT and less IIoT / I4.0.  LoRaWAN excels in these applications because there generally isn't infrastructure in place.  There is a scarcity of network and power resources.  A construction yard or trucking company aren't going to have teams to support this stuff.

LoRaWAN could have some merits in some low-tech manufacturing with low levels of automation.  I'm sure there exist off-the-shelf solutions that non-technical teams in operations could deploy for continuous improvement projects.  Though, in a broader digital transformation context, this could be creating a data silo long term.

Process industries and utilities might benefit from LoRaWAN.  They generally have a scarcity of networks and low voltage power.  Their assets are widely distributed.  Having low voltage power available for instrumentation is probably the greatest challenge.  This is why they generally prefer field network technologies that can also deliver power.

Wireless networks in manufacturing are interesting.  They're incredibly useful for supporting functions (e.g., material handling, shipping/receiving, collaboration, inspection, programming automation).  In practice, they're less useful for assets.  Control systems are generally wired and deep in electrical panels.  Setting aside performance and reliability concerns, the cost of bridging a resilient WiFi network to many wired field networks exceeds the cost of running structured cable.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It depends on the constraints of the environment and infrastructure.

Suppose a CNC machine does not have any panel space or inputs for additional sensors.  A standalone sensor can be installed.  It will need low voltage power.  The asset already has this.  The asset is already on a network.  If given the choice between deploying an entirely new wireless network or simply installing a sensor gateway, I would opt with the latter.

Using your turbine scenario or perhaps a legacy air compressor, the environment may look different.   There may be no 24VDC control power infrastructure in place.  There may not be field network to easily connect to.  There may not be an existing data infrastructure (e.g., SCADA, historian, MQTT broker) to acquire this data.  In this scenario, LoRaWAN could be appealing.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I suspect LoRaWAN may be appealing because of your business model.  You may be contracted by a specific persona to solve a specific problem in an industrial company.  You have to deal with all the infrastructure constraints and narrowly solve that problem.  It many not necessarily be in the purview of the buyer to digital transform the entire business including its infrastructure.  They might not be able to solve the problem that their assets still don't have 24VDC and Ethernet as a bare necessity in 2023.

An end user tasked with technology strategy, implementation, maintenance, training, etc may have a different perspective.  They might be less concerned with acqusition cost.  They may be more concerned with total cost of ownership, scalability, extensibility, vendor lock-in, etc.  They also may be more concerned with empowering the entire enterprise to build a set of tools and competancies to support a broader set of objectives.  They may be less concerned with the solution, but the tech and architecture.  That's not to say you aren't concerned with these things.  It's just that the the scope of builders vs buyers can be very different.

Contractors providing solutions for construction, transportation, agriculture industries to manage assets are using LoRaWAN.  Manufacturers producing automobiles and bearings are using PLC inputs and sensor gateways like IO-Link.

Author: efb1010
Content: I definitely see far more opportunities for LoRaWAN in manufacturing.  Many manufacturing sites don't have sufficient infrastructure to have network drops or wifi connections easily.  The lack of technical resources make many manufacturers rely heavily on external resources, even for tasks such as getting a network drop to a machine.  I have seen examples of network drops costing $1500 each and even more if switches don't have available ports.  Also, older equipment may not have ethernet ports.  Many equipment are custom and typically there is little documentation, if any, about the plc code.    It takes months to setup infrastructure, connect with OEMs to get info  and  connect to equipment.   Lorawan could provide an alternative for much faster deployment to test use cases and provide production visibility.       A UNS should still be implemented for scalability and future use cases like utilizing plc data when available.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Though IP/TCP/HTTP and related protocols over LoRaWAN is still a hack. Most use manufacturing cases would work best with Wifi or a 5G network vs a LoRaWAN network.

Author: ericschummer
Content:
I have rewritten the text to improve its clarity, grammar, and punctuation. Please find the revised version below:

Its evident that LoRaWAN is not suitable for large volumnes of real-time monitoring, its just not designed for that purpose. Instead, we use protocols such as HTTP, MQTT, or OPC-UA, depending on the architecture. The MQTT brokers we use can handle millions of messages per second on small footprint appliances. I agree with Ehab that many applications require a certain type of monitoring where one minute, five minutes, or even one message per hour is sufficient. In many cases, it is much cheaper to drop wireless sensors, even if the equipment has a local screen.

LoRaWAN is not intended to replace real-time data networks or ideal for most manufacturing cases. However, it is an excellent new onion layer in the world of data capture. When combined with edge computing, it provides an economical and quick-to-deploy solution, sometimes outside the scope of the network, which is critical for pilots.

Nevertheless, LoRaWAN is fantastic for asset tracking, facilities management, air quality or sound monitoring, and EPA or OSHA reporting. It is also useful for counting and predictive maintenance on rotary equipment, among other places where reaching out is dangerous, complicated, or cabling is not an option.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Exactly.  There are already tons of wireless implementations of the well-known field networks that manufacturers already use.

I think it's important to mention that infrastructure is "expensive" when it's built for a one-off project.  It's not "expensive" when it's built out as infrastructure.  For example, a plant should have a distribution frame every 100m with structured cabling.  This reduces the total and marginal cost of adding nodes to a network.  Similar things are done with power, compressed air, water, etc.  They're installed in a such a way that brings down the cost of extending and deploying these resources.  

Infrastructure is stood up to make other projects possible and not cost prohibitive.  The ROI of infrastructure is indirect and benefits multiple things.  If the same mindset and logic that people use for justifying continuous improvement projects were applied to everything, there wouldn't be a business started or a plant built.

Author: efb1010
Content: Rick.  I definitely agree.  Lora has a very limited payload and only suitable for use cases like communicating sensor state, measurement.   Though many manufacturers have older equipment that can benefit from the quick deployment and lower cost from LoRa uses case.

Author: efb1010
Content: I totally agree. If a manufacturing site has the infrastructure and thier equipment support connectivity, there will no point to look for other limited protocols like LoRaWAN.  However, this is not the reality in every manufacturing site.  Many sites don't have the proper infrastructure and have >30 years old equipment and it's cost prohibitive to upgrade these assests to allow connectivity.  Eric's point to prioritize value by utilizing LoRaWAN in these situations could be a good option.

Author: aronsemle
Content: @jpmoniz we're pretty flexible on when and how we'll make external calls to REST/SQL etc. How frequently are you getting the OPC UA data? You can set up a flow or pipeline to control when and how often you make the REST call, and you can even cache the response for a period (assuming the REST data isn't changing that often). Shoot me a DM or an email aron.semle@highbyte.com and happy to help.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: API calls are made as part of a flow. They only run based on the rule you establish.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: What Aron said...

Author: aronsemle
Content: @DavidSchultz has it :-)! I was trying to look for a video (I've been slacking on the videos) but I would steer you towards using a pipeline read stage to control the REST call. The basic process is gather/model the UA data, send to a pipeline, use a read stage to make the REST call using data from OPC UA, mash the data together, send away

Author: aronsemle
Content: We're working on version 4.0 now where you'll actually be able to control some data flow in your instance javascript. So through javascript read a UA input, pass a param to REST and read that.. it'll be cool but it's still in a prototype phase and QA would be mad if I sent it to you

Author: mparris
Content:
Yeah, Windows 10 IoT Enterprise LTSC is supported with feature updates for 5 years and security patches for 10 years.  The Long-term Servicing Channel is available only in the Windows 10 Enterprise LTSC edition. This edition of Windows doesn‚Äôt include a number of applications, such as Microsoft Edge, Microsoft Store, Cortana (though limited search capabilities remain available), Microsoft Mail, Calendar, OneNote, Weather, News, Sports, Money, Photos, Camera, Music, and Clock. These apps are not supported in Windows 10 Enterprise LTSC edition, even of you install by using sideloading.

Windows 10 Pro versions are only supported for 18months after its release date.  To receive security updates beyond 18 months requires upgrading the OS to a newer version which is likely to include many feature updates, some of which could adversely affect the functionality of the existing applications on the PC.

It just in every implementation I've seen, only the sensor process values get published and the configuration is left hidden away. Seems asinine to me.  They went to the trouble to standardize on a format/protocol.  Why not extend it over to the whiz bang IOT port and MQTT service they so proudly market. Instead stopping 10 feet short. In a kind of "Fu dear customer" buy more shit.  Their IOT Core interface is usable.  Just could of been better.  Rev 2.0 I guess.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'm familiar with their libraries (e.g., AOI, FB) they maintain for PLCs on the fieldbus models (e.g., EtherNet/IP, PROFINET).  These work relative well.  They parse the data structure, defined by the IODD, coming over the fieldbus.  However, I was confused when I explored the "IoT" models.  It doesn't make sense why they didn't make everything browsable as defined by the IODD.  Maybe it was an overhead or performance issue?

I could see the rationale behind putting configuration on a separate REST API to make updates, but it's not clear why they can't publish the config and everything else for monitoring.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Yes I assume its an overhead thing.  I agree the AOI's are good but requires a lot of bloat if you want to do everything over EIP.  What seems to make the most sense right now is to keep the basic sensor data in the PLC and pull via OPC and then manage the configuration status/updates via REST.  This is why I was interested in how highbyte manages the REST connection.  Working this out in Ignition right now.  Thinking HB at the edge would be a better solution.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: For example we use the Balluf BCM 001 3axis vibration monitoring sensors for condition monitoring. We pull the PDO/PDI into PLC's.   Once my controls group commissions them on an application. I want to transfer the management of them to my reliability staff.  To do that they need the requisite tools to manage the sensors. Management includes changing configuration if needed.  Setting alarm points and all the other good stuff. To effectively do that then you need to publish a data object that supports that goal.   Right now you have to essentially custom build that functionality into tools like Ignition. What would make that process a bit more seamless is if the device had a self describing nature built into it. This functionality would obviously have to exist at the master level.  The counter argument to this is to give them the native IFM tools to perform the management functions. I'm not a fan of that as it gives them access to all of the other sensor devices used for other general automation aspects. It also perpetuates the continuance of digital silos and hidden data.

Author: naveed8415
Content:
I have 1400 sewing machines on the production floor, with 1000 machines being IoT-enabled. These machines transmit data through proprietary gateway devices, and each gateway has the capacity to handle data from 30 sewing machines, which is then transmitted to the network router. For the remaining 400 sewing machines, I intend to install IoT sensors to capture data from each machine and transmit it to a standard Wi-Fi router for further processing.

However, with this extensive network of 1400 machines transmitting data to the routers, occasional abnormalities in network traffic occur. These disruptions sometimes necessitate a manual reset before normal traffic is restored. Unfortunately, this can lead to data loss in production, resulting in inaccurate reporting thereafter. What do you think is the issue and how can we resolve this?

Author: naveed8415
Content: 1000 machines transmission is on 433 MHz frequency band while others which are 400 would be WiFi based

Author: ted.garrison
Content: do all 1000 drop at the same time? or is it an individual gateway having an issue each time.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If the reset is a power off/on cycle, a WiFi connected switch or other smart switch can be used. Few will admit it publicly, but this is frequently done with systems that hang, have memory leaks, etc.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I build a system where I for a remote location where I could text the PLC and it would mean that one DO was turned on which open a contractor which was connected to the Internet Router power supply.

Loss of data from a.windfarm had the technicians driving 3 hours each way to turn the router off and on again

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It‚Äôs way more common than many think!

Author: mparris
Content: I think Ubiquiti sells a power switch that their network grease can talk to. Plug the Internet modem into the power switch and if the network gear detects lack of Internet, it will power cycle the modem.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: Anyone successfully configure a Red Lion C10 HMI Sparkplug B connection to Ignition with Distributor and Engine modules? Getting disconnects after a birth payload. No data transmitted. Digging into the Crimson 3.2 documentation to determine any misconfiguration. Thanks!

Author: patanj2
Content: Most common issue causing this would be a duplicate client id  somewhere.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: Thanks for the insite! I will look for that possibility. Although I'm examining the Ignition log files and there's no messages that indicate a duplicate client ID. In the log file I do get a Keep Alive time out message. I made a simple Ignition app to publish and subscribe with the broker and it works fine. Using a different client ID. We've been using a broker in the cloud. We're going to start with a local connection. I'll post when I come up with.

Author: patanj2
Content: The keep alive timeout being exceeded would also cause the broker to forcibly disconnect a client.  I think it actually is triggered at 1.5x the keep-alive timeout,   I would definitely try to chase the cause of that error message down.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content:
Here are some more details: 

Focusing on the Keep Alive Timeout indicated in the Ignition Gateway Status Logs. It looks like the Red Lion HMI is not sending the Keep Alive message and the Sparkplug¬†B connection closes. The broker then reconnects and the Keep Alive Timeout occurs after 15 minutes. 

The MQTT.fx app examines the MQTT messages and indicates the "BIRTH" messages which establish the connection. Then after 15 minutes the "DEATH" message appears. I can see data in the Ignition tag browser, although it goes stale after about a minute (red). I assume this data is coming from the "BIRTH" message payload. See figure. No normal data payloads are transmitted for some reason.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: I just put in a Red Lion support ticket. Will report back after I get more details.

Author: naveed8415
Content: Individual issues and randomly occur once or twice in a day

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: For the curious, we eliminated the Red Lion to Sparkplug misconfiguration by successfully connecting to a local Ignition broker. The client architecture includes a Pepwave cellular internet connection. We have been using mqtt port 1883. We suspect the cellular internet provider, Verizon, blocks that port. We're going to switch over to the secure port 8883.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Genuinely thanks,

my OCD hates when I don't hear how problems get resolved.

Author: patanj2
Content: Interesting though from your description it sounds like the device made a connection and then successfully published a birth message,  which would have been over the same port.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Do all the machines on a given gateway fail at the same time, or just random machines, while others on the same gateway continue to work fine.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: Looks like multiple issues. Tech support at Red Lion discovered a firmware issue with Sparkplug B. Will post an update when I have More details.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: This company is new to Ignition and I'm working on their development system. Only one Red Lion device, Graphite G10, and one Ignition Gateway. Red Lion support discovered a Sparkling B software issue they're working on.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: Right now getting my head wrapped around the SSL CA, self signed, third party certificate jungle. Been having conversations with ChatGPT about it.

Content: @Mario Ishikawa has been a great help in this process. He's been there and done that.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I was talking to a client earlier who asked about an upcoming project.
The idea will be to connect and control some electric chargers.( No ides the make or model or the comms protocols yet)
There will probably be some integration to hardwired devices, but of the focus will be on pulling the data from the Charger and collect, Contextualise, Normalise it and publish it somewhere.

The conservative approach for this would be a siemens IOT2000 with maybe a soft PLC running. ( Or 
But I wanted to look at some other options such as the PLCNext, or a Revolution PI  or maybe even the ONLogic ( 4G comms might be usefull too)

I just wanted to check was there anything else I am forgetting in the small IoT gateway, that can have some hardwired options.

Content: Solar battery chargers?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
will be charging cars etc. from the general electric Grid. Tied in to an eco system that contains >1000GW of Generation, Gas, Wind and Solar. Wind and Solar are >100MW sites

I figured if I could run the MING stack, or even Ignition Edge, and also have a small soft PLC, I shoudl be covered for most of the uses cases. 

I came up with a list of 5 
1.    Siemens IOT2000 Series:   ( Customer uses a lot of Siemens, already)
2.    RevPi Connect 4 (Revolution Pi): 
3.    WAGO PFC200 Controller: A pretty good option, but CODESYS
4.    OnLogic Systems (FR202):  I really like the look of this, especially the inbult 4G which could be useful
5.    Phoenix Contact  Edge or PLC Next.

The Lenovo and Dell mentioned previously are probably a bit too powerful.

Author: aristotelestn
Content: Why not consider using Siemens Industrial Edge, especially since the client prefers Siemens products?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Is Siemens Industrial Edge an updated MindSphere, or an Edge Based equivalent?
I included the IOT2000 series, is that not part of the Siemens Industrial Edge? Do you have experience with any that would point toward  the other devices. 
IF this scales there could be a reasonable numbers, let's say scores, hundreds is a bit optimistic. so price point become a concern too.

Author: aristotelestn
Content: In fact, they are complementary things. The IOT2000 is basically an intelligent gateway with industrial robustness, while the Siemens Industrial Edge is a multifunctional platform. I don't see an equivalence with Mindsphere because the objectives are different. It depends on the need and application. For example, if the solution needs to work on the Edge and requires running apps, the Siemens Industrial Edge would be a great solution with affordable cost. On the other hand, if the goal is to transfer data from the plant to a remote operations center, the IOT2000 would be the solution. To give a better opinion, I need to know more details about the use case. Feel free to send me a DM if you need anything else.

Author: aristotelestn
Content: Currently, I use both solutions, but for small to medium-sized applications.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: It is still at concept, but I will reach out if it takes off.  thanks

Author: diederik9434
Content:
Hi everyone, I'm looking for a historian fitting for my usecase.
I have a beginning OEM that wants to collect data from its machines worldwide.

Ideally it should be: cloudbased, easy to setup & maintain, able to connect to MQTT and/or OPCUA and cheap

We very price bound and not very IT minded. Ideally i would have a historian as a service somewhere in the cloud. I dont know many of these. (Factry.io & Canary?) These are pricy. 

Second best option i could think of is to reproduce their functionality kinda DIY.
using cloud grafana, cloud influx/timescaledb and nodered connection i was able to make something.

other option is to have a local NAS with some docker containers and visualize locally (and connect over VPN?)

Anyone has some experiences/recommendations? 

Thanks! Diederik

Author: scrapper7161
Content:
I am quite bias in this case, but definitely I would use mqtt first on the edge. Full TLS  using a bridge to a main IOT (mqtt broker) . This main broker, probably would use something like a linode or vultr using mongo/ PostegreSqL to store a database and place a service that connects from the main broker to the connector. If required to scale the system we can place another sink machine.  
The main broker is something that needs to scale, there are a lot of solutions . ( One where I work üòÄ)
But it is best to do that because you focus on what creates value.
Mounting the pipeline you probably have a lot of recommendations here , but UNS all the way. Since you can route with UNS the customers and make a "data  balance" solution.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
@Hugo Vaz here's what Walker had to say.

Walker Reynolds
Deploy container that runs a pull from GitHub

Docker Scout is not inherently unsafe

Author: scrapper7161
Content:
Thanks, @Vaughn Turner . Given your approach, it actually sparked more ideas. Sorry to pick your brain and @Walker Reynolds , but now I have a couple of quick questions that really got me thinking üòÖ:

With the GitHub pull strategy, how do you tackle security vulnerabilities in containers?

And regarding managing dependencies within these containers, have you ever run into issues where this setup complicates package updates or conflict resolution?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Not just containers - anything that does a pull from places like NPM, that loads browser libraries/frameworks from external URLs, low-code environments that allow uncertified and uncurated "extensions", and so on.

Author: scrapper7161
Content: NPM is a can of worms..... üòÖ

Author: rickbullotta
Content: So is any devops or deployment process that downloads from a public repo!

Author: scrapper7161
Content:
exactly my question, how can we really overcome that. that is why i ask -> With the GitHub pull strategy, how do you tackle security vulnerabilities in containers?
is this a really necessity for the industry, how we all valdiate this?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: End the lunacy of continuous deployment.  It was a dumb idea from the getgo.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also, curated and validated ecosystems of plug-ins are essential.  They need to be vetted, tested, security scanned, and associated with an entity that stands behind them.

Author: nkhalasi
Content: Is it possible to share the Dockerfile to be able to understand your containerisation process and security requirements better?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Show me the specific vulnerability and I'll tell you how I'm going to mitigate it.  We have not run into package update/conflict resolution issues yet.  That being said, most commercial industrial software providers manage docker files and compose themselves -- they are not managed nor supported with public repositories.  The days of commercial, internal, closed dev ops and SDLC are way long gone.  We make it work because we won't be relevant if we don't.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: I think they are a great solution. They have products at the edge and a central broker. + they work well with other solutions. Open Architecture by design. I look forward to diving deeper with Litmus in our next Mastermind Session on April 12th.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: have you looked at Portainer.io as a docker management solution?

Author: zack.scriven
Content: what makes continuous deployment dumb?

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Zack Scriven, you just advanced to level 8!

Author: scrapper7161
Content: Yes. It doesn't fix the problem it kinda of automates the issue. Ci/CD is key. But how do you know what you have inside your docker?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Dependency issues that don't show until deployment, often forces inadequate testing time, doesn't synchronize releases with a stable system typically (stable features, maybe, but feature cross dependency issues can get AFU), not super great for regulated environments with validation requirements.  Also, UX issues and side effects from service/back-end changes are rarely adequately tested automatically.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: "In theory" if you have adequate testing and security checks in the pipeline it could be manageable - very few do.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: i always took it you live in the world of theory lol

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The world of practice.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: But in theory you are correct about the short comings of MQTT specifically sparkplug. But in practice it has proven to solve business problems today. I‚Äôm not convinced

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Yes but we can do so much better.  Everything we talk about with digital transformation and learning and improving is all about ‚Äúdoing better‚Äù.  We need to expect the same from our industry and our vendors, and we need to be a  force for change.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: üíØ

Author: zack.scriven
Content: I think one way to accomplish that is making sure all software vendors adopt the land and expand / 2-hour demo model. This allows the most users to try the software, build a POC and show value all before going to get approval for funding.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: Wouldn‚Äôt you agree?

Author: nickn5549
Content: It is a hard thing to do.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Some, not all.  Some have too big a ‚Äúlift‚Äù and/or are an all or nothing implementation. I‚Äôd also like to see more transparent pricing from more vendors.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: But if I had a choice between a vendor with a 50% solution who offered free POCs and another with a 90% solution who didn‚Äôt, I‚Äôm going with the better fit all day every day.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: I agree with your choice. Though that is a false dichotomy obviously.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The problem I run into is how do I know what a software can do,  a 3 month trial is great, but not really if there are other pressures between work and life. and especially if it is a performant software that takes a bit of learning. 

I'll have used the free POC, and a few tool and some spit and baling twine to get to a 85% solution, and I never knew what the other 90% solution could do because I got distracted during the trial, or even worse , I couldn't just download the software and look.

If the alternatives are crap, that is ok, so Excel is ok, because I can try openoffice calc, but I'll come back to excel.
But if the use case is a broker, I'll start with Mosquitto, and if I need to scale, and EMQx or Hive don't allow me easily check out the software, I'll have gone with the other one.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I can get a pretty good sense of a product‚Äôs capabilities and such via the docs and training videos. Which is another thing that more companies need to make accessible and openly browsable. Ignition does a very good job of this.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: This.  While I'd prefer to be able to just play with it myself so I can truly understand learning curve, at a minimum give me access to the training vids so I can see how it's USED, not just some canned sales videos showing how amazing the dashboard is going to be for the CEO to run the company with.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: The Inductive university course was a very effective intro to what Ignition can do..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Word! Getting a three month trial is a big commitment.. i have to devote the time to trial it properly, in an already busy schedule.. not to mention that i may have like eight different at any time, that id want to try, first just getting to the point of actually getting access to the trial from those business dev people, installing it, squeezing in like 30 minutes to trial it, following up further with the business developer that keeps asking how the trial is going, getting a quote that is 10x your budget, politely letting them know you have to reconsider the scope, trial it a bit more finding it is not what you imagined as the online documentation is too limited, keep getting emails every 6-12 months, and being subscribed to yet another newsletter..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Compare this to, Hey, this is interesting, download, try for a couple of hours, nah doesnt quite do it for us.. rinse and repeat!

Author: _dyland
Content: This last part is a compelling argument against the 2 hour trial license though. While I believe that a lot of bad software hides behind this obfuscation there are instances where more context is required than what a self guided and isolated couple hours can display.

Author: _dyland
Content: But as a user of software, I 100% will ignore a product if I have to talk to someone... If barriers are places between me and a product I often just walk away. I am just saying I can see both sides.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I don't mind the talking to people, or having to send an email, or join a mailing list, as long as it is quick,
but to expand on @Jon Forbord While I am waiting for access to some software, I have downloaded 2 or 3 alternatives, tried them out and found that I think one of them can work, and I go with that one.

Author: _dyland
Content: That is my main issue, by the time I get a response or a 30 day trial I am often on a whole other thought... 31 days later when I return to the original issue the trial is expired.

Author: _dyland
Content: I am a fan of the trials that count down time in the software rather than calendar time though.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: 100% this, but getting an extension is normally easy, with a polite email. I don't mind that.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: The last part had a cost if excactly 0 for the vendor. The mental leap for the vendor to accept this risk, is probably why so many are hesitant to adopt the land and expand model. They are used to every sales opportunity having some associated cost..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I do mind, if all I‚Äôm doing is ¬´browsing¬ª.. i dont want to impose or overstay my welcome.

Just one outbound connection so shouldn't be an issue in my opinion but in reality it might be a hard sell.

Author: mparris
Content: Are controls engineers directly interfacing with the Cisco tools to help manage those networks, or is it only a dedicated team with network specialization that interfaces with the tools?

Author: zeratall
Content: It is OT assigned network engineers that work hand in hand with controls engineers but they are part of a specialized team under the CIO. SDA is centrally managed by design.

Author: mparris
Content:
SDN as a technology is clearly a game-changer...but how it is implemented tells me whether it's an IT SDN solution or an OT SDN solution.

At one edge of the spectrum, if the interface is intuitive enough for a controls engineer to manage day-to-day himself after being setup by an OT network group, then I consider that an OT SDN solution.

At the other edge of the spectrum, if the interface is complicated (lots of pages to cycle through, lots of levers to configure, etc) where a dedicated team is required to manage it on behalf of controls engineers, then I consider this an IT SDN solution...even though it may be used within an OT-type environment.

The organizational structure of a business is what will drive which type of solution is most appropriate to use....and I get the sense that the majority of manufacturers need a solution that controls engineers can be empowered to manage.

I'm curious to hear what others think....

Do you prefer to have controls engineers manage the networks of the systems they are responsible for (within a guidelines setup by an OT architecture team), 

or

Do you prefer to outsource network management to a specialized network team that a controls engineer must engage?

Author: zeratall
Content:
Let me ask you this, what sort of activities are you expecting controls engineers to be able to perform regarding Reoccurring Network Support? 

In a large organization I would be **shocked **if Controls Engineers were authoring/updating IOS configs and remoting into switches and deploying them. Traditionally for enterprise where you have large breakouts of functional teams, the typical reoccurring support of a network is **ALWAYS **done by a dedicated Network Operations team member. That Network Operations member will be part of a product team to ensure they understand the specific needs of a control engineer and to be embedded to be more responsive to the needs of engineers, but its always a separation of activities which is often dictated by requirements (No one role can do everything, you have to be a separation of responbility) 

SDA is not a lot of levers to configure, its designed to be an "Intent-Based" Meaning it abstracts the complexity from Network Operations Teams so they can refactor faster and manage complexity at scale. Here is a good refence that expands (still high level) from Cisco: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/internet-of-things/nb-09-intent-based-iot-wp-cte-en.html

Author: mparris
Content:
To clarify, I view SDN (software-defined networking) to include SDA (software-defined access).

Consider that a SDN deployment allows the team to lock down network access, where devices are identified and authorized to only communicate with other identified devices.  The concept here is to bring firewall capability to every switch port.

Given this scenario, I would say the controls engineers that know the machine are best suited to identify what devices should be on teh network, and what connections should be happening between those devices.  So I see the controls engineer being able follow a workflow to:
(1) create groups of devices (PLC, IO, HMI, etc)
(2) create communication flows between groups (protocols, directionality, etc)
(3) identify devices on the network, and assign to these groups.

Given a deny-by-default posture, I also view the controls engineer needing the ability to sustain the SDN system over the life of the machine, as components are added to the network, or components need to be replaced whcih have new unique identifiers.

I agree, controls engineers are not "authoring/updating IOS configs and remoting into switches and deploying them".  And to be honest, given we are in 2024, the thought of asking anyone to do this makes me ü§¢

Author: zeratall
Content: Your exactly correct, the difference is that domain knowledge is being fed to the Network Ops team to implement, it‚Äôs designed by controls engineer (to meet OT needs) but implemented by Network Ops. That‚Äôs why I wanted to understand what you meant, I think the point you‚Äôre making is the information should be coming from the controls engineer, which I agree.

Author: mparris
Content:
I actually do go one step further...

An OT SDN solution should provide an platform where an OT Architect (or team) can stand up and implement overarching guidelines/restrictions regarding connectivity (controlling site-to-site comms, or cell-to-site comms, etc).  Additionally, an OT SDN solution should provide an intuitive interface for a controls engineer work within the implemented guidelines/restrictions to follow the workflow I outlined above to manage the system directly, without needing a middle man.

Author: zeratall
Content:
And that‚Äôs where I disagree, I understand the sentiment of empowering people to make changes on their own for the sake of speed, but process engineers are not network SMEs they are focused on process/control. Network support should be managed by Network Ops. The domain knowledge should be coming from OT but it must be a separation of responsibility which is often a hard requirement. 

The only problem with the approach I‚Äôm talking about is the ‚Äúresponsiveness‚Äù of Network Ops to be able to respond to OT requests. That‚Äôs why you MUST embed  network ops in OT teams.

Author: mparris
Content:
To help me understand your POV, lets slide all the way over to one end of the complexity scale: consider a single switch, with a single subnet and devices communicating with other devices within that subnet on that single switch.

In this scenario, the desire is still be to have a deny-by-default posture, where connecting a new device into that switch would result in no traffic going to or from that new device.

Where do you see needing Network SME-level expertise to assist a controls engineer to identify devices, group devices within functional groups, and define the allowed networking flows between those groups?

Author: zeratall
Content: In that scenario I think it does make sense to give more control to the environment owners because what your talking about essentially is an air gapped network and the changes to that environment are constrained to that single subnet, the enterprise use case I‚Äôm talking about is the opposite of that.

Author: mparris
Content:
We might be on the same page here, then...

So, starting to expand this simple scenario, what if there are two switches, each with different subnets, and they are connected by a router?

Thoughts on a controls engineer managing their respective subnets, and an OT Architect/Network Engineer managing the comms between subnets?

Author: zeratall
Content: Yep exactly.

Author: mparris
Content: Given your experience with the Cisco SDA solution, does it provide an intuitive interface for Controls Engineers themselves to manage their respective subnets?

Author: zeratall
Content: Without getting into specifics, I would say if that is your intent, SDA wouldn‚Äôt be the optimal choice, it‚Äôs really designed for enterprise use case where governance is needed, I still think it‚Äôs a good choice for OT but especially for smaller more isolated networks there are better options.

Author: mparris
Content:
So back to my question to understand your POV:

what items within the scope of a single subnet (within a larger enterprise) are you seeing a need to centrally govern?  Items that would typically be managed by independent controls engineers?  Is it naming conventions for groups, communication flow definition, other?

Author: zeratall
Content: At a high level and I can‚Äôt get into specifics, I will say because SDA is meant to be deployed as a hub and spoke, there are some mechanics of why that it becomes hard to do what your proposing without having someone to govern what‚Äôs being implemented. If you read the documentation I think you‚Äôll understand what I mean fairly quickly.

Author: zeratall
Content: Maybe a better way for me to phrase my opinion is I think we largely agree, the problem is I haven‚Äôt seen a  SDN technology that would pair nicely with that approach yet.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I think the root issue is that there are not formal resources allocated for standing up and maintaining ICS networks.  It‚Äôs either this locked down, excessively risk adverse, and impossible to change scenario -or- it‚Äôs this chaotic, risky, free-for-all scenario.

Companies should be thinking of factories as more like data centers in which there is an operational competency in keeping up with the adds, moves, changes, etc.  If the only person with access to IOS CLI is also responsible for a ton of other stuff (e.g., plants, branch offices, data center, integrating acquired business units), it‚Äôs going to be a disaster.  If it‚Äôs maintenance techs improvising with an unmanaged switch they bought at the local consumer electronics store or automation direct, it‚Äôs also going to be a disaster.  

If one thinks about it, adding a new line in a factory with modern automation is not unlike adding a small data center, an IDF, or a mid sized branch office.  These types of projects can keep network teams busy for many weeks or months.  If the solution is to submit a ticket to a overloaded help desk or improvise with ad-hoc efforts, it should be no surprise there are issues.  SDN or non-SDA, people need to know what they‚Äôre doing and its impact.  Companies need to simply invest in efficiently managing their industrial networks.  If a controls engineer doesn‚Äôt how routing protocols work and it takes a network engineer six months to process changes, they‚Äôre under investing.

Author: zeratall
Content: Very well said, I think we all agree it CANNOT just be submit a ticket and then wait 6 months, if you are going to have discrete roles aka dedicated Network Ops, they have to be embedded with the teams. That being said it requires a large org structure to achieve that. The model I see is very similiar to organizations that have adopted development teams for microservices.

Content:
I don't have experience with LMQTT. However, we have used Proxus Edge for several projects with similar requirements (disclaimer: I am the creator of https://www.proxus.io/). Yes, an edge device will be needed, but you can group PLCs on the same network with a single edge, and Proxus Edge can even run on a Raspberry Pi. The best part is that you can do the analysis of the collected data at the edge. In this way, instead of using the edge device only for data flow, you can distribute the workload by moving all data analysis and actions to the edge.

https://youtu.be/DYeAaFOcEsg

Author: eoinmurphy
Content:
I haven't used it in production, just did a benchtest with an S7-1212 and S7-1516 PLC. 
Like others have mentioned, the issue is that the LMQTT library can be quite heavy on resources (uses a lot of work memory).
What I have found is that for a S7-1500 it can be used for some small use cases / small quantity of topics.
For an S7-1200 I wouldn't recommend it as you will run into memory issues pretty quick (I maxed out the work memory on the S7-1200 with less than 10 topics being published).

Author: aaronglennshepherd
Content:
Hello all, trying to interface to some legacy PLC's (Omron CQM1H) in our facility.  I have been trialing a cMT-SVR-102 as PLC only has a serial port available.  On the test stand we have the PLC connected via serial Omron Hostlink to CMT and a separate existing HMI to the PLC also via Hostlink. CMT is publishing to local Ignition server via Sparkplug.  I have a few questions:

1.  Is there an easy way to import tags into the MQTT payload?  These seem to have to be done manually.  I understand I can upload a CSV or Excel with the tags themselves to the program, but to build the Sparkplug payload seems manual.  I have 9 devices with about 500 tag each, so was looking for an easier way.  I'm currently trying to do up a python script to automatically load the payload with them in an organized folder structure from an excel file. 

2.  More critically, I am running the Sparkplug demo project and added in my PLC and a few tags to the MQTT payload.  When the DDATA being sent transitions from the HMI to the PLC and back again the node rebirths on every handover.   I'm only planning to use this as a gateway to connect PLC tags only to Ignition and no HMI tags/functionality, so maybe this is a non-issue if I only have PLC tags, but it's a bit concerning I'm possibly missing something basic.

Author: aaronglennshepherd
Content:
I wanted to circle back on this for anyone having the same issues.  Matt had nailed the issues.  

1. Duplication in the GroupID and Edge NodeID.  I have only one CMT-SVR device I'm testing, but while the physical device used the programmed GroupID and Edge NodeID, when I ran the device in "online simulation mode" to modify tag values to see they propagated to the broker properly, this simulated device also used the same GroupID and Edge Node ID causing the conflict and multiple instances of stale data, Message Sequence number ERROR messages in the logs and rebirths . When I changed the Edge NodeID before running the simulator so it didn't conflict with what was programmed in the physical device the issue went away.

2.  The namespace error:  I had been following the "Building a UNS Part 1" video in the mastermind series and about an hour into the video Walker had us add a custom namespace called "All" subscribing to "#".  This caused the sparkplug payload to conflict and give the "unable to handle payload on custom namespace" error in the logs.  I temporarily have changed this custom namespace to subscribe to "EverythingElse/#" until I work through the rest of the series to see the best way to configure the tag structures/namespaces.

Matt, thanks for your support on troubleshooting this.  I've had it running for a while now with no stability issues sending data from either source (local HMI, CMT-SVR Simulator, or connected PLC).

Author: aaronglennshepherd
Content:
I'm following along /learning this with you.  What are you connecting to COM2?  Are you running one of the Sparkplug demos?    Some things that got me tripped up were:  Tweaking PLC settings and left it in program mode and not run mode, oops !,  and doing a "clean program" to get rid of the HMi demo stuff, but not setting up the sparkplug registers.  In the sparkplug demo, the data you enter for the MQTT setup is loaded to HMI registers & I believe and these are displayed on the demo, but the HMI interface, specifically the start button is programmed to push a 1 to the correct register to open the actual connection to the broker.  So if you aren't doing an online simulation and aren't getting any data, check this.  If you are simulating and also have the software running, make sure the Edge Node ID on your physical device and your "online simulation" are different so they don't cause a conflict. 

I too am now looking for:  1) How do I set this up so it lands in the right spot in my UNS (currently it's landing under Edge Devices under the [MQTT Engine] tag provider, but I want this to be in the ISA structure or at least an organized sparkplug structure, and 2) at what point do I flatten this to vanilla MQTT?

Content:
Refer to this article:
https://www.hivemq.com/blog/implementing-unified-namespace-uns-mqtt-sparkplug/#heading-parris-and-schultz-methods-for-uns-structuring-with-mqtt-sparkplug

Sparkplug is limited in the way you are wanting to use it.  This has been suggested: a variable topic ahead of the spBv1.0 keyword: 
https://github.com/eclipse-sparkplug/sparkplug/issues/261#issuecomment-2126299472

Author: dramon93
Content: I read both articles, however, in the GitHub forum, how is it possible to publish under a prepended topic path (e.g., "plant1/area51/spBv1.0/myGroup/NDATA/myNode")? or is he referring to the Schultz method where that is a different broker being called in another UNS to form your ISA-95 format?

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content:
As I understand SbB can just be published on the root, so it always start with spBv1.0
Question, why is it always spBv1.0 if Canary works with SpB v 2.2 and 3? Ignition just use version 1.0? are they compatible?

Author: mparris
Content:
"how is it possible to publish under a prepended topic path"

If both the producer and consumer have the capability, then it's possible.

But since the Sparkplug Standard never advertised that this could be possible and defined "spBv1.0" as a root topic, then no products are doing it.

The Github issue is a request to update the standard to provide a mandatory option to configure a prepended topic path

Author: mparris
Content:
you are referencing two different version numbers, which is why it's confusing.

There is the namespace version number (spBv1.0), which means a consumer that understands this namespace will always be able to decode/participate in that namespace.

Sparkplug v2.2 and 3.0 are specification document revision numbers that tell you how to create/participate in a spBv1.0 namespace.

Sparkplug version 4 may come up with a new namespace (spCv1.0), whcih has different rules/function than the spBv1.0 namespace

Author: dramon93
Content:
To give a little bit more context about my experiment, let me start with my previous setup.

A few years ago, I bought the AutomationDirect MQTT gateway (SGW-MQ1611) and have been using it to the best of my knowledge as part of my Unified Namespace (UNS). This device only works with flat MQTT, which has been great, but I decided it's time to move up to Sparkplug B (SPB).

Based on Walker‚Äôs recommendations in various videos, I decided to try the cMT-SVR device from Maple Systems.

Currently, I have 25 industrial oven controllers connected to the MQTT gateway over serial COM (Modbus RTU). For my online testing with the cMT-SVR, I created a simple HMI screen in EasyBuilder Pro, version V6.09.01.524 (the version is important because it allows me to export and import tags via Excel; otherwise, it would be a massive pain to create 100+ tags manually).

I connected my laptop to my oven devices via serial COM 4 (configured in the system parameters tab before trying the actual hardware) and ran the online simulation. I verified that the HMI screen shows real-time data from my devices, and I checked via Ignition Edge to see if it is publishing the SPB data.

When I run the online simulation, it shows that it is publishing the SPB messages under the "local_hmi" topic (even if you don't have any tags set up in SPB). However, the tags I created for my "local_device_2" (the device set up on COM2 or COM4 for PC) are not being published to the broker.

This is my current situation with the cMT-SVR. I have reached out to Maple Systems to see if they can spot an issue in my current setup or if something else is going on. It doesn't make sense that it's not publishing anything from that local device.

I wonder if the issue has to do with the import/export beta version they let me use for the SPB tags in EasyBuilderPro.

Author: aaronglennshepherd
Content:
Sorry, I'm new to this and only working with it recently as well, but did you get your COM data publishing from your laptop, but not from your CMT?  

What I experienced was the UNS would show the PLC as active when the PLC published data to the COM port and the HMI was stale/red/empty and when I published HMI data, the HMI would rebirth and the PLC data would then be red/stale/empty and so on.

When I ran into this issue, it was because the Group ID and Edge Node ID from **the physical CMT MQTT configuration** that I downloaded to the CMT was conflicting with **the Online Simulation MQTT configuration** Group ID and Edge Node ID. What I experienced when they were the same was I would get multiple disconnects and rebirths of the edge node.  So log into your Ignition Gateway and check the STATUS, DIAGNOSTICS, LOGS for a message similar to this:  Failed to handle the DDATA message for SpBv1.0/[YourGroupID]/DDATA/[YourEdgeNodeID] with a + symbol next to it and that plus when expanded would tell you "Message Sequence Error...".  if this is the case, you have to change your Edge Node ID or Group ID in MQTT configuration BEFORE launching the simulation so it is different than the CMT.

Author: dramon93
Content:
everything that I ran was without the actual cMt-SVR device. so, i connected my laptop as if it was the SVR. 
it makes sense because they need to be unique to work well in the broker. if you had the same program in the online simulation and the SVR it will come with conflict issues in the broker.

Author: dramon93
Content: but I have not run it like that. I'm either using the online simulation only or the cMT-SVR, not simultaneously.

Author: aaronglennshepherd
Content: OK.  I'm not too  familiar with how else I can fail with this yet, but maybe the CMT was not making connection to the broker somehow?  I did also try a "fresh" program with only my COM device tags and configured the MQTT settings on the CMT, but I had failed to recognize that the registers on the HMI need to be populated specifically to initiate the broker connection.  Were you getting the connection the the broker with the CMT at all  or just your laptop?  Sorry, I don't have many other ideas to try out.

Author: dramon93
Content:
if you are using the default settings in the mqtt settings in the easybuilderPro you should have in the local hmi, tags LW -0 and LW-1 should give you the status of the MQTT connection to the broker.  you can use it when you run the simulation or when you compile everything to you SVR. 
if LW-0 = 2 is connected. 
if thats the case you could try using MQTT Explorer to see if youre getting the messages there from your broker, and if that is the case, we move to the ignition side and troubleshoot from there.

Author: dramon93
Content: I figured it out. the online simulation in the easybuilder pro does not reflect well the SPB messages going from other devices that are not the "local hmi". It took me a long time. Then, it also does not publish the values in your cMT-SVR if the hardware is not communicating well with your local devices. it needs to be able to provide real data in order to publish the SPB messages to the broker from any other device that is not your "local hmi" (in my case my COM2 oven devices).

Author: joonas_e
Content:
Hello experts! I'm new to the IoT field, so any advice is welcome. I've been watching the 4.0 Solutions YouTube channel and trying to absorb a lot of new information. For my computer science and communication engineering thesis, I need to conceptualize an IIoT (Industrial Internet of Things) application. As a gateway, I plan to use the Linux Debian-based **Simatic IoT2050** device, which sits between the PLC (Programmable Logic Controller) and the cloud. I'm considering using either the **EMQX broker** or **NeuronEX**, both of which can be installed on the IoT2050 gateway. And I definitely want to use the **Sparkplug B protocol**.

So far, I haven't found a ready-made application or add-on that allows data from the PLC or sensors to be stored in the gateway's memory when the internet connection is lost and then sent to the cloud once the connection is restored. In some applications, it's crucial not to lose data during connection outages. Is there a free application for this, or do I need to write custom code (e.g., in C#) to achieve this functionality? Any good suggestions? üòä

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Why Sparkplug though?

Author: joonas_e
Content: Apologies for the lack of clarity. The intention is to use OPC-UA between the PLC and the gateway, but between the gateway and the MQTT broker, I would like to use Sparkplug B.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Why? It has little value unless the consumers of the data can understand sparkplug, and that‚Äôs a very short list.

This would be critical when sending UDTs/structs etc. from the PLC.

Author: dylan_iiot
Content: Hello Industry 4.0 world. Question regarding edge devices. Is it better to have edge devices sending data directly to your central UNS platform, or devices that send data to their own OEM cloud platform first and then via APIs send the data to the UNS? My concern with devices that have to send to OEM platforms first can create vendor lock-in. Any advice/thoughts please?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I strongly favour Edge devices publishing to a local platform/Broker
That allows me use the data on-prem regardless of the cloud connection.
I can then push the data from the UNS to the Cloud for analysis.

Author: dylan_iiot
Content: Thanks Mark. Could you give me a couple business benefits of this, why I ask is that I'd like to learn how to articulate this to clients who, for various reasons, seem to prefer these OEM platforms. I believe it creates potential data silos, vendor lock-in and less flexible/future proof deployments. Would I be correct. Would you agree

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
1. Contracts - What happens if the cloud provider goes out of business, or kills the product. not relevant if you are hosting your own cloud services, Amazon Google and Microsoft are probably around for a while.
2. Common-Sense. I spend years working with utilities, Boilers air etc. It just doe not make sense to me to send data to the cloud just to consume it back down.
3. Connectivity, I am thinking here that latency and micro outages, really mean that this approach is not suitable for quite a lot of applications, in particular MES functions or SCADA. So I need to build an on-prem solution of some sort
4. Consistency. Given that I thin I need to build an on-prem solution of some sort. I want to KISS and have all my data following a similar path. I do not want to be in downtime situation, where I cannot pull down the next recipe on any machine, trying to remember if data from a machine is going to the cloud and back or directly from the edge to the on -prem broker
5. Control. Again in a downtime situation I want to be able to power cycle my server, or do other actual trouble shooting, and not have to raise a ticket and wait for someone to get back to me.
6. Cost - I am very worried about TOC for Cloud

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
7. Completeness. Some data from my Edge devices will be given additive context in the SCADA and MES layers. Is the route going to be Device-> Cloud->On-Prem Broker->SCADA-> On Prem Broker-> Cloud
8. Closed-Loop,. some edge devices will want to subscribe to data, I don't want my Closed-Loop to be dependant on the Cloud. But I also want to keep my single connection from each edge device

Todays response was Brought to you by the Letter C

Content: yes, yes, and yes.

So I'm building out a sales story to give clients a better view of the long-term value of a UNS architecture which scales and is future proof for more easily adding use cases they discover down their digital transformation road

Author: united_flamingo_52188
Content:
Hi i4.0!

In sparkplugB world, is there a "Node Discovery" feature?

I have this scenario:
1. Primary host application STATE online
2. Edge node published node NBIRTH
3. A second host application (custom that we are developing) goes online and wants data from every node on the network, but got late to the party and Edge node already advertised itself.

Question: without listing every node on the second host application, how could this one discover the edge node?
If it were listed, we could simply use the Node Control/Rebirth. But that is not the case. 
I can't find anything in the specification related to this.
Do you have a hint?
thanks

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content:
> without listing every node on the second host application, how could this one discover the edge node?
If you dont subscribe to the topics of the edge node you wont get any of the data from it, for you it wouldnt exist. The broker is the one will send you the current state of everything you subscribe to, you dont bother the Edge node when your second host come online. 
If you want just the initial state of the edge node, you could subscribe and then unsubscribe so you dont get the updates.

Author: united_flamingo_52188
Content:
thanks Mariano,  For the second host application, I want to subscribe to it, but at boot time, I don't have it's ID. I would like to discover it on the fly, e.g. when it publishes a NBIRTH.
And, as I understand it, even if I know the egde node ID, and I subscribe to it, but after its NBIRTH, the broker won't forward me the NBIRTH. I have to request a rebirth, right?

Author: united_flamingo_52188
Content: NBIRTH have QoS 0 and retain flag false, so subscribing to it won't give me the initial node state

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
That is an interesting case where cloud certainly has some merits.
The issue I have come across with that sort of property management is the vendor devices talk to the Vendor cloud solution.
but combining data from the two can be hard, so how to you compare the HVAC with occupancy or Solar PV
Unless you have all the systems from a Single vendor an that is a lot of lock in, if you can find a vendor.

so now you have to build a custom solution for that, consisting of API's to each vendors solution.
So a Data ops platform to connect to each Vendor system and then you own UNS
And If I am going to that much trouble I would much rather an Edge Broker in each property. That allows me run apps locally where that makes sense.
An Enterprise broker and that can be cloud based no problem.

And the Vendors take their data from the Enterprise broker.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Sort of.  Some of those messages/topics can be published with the retain flag set to true.  For those, if you do a wildcard subscription, you'll get an initial value for the topic which can be used to derive the identities of the node(s).  It's still just a giant nasty hack though.

Author: united_flamingo_52188
Content:
Thanks Rick,
that is the point where I'm at. I do a wildcard subscription for every node ID, but the host application needs, sometime, to be run after node's births.
Will take a better look at messages/topics with retain flag true.
thanks,

Author: mparris
Content:
The only dynamic way to discover is to do a wildcard subscription to the Sparkplug namespace "spBv1.0/#", or "spBv1.0/<groupID>" if you know the groupID of interest is known,   and then wait for NDATA or DDATA packets to come in.

 When a *DATA packet comes in, your application could issue a Rebirth request, to receive all the possible metrics (variables) and their current value. This method of discovery, however, is not guaranteed to be immediate, especially if a node has slow -changing data, you won't see a *DATA packet until that change.

Look in the spec for the idea of a "Sparkplug-aware broker". HiveMQ may be the only one that implements this function. 

The idea is that the broker can store all the NBIRTH and DBIRTH and make them available on separate, RETAIN=true topics. So using this broker and having the clients subscribe to those special topics allows immediate discover, but you have the problem of the values on the birth certificate being almost certainly stale. So, your client application will know if the nodes, what metrics they have available, but will not know the current value until a new *DATA comes to it. 

Because Sparkplug was designed for a single application to receive all data, and didn't design accommodations for other, distributed clients (secondary hosts), this is the best you will get today.

This whole mechanism, however, should be revised in the new version of Sparkplug:

For example:
https://github.com/eclipse-sparkplug/sparkplug/issues/96

https://github.com/eclipse-sparkplug/sparkplug/issues/445

Author: ricardo_maestas
Content:
Makes sense. Same goes for @Mariano B's observations about tool recognition and audit concerns. You mentioned accessing the data via the equipment vendors' APIs ‚Äî this may be the best near-term option, but the added complexity (@Mark O'Donovan covered these issues well in his replies) isn't optimal.

I would be sure to bring up MTR's in the conversation with this client. I would predict that there will be issues with connecting some of the data producers to a central UNS, but defining MTR's for new equipment will help with this issue over time. Not knowing more about the specifics, you might also be able to raise some cybersecurity concerns with their current approach.

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
There‚Äôs theoretically no difference between a second host coming online, and the first host reconnecting after a disconnect from the broker. In the latter, the host has in theory no idea if a new edge node has entered the network while it was disconnected (or left the network for that matter). So it is in theory forced to rediscover nodes upon reconnect anyway. 

I‚Äôve not read the fine details of the spec, but in practice a host application will subscribe to ddata, ndata, dbirth and nbirth of either the entire SpB Namespace, or specific group or node topics (depending on if its host to all of SpB, or a subset of group(s) or node(s)). When and if the host recieves data from an Edge node of which it does not have a birth, it should issue a rebirth command to the node. 

This is the Discovery mechanism in practice. Unless you have a Sparkplug aware broker. Then you can subscribe to the retained topic where the broker makes the births available, and this will be the Discovery mechanism instead of waiting for data payloads.

Author: united_flamingo_52188
Content:
Thanks Jon. 
There is a huge difference if the host application is the Primary Host Application, because the edge node must wait for it having a STATE online=true to publish NBIRTH.
As MParris wrote, waiting for NDATA/DDATA and issue a rebirth can lead to a long wait time before the state of that node can be know. Is a possible solution, but not viable to our case. 

While we wait for Sparkplug new version, we are considering A) the use of a Sparkplug aware broker; B) or extending the specification by publishing a NSTATE retained message from edge nodes (similar to the host application STATE), NDEATH would indicate it is no longer valid, C) Having the Primary Host Application to keep a registry of the Nodes and publishing it
@MParris posted very good pointers to an array of solutions for this. We are still evaluating what we will adopt.

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
I think you‚Äôre kind of missing my point. From an information theory perspective, primary host doesnt change a lot, because its Edge nodes that defines who is primary host, so when a host enters the network, it itself doesnt know if its primary host to anything and is equally ignorant to the presence or non-presence of nodes as it enters the network, so it has to sub to the same topics. The only difference is that it doesnt have to wait for data payloads from nodes it is primary host for as they will publish births when it enters the network. Anyway its not very important in practice, particularly if you assume all Edge nodes have the same primary host. (Btw primary host is not mandatory, we didnt use primary host the first two years we had SpB). 

How much of a problem is this reallly going to be in practice? We have our Edge nodes publishing at 1 second intervals, so the longest time non-primary hosts have to wait is 1 second. 

A Sparkplug aware broker is probably not the cheapest option. Are you making your own custom primary host or using some OTS solution?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Option B sounds like the best option if youre doing custom stuff anyway.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: But if youre doing custom stuff, why are you using SpB to begin with?

Author: united_flamingo_52188
Content:
Yep, I got that. In our case we have considered not having a Primary Host Application, but then even the Primary Host Application would have to wait for *DATA to discover the network (or we would have to provide it with the listing of nodes, and they are dynamic). Furthermore, we don't wan't edge nodes publising their data into vacuum. When primary host is offline, it must cache data and later publish as historical. 

Losing a sample or two is not a problem, but we are using RBE, and some data only changes every hour, or day. We cannot afford to wait that long to discover nodes and their state.

Why SpB? it fits very well in our use case. Single Source of truth, Decoupled Data, Immediate Discovery. Since it is an open specification, others can develop as well software to integrate in the solution, as well as we would like to use as much already available software as possible. 
We are always open to other suggestions üôÇ

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Do you have Edge nodes where the entire Namespace of the Edge node is very slowly changing? Unless the entire Namespace of the Edge node doesn‚Äôt change often, at least one metric will eventually change, and the hosts will be made aware of the node‚Äôs presence.

Author: united_flamingo_52188
Content: Yes, a high percentage of the edge nodes are Sparkplug Enabled edge nodes, and the data being monitored can be as low as a single metric.

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
Interesting! I think you‚Äôve found somewhat of a gap there. I mean, you have a lot of ways to circumvent this, and with the exception of Sparkplug aware broker, I think they‚Äôre all outside the spec. An interesting case you‚Äôve got there. Thanks for bringing it up! 

Since they came out with V3.0 I‚Äôve been wondering what the point of the SpB aware broker was, as you‚Äôd still have to request rebirths to get the current state (as pointed out by Matthew, the retained births are always going to be stale as far as current state goes). Perhaps this is why!

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
thank you for the error from Windows Event Viewer. with that i can confirm that this is the same issue i was told was discovered before i left for vacation last week. perhaps the Support person didn't know about this yet.

the resolution (pre patch or maintenance release) is to add a dependency for the event log service to wait for the key service to be done before it starts up. A Windows Admin can run the following command in Windows CMD/Terminal:

sc config KEPServerEXLoggerV6 depend= KEPServerEXKeySvcV6

this relates to competition between keyservice and server_eventlog attempting to access a file at the same time, and the server_runtime fails to start because of it.

looks like we are adding this to our upcoming maintenance release for 6.16, and support could cut you a patch for 6.15 if you need to stick with it

Author: ravil1
Content:
Not sure this is "simple". You need write code to make it working. And you need to have the PLC data to be accessible over OPC classic server.  Also, you will need to make  MS IIS secured with TLS and probably  with user authentication too.
I wonder, is it used somewhere on production?

Author: martin_68109
Content: Think how much effort you have put in UA implementation for common features like authorization/authentication/firewall/certificate/encryption etc. When all those features are taken care of by IIS and what you need is focus on your own business logic - can any other solution be simpler than that? I believe it has provided an ultimate solution bridging classic OPC and modern needs. Yes, quite a few people are using it, especially in brownfield. It is an ideal edge solution as well without custom hardware required.

Author: ravil1
Content:
All might be true. But this not a tool for end users, rather like a library. I would compare it with OPC UA  SDKs.
And requirent to have to use MS IIS can be obstacle if there is a requirement to be non-Windows.
Also, IIS itself does not implement user authentication and certificates generation / validation, it relies on Active Directory and PKI infrastructure to make these festures working.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: what's the best way anyone has found to move edge data to an offsite VPS server? I like the solution to be as simple as possible meaning minimum requirements on the edge side to establish a connection (and firewall/ports changes). I've used Cloudflare ZeroTrust tunnels before, what I like about those, it's a small service with HTTPS 443 endpoint. Otherwise anyone have luck with other VPNs that use TCP instead of UDP.. obviously UDP would be better (like Wireguard) but that would require ports to be opened. OpenVPN seems to use TCP, not as performant but I don't need to send a lot of data over the VPN.

Author: ravil1
Content: Can you please clarify, why you need VPN tunnel to move data from the edge to offsite VPS? Couldn't it be done using just with connections outgoing from the edge to the VPS? Usually this connection is already secured, so no need additional VPN to secure it. Examples are pushing data using MQTT, or to InfluxDB or SQL servers - all support secured connections.

Author: stephenbryant_89711
Content:
Probably because edge devices are notoriously poor in supporting modern security protocols and keeping their TLS libraries up to date etc.  Some are due to the vendors, but others are simply due to not having been updated because they otherwise work.  OT people don't like to fix things that aren't broken (unlike certain software companies).

If you move the transport security to a VPN tunnel, you don't have to update or replace a load of other hardware - multiple devices can share the tunnel too.

Author: ravil1
Content: I see, seems reasonable at such use cases.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Great feedback. Yeah I'm trying to figure out the difference between using TLS to send data vs tunneling the data. The actual transmission of the data TLS & VPN is encrypted. The difference is TLS only support certain protocols while VPN encrypts everything. What is 'better' depends on use-case and trusting the security implementation of either TLS (application level) or VPN (service level).

Author: jbonhage155
Content: then there's the whole certification management piece which if there's multiple TLS endpoints that can become a pain vs a single cert for the VPN gateway. Looks like some VPN services (Wireguard) avoid certifications altogether. I hate certificates, lol
