Author: j061
Content:
Hallo Gents,
We are facing a challenge in a project connecting a soldering machine weich is 20 years old. I was wondering if somebody could give us an advice on our questions.

Unfortunately in pur company,  knowledge about the plc program was always managed by the machine builders so we are are pretty blind...

Here is our approach:
1. Identify the PLC type in order to select a software  which has a driver which is able to connect. (E.g. Kepware)
2. Ask at the machine vendor for a list with all used adresses within the the PLC
3. Configure the software with all the tags and select the data we would like to get from the machine (temperature, O2 concentraion, machine state, counter) 

A question/precaution that was mentioned by a colleague was that we lose the warrenty of the machine if we read the PLC in that manner.

I would highly appreciate advice from an experienced fellow here since we are all quite young in our team but try to make it work somehow.

Thank you in advace!

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
the ideal approach would be to contact the machine builder, and ask them and they either
- give you a map to get the key data
- Do some modifications to prepare the data and send it to whatever system you want.
- if it is a built to order machine, provide you a copy of the code

Bitter experience is that Machine builders ask about$15 to 20k per machine to do that.

So I think the Kepware approach is good.
have you a picture of the PLC and especially the front to see if it is ethernet or serial( 20 years old might not have an ethernet port).
Warranty should not be affected if you read data from the machine. If it is 20 years old is it still overed by warranty?

 If you can get access to the PLC code, you should be able to find out the key values, pretty quickly, or hire someone who could do so . The Temp and 02 probably have instruments, that you can see where they are wired to in the PLC
if there comments and tag name in is reasonable you can find the counter and state, if count can be simple to find if there is a value on a HMI, State can bo ok to find, but sometimes hard to decode, but you can get the main one, Idle, Running etc.

Good luck with it

Author: j061
Content:
Hello Mark

Thank you for the quick response! About the machine vendor... we contacted them and the result was exactly what you wrote above... (30k..)

I will try to find out more about the PLC next week!

The machine also has an HMI which displays a lot of useful data. Is it common to connect via the HMI somehow?

You thoughts on the warranty are good in this case üôÇ

In general, for a new machine, reading is generally ok? Is this usually written in some terms and conditions when buying a machine?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
It depends very much on the HMI.

but generally I would say, on an old machine,  9 times out of 10 you connect to a PLC but not the HMI on a machine.

but if you can ge the HMI data it can provide better context.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I don't know anything about soldering machines specifically but as an integrator who has had to deal with a lot of 20+ year old PLCs - your next steps will depend on what the specific PLC is. 

1st step is to open (or have someone open) the panel. Find the brand and part number of the PLC. 

From there go to Google and see what software is used to program that PLC, there should be 20 years of forums complaining about it so that's a good start. 

After that you need to get a 
hold of the software, this may be tricky... And may be stupid expensive.

Once you get the software you need to figure out how to connect, a 20 year old PLC is probably a serial or some proprietary cable. 

After you are online, I hope that you can upload the program without the original file. Best case scenario you will get online with it. Most likely you won't have any tag names, symbol descriptions, or comments. Worst case you can't upload without the original file. 

Assuming you get online without comments, the next step is to take the IO list / panel drawings (if you have them) and reverse engineer the code until you get what you need. 

If you don't have any IO lists or drawings, then you need to trace back the wires and reverse engineer that first.

You could attempt the same process with the HMI but I doubt a 20 year old HMI will have many options for connectivity.

I oversimplified this process a bit for brevity... Honestly, $30,000 is not that bad for a job like this (depending on the machine). I'm assuming that the OEM will have to send someone onsite to do some version of this exact scenario... Odds are that there have been changes over the years, so anything the OEM has on hand is likely not up to date.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
@JT   Dylan gives good advice,
I have seen people claim to sniff the packed being communicated and be able to extract the data, but I have never seen it successfully done

It might work for Modbus Comms, to the HMI etc. but the data you want would have to be transmitted.

What I have seen done in similar situratiosn is iinstall a small PLC, and take the inputs to the OLF PLC and wire them into the new PLC for signals you are interested in i.e. Temp, AI, Pulses etc. and then wire the NEW PLC outputs int the old PLC inputs.

you can miss Machine Status, sometimes, but I have been lucky and has do Digital Outputs from a Machine to another machine that allowed me infer the Status.

but more normally you can use the counter to get some understanding of the status and get the rest from operator input.

Author: _dyland
Content:
This is the type of project where the risk/reward cost/benefit really needs to be evaluated from a few different angles. 

What is the expected life of the machine? Is it still planned to be in production for the next year or 5?

Is production already planning an upgrade to the machine? If so don't waste too much time or money on the old one - rather influence the requirements of the new.

I would typically tend to agree with you on the outside monitoring, add in relays to hijack signals, new sensors, and some controller to communicate with. I'd probably be between a Grove RIO or an IO Link Master depending on some other factors.

Author: _dyland
Content: Problem with stuff like this is not knowing the specifics - because it boils down to "It depends"

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Actually, if the instruments are IO link something like Morneo could be a game changer.

But a 2004 machine in a lot of places has a lot of life in it. In Europe if it had a Siemens s7-300, that would probably run for another 15 to 20 years, and you could probably get online, or the data out using S7Comms, as it is old enough to not have the indirect memory addressing.

Would the Kepware S7 driver browse for you through the DB's?


I'd  go Groove in this instance too , 
Maybe  WAGO if cost was an issue, and I know how to use CODESYS properly ü§¨ .

Author: _dyland
Content: Grove RIO for hijacking random signals from the panel - IO Link for adding a few sensors to monitor the system while leaving the machine alone.

Author: _dyland
Content:
And for the PLC it really depends on the brand... I'm just saying to look into it. I've been asked to work on PLCs that were already planned for upgrades but due to communication issues the people asking me to  fix it didn't know that it wasn't going to be around for much longer. 

Also 20+ could mean a 30 30 year old PLC, in that case I would check if it's EOL because if it is and when it breaks, the end user is SOL.

Author: _dyland
Content: The problem with a "simple" project like this is it can get expensive fast, and if they don't look at it from multiple perspectives, they might be throwing away money.

Author: _dyland
Content: The big issue is there are maybe 10 different recommendations I could give depending on the specific scenario... I'm sure @Mark O'Donovan could add another 10 recommendations on top of that.

You guys are amazing - great advice, thank you!

First thing monday we be clarifying details of the PLC and also the lifetime of the machine.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The vendor shall provide the following information via an open interface to allow it to be used by external systems. the following information shall be profided as a minimum

4.8.2    Any data that is transmitted between platforms, (e.g. SCADA/MES/WMS/WCS) that data shall also be sent to the MQTT Broker. 

4.8.4    Any data collected transmitted between level 1( PLC/HMI) and level 0 devices ( instrument )shall be sent to the MQTT Broker 
4.8.5    Any Data Sent between Level 1 Devices (E.g. PLC/HMI to PLC or PLC to HMI) Shall be sent to the MQTT. 
4.8.6    Operator Actions e.g. 
‚Ä¢    Change of operator 
‚Ä¢    Change of setpoints 
‚Ä¢    Selections from HMI/SCADA 
‚Ä¢    Pushbuttons 
‚Ä¢    Any information being Historized  
‚Ä¢    Information that is Available on the HMI/SCADA or other User interface . 
‚Ä¢    Machine Status ‚Äì Code and Text 
‚Ä¢    Alarms ‚Äì Code and Text 
‚Ä¢    Operators 
‚Ä¢    Work orders 
‚Ä¢    Inputs from the HMI 
‚Ä¢    Setpoints 
‚Ä¢    Pushbuttons 
‚Ä¢    Machine Status ‚Äì Code and Text 
‚Ä¢    Alarms ‚Äì Code and Text 
‚Ä¢    Inputs from the HMI 
‚Ä¢    Setpoints 
‚Ä¢    Pushbuttons 
4.8.7    The Vendor shall also publish any information they determine to be of importance to understating the system to the Broker

Author: y0cef296
Content: Hello everyone, I'm new to the server i'm a college student first year, i study iot and the first year you can say they are teaching us nothing about iot, it's a lot of physics and math, how can i start learning about it more alone?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
A good basis in Physics and Maths is really valuable.

To get started in IIOT
Do you have a raspberry Pi.
You can use a laptop too.

What in your house is smart?
Fridge, plugs TV,

Download the MING Stack.
Find the API for your devices.
Connect to the devices
Collect the Data
Store it in. A DB
Make some displays to Visualize it.

Make an improvement somewhere

I'd think they are pretty performant. We (HighByte) published some OPC UA --> MQTT (+ modeling) performance tests  that might be helpful. Generally 100K+ tags, changing at 1 second is doable. https://support.highbyte.com/kb/performance/opc-ua-data-modeling

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
Litmus bundles a fully compliant high performance OPCUA Client and Server. Should be good for majority of usecases out there. If you want best of the both worlds, IoT Sitewise also has Litmus Edge inside it! 

Litmus Edge directly:
https://docs.litmus.io/litmusedge/quickstart-guide/industrial-systems-connection-guide/opc-ua/opc-ua-client-advanced

Litmus Edge inside AWS Sitewise Edge:
https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2024/09/aws-iot-sitewise-edge-100-protocols-litmus-edge/
add here : https://docs.aws.amazon.com/iot-sitewise/latest/userguide/cpa-add-source.html

Any specific throughput you are looking for - happy to ask the Customer success team to check.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Those are programmed using a the Step7 software, Ithink it essentially has a S7-300 PLC, so it should be possible to connect a PLC to all the machines VIA Profinet or Profibus

But you might even be able to use Kepware/Ignition/Aveva/Fameworx/Litmus .... IO driver to communicate with the S7 DB's

If ther is s7 comms, you can use a CC716( about ‚Ç¨1500) to connect to all the devices and publish them to a MQTT broker or the CC716 can act as an OPCUA server

Author: d_leblanc
Content:
Are there any OPC UA client libraries you would recommend? we have used the Traeger library but it is pretty slow. creating a linux service with .net core connecting to kepwares OPC UA server is very slow. 

eg reading a group of 50 tags from a siemens PLC though kepware using the above driver takes 1-2 seconds.

Reading the same tags directly from the siemens PLC with a siemens driver (ASComm IoT) takes abuot 40-50ms. 

we try to stay away from OPC if we can as it is slow compared to direct connections.

Author: d_leblanc
Content: Do private applications in Litmus edge have direct access to device drivers or only to OPC-UA?

Author: vatsalshah
Content: Yes Private applications (hosted in Litmus marketplace / docker) or Application outside Litmus Edge have NATS  based realtime APIs access or use internal OPCUA server.

Author: aronsemle
Content: You mean code libraries? It'll depend on the language but in general C/C++ Ascolab (costs money) is decent and I've used it. They also have a C# version but I haven't used it. Node I'd use node-opcua, and java I'd use the milo stack. Milo is written by Kevin from Ignition and it's probably one of the better stacks. Keep in mind performance will usually depend on the UA server more. And when they are hosted on PLCs it's generally not great given system resources.

Author: sim_sam3
Content: Are these tags array types? Kep treats arrays as atomic in the legacy Siemens driver and you‚Äôll see one request per array vs bulk requests for max block size (940 bytes)

Author: rickbullotta

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I have a Pi 5, I can't get Litmus to work on it.
According to Chat GPT

The Raspberry Pi 5 uses the BCM2712 SoC, which requires the DTB file:

        bcm2712-rpi-5-b.dtb

        This DTB file is only available in newer OS images and firmware updates specifically designed for the Raspberry Pi 5.

üí° Why the Issue Occurs

    If you‚Äôre trying to boot an OS image created for the Raspberry Pi 3 or 4 on a Raspberry Pi 5:
        The image will not contain bcm2712-rpi-5-b.dtb, because the Pi 5 didn‚Äôt exist when that image was built.

How far away from viability is it to then pile on and run codeSys?  And what I then come up with  on par, is you‚Äôre gonna lose five to 10 hours of downtime per year based on sticky OS‚Äôs, docker stacks, and corruptible SSDs‚Ä¶ you go from five nines of reliability in Allen-Bradley to a 99 something IPC.

Author: portainer.io
Content: Hey Folks, we (Portainer) just released KubeSolo.io, a way to run Kubernetes on devices with 512MB RAM.. real Kube‚Ä¶ if you need this capability (say to run UMH), check out the website.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: So the obvious follow up is... When should I use Portainer and when should I use KubeSolo?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: And how does this differ from k3d?

Author: mparris
Content: I think the question is more of when you use docker, podman, kubertenes, k3s, k0s, or kubesolo ‚Ä¶with Portainer being able to manage stacks/containers on any of them

Author: portainer.io
Content:
yes that is correct.. Portainer is a management tool, a central control point for Docker and Kubernetes... 

KubeSolo is a Kubernetes distro, that can be managed with or without Portainer (but without would be painful)

Author: portainer.io
Content: k3d is Kubernetes inside a Docker Container = Lots of RAM... KubeSolo = Kubernetes as a single installable binary that runs on any Linux device, and in that one binary we run Kubermetes in as little as 220MB of RAM

Author: portainer.io
Content:
Why use KubeSolo ? Becuase you NEED to run a Kubernetes-centric application on your IOT/IIOT fleet... 

Honestly, if your app stack supports Docker, then run it in Docker (as Docker/Podman is still the lightest weight approach)... but more and more, application vendors are only shipping and support their apps as a Helm Chart or Kube Manifest (eg UMH.app..

Author: portainer.io
Content: and so if you cannot avoid the use of Kube, you can either 1) buy big IOT devices with at least 2GB of RAM, and then run k0s, k3s on them), or 2) use low capacity devices (<1GB RAM) and now run KubeSolo

Author: deralex123
Content: @portainer.io we are also launching soon (experimental already available) UMH Core which bundles a lot of components in one single docker container. So UMH x Portainer seems to be easier then ever, in multiple ways üôÇ

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
Makes sense! Thanks for the explanation. I have two RHEL 8 VMs and one I setup some services on prior to learning about Portainer, so I'm running things manually.

What I like:
- Most services do not need to run as `root` and of course by default with Podman, containers don't.
- Works for very simple single containers 
- Starting the container on boot is as simple as using `podman` to create a SystemD service file. While this is now deprecated, it still works quite well.

On the other VM, I installed Portainer first and learned how to deploy stacks, which is now my preferred method with the downside that everything runs as `root`.

Author: portainer.io
Content: Install rootless docker‚Ä¶ its an option.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: My experience is that I not only need to run Portainer as root, but with `--privileges` due to SELinux. Is there a way to run containers as normal users in Portainer?

Author: portainer.io
Content: Yes, containers you can. You can change the uid:gid, but not Portainer itself.

Author: evjakec
Content: I was wondering if this was an AI bot. Looking forward to how it responds.

Author: milanhurban
Content:
Wanted to split these up so that folks can react to individual questions. Oh well. I have a few questions:
1) What is the difference between the two "edge" channels on this Discord? Wasn't sure which one fits my questions better.
2) In your projects, in order to get data out of the machines that don't natively connect to the rest of the data infrastructure, do you push for many small edge devices/gateways, or a big central server for the entire site running some platform with protocol converters? Or is this entirely dependent on the existing infrastructure (i.e. is it even possible to run everything directly to a central server)?
3) If using many smaller devices, how are you managing updates, both for the applications and the IPC/device firmware itself? I assume the applications nowadays involve some sort of containerization and can be deployed/updated remotely. Is it important for your edge devices to allow mass OTA updates of the underlying OS? Or is each device handled individually, by an actual person connecting to it over the network or, god forbid, using a USB stick? Or is the whole thing just set up once and then never touched again?

Author: brianpribe
Content: Both channels were reorganized to where they are today, but we didn't want to delete either (cuz both were popular), so we left it until one died.

Author: brianpribe
Content: As far as deployment options, I don't recommend any of the raspberrypi devices. Great for one-off solutions, but for edge where you may connect mulitple machines, I recommend a smaller IPC with plenty of resources (4CPU, 8-16GB RAM, 256GB storage minimum). Multiple ethernet ports is a bonus. For the same price of 5 RPi, you can get 1 IPC that connects to 5 of your machines and only requires you to manage 1 device.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Question 1: see @Brian Pribe answer.
But I thought IIoT-edge was for edge CPU devices and edge was traditional I3.0 edge PLC and instruments

2 . It depends, but for me it normally comes down to
 whether I need some buffering at the edge 
Or
If I want to have some local visualisation 

3. Portainer. And Flowfuse ( the üí∞ üí∞ version is Dell Native edge.)

Author: brianpribe
Content: 1. I think you're right.

Author: brianpribe
Content: 2. I think you're right as well.

Author: brianpribe
Content: 3. Pretty banger. Right as well ‚≠ê

Author: milanhurban
Content:
Right, but even with a bigger device you'll likely end up with multiple and at some point the question of mass OS updates has to either be solved or ignored. I'm asking because I know about tools like Mender and Balena that can remotely update Linux-based edge devices and am wondering how this is usually done at sites you've seen. Or does it usually come with the cloud IIoT platform of choice?

In my work at Siemens I've also seen pretty much the whole range from Raspberry-sized devices (something like the IoT2050), through classic IPCs like the ones you describe, all the way to everything being virtualized on a central server, and each had their pros and cons. But even though OTA updates of the OS were often pushed as one of the big features of the edge product we offered, I've never felt it had a big impact on the final decision.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Typically IT gets involved on updating the OS. That or an integrator with a service contract does it.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Consider licensing cost per edge device and future use-cases where you may want to run more apps.

Author: trentc
Content:
2) what @Brian Pribe and @Mark O'Donovan  said but i will add‚Ä¶‚Äùit depends‚Äù‚Ä¶
on network proximity also‚Ä¶ you don‚Äôt want a single gateway at the highest level of your network‚Ä¶. This defeats the benefits of edge driven technology‚Ä¶. Ideally every node has capabilities to talk the ‚Äúcommon language ‚Äú to your infrastructure‚Ä¶. But when they don‚Äôt, it‚Äôs a balancing act of where are your devices, what is their network proximity 

what does the security architecture look like‚Ä¶ how much data am i polling‚Ä¶

does my edge pc/device/gateway have enough resources? 

What about possible caching and buffering, does production rely on this device to remain connected‚Ä¶ what is the criticality of unexpected disconnections‚Ä¶

I don‚Äôt think there is a fits all solution unless it‚Äôs every device can be managed remotely at scale, meets the minimum technical requirements and has enough resources to adapt to new needs‚Ä¶ which accommodates most scenarios.

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content: Hi guys, do you know any cheaper than Kepware option (with one time payment customer don't want any recurring bills)  for IP-Uni-Telway => OPC UA/Modbus TCP conversion. We are collecting data from bunch of PLC's via Ignition Edge and that one is the only with driver that can't be handeled by Ignition itself. OEM recommended us to use TSX ETG 1010 gateway but unfortunately it is no longer produced and cannot be purchased...

Author: brianpribe
Content: Litmus could build one, but none of our solutions aside from kepware have that driver.

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
Quick price check: Perpetual Kepware Uni-Telway with an OPC UA server (fit for control or acquisition) is $1,652 USD (unadjusted for local pricing). 
 
If you need Modbus TCP server or client (as output for Uni-Telway in addition to OPC UA) we have to add a couple of components and we‚Äôre over $3K perpetual.

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content: If we add to Kepware ModbusTCP we're over 3k, or did I misunderstood something?

Author: sim_sam3
Content: No you got it, you‚Äôd need linking between drivers (advanced tags) plus Modbus suite (in addition to unitelway) so yes over 3K perpetual.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Sam.E, you just advanced to level 14!

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content: Ah yes, understood üòÑ

Author: hanno23
Content:
@portainer.io  I found that portainer is great to manage container workloads and although it can run edge jobs, it is not really ment for host os level config. Someone at work suggested Saltstack to manage the host os and containers. I am sure you guys have come across clients that have used / asked about Salt?

To me it feels very low level, steep learning curve and complex but super powerfull. Might be overkill but seems like the best way to at least manage host OS config?

Author: hanno23
Content: Basically, it would be great to be able to manage the lifecycle of host and container config from portainer. Any tips/ways some clients have been able to do this or is the best option cron jobs via edge jobs?

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content: Wow, I didn't know about it. Did you use it @trentc - 4.0 Hero LLC ? 3 stars on GitHub always make me a little bit anxious üòÑ

Author: ravil1
Content:
You can manage both host and containers with https://balena.io 
Although, it comes with own OS, based on Yocto, cannot use on a regular Linux distro. But you can build and use your own custom image of the OS based on Yocto if generic one is not suitable.

Author: joshuastover
Content: @here Have you ever had to create a REST API interface for a device or system that didn‚Äôt support it? How did you approach it?

Author: jdingus
Content: Great question

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content:
Depends on requirements. 

1) If system/device has any other API (like SOAP, TCP/IP) I created simple translating app and hosted it. 
2) If system/device you want to integrate has accessible db you can write custom api with REST API as layer of abstraction to db.
3) For devices that supports industial protocols you can for example use MOXA AIG. It allows you to specify for example Modbus TCP device and you can access created tags with values using moxa's built-in rest api.  I think this advantech ecu-1051 would also fits the needs

for 1 and 2 you can also use Ignition and with it's web server module capabilities create REST API. 

I think there are also some low-code/no-code tools for 1) and 2) but I didn't use one

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That's pretty much what Lighthammer and ThingWorx actually were...

Author: joshuastover
Content: Neat! You built them as the solution for developing REST APIs?

Author: terrancesmith
Content: It's the best part of thingworx! You get an automatically created, documented and hosted discoverable api for "device/system" properties and methods just for modeling them.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The model basically *is* the API.

Author: sim_sam3
Content: Commercial stuff like Kepware has made this pretty easy, and am bias because of my data set of course. I do wonder in general what other tools automation folks have used over time to add REST API to their systems (and for what reason, which is IMO just as interesting).

Author: aphexddb
Content: Does the community have a mosquitto or other public broker with any fun simulated data? looking to explore various UNS structures and tags

Author: evjakec
Content: @Dylan DuFresne I believe has a repo you can pull. It pushes simulated data into a broker.

Author: _dyland
Content:
https://github.com/DMDuFresne/UNS-Payload-Examples

Is the one I threw together, there are a couple forks that made it better though. Like: 

https://github.com/oliviamorales/UNS-Payload-Examples

Though, honestly - @M. R. McCormick's testbed as a service is a much better more complete example. As it's playing back recorded data rather than simulating it. 

https://github.com/m-r-mccormick/Testbed-as-a-Service

There is also the PackML simulator from Rhize. @GeoffNunan 
 https://github.com/libremfg/PackML-MQTT-Simulator

Author: _dyland
Content: I'm sure there are others too. These two are just the first to mind for me
